Title: Visiting Rome: The Good, The Bad, & The Ugly
Content:

‚ÄúIf the whole world lived in their favorite vacation spots, then the whole world would live in Hawaii and Italy and Cleveland.‚Äù
Floyd to Liz, 30 Rock, Season 1, Episode 20 ‚ÄúCleveland‚Äù
That is one of my favorite TV Show quotes ever. What Floyd from 30 Rock is really saying is that everyone loves Italy, right? Well, actually, we didn‚Äôt love Italy and we very nearly hated Rome. Rome was the next stop on our month-long tour of Europe, which started in the United Kingdom. (You can check out our UK itinerary and trip information here, here, and here.)
I was particularly looking forward to visiting Italy. After I‚Äôd gone to Rome in my 20‚Äôs, I thought of it as one of my favorite cities in the world. Now, perhaps because we went during tourist season or because I have different travel tastes, it‚Äôs basically a reeking cesspool of humanity with some amazing historic structures and art. Ok, ok, maybe I‚Äôm being too harsh here. There are some highly delightful things to do in Rome, but I‚Äôm going to take off my rose-colored Italy glasses right now and share with you all of the Roman highlights: the good, the bad, and the ugly.
This was our Italy itinerary. We didn‚Äôt actually bike around Italy like my map shows, we took the train, but this is where we went. We started with five full days in Rome and then got out into the countryside from there.
Let‚Äôs start by talking about the highlights, starting with the good stuff and moving down to the bad.
One of my favorite Italian adventures was Pompeii. Seeing Pompeii has been on my bucket list for a really long time and it did not disappoint. You can get down to Pompeii from Rome and back in a day. Typically, you‚Äôd drive or take a tour bus and it would take 15 hours or so to take the tour, but we found a tour that took us to Pompeii by high speed train. We got an amazing guided tour of Pompeii for around two hours and then went to a local winery with very good wine and very good food. We were home by 5pm instead of the normal 9 or 10pm for the typical Pompeii tour from Rome.
Pompeii itself was truly amazing! We saw the original streets, bars, residences with beautiful frescoes and mosaic floors, political graffiti, the famous brothel, the forum, an amphitheater, and plaster casts of Pompeiians just as they were discovered. There is a section of Pompeii that just opened up to visitors where you can see some of the most amazing frescoes in the whole town, a bakery complete with intact terracotta ovens, and large wine jars, also completely intact. The whole time you‚Äôre touring in the shadows of Mt. Vesuvius, just as the Pompeiians lived. I highly recommend taking a tour through Pompeii with a tour guide as ours added a lot to our visit.
Italian food is fresh and delicious. Yes, the pizza is the best pizza you‚Äôll ever eat in your life. Yes, they do gelato better than any other ice cream in the world. And, yes, the pasta is also amazing and you can eat at a new restaurant every single night and never get the same dish twice. But, we did get sick of pizza and pasta by the end of our trip. We found an Indian restaurant on our first night in Florence and were relieved to have a little variety.
Our very favorite meals were the ones that we ate in tiny restaurants tucked into narrow streets, far from the throngs of tourists. There was a six table place down the street from our AirBNB with wine racks covering the walls. We had an amazing carbonara there. We also had a wonderful meal in a three-table restaurant in Vernazza (Cinqueterre), where we were scrunched in a corner and had to keep moving to let the waitress by. They had the best seafood linguini I‚Äôll probably ever have in my life.
We got used to having wine with all of our meals and gelato on almost a daily basis. I won‚Äôt miss Rome, but I will miss the food.
First up on our list of ‚Äúbad‚Äù Italian experiences is seeing the ancient Roman ruins. If you haven‚Äôt seen the famous ancient Roman sites yet, go. They themselves are amazing. I adore the Colosseum and Roman Forum. I love standing there and imagining life around 100 AD and I loved learning about ancient Rome.
But, these sites bring new meaning to the word ‚Äúcrowded‚Äù, at least during peak tourist season. There are so many tourists that you can‚Äôt freely move around. There are so many aggressive salesmen lying to you about their work and just trying to make a sale. Tourists pose everywhere, sometimes for 30‚Äì60 minutes trying to get the perfect selfie. No wonder the Italians are sick of us.
You must buy timed tickets ahead of time to most sites and none of the Italian websites are easy to navigate. I ended up just booking tours that came with tickets so I at least had a ticket and a guide. Just trying to see a few sites is hot (in June/July), uncomfortable, and annoying. It‚Äôs quite frankly not worth it. I don‚Äôt think I ever need to go back.
The Vatican Museums and Saint Peter‚Äôs Basilica are equally as crowded. They are beautiful and filled with famous works of art. At times, I loved it, but mostly I felt a bit like I did in the British Museum, where most items have been stolen from other cultures. I couldn‚Äôt stop thinking about how much money the Catholic leaders accepted from ordinary Catholics, telling them they could pay to get into heaven, then turning around and building the most ornate buildings in the world. We learned during our Colosseum tour that the Colosseum was once covered in marble. Then, the Vatican (as well as others) gutted the place so they could build St. Peter‚Äôs and other structures. I didn‚Äôt grow up Catholic and I have no tolerance for the Catholic church‚Äôs patriarchal views and other ongoing bullshit. So, visiting the Vatican was both mesmerizing and deeply appalling. No need to visit the Vatican again.
OK, now we‚Äôre getting into the ‚Äúugly‚Äù territory. After traveling around the UK for a couple of weeks, we got used to trains that were clean and ran on time. There seems to be no such thing in Italy. Trains are gross, packed, late, and graffitied. Buses don‚Äôt run on time and sometimes skip whole portions of their routes. Not to worry, you can just take a taxi, right?
Wrong. Italy doesn‚Äôt not have enough taxi drivers so the drivers they do have will only pick you up if they want to go exactly where you need to go. Especially at the airport. Finding a taxi at 11pm when we arrived was a nightmare. Everyone made up excuses until we found a great driver who needed to get home to our neighborhood. We also had a horrific experience trying to get from the airport to our final night‚Äôs hotel on the seaside in a town 25 minutes away. No one would take us. Not taxi drivers, not Uber drivers. No one. So, we spent two hours trying to figure out the bus system and I nearly lost it. If you go to Rome, find a place to stay that you can walk to from the Roma Termini train station. The train between the airport and Termini is great.
Luckily, we stayed in a place in Rome near the Campo d‚ÄôFiori, a famous outdoor market within walking distance (30‚Äì45 minutes) of the Roman Forum, Termini, and the Vatican. So, most of the time we were in Rome, we didn‚Äôt have to fight their public transit system.
And there you have it. My take on Rome: the good, the bad, and the ugly. I highly recommend visiting Italy during the off-season. The heat and the crowds were a major contributing factor to our impression of the country. But I sincerely also suggest you visit another country. So many people rave about Italy and I honestly don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs worth the hype. If you‚Äôre debating between Italy and somewhere else, do yourself a favor and pick somewhere else. Italy will be there for you to see later if you really need to go.
This post first appeared on amberrfield.com. If you‚Äôre interested in similar updates you can follow me here or there!

Title: A Traveller‚Äôs Perspective: Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Many a poet has referred to Rome as the eternal city due to its seemingly immortal beauty, which has enchanted locals and visitors alike for millennia. It goes without saying that one day is not nearly enough time to fully appreciate, or even see, the thousands of years of history and culture located within, but until October 2, 2015, that‚Äôs exactly how much time I‚Äôd spent there.
See, three years earlier during a family trip to Germany, my parents, sister, and I hopped in Oma‚Äôs VW Rabbit and embarked on a whirlwind tour of Italy, southern France, and the Alps. In the time most would dedicate to Rome alone, we drove from Frankfurt to Venice via Austria, then to Florence, Siena, Rome, Pisa, Monaco, and Nice, before finishing up with a nearly non-stop dash from Cannes back to Frankfurt ‚Äî we stopped once in Switzerland for the most scenic cold gas station pizza I‚Äôve ever eaten.
We were on such a tight schedule that in Siena, for example, when we took a wrong turn and missed the famous town square by just a few streets, we simply stopped at a grocery store to quickly grab ice cream, then kept on driving towards Rome.
With that in mind, it may come as a surprise that we opted to stay an hour outside the city instead of finding a place in the midst of it all. If you are at all familiar with Roman traffic and the absolute disregard for rules, if any exist to begin with, however, our decision makes a lot of sense.
On the morning of our day in Rome, we parked the car at the station next to our eco-sport resort hotel and hopped on a train into town. As it wobbled back and forth on the tracks, the countryside gave way to industry, then apartment blocks, then all of a sudden we were there.
Rome, unlike say, Paris or New York, is the type of city that sneaks up on you. You feel like you could be anywhere and then all of a sudden, boom, you‚Äôre thrust into the middle of everything. There are no tall landmarks to warn you of your imminent descent into chaos.
We spent a total of 12 hours in Rome, running about trying to fit in as much as possible. We ticked off a few of our must-dos, the Coliseum, the Trevi Fountain, and Roman cuisine, but the list of stuff we missed was far longer.
Needless to say, I vowed to go back, and in 2015 I did. After nearly a year working at Value Village, I ‚Äúquit‚Äù to travel for a bit, and mapped out a two-and-a-half-month long trip that took me to Toronto and New York, then over to Europe. Most of my time there was spent with family in Germany, but I also spent a couple weeks exploring southern and northern ends of the continent as well.
After visiting Paris, Torino, Bergamo, and Athens, I found myself once again in the eternal city, this time with three whole days to explore.
After flying in from Greece, I hopped on a train into town. When I stepped out of Roma Termini, I was taken aback by the sheer assault on my senses. The smell of fresh-baked goods and garbage mingled in my nose, producing a lovechild that wasn‚Äôt quite pleasant, but not entirely repulsive either. I heard people shouting at one another, but when I turned to look, I realized they were just speaking Italian; both had smiles on their faces.
And the horns. All around me locals zipped about on Vespas, beeping and showcasing both the country‚Äôs lax helmet policies and the city‚Äôs nonexistent traffic laws. Somehow, though, it worked. I didn‚Äôt understand why, but who was I to question a city that had been around that long.
I decided to knock out the famous sites first before delving into my preferred attraction, the city itself.
After a quick hop over to the Coliseum and other places you‚Äôd find on a Lonely Planet ‚ÄúTop 10‚Äù list, I made my way down to a neighbourhood called Trastavere. It‚Äôs the type of place that shows up on tourist maps, but is often overlooked. Wanting to explore the area sans local guide while still learning, I‚Äôd procured an audio tour by travel legend Rick Steves. He, and the impact he‚Äôs had on my life, warrant their own episode, but I digress.
Phone in hand, headphones in ear, I pressed play and began walking. As I passed through old courtyards with even older fountains, Rick told me about their history, and the role they played in present day Rome. Just as I neared the end of the tour, I saw a raindrop fall on my screen, followed by another, and another. Before long, it was a full on downpour.
I sought shelter under an awning, and, unable to check in to my hotel for a few more hours, looked on Google Maps for somewhere to wait out the storm. I wasn‚Äôt hungry, so I ignored all the restaurants, I didn‚Äôt want to stand around, so shopping was out of the question. Wait, what about a bookstore? There was a chain with numerous locations around the city called Feltrinelli, so I picked the closest open one, and headed over.
Upon arrival, I quickly realized that I had stumbled into a local shop. Everything was Italian ‚Äî well, almost everything. There was a small English section with a variety of old and new titles. I looked at the options, and came across Oliver Sacks‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Man who Mistook his Wife for a Hat.‚Äù Perfect! See, at the time I was very into neuroscience and psychology, and had just the day before listened to a BBC podcast featuring Sacks, who had recently passed away.
Book in hand, I found a comfy chair by the window overlooking the street and sat down. I put some Italian instrumental on and cracked open the pages, losing myself in Sacks‚Äô prose.
A couple hours later, I felt a rumble in my stomach. Time for lunch. I spent a few minutes looking for a place to eat on Google Maps, and came across this little restaurant nearby that had barely any reviews, all of which were in Italian, and no website. Perfect.
I did my best to uncrease ‚ÄúThe Man who Mistook his Wife for a Hat‚Äù before placing it back on the shelf and walking out. A few twists and turns down back alleys later, I found myself at the restaurant. There was one small Italian sign out front advertising what, I assumed, was a 5-course meal, but if you weren‚Äôt looking for it, you couldn‚Äôt be blamed for walking right past.
Upon entering, I was greeted by the host, who, quickly realizing I was a foreigner, began speaking in broken English. He guided me to a table in the main dining area, and I sat down, noticing that I was the only one there. My earlier suspicions were confirmed when the waiter came by and informed me that the special of the day was, in fact, a five-course meal. Knowing it would likely be my only meal of the day, I went for it. He smiled, and hurried back into the kitchen.
The waiter returned a short time later with, I kid you not, a litre of wine and another of water. I poured a glass of the former and sank deeper into the well-worn seat of my chair. He then brought what I, in my na√Øvite, thought were the first four courses: green lentil soup, olive oil marinated tomatoes with fresh basil, prosciutto and mozzarella balls, and a basket of bread.
As I took my first bite, I looked up and saw an old woman peeking out from behind the wall that blocked off entry to the kitchen. She watched my every move, smiling as I dug in and returned an approving gesture.
When the plates holding what I soon learned had just been the antipasto were taken away, the waiter returned with the primo course, homemade pasta with two types of sauce.
‚ÄúGrazi,‚Äù I said before digging in, alternating between the red and the white. When I looked up from my first bite, the old woman had moved closer, sitting at a table near the aforementioned wall. Once again I returned an approving gesture, and continued eating.
When every last lick of sauce had been cleaned from the plate, it was whisked away, another three taking its place on the table in front of me. The secondi course consisted of marinated fish from the Mediterranean, homemade potato chips, and Roman-style spinach.
I began with the latter, twirling a few strands around my fork and bringing it up to my mouth. It was only when I shovelled it in that I realized Roman-style meant cold. Now I‚Äôm not a fan of the vegetable to begin with, so this came as a bit of a surprise. Knowing who was watching, however, I tried my best to pretend I was enjoying it. From her vantage point now two tables away, the old woman chuckled and gave me an approving nod. Feeling as though I‚Äôd passed some sort of test, I finished the spinach with a smile.
The dolce and digestivo courses, a lemon curd cake and mango liqueur, arrived together shortly after I took my last bite of the fish and chips, as it were. As I took a bite and sip, in that order, I looked up. The old woman was sitting at the table right in front of me now. Any closer and we would have been asked, ‚Äútogether or separate?‚Äù when the cheque arrived.
For the fourth time, I transcended language barriers by exhibiting the universal gesture for ‚Äútasty.‚Äù She appeared oblivious to any such barrier, and launched into a conversation with me, in Italian.
I nodded along, smiling when her words sounded happy and donning a concerned expression when she pointed at the empty tables around us and frowned.
After a few minutes, the waiter came back out and said something to her, at which point she scurried back to the kitchen. He presented me with the cheque; everything I‚Äôd just devoured came to ‚Ç¨25. At the time, that seemed like a lot, but looking back on it now, it was a deal.
I paid up, extended a round of ‚Äúgrazi‚Äùs to the waiter, the old woman who I learned was his nonna, and a chef, his brother, who emerged from the kitchen to see me off, then walked out of the restaurant.
The rain had subsided, the dark clouds giving way to blue sky. I looked at my phone, and realized it was time to check in to my hotel. It was a quick ride on the metro, but stomach full, I opted instead to walk.
I wandered through the streets in the hotel‚Äôs general direction, observing Romans as I went. Before long, however, the Italian conversations I heard were replaced by those being held in English, Japanese, and German. I glanced over at a sign hanging in front of a nearby restaurant. It was in four languages, confirming my fear that I‚Äôd unwittingly entered a touristy area.
As I made my way through the square, I saw countless other visitors sitting on crowded ‚Äúristorante tradizionale‚Äù patios with fellow foreigners, shelling out ‚Ç¨25 for a pizza.
On one hand, I felt sorry for them for missing out on what I had just experienced, but on the other, I was happy places like the one I dined at were still unknown to all but the most curious and competent of travellers.
I was tempted to spread the word about the restaurant tucked away in the back alley a few streets down, but the only thing I feared more than them going out of business was returning next time to find that their menu was no longer only in Italian, and that the tables were filled with influencers too busy sharing the hidden gem with their followers to truly enjoy the experience. For the record, I only took my phone out to take pictures of each course, and waited until I returned to the hotel to post them. Most importantly, I did not name the restaurant, nor did I pin its location.
Over the next couple days, while I did venture down to the Vatican to admire the architecture, I spent pretty much all my time in areas not listed in any tourist brochure. I shopped at grocery stores where nobody spoke English, dined al fresco in local parks, and rode the bus alongside those on their way to work or running errands.
When people ask me now what they should see in Rome, my answer is always, ‚ÄúRome.‚Äù I encourage them to hop on a bus and see where it goes, dine places where they don‚Äôt even know what they‚Äôre ordering, and truly immerse themselves in the city.
My southern excursion ended with an overnight train from Rome to Munich, for which I had declined to book a sleeping cabin. I was still at the stage in my travel career, and age, that I could sacrifice comfort at the altar of saving a few bucks and still feel fine the next morning.
As the train pulled out of Roma Termini, I pulled out a bag of things I‚Äôd picked up at a grocery store and laid them out on the table. Thankfully, the other passengers in the compartment weren‚Äôt getting on until Firenze, so until then I had it all to myself. I first went for the tomatoes with olive oil and fresh basil, pairing them with prosciutto and mozzarella.
As I took my first bite, I looked up, half expecting to see the old woman staring back at me. Though it was just me and my reflection in the window, I smiled and gave an approving gesture nonetheless‚Ä¶
--
--
I‚Äôm usually somewhere else, listening to a podcast... No matter where I go, I always come home with the greatest souvenir: a broader perspective.

Title: Rome: The Most Beautiful Nightmare

Spending a summer in Rome, or anywhere in Italy, has long been on my bucket list, one I hoped to check off by the time I turned 30. However, the universe had other plans, and I found myself traveling there this summer at just 22 years old. The excitement was palpable as I anticipated visiting the iconic sites I had seen in encyclopedias and documentaries.
Those visuals‚Äîespecially depicting battles and mythological tales‚Äî shaped my understanding of history. Although I‚Äôve always been enchanted by Greek mythology, the allure of the Roman Empire is undeniable, I found myself both enchanted and repelled by the city.
I traveled with my mom, and we spent a few days first in Milan, then Verona, and Venice, before finally arriving in Rome. The train journey from Verona to Rome was straightforward and economical compared to other kinds of transportation, although our arrival was anything but pleasant.
The central train station was dirty and chaotic, reminiscent of a jungle. It was like that infamous scene from Mean Girls, where teenage life is likened to the wild antics of animals in the jungle, except without the comedic elements.
The station was filled with unruly crowds, a stark contrast to the pristine and gorgeous Milan Centrale, and it felt as though many of the travelers had never experienced civilized travel etiquette.
As we navigated the streets from the station to our hotel on Via Marsala‚Äî1.7 kilometers away‚Äîwe were confronted with a shocking amount of litter. Having lived in Egypt for years, I thought I was prepared for extreme levels of pollution. Yet, this was Rome, a city many consider a first-world destination!
We couldn't help but feel disheartened about the historic sites we came to explore, deciding to lower our expectations. The walls were marred with vulgar graffiti, plastered with posters advocating for communism and the freedom of Palestine, which are important movements, yet for being such a historical and touristic city, these messages felt completely out of place.
What struck us most was the sight of people living on the streets‚Äîmen and women surrounded by their belongings, some sleeping, others attending to their bodily needs or taking drugs. Witnessing such stark poverty in a city steeped in history was heart-wrenching. Our otherwise lovely trip to Italy took a downturn the moment we stepped into Rome. All of this unfolded in a span of maybe 45 minutes. What could we possibly expect for the rest of our stay?
Once we checked into our hotel, my mom suggested we take a moment to rest before embarking on our walking itinerary, which included the stunning Basilica of Santa Mar√≠a Maggiore, the Roman Coliseum, the Roman Forum, and the Victor Emmanuel II Monument.
Our spirits lifted slightly upon entering the Basilica, which was breathtaking both outside and in, with gold details adorning every surface. We then set off toward the Coliseum, and we could see it while walking along the Oppian Hill.
While it was indeed an impressive structure, being the largest construction of the Roman Empire, I found the hype surrounding it somewhat exaggerated. It didn‚Äôt match the grandeur depicted in countless documentaries and books. More than half of the structure has been replaced or supported by modern restoration efforts, which is understandable given its age, but it detracted from the authenticity. Nevertheless, it was a landmark worth checking off our itinerary.
Adjacent to the Coliseum lies the Roman Forum, easily viewable from the outside, which negated the need for us to purchase tickets. This led us to a lengthy walk, almost two kilometers more, through the remnants of Roman temples and architecture until we reached the Altar of the Fatherland, honoring Victor Emmanuel II.
This was undoubtedly my favorite part of the day. Victor Emmanuel II, the first king of unified Italy, played a crucial role in bringing together disparate kingdoms, fostering peace and unity among them. His story is fascinating, and his monument is nothing short of extraordinary.
The architecture and panoramic views of Rome from the top are breathtaking. Scattered sculptures of the twelve gods‚ÄîRoman adaptations of the Greek deities‚Äîsurround the site. It‚Äôs amusing how Rome appropriated so much from Greek culture, including its mythology, architecture, and even major elements of Catholicism, effectively erasing the origins and making them their own.
As the day waned, we needed to head back to the hotel. The journey back was over three kilometers, and we only walked a few meters before fatigue set in. We attempted to call a taxi, but in Italy, you must use an app, and you‚Äôll need an Italian phone number for that (at least for the most popular app, itTaxi). In other cities, our hotel staff assisted us with this. With the sun setting, we didn‚Äôt want to risk being out too late.
Frustrated and weary, we decided to walk to the hotel. However, once we reached the station, we found ourselves surrounded by numerous vagrants, and two of them began to follow us. We quickened our pace until we felt we had to run and hide inside a supermarket located within the train station.
Desperate for help, we asked the staff if someone could call a taxi for us; the atmosphere outside felt increasingly unsafe. Unfortunately, the staff members were unhelpful, some pretending not to understand our language. As someone whose mother tongue is Spanish‚Äîalmost identical to Italian in many aspects‚ÄîI found it perplexing that they claimed not to understand us, as if the similarities in the languages weren‚Äôt striking.
We eventually located a taxi station, and although my mom couldn‚Äôt stop complaining about the experience the driver understood every word of our frustration.
It had been a long, exhausting day. We managed to appreciate the views, but at what cost? For the first time in our travels, Rome made us feel utterly insecure, even with its stunning beauty and historical significance, it can also be a place of stark contradictions.
The city projects an image of grandeur in glossy travel photographs and brochures, yet it can swiftly crumble upon closer inspection. Yet, there‚Äôs more to add to my bucket list, and more lessons to learn.
In the end, it's a matter of either falling in love with the city or feeling a sense of disappointment. While we visited some impressive monuments, most failed to live up to our expectations, except for the striking monument to Victor Emmanuel II. Our stay in Rome left us yearning for the beauty and charm we envisioned but couldn't quite find.

At first this can be quite a grotesque and confronting place. In about 1631, the Capuchin monks used the bones of over 4000 dead monks, plus a few others, to decorate the walls and ceilings of the crypts.
However, if you look past the fact you are surrounded by death, you can see the messages the monks have incorporated into these series of small chapels. Each chapel has a different point to make to visitors, but all share the common theme that life is short, while death is for eternity. This is not meant to be morbid. The bones are arranged to create symbols, such as clocks to remind us to embrace life, to live life well and with meaning.
The story of how the order of Capuchin monks was established and how these crypts were created are fascinating. Capuchin means hoods in Italian and they are a branch off from the Franciscan order. Occasionally there are performances of sacred music in the crypts, usually at night which would be both powerful and slightly petrifying, despite the uplifting messages.
A tour is probably the best way to get the most out of this place as the untrained eye will miss a lot of the details and hidden metaphors. City Wonders is the original tour of this kind, reasonably priced and the tour guides really know their stuff, often university graduate students in the field.
This is Rome‚Äôs answer to Pompeii. It is close enough to Rome to visit in a day trip.
During ancient Roman times, this was a major seaport, a significant city to the Roman Empire (509BC ‚Äî 27BC). However, other seaports sprang up and Ostia became neglected. When a malaria plague hit the city, people left in droves and it became forgotten for centuries. At its height 100,000 people called Ostia home and your can still walk down the main street and see the theatre, taverns, and public baths.
Ostia provides a window into ancient Roman life without having to go too far afield.
Just up the road from the Colosseum, St Clements Basilica is an eye-opening experience. The current basilica, completed in the 12th century, was built on the ruins of Rome‚Äôs past. Rome is a city of layers as each era builds on top of the last. This is good for archaeology as it preserves the past, but not so good for building new metro lines. Construction has been held up for years because every time they dig, they find yet another historically significant site and have to down tools, but I digress. St Clements Basilica provides a first-hand experience of what lays beneath the surface of Rome. The Basilica itself holds and interesting story about St Clement, but narrow, damp stairs lead you down through history to a 4th century church. But it doesn‚Äôt end there. Further down is 1st century Rome including a store room for the Colosseum, a surprisingly intact pagan temple, alleyways, baths, homes and the river that connects to the Colosseum is still running down there. These all date back to Nero‚Äôs fire. Truly a journey through the hidden depths of Rome.
Note: A church (chiesa) is different from a basilica. A basilica in a church that contains a sacred relic and therefore hold more religious significance. This basilica allegedly holds the martyred remains of Saint Clement and Saint Ignatius, which leads me neatly to the next point.
Like many churches in Rome, the exterior of St Ignatius looks quite bland and you‚Äôd be forgiven for walking past it without giving it a second thought. I did. Once I went inside and was amazed, I pledged never to judge an Italian church by it‚Äôs cover again.
The beauty and magnificence of the ceiling fresco is awesome. It depicts representations of the continents to symbolise the missionary work of the Jesuit order, a refreshing change from the usual sacred art subjects. For me it is better than the Sistine chapel. A big call I know, but the optical illusion created of people seemingly falling and infinite space in genius. Andrea Pozzo is the Jesuit painter and architect who you have probably never heard of who specialised in these illusions in the 17th century.
Pozzo also created a false dome win St Ignatius, another optical illusion of great magnitude.
St Ignatius Church is just around the corner from the Pantheon. Entry is free.
While we‚Äôre on the subject of under rated artists: Bernini. So often he is overlooked, but without him Rome would be far less beautiful, or interesting. Rather than go one about it, here are some picture of his work. They speak for themselves.
6. Dawn
Dawn is the best time to appreciate Bernini‚Äôs masterpieces and the eternal city itself. It‚Äôs also a great time to take memorable photos, without random tourists and hawkers getting in the way. At this time there‚Äôs a serenity to the eternal city that is lost when battling the hoards.
7. Appian Way
When you ask: What have the Romans ever done for us? One of the first answers is the roads. Goes without saying. The Appian way is one of the first and most important roads the ancient Romans built, and the original paved path is still intact.
But even if you‚Äôre not mad keen on soaking up the beauty of ancient roadways, the Appian Way is another site to enjoy some distance from the crowds. It also provides a host of interesting attractions as well as a deliciously sinister history. Since it was prohibited to bury people within the city walls, the early Christians and Jews buried their loved ones in catacombs beneath the Appian Way. More infamously, Spartacus and his legion of slave followers were crucified along the road sides following their unsuccessful uprising to serve as a warning to other would-be upstarts.
If you‚Äôve got the time or inclination you may want to walk the entire 62 KM length (originally it was more than 200 KM long), but you certainly don‚Äôt have to. Indeed, you don‚Äôt even have to walk. There are bike tours, and even Segway tours available.
I would rarely suggest a tour, but this one is different. It‚Äôs a 90-minute, small group night time walking tour that takes you to the sites of some dastardly happenings in the city. The cases selected for the tour tended to be more domestic nature, rather than political, so no Julius Caesar murder or incestuous Caligula. But there was one case involving a sinister pope. One doesn‚Äôt want to give too much away. The walk was easy, and the tour ends near a taxi rank. It‚Äôs also one of the cheapest tours on offer. Check out the tour and tickets here. Would recommend doing the tour before visiting the Castel St. Angelo.
Julius Cesar was famously stabbed in the back by his senators, including his best mate. It all went down in Pompey‚Äôs Theatre ‚Äî not to be confused with Pompeii of volcano infamy.
Pompey‚Äôs Theatre is in the city of Rome. It is currently the site of a cat sanctuary where the city‚Äôs stray cats are fed, de-sexed, given medical treatment and re-homed. The cats live among the ruins of the theatre. It‚Äôs a great place for cat lovers. Be quick though as there are plans to re-purpose the site as a tourist attraction with new toilets and gift shop.
If you‚Äôre not a big fan of opera, but would like to experience some high Italian culture, then check out I Virtuosi Dell Op√©ra di Roma.
A collection of well-loved opera arias are performed in the Church of St. Paolo Entrole Le Mura and is far less formal than a full-blown operatic experience and at 22 Euro, much cheaper. The company has been around for a good 20 years. Musicians and singers are first rate and the acoustics in the church are phenomenal. But the company also offers other options of varying degrees of formality here.
Of course, there are far more fascinating and unusual things Rome has to offer. A city doesn‚Äôt get to be eternal without an eternity of captivating interest points. Just wandering about getting lost in the lanes and discovering hidden gems is a wonderful way to spend a few hours.
There are many tours available in Rome, but I recommend City Wonders because they are reasonably priced, the guides are experts in their fields and the content of the tours take you to next level, not just same-old tourism info.
For more nomadic tales and experiments come see me at Coolfooting where life is a journey not a race.
--
--
A teacher, writer and traveller, but not necessarily in that order. Writing on life, both real and imagined.

Title: With Upcoming 20-Year Anniversary of HBO/BBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúRome‚Äù Series, Let‚Äôs Celebrate Ray Stevenson & His Indelible Portrayal of Pullo
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúMe, I have simpler tastes. I like to kill my enemies, take their gold and enjoy their women.‚Äù ‚Äî roguish Titus Pullo
The first battle scene in the Rome TV series, which stunningly comes across like a movie, sets the tone of a rocky but true buddy relationship between two career Roman soldiers ‚Äî the charming anti-hero Titus Pullo (played by Ray Stevenson) and his officious pal Lucius Vorenus (Kevin McKidd). By-the-book centurion Vorenus excoriates rabble-rouser legionary Pullo to ‚Äúget back in formation you drunken fool‚Äù during the battle with the Gauls.
The Romans win the battle but Pullo is flogged for his insubordination, even though he single-handedly took down several Gallic warriors. After he gets his due punishment, Pullo, who knows how to drink, brawl, kill a lot of enemy combatants, and make love, continues to show his anti-heroic ways, chiding his torturers:
‚ÄúIs that it? I was just beginning to enjoy myself‚Ä¶‚Äù
During the two seasons and 22 episodes of Rome, there were many more ‚ÄúPullo-isms‚Äù ‚Äî wisecracking, but sometimes surprisingly insightful quips by the brutal but lovably giant character that he was.
‚ÄúJuno‚Äôs a c‚Ä¢nt, but you‚Äôre salty! And I was worried about bringing you!‚Äù Pullo to young Octavian, emperor to be
Englishman Stevenson and his onscreen creation Pullo were larger-than-life-characters. Pullo was described as a ‚Äúdevil-may-care soldier with the morals of a pirate, the appetites of a hedonist‚Ä¶‚Äù
When visiting Hollywood, where I live, actor Stevenson once told me: ‚ÄúPlaying Pullo on Rome turned my life around. It got me agent representation in the States and effectively started my movie career, which led to my lead roles in the Punisher franchise, and another feature movie, Kill the Irishman, and much more. So much happened because of that portrayal of Pullo in Rome.‚Äù
Octavian: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve given you up for dead.‚Äù Pullo: ‚ÄúNah. One of these days maybe. But not yet.‚Äù
But Pullo the character survived the series and essentially outlasted the man who portrayed him. Stevenson was filming Star Wars: Ahsoka in Italy in 2023 when he suddenly and sadly passed away.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve never actually tortured anyone. I don‚Äôt know how‚Ä¶ They have specialists!‚Äù ‚Äî Pullo to Octavian
I knew Ray personally, as a journalist who hung out with him several times, met his family, and sipped scotch malt whisky with Ray, while interviewing him for Playboy and other magazines.
Once, I and entertainment lawyer Angela Jackson also listened to him play surprisingly well on his Dobro guitar in his hotel room off LA‚Äôs famous Sunset Strip ‚Äî while sipping several glasses of The Macallan in some fine crystal. He told us of sipping scotch at The Scotch Malt Whisky Society in London. Oh, to be a fly on the wall there.
‚ÄúCalm down, love. It‚Äôs not for me, it‚Äôs the young master we‚Äôre here for.‚Äù ‚Äî Pullo to madam on taking Octavian to a brothel
Ray and I had an idea of writing up a book on the best Pullo-isms, and explaining the context. He immediately warmed to the idea, rhyming off some of his favorite sayings by Pullo.
‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs a traitor until they are.‚Äù
‚ÄúForculus, if you be the right god for the business here, I call on you to help me. If you will open this door, then I will kill for you a fine white lamb, or, failing that, if I couldn‚Äôt get a good one at a decent price, then six pigeons.‚Äù
Vorenus: ‚ÄúYou‚Ä¶ talk too much.‚Äù Pullo: ‚ÄúWe all have our faults.‚Äù
Indeed, Stevenson said getting into the shoes of Pullo, helped him become the actor and person he was to become: ‚ÄúAs an actor, playing Pullo, I feel I learned to get out of my own way in that series. I stopped having a stupid projected view about if I did this then maybe I could then know this or that thing about actors. It really made me sit down in my own skin and just turn up and do the job ‚Äî the job‚Äôs enough.‚Äù
When we got to the impact of playing Pullo on his personal life, he added, ‚ÄúThat period, shooting Rome mostly at the Cinecitt√† studios, was one of the major periods in my personal life, as well. I basically found my partner who was my landlady. And, that led to us having three boys together.‚Äù
The final scene of the second season of Rome, which set up the possibility of a third season which unfortunately never came off, involves Octavian with the returning Pullo, who ‚Äúfibs‚Äù a little telling Octavian that young Caesarion is dead. Octavian is on his way to ascending as Caesar Augustus, Rome‚Äôs first emperor.
When Pullo leaves Octavian‚Äôs palace, he meets up with the still-quite-alive Caesarion, the son of Cleopatra and supposedly Julius Caesar. The young lad swears vengeance, saying, ‚ÄúBy my blood, I‚Äôll not rest until I have avenged my mother and redeemed my father‚Äôs name.‚Äù
Stevenson and I couldn‚Äôt help but crack up when we recalled that final scene with Pullo and Caesarion, and the final Pullo-ism of the series, a final line of dialog that encapsulates the mischief that underscored Stevenson‚Äôs portrayal of Pullo. The underlying context in this somewhat fictionalized version of the historical story, is that Pullo had done his soldier‚Äôs duty by ‚Äúgetting it on‚Äù with Cleopatra and afterwards exclaiming in his inimitable fashion: ‚ÄúThat Gyppo princess, now that‚Äôs good c‚Ä¢nny.‚Äù
So, immediately after Caesarion‚Äôs little boy vow to avenge his mother, Pullo plainly but mischievously responds:
‚ÄúListen, about your father‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî Pullo to Caesarion
Rome debuted in summer of 2005, the first series on which HBO and the BBC worked together as co-producers. So, next year in 2025 would be the 20-year anniversary of Rome the series. For fans of the show and of Ray Stevenson (RIP, sir knight), wouldn‚Äôt it be a fine bow to have some celebration and/or memorial for both next year? So, let‚Äôs do something‚Ä¶
Check out the first and final scenes of ‚ÄúRome‚Äù on YouTube. And, also drop in on Ray Stevenson‚Äôs IMDb Pro page with contacts.

Title: Rome ‚Äî it sure wasn‚Äôt built in a day
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
Rome is one of the most history-rich cities in the world. It was our third stop on our whirlwind trip through Italy with my friend Melissa, who has been visiting from Texas. This was Eric‚Äôs and my fourth trip to Rome and we still saw things we‚Äôd not encountered before.
I‚Äôm going to take a different slant in this article. Everyone talks about the same ‚Äúwhat you must see‚Äù things: the colosseum, Trevi fountain, the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill, the Pantheon, St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, the Vatican Museum and Sistine Chapel, Piazza Navona, the Spanish Steps, and the Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelo. Rather than do the same old/same old descriptions, however, here are some unique facts about three of the historic structures in this amazing city.
The most famous structure in Rome, and probably one of the most famous in the world, is the Flavian Amphitheater, better known as the Roman Coliseum. It‚Äôs the largest ancient amphitheater ever built, and is still the largest standing amphitheater in the world today. Since 2007 it‚Äôs considered one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World.
The Colosseum was commissioned around 70‚Äì72 CE by Emperor Vespasian of the Flavian dynasty as a gift to the Roman people. In 80 CE, Vespasian‚Äôs son Titus opened the Colosseum‚Äìofficially known as the Flavian Amphitheater‚Äìwith 100 days of games.
Each sector (level) was reserved for a specific class of citizens, based on their importance. However, the entrance was free for anybody. It could hold an estimated 50,000 to 80,000 spectators at various points in its history, having an average audience of some 65,000. The structure was so well designed and organized all of its audience could exit the structure in less than 15 minutes.
The Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles including animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Roman mythology, and briefly mock sea battles. Nude synchronized swimmers sometimes performed by moonlight.
Usually the daily program was the following:
Once upon a time, the Colosseum featured a velarium (curtain) which was a type of awning. Retractable awnings were relatively common throughout the Roman Empire. Their unique design created a ventilation updraft, providing circulation and a cool breeze. The velarium stretched over the whole of the cavea, the seating area in the Colosseum, to protect spectators from the sun. Precisely how the awning was supported is a matter of conjecture.
The velarium that covered the Colosseum was the biggest that had ever been constructed. It‚Äôs believed that sailors from the Misenum fleet, with their background in sailmaking and rigging were employed to build, maintain and operate the velarium.
The colosseum remained almost intact until the 6th century, although t was damaged by earthquakes in 847 and 1231 (and subsequently repaired).
But after four centuries of active use, the fall of the Roman Empire brought an end to regular activities. The magnificent arena was abandoned and fell into neglect. It was repurposed many times, including being used for housing and shops, a church (that used the stage for a cemetery), a fortress for the Frangipani clan, and finally a monastery.
Unfortunately, until the 18th century, it was also used as a source of building materials. Marble cladding, seats, statues, support structures, and more were removed and used for other buildings around Rome, including a few larger projects by the Vatican. Two-thirds of the original Colosseum was destroyed through this ‚Äúlegal pillaging‚Äù.
Damage continued during the Middle Ages, when holes were drilled into the side during the Middle Ages in an attempt to locate the metal support structure.
The original floor of the Colosseum is long gone, exposing the hypogeum, the Colosseum‚Äôs substructure of underground passages, cages, and rooms where prisoners, animals, and gladiators were kept. The complex underground system‚Äôs hatches, hoists, and mobile types of machinery, allowed men, wild animals, and props to be brought up to the arena floor.
A partial floor has been constructed and is used as a stage for occasional concerts and performances.
Outside the Colosseum near the Arch of Constantine you can still see the remains of little shops which sold food, drinks, and souvenirs for the spectators, much like our professional sport arenas today. (They‚Äôre on the right in this picture.)
In 2013, a massive restoration and preservation project began. The last of it was still continuing when we visited, and some sections of the interior only opened the week after we left.
Today, the Roman Colosseum is the symbol of Rome in the world. It‚Äôs become a historical and archaeological treasure able to remind us of the greatness of the Roman Empire.
The city of Rome has big plans for the upcoming years of the Colosseum‚Äî including a retractable floor that will act as a stage for performances and shows. The arena will return to its original purpose: a space where visitors can attend concerts, theater performances, and more, just like it did nearly 2,000 years ago when it was first built (except without the human and animal deaths). Current completion is scheduled for 2023.
According to a calculation made by the Ministry of Culture, Flavio Amphitheater receives over 7 million visitors a year and ranks first among the most visited monuments in Italy. In 2018, TripAdvisor wrote that the Roman Colosseum was the most popular tourist attraction in the entire world.
Thanks to the above numbers, the Colosseum can get a bit crowded. We were lucky it was drizzly and overcast, not to mention off-season, so crowds were down. It‚Äôs absolutely worth seeing, but if you can go off-season, do it.
The largest fountain in Rome is the beautiful, baroque Trevi Fountain, featuring Neptune, the god of the sea, on his chariot. Construction of the fountain began in 1732 under the direction of Nicolo Salvi and was completed in 1762 by Pannini.
Rome has over 2000 fountains (more than any other city in the world). There are 50 monumental fountains, of which the Trevi is the most famous. There are also hundreds of smaller fountains and thousands of nasoni (big noses), which still supply citizens and tourists with free drinking water.
The fountain is located at the junction of three roads, which is actually how it got its name (the Latin name derives from the word trivium (tre vie ‚Äî an intersection of three streets). It is literally the Three Street Fountain.
The fountain is located at the end point of what was the Aqua Virgo (Virgin Waters) Aqueduct, constructed in around 19 BCE. It was one of the eleven Roman aqueducts that supplied the city of ancient Rome. Legend says that with the help of a virgin, Roman technicians located a source of pure water some 13 km (8.1 miles) from the city. This scene is presented on the fountain‚Äôs fa√ßade.
The Trevi Fountain has been featured in many movies and TV shows, including: Roman Holiday (1953), Three Coins in the Fountain (1954), Federico Fellini‚Äôs classic La Dolce Vita (1960), Sabrina Goes to Rome (1998), and The Lizzie McGuire Movie (2003).
There‚Äôs a legend, inspired by the movie Three Coins in the Fountain, about throwing in three coins: the first guarantees a repeat visit to the city, the second means a love affair, and the third means a wedding. Yes, I did it, but only threw in one coin. I don‚Äôt need a love affair or a wedding, as I‚Äôm happily married for 30+ years. But I‚Äôd definitely like to return to Rome!
Over ‚Ç¨2,000,000 worth of coins are thrown in by hopeful tourists every year. That money is regularly collected and used to support a food bank/social supermarket for people living in poverty in Rome.
The Trevi Fountain was once one of the most important sources for distributing fresh water to the public baths and drinking fountains across the city. Today the fountain is recirculated, to the tune of 2,823,800 cubic feet of water every 24 hours. It‚Äôs one of the few fountains that are non-potable (not safe to drink from).
The day we visited with Melissa was moderately crowded. The sun was out and air was warm, even though it was late March. We also went on a Sunday, so there were many locals enjoying the area. When you get a chance to go, pick a weekday, and go off-season. This picture IS off season, so if you go in the peak of summer, expect much denser crowds than this.
A bit less well-known, but equally spectacular, is the Roman Pantheon, the most preserved and influential building of ancient Rome. The name pantheon means ‚Äútemple of all the gods‚Äù so it‚Äôs believed the Pantheon was originally dedicated to all the gods of pagan Rome.
It‚Äôs nearly as popular as the Roman Colosseum, with 7 million annual visitors. And unlike the Colosseum, the Pantheon is free to visit during the week.
It‚Äôs location wasn‚Äôt chosen by chance. According to legend, it‚Äôs the place where the founder of Rome, Romulus, at his death was seized by an eagle and taken off into the skies with the Gods.
The current Pantheon isn‚Äôt the original. It‚Äôs actually the third built on the same site. The first was built by Marcus Agrippa in 27 BCE. It burned down in 80 CE and was reconstructed by Emperor Domition. This second one was struck by lightning in 110 CE and burned down again. It was rebuilt the second time by Emperor Trajan, although he died before completion. The building was completed by Hadrian between 118‚Äì128 CE and remains to this day, having survived almost 2000 years. One problem with tracking Hadrian‚Äôs construction is that he reused the original inscription (from 27 BC) attributing the building to Agrippa.
The building is a rotunda (cylindrical in shape) with a portico of large granite Corinthian columns (eight in the first rank and two groups of four behind) under a pediment (the triangle gable). A rectangular vestibule links the porch to the rotunda. In the top of the dome is an oculus (central opening) to the sky. Almost two thousand years after it was built, the Pantheon‚Äôs dome is still the world‚Äôs largest unreinforced concrete dome.
The building precisely follows the rules of Classical architecture laid out by Vitruvius, creating an aesthetically pleasing form. The height of the building is exactly the same as the diameter, meaning that a perfect sphere would fit inside. This gives the Pantheon the impression of perfect balance and harmony.
The large circular domed cella (inner chamber of an ancient Greek or Roman temple), with a conventional temple portico front, was unique in Roman architecture. Nevertheless, it became one of the most imitated buildings in history. For example, the library Thomas Jefferson designed for the University of Virginia is based on the Pantheon. Michelangelo said it was the work of angels, not men.
The Pantheon wasn‚Äôt just built as a pagan temple dedicated to all the gods. In fact, it was the first temple built for the common people. That‚Äôs common for temples and churches today, but in ancient times temples were forbidden places, only for vestals and priests.
Had it stayed a pagan temple, it might have fallen into ruin like so many other ancient Roman buildings. But in the year 608, Emperor Phocas gave the temple to Pope Boniface IV as a gift. The Pope had all remnants of paganism removed and consecrated it as the church of St Mary and the Martyrs.
The building‚Äôs consecration as a church saved it from the abandonment, destruction, and the worst of the pillaging that the majority of ancient Rome‚Äôs buildings suffered during the early medieval period. It‚Äôs the reason the Pantheon is one of the best-preserved of all Ancient Roman buildings.
One of the Pantheon‚Äôs greatest elements is its 43.2 meter (142 foot) dome. It was the largest dome in the world for more than 1300 years until Brunelleschi, inspired by the Pantheon, built his famous Duomo in Florence. It‚Äôs still the largest unreinforced concrete dome in the world.
The dome was built with a single casting of concrete in subsequent layers. The concrete was lightened by mixing it with lighter stones as it neared the highest point, as well as gradually making the wall thinner. In lower levels, the concrete was mixed with heavy travertine stone. As the dome grew, progressively lighter materials (such as tuffo stone) were used. The top layer was made with pumice, a light-weight stone.
Plus, the coffers (sunken squares) in the ceiling also help to minimize the weight.
The dome was originally covered in bronze, which must have been a glorious sight in the sun. Unfortunately, throughout the Middle Ages, materials were gradually stripped away to be used elsewhere. Pope Urban VIII (a member of the Barberini family) took the bronze from the Pantheon‚Äôs portico in 1631 to construct cannons for the Vatican, giving rise to the saying quod non fecerunt barbari, fecerunt Barberini‚Äô(what the barbarians didn‚Äôt do was done by the Barberini).
At the centre of the dome, there is a 9 meter (30 foot) diameter hole, called the Oculus. Looking up, you‚Äôd never guess the hole is that big. It‚Äôs the only light source inside, and yes, water does get inside when it rains.
We walked an average of 17,000 steps every day we were in Rome, so we obviously saw much more than the above. I‚Äôll add a few additional photos in closing, but am not going to go into detail about the locations (‚Äúminutes to read‚Äù matters).
I would very much like your thoughts on the style of my last couple of articles. Most writers do a travelogue/commentary style, describing their walk around a location, and including brief descriptions of everything they see. Instead, I‚Äôve chosen to follow my former life as a technical writer, by giving facts, history, details, and trivia about a few select locations. Please let me know if you like this style or would rather read a more traditional travelogue.
More of our favorite stops in Rome:
And, of course‚Ä¶

Texan who retired to Spain. Tech writer turned mystery writer, blogger, and world traveler. For fun I handbuild pottery pieces. Life is great. It should be!

Title: The Founding of Rome: Myth vs. History
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

1
Listen
Share
Click here to see the video
The city of Rome, with its rich tapestry of history and legend, stands as a testament to the complexities of human civilization. Its origins, shrouded in the mists of time, are a blend of myth and historical fact, a confluence that has fascinated scholars, historians, and enthusiasts for centuries. This article delves into the depths of Rome‚Äôs founding, exploring the interplay of myth and history, and unraveling the threads of truth that lie within the legendary tale of Romulus and Remus.
At the heart of Rome‚Äôs foundation story is the legend of Romulus and Remus, twin brothers said to be the sons of Mars, the god of war, and Rhea Silvia, a Vestal Virgin. According to the myth, they were abandoned as infants and left to die in the Tiber River. However, fate intervened, and they were discovered and suckled by a she-wolf, an image that has become emblematic of Rome itself. The twins were later found and raised by a shepherd and his wife. As young men, Romulus and Remus became involved in a dispute over the rightful ruler of Alba Longa, their ancestral home. This conflict led them to leave and establish their own city. However, disagreement arose between the brothers over the location and governance of the new city. This dispute culminated in Romulus killing Remus, either in a fit of rage or as a consequence of Remus mocking his brother‚Äôs efforts to build a city wall. Romulus then became the sole founder and the first king of the new city, which he named Rome.
Click here to see the video
While the tale of Romulus and Remus is rich in symbolic and cultural significance, historical evidence paints a different picture of Rome‚Äôs origins. Historians generally agree that the city was founded in the 8th century BCE, though the exact date remains a topic of debate. The traditional date of Rome‚Äôs founding, as calculated by the Roman historian Varro, is 753 BCE, but archaeological evidence suggests that the area was inhabited earlier. The early Romans were likely a mix of Latin and Sabine peoples, indigenous tribes of the Italian peninsula. These groups settled on the seven hills that would later become central to Roman mythology and city planning. The location of Rome, near the Tiber River and at a crossroads of trade and migration routes, was strategic for commerce and defense, suggesting that the city‚Äôs origins were as much about practicality as they were about destiny.
Click here to see the video
The story of Romulus and Remus serves as a powerful founding myth, providing Rome with a narrative of divine origin and heroic founding. Myths like these often arise in ancient cultures to explain the unexplainable and to offer a sense of identity and purpose. In the case of Rome, the myth of its divine founding by the sons of Mars lent the city and its people an aura of destiny and greatness. However, the line between myth and history is not always clear. Historical events often become embellished with mythical elements, and myths may contain kernels of historical truth. The legend of Romulus and Remus, for instance, might be seen as a symbolic representation of the struggles and conflicts inherent in the founding of any city or civilization. The fratricidal conflict between the brothers could reflect the real-life conflicts between different tribes or social groups in early Rome.
Click here to watch the full video
Archaeological excavations in Rome and its surrounding areas have provided valuable insights into the city‚Äôs early history. Discoveries such as the remains of early settlements on the Palatine Hill, pottery, and burial sites have shed light on the lives of Rome‚Äôs earliest inhabitants. These findings suggest a gradual development of the city from a collection of small villages to a more organized urban center. One of the most significant discoveries is the Lapis Niger, an ancient shrine in the Roman Forum. Inscriptions found at the site date back to the 6th century BCE and reference a king, possibly linking to the period of the Roman Kingdom. While not directly confirming the existence of Romulus, these findings support the idea of a monarchical system in early Rome, as the legend suggests.
Click here to watch the full video
The influence of Greek culture on Roman mythology and history is undeniable. Many of the myths, including the story of Romulus and Remus, show parallels with Greek mythology. This cultural crossover is likely due to the close interactions between Greek colonies in southern Italy and the early Romans. The Romans were known to have adopted and adapted various elements of Greek culture, including art, religion, and literature. The adaptation of Greek myths and legends into Roman culture served not only to enrich Roman mythology but also to establish Rome as a continuation and successor of the great Greek civilization. This cultural appropriation helped Rome to build its own identity, borrowing from the prestige and legacy of the Greeks.
Click here to watch the full video
The legend of Romulus and Remus has had a lasting impact on Roman culture and identity. The image of the she-wolf nursing the twin brothers is a symbol of Rome that persists to this day. This iconography has been found on various artifacts, including coins, sculptures, and paintings, throughout the history of Rome. The story of the city‚Äôs founding by divine descendants also served to legitimize the rule of its leaders. Emperors and politicians often traced their lineage back to divine or heroic ancestors, using these connections to justify their authority and policies. The myth of Romulus and Remus thus became a tool for political propaganda as well as a foundational narrative.
Click here to watch the full video
The founding of Rome, a blend of myth and history, continues to captivate the imagination of people around the world. The story of Romulus and Remus, whether viewed as literal truth, symbolic narrative, or a combination of both, is central to understanding the ethos and identity of ancient Rome. It speaks to the human need for stories that give meaning to our past and shape our collective identity. As we explore the origins of this great city, we are reminded of the power of myths in shaping history and the importance of historical research in understanding our myths. The story of Rome‚Äôs founding, in all its complexity, is a testament to the enduring legacy of one of the world‚Äôs greatest civilizations, a legacy that continues to influence us to this day.

Title: When Did Ancient Rome Actually Fall?
Content:

An Ancient Roman aristocrat would surely feel proud that 2,000 years later, Rome still looms large in the Western consciousness as the greatest empire that ever was. Careers have been built on studying why Rome fell, and even the general public has heard some of the proposals: was it immigration, horse-back barbarians, Christianity, inflation, dependency on slaves, the decadence of the elites, or perhaps even lead poisoning?
We care about this mostly because we see Ancient Rome as a mirror of modern empires, especially the US. If Rome fell because of barbarian hordes, then surely that means America must kick out all the Mexicans or else it will suffer the same fate! ‚Ä¶ Right?
Today, I will be putting my ancient history degree to use by writing not about why Rome fell, but about the even more thorny topic of when it fell (if we can even pinpoint a date). You learn very different lessons about its decline depending on whether you feel that Rome fell in 330 AD, 395 AD, 476 AD, 565 AD, 1453 AD, 27 BC or even 105 BC. Which of these was the ‚Äúreal‚Äù date has a lot to do with how you define ‚ÄúRoman-ness‚Äù ‚Äî a tougher topic than it seems.

Content:

1
Listen
Share
After experiencing my Venetian Dream and enjoying the sunsets of Florence, all roads lead me to Rome. And here I am‚Ä¶
Yet, it seemed Rome wasn‚Äôt so happy to see me. I went to the hotel and found out this wasn‚Äôt my hotel. Seems like there are 4 hotels with the same names or similar, and my map showed me the most-rated one. So I booked a hotel just by checking its name on the map without double checking the address and‚Ä¶ My hotel is somewhere else‚Ä¶ OK, not funny, but first, let‚Äôs find it.
It wasn‚Äôt super easy, but I like challenges. I found the hotel, and checked in, and I didn‚Äôt have the energy to go on. Usually, I book a hotel near the sites I want to visit. This helps me not to waste time and energy on transportation. Now my hotel isn‚Äôt in the place I thought and‚Ä¶ In one word‚Äîstressful.
Okay! I just had a little rest and went out very hungry. I decided to eat carbonara and went to the nearest restaurant to my hotel. The pasta was very salty. Okay, Rome doesn‚Äôt like me.
Still tired and stressed, disappointed with Rome, I started walking, and in about 15 minutes I appeared near the Colosseum. Seems like my hotel wasn‚Äôt so far away. Maybe everything isn‚Äôt so bad, haha‚Ä¶
Colosseum ‚Äî the first World Wonder my eyes saw!
It‚Äôs huge and impressive. I was walking around and going back through history. This is the largest amphitheater ever built, and it is still standing, despite its age. This is a great achievement in ancient architecture. Really significant‚Ä¶ but I‚Äôll speak more later, as this was just the first meeting and I was going to see this wonder every day.
Rome is rich with fountains. You can see these water sources in every square. For instance, another beautiful fountain is located in the Piazza Navona‚Äîthe Fiumi Fountains. Yet, the pearl of the Roman fountains remains Trevi Fountains. I walked there and understood that this fountain was meant to become one of my favorite spots in Rome.
Trevi fountains are huge and significant. And, of course, overcrowded. I loved it a lot‚Äîthe architecture and especially its symbolism.
It was built as a water source for the city and constructed in travertine stone‚Äîthe same material as the Colosseum. The magnificent view and stone decorations we see today were done in the late 18th century, commissioned by Pope Clement XII, who wanted to showcase the power and influence of the Catholic Church in Rome.
You may know that people throw coins into the water. The first and most well-known reason is based on local lore: it will bring you back to Rome again someday. Yet, some people do it hoping to find love or romance while in Rome and to marry there happily. And they say that each wish requires its own coin. As for me, I just enjoyed the magnificence of the fountains.
Rome is Rome, and there‚Äôs anything to see, whatever corner you step into. I was just walking around and appearing in another beautiful and historical place to enjoy. Piazza Navona was one of them‚Äîa nice square where you may just have a break, sit on a bench, and enjoy the weather, and how Roman people live their daily lives, how tourists react, and so on‚Äîlots of emotions and feelings.
The Spanish Steps is another favorite site in Rome. The view from the top is very beautiful, and walking up is another way to discover the lifestyle in Rome. It all began when the French wanted to create a symbolic connection between France and Spain in Rome. Spanish Steps was given to the world to connect Trinit√† dei Monti church, owned by the French, to the Piazza di Spagna, named for the Bourbon Spanish Embassy that stood alongside it.
Quirinal Palace is another square and another historical building in Rome. This is the home of the president of Italy. They say that it is possible to have a guided tour of this building in Italian language. So, if you‚Äôre interested in where the Italian president lives and you‚Äôre okay with the Italian language, book a tour.
The next square you may easily appear in is the Piazza del Popolo. Here you will see the Twin Churches and fountains. I loved the idea of having such churches.
And if you walk up, you‚Äôll appear at a viewpoint from which you can see the square and a beautiful view of the city as well. It is worth waiting for a sunset there.
Of course, I couldn‚Äôt be in Rome and not find an Armenian site. This time it was San Biagio degli Armeni‚Äîthe national church of the Armenian community in Rome. The church is frequently recorded in medieval catalogs. It originated before the 10th century but was first recorded in a 1072 inscription preserved inside it.
I read that there‚Äôs Armenian liturgy on some days of the week. Unfortunately, when I went, there was a nun who was praying, and I didn‚Äôt want to disturb her. I would like to talk to somebody and try to learn more about this Armenian piece, but it wasn‚Äôt meant to be.
I met the Colosseum every morning and evening, but of course, I couldn‚Äôt miss my chance to enter this masterpiece and see the ancient history, architecture, and culture. I had booked a tour in advance, and it was one of the best things I did. First of all, let me tell you, the guides are very enthusiastic and funny, and they help you understand everything better. My tour started with the Roman Forum.
I learned a lot about Roman history when I visited the Roman Forum, surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings at the center of Rome. Here you may see even a few columns of an early building, and it‚Äôs so lovely how Italians preserve their history and ancient heritage.
These days, the Forum is part of the Parco Archeologico del Colosseo.
After exploring the Forum, my group was guided to the Colosseum. This amphitheater has three levels of arches around the outside. In height, the Colosseum was as tall as a modern 12-story building; it held 50,000 spectators.
When I entered, I saw that the walls were darker from the inside. They say that in ancient times, when there weren‚Äôt lights, people had to use torches when going inside, even during the day. This ancient giant is even greater from the inside. It was a very interesting experience to see the arena floor and imagine gladiators fighting.
When looking closer at the walls, you can see that the building has many holes that resemble Swiss cheese. The guide explained that the massive travertine blocks that make up the outer wall were not stuck together with mortar or cement, as you might expect. Instead, they used iron clamps. And after successive Barbarian invasions, iron had become very valuable. The Romans gouged out the plaster covering the iron, pulled it out, and used it for various purposes (mostly weaponry). I read somewhere that it is estimated that over 300 tons of iron were removed from the building, leaving it pockmarked as it is today.
In any case, Romans know how to preserve their history and historical heritage. There was even a few meters of the ancient floor outside the Colosseum that they enclosed so that people don‚Äôt walk on it.
I‚Äôve always used to say that my eyes are blessed to see this world and its wonders. But in Rome, it became even more practical.
As the Colosseum was the nearest spot to my hotel, every morning I was passing by it. It was probably my second morning there when Viktor Hladchenko approached me and asked to take a photo of my eye reflecting the Colosseum. I leave it to your judgment.
Don‚Äôt you think I‚Äôm lucky? I do.
I forgot to tell you that wherever I was walking in Rome, the dome of Saint Peter Basilica was visible.
And finally, that day came when I visited the Vatican‚Äîthe smallest country in the world. This isn‚Äôt a joke; imagine that this small territory is a separate country inside the city of Rome. It has everything: a passport system, license plates, a post office, a flag, a telephone system, and a radio station. The Pope himself heads the state, and every year, over 6 million tourists visit Vatican Museums.
This small country has great significance in the Christian world. And being an Armenian (the first nation that adopted Christianity as a state religion in 301), as well as being a museum lover, I was waiting for this day. Unfortunately, I wasn‚Äôt lucky enough to see the Pope‚Ä¶ haha‚Ä¶
I spent 5 hours wandering in the Vatican Museum, Sistine Chapel, and Saint Peter‚Äôs Basilica. And I was impressed. However, the most significant for me was the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. Here, I understood why it isn‚Äôt allowed to take photos there. No photo may express what my eyes saw, even a little similar to that. The ceiling is live, and all the figures and creatures are real, and sometimes it even seems they‚Äôre moving‚Ä¶ This is a real masterpiece, and it is worth spending hours looking up at the ceilings, even if your neck already kills.
I also had a chance to see the dome of Saint Peter‚Äôs Basilica from one of the best possible angles, where the windows and the dome are wholly visible. It‚Äôs not possible to see it from the front side.
The inside of the church is impressive as well. It‚Äôs really huge, especially for me, as I am used to small Armenian churches with humble church architecture without so many colors. Imagine how tired I would be after walking so long and getting so much information and emotion. And that wasn‚Äôt enough. I went out of the basilica and looked up instinctively (because you need to look up in order not to miss), and you guess what?
In front of me on the wall of Saint Peter‚Äôs Basilica, there was a statue of St. Gregory the Illuminator‚Äîthe Armenian Saint, thanks to whom Armenians adopted Christianity.
I saw the Armenian letters and thought I was so tired I had an illusion. But no, it was real, and you can see it when you visit the basilica.
After a tiring and informative day in Vatican City, I was very tired and tasty. So, I decided to walk to the Trastevere neighborhood to eat something. This part of Rome is well-known for its bars and restaurants. There is an interesting atmosphere and, of course, tasty dishes.
Trastevere is colorful, with many people sitting inside and outside restaurants, enjoying their Roman experience. I like this neighborhood and recommend going there even if you don‚Äôt want to eat; just enjoy the narrow streets, color, and atmosphere.
As I‚Äôve already mentioned, I tried a salty Carbonara during my first day in Rome. But I never give up. I gave another chance to this pasta, which originated in Rome. I tried it once more in another restaurant (unfortunately, I don‚Äôt remember the name), and it was super delicious. I loved Romanian Carbonara.
In Trastevere, I tried another pasta originating in Rome‚ÄîCacio e Pepe (Spaghetti with Cheese and Pepper). This is a simple but very delicious pasta to try when you are in Rome. It was great.
To make the long story short, I loved Italian pasta.
I spent 4 full days in Rome and I think that‚Äôs enough to explore the city for your first visit.
I went to the hotel in the evening (by the way, as my hotel wasn‚Äôt in a walking area from everywhere I was going, I used buses to go back to the hotel). Of course, after enjoying the best tiramisu in my life and with the best view. I couldn‚Äôt leave Rome without saying ‚ÄúSee you soon‚Äù to the Trevi fountains. Btw, do not miss this spot at night as well.
OK! Let‚Äôs come back. My flight was early in the morning (about 6 AM), and I had to arrive at the airport at night. Somehow scary, isn‚Äôt it? Okay, it wasn‚Äôt until it became.
No buses, no trains; I only have one option‚Äîa taxi. A friend told me I could use Uber. I tried earlier, and it showed some cars nearby, but when the time came and I tried to request a ride, it didn‚Äôt work. Okay, it was about 2 AM; I needed to go to the airport, and I didn‚Äôt know how. Then it was scary.
I went out of the hotel, walked for about 10 minutes, and saw some people. At first, I was scared to approach them, but I realized I didn‚Äôt have another chance. So, I asked them for help. Fortunately, they were very kind and willing to help me. It wasn‚Äôt easy to find a taxi for them as well. They called some services, tried some applications, and managed to find one for me. I‚Äôm so thankful to these people. If you read me, guys, write to me. I‚Äôll be happy to help you whenever you‚Äôre in Armenia.
I love Rome!
I love people in Rome. I love the Italian way of enjoying life. And I love the idea of living in Rome for a few months. For me, Rome is a middle-aged man who is smart inside and who also cares about his look and appearance. He‚Äôs well-trained and wearing a classic outfit‚Äîa dark blue suit and white shirt with a tie, probably. And maybe he is riding a motorcycle.
Of the 3 Italian cities I lived in, I go for Rome. Okay, Venice is unique and special‚Äîa real dream of magic; Florence is cozy and cultural‚Äîwith breathtaking views; but Rome is Rome‚Äîancient but aesthetic, historical but fictional, architectural, sweet, and lovely. I loved the vibe in Rome. Rome is closer to my soul. It‚Äôs like me‚Äîromantic and real!
I love Italy üñ§

Title: A Beginner‚Äôs Guide to Getting Into Ancient Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
