1
Listen
Share
By now, all my friends know how obsessed with Ancient Roman history I am ‚Äî if the Hadrian necklace around my neck wasn‚Äôt a major indicator, my Facebook wall is covered in memes about Julius Caesar‚Äôs stabbing and the gayness of Ancient Greeks. I don‚Äôt see how everyone isn‚Äôt googly-eyed about Trajan‚Äôs conquests in Dacia or the way Romans engineered their Forum.
But as my sister so eloquently said in Barnes&Noble, as I was crouched down at the ancient history section, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a bunch of dead guys.‚Äù Incorrect! The Gallic Wars by Julius Caesar, Meditations by Marcus Aurelius, and the speeches and private letters of Cicero create a breathing, amorphous view of Ancient Rome as the Romans lived it. They‚Äôre crumbling now, but it‚Äôs so easy to get into Rome when you hear them speaking to you. Here are a few ways to submerse yourself in Ancient culture without wasting money on classes or feeling like an anachronistic nitwit ‚Äî because the Ancient do matter, and they were pretty wild.
Although a painfully in-depth history of Rome isn‚Äôt necessary, it does make understanding memes easier and dropping highfalutin facts at parties a treat. After I visited Rome for the first time, I flocked to the internet, looking for anything to teach me ancient history. I stumbled on this podcast, The History of Rome by Mike Duncan, which was a five-year project detailing the early years of the Roman kingdoms to its ignominious fall in 476 CE. 189 episodes of wry humor, encyclopedic facts, and anecdotes testifying to the gore of Rome, the series is thick but enjoyable. 14-year-old Mackenzie lived for this podcast, scrawling little notes in a dark bedroom (this is only half exaggeration). Although this fascination only heightened my social ineptness, I learned so much (too much) about dead guys.
2. Join the Ancient Roman Meme Pages
Browse a few Facebook meme pages, and you‚Äôll have working knowledge of the big kahunas of ancient history. My top two pages are Roman SPQRposting and Rough Roman Memes ‚Äî the former is crass and attaches names like Julius Caesar and Seneca to PornHub screenshots, but it‚Äôs so hilarious. My social media walls are a running joke, with all my friends knowing me as the Ancient Meme girl. But beyond the porn and Elon Musk memes, history is explained and jabbed at. It forces users to research memes they don‚Äôt understand (i.e. What happened at the Teutoburg Forest? What does the two walls of The Battle of Alesia mean?) This subculture of meme trolls is highly educated and highly derisive, with people posting revisions to already revised memes in the comments. Also, I just saw someone post 50 shades of Alcibiades, and I am done.
3. Brush Up on Ancient Roman TV and Movie Adaptations
Russell Crowe isn‚Äôt the apex of Roman history, but at least his attractiveness seduces people into the ancient history genre. Netflix has 5+ smarmy shows about Rome, although the HBO ROME series is the most salacious and salient of them all. And we can‚Äôt forget I, Claudius, that 1970s BBC show that was weirdly great despite the multiple incest and boob scenes. It‚Äôs important to take these shows with a granary of salt (get it?). While they are dramatic and make everything seem neatly cut and sequential, Ancient Rome wasn‚Äôt easy to follow ‚Äî communication between armies took weeks or months and it‚Äôs easy to focus on megalomaniacal Emperors instead of the reams of ‚Äúnormal‚Äù Roman citizens.
As for movie adaptations, I would watch the 70s/80s movies that are as cringy as they are wholesome. Ben Hur, Quo Vadis, and Monty Python‚Äôs Life of Brian aren‚Äôt 100% accurate, but they uncork a lifetime so foreign to us today. Yeah, that lifetime is badly CGI-ed and filled with tan, blue-eyed men with chin dimples, but it gets us thinking about the Romans nonetheless.
4. Hit the {Serious} Books
Nothing beats a primary-source literature bath. To understand the Romans, one must read their words, marvel at the mosaics they left behind, see their skeleton structures. The Aeneid is nice & historical, but I‚Äôm talking about the meatier works ‚Äî Julius Caesar‚Äôs Gallic Wars, the satire of Petronius, the personal letters that Cicero wrote to enemies, friends, and lovers (thanks for the inspiration, Mary Beard). A culture can be expressed through characters, and Mary Beard makes that evident in her Meet the Romans BBC series ‚Äî reading the gravestones of imperial hairdressers, gladiators, and wine makers, she recreated life from thousands of years ago.
Besides primary sources, a Roman history dilettante should read seminal writings and critiques written in the last few centuries. The prime example of this is, of course, The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire by Edward Gibbon. Six volumes and published in the late 1700s, it discusses the reasons why Rome deteriorated, most notably by Christianity. A more recent *must read* is SPQR by my favorite intellectual, Mary Beard. Her first chapter situates readers in 63 BCE, during the throws of the Catiline Conspiracy and the Ciceronian executions ‚Äî what a climax in the first few pages! I‚Äôm currently reading that book now, although I also have my eye on Resurrecting the Granary of Rome: Environmental History and French Colonial Expansion in North Africa.
5. Deck Yourself Out in Roman Jewelry
This isn‚Äôt strictly necessary (yes, I‚Äôve said this before), but bejeweling your collarbone in Ancient denarius, a Roman currency, looks and feels like royalty. I bought a faded denarius with Hadrian‚Äôs profile from Civitas, an online coin dealer ‚Äî it was only $50, so here‚Äôs to hoping it‚Äôs not a fake. Fitting the coin into a bezel (a plated ring the coin slips into), I then found a spare chain and aha! Now the Romans are literally close to my heart all the time. Forever 21 also sells bracelets made of fake gold ancient coins ‚Äî it‚Äôs not the most savory or classy accessory, but I appreciate the nod to our forebears.
6. Adopt a Roman Diet for a Week
I‚Äôm not an expert on regular Roman diets, but I know it included a f*ck ton of grain, diluted wine, and homemade fish sauce spread on everything (in Latin, garum). By contrast, the rich ate lavishly, supplementing their goblets with fruits, cheese, rare meats (i.e. flamingo, duck, hare, snails), and lots of fish ‚Äî it didn‚Äôt include any of the processed nonsense our palettes are used to.
As part of an upcoming Spoon article, I‚Äôm going to eat religiously Roman for a week ‚Äî my mother just handed me a bottle of Portuguesier (a sweeter merlot), so let‚Äôs start this Bacchanalia. The oldest surviving cookbook in history, Cookery and Dining in Imperial Rome by Apicius, dates back to Ancient Rome. It describes in detail the opulence of Roman tongues and the food which modern people would consider gross and exotic ‚Äî fish balls? Boiled ostrich? Ragout of brains anyone? I couldn‚Äôt eat those foods for a week, but I‚Äôm THRILLED about the plebeian alcohol and carbs.
7. Listen to Roman Music (aka the Lyre)
For all the audio learners out there, listening to traditional Roman music can set the SPQR mood. Roman music was heavily dependent on the lyre, a stringed instrument from classical Greece. Resembling the harp, it makes the listener simultaneously snoozed and hypnotized ‚Äî it‚Äôs the music of cults, sounds of the Villa of the Mysteries. Music was traditionally played during funerals, although contrary to the popular phrase ‚ÄúNero fiddled while Rome burned,‚Äù the fiddle was not around in Roman days. According to the History Channel, the Romans had the cithara (a wooden, stringed instrument) and the double-reeded aulos (the ancient version of the oboe). YouTube has several videos of European professors playing these outdated instruments, as well as the music of Michael Levy, a master lyre musician.
8. Watch Mary Beard Lectures on YouTube
My! Lady! I‚Äôve already mentioned Mary Beard multiple times, but she‚Äôs truly an intellectual to be admired, praised, and learned from ‚Äî her brain is impressive, but it‚Äôs her edge and distaste for sugar-coating that gets me. She‚Äôs a professor at Cambridge, author of several history books, a debater against Boris Johnson for Christ sakes, and yet she still says ‚Äúbloody hell‚Äù during lectures! Any lady that can combine intellect with tongue-and-cheek is my kind of woman.
Her words fuse the modern and the ancient, the lascivious and high-brow. Watch her series Meet the Romans, take notes on her lectures about Women in Power, or marvel as she discusses portraits of Augustus. My early-morning routine includes boiling peppermint tea and fangirling over her excitement for the Romans. For Mary, the Romans aren‚Äôt crumbling headstones on the Appian way ‚Äî they‚Äôre accessible if we read (or translate) close enough.
9. Travel to Rome
This tip seems obvious, but it‚Äôs difficult to grow an obsession without any substance. Walking in the Forum, seeing cats slink in the Largo di Torre Argentina (the square where Caesar was stabbed), or watching indigo skies through the Pantheon oculus is so much substance. Running into a literal brick wall of history is more affecting than listening to a podcast. There‚Äôs nothing like sticky hands after eating gelato outside the Circo Massimo. Dragging unwilling parents to Ostia Antica (an ancient port) is my idea of fun. I only became interested in Rome after traveling there ‚Äî I didn‚Äôt know anything about ancient history; I just wanted to gorge on gelato and pizza. But the spell of the city creeps, like a mono contagion, overwhelming and all-consuming until you‚Äôre sitting in a closet scribbling notes about Nero. Or maybe that‚Äôs just me.
Hopefully this guide inspires readers to a) fly to Rome and/or b) hold the Ancients in a higher regard. Although we‚Äôre separated by 2,000 years, aspects of life like love, sex, food shortages, civil war, and satirical literature are familiar, both striking and unexpected. I will never stop being amazed by these humans, people I will never meet. I can read their poems, recreate their music, and steal little rock fragments from their remaining monuments ‚Äî and yet they‚Äôre dead with nothing but epitaphs left. But despite dust and Latin separating us, they‚Äôre so close. Nothing unfamiliar about it.

Title: Men Think About Rome Almost Every Day. That‚Äôs a Problem. But It Doesn‚Äôt Have to Be.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Engaging premodern literature, history, culture, and art to speak to contemporary social issues

--
Listen
Share
by Robert Clines
Men cannot stop thinking about the Roman Empire. Viral social media posts and news outlets from The Guardian to Italy‚Äôs La Repubblica have all suggested that men are obsessed with Rome. Memes abound. Rome apparently crosses the minds of men anywhere from a few times a month to a few times a day! Rome remains a cultural touchstone, and that probably won‚Äôt change. Ancient history books remain best sellers; films like Gladiator or Ben-Hur are award-winning classics; Rome and Pompeii, as I saw firsthand this summer, are as crowded as ever.
As a scholar of Italian humanism, I spend a significant amount of time in Rome and I write about men who think about Rome. While I don‚Äôt find this phenomenon surprising, I believe it is problematic...and that‚Äôs because Rome is often equated with concepts like ‚ÄúEurope,‚Äù ‚ÄúWestern Civilization,‚Äù and ‚Äúwhiteness.‚Äù No, the Romans were not white ‚Äî whiteness as a marker of racial difference didn‚Äôt exist in antiquity. Romans weren‚Äôt even just from Italy or Europe. There were numerous Roman writers from Africa; the emperor Septimius Severus (145‚Äì211) was born in modern-day Libya; and Augustine of Hippo (354‚Äì430), a theologian whose works are central to Western Christianity, was from modern-day Algeria. But the Romans have been made white because white people ‚Äî mostly men ‚Äî have linked the Roman past to themselves.
Petrarch (1304‚Äì1374), whom we often problematically call the ‚ÄúFather of the Renaissance,‚Äù wrote letters to ancient figures like Cicero and Homer. After visiting Rome for the first time in 1337, he wrote ‚Äúwho can doubt that Rome will rise up again once she begins to recognize herself?‚Äù But what is the ‚Äúself‚Äù Petrarch hoped Rome would recognize? Petrarch was writing after the Crusades and during the rise of the Ottomans and the papacy‚Äôs relocation to Avignon, France. This geopolitical reality led Petrarch to believe that Europeans must revive Rome and end the Middle or Dark Ages, which for him meant everything Rome was not and everything we should resist: backwardness, barbarism, unfettered violence, lack of culture.
Petrarch wasn‚Äôt alone. Humanists like Poggio Bracciolini (1380‚Äì1459) scoured libraries and monasteries for ancient texts. In his On the Vicissitudes of Fortune, Bracciolini used the ruins of the Roman Forum to wax philosophical on how far European society had fallen. Lorenzo Valla (1406‚Äì1457) believed the barbarians who destroyed Rome corrupted the purity of Latin; the result was Italian, which was called volgare. Biondo Flavio (1392‚Äì1463) called for restoring the Forum and Colosseum so they could be centerpieces in victory parades against Europe‚Äôs Muslim enemies, similar to ancient triumphs. Cyriac of Ancona (1391‚Äì1452) wrote about invading the Ottoman Empire to reclaim antiquities from Islam.
This preoccupation with the Romans as the forefathers of Western Civilization continued beyond Italian humanists as Europeans began building global empires. In two important essays in The New Centennial Review and Boundary 2, Sylvia Wynter shows how debates on the humanity of both Indigenous peoples and enslaved Africans centered on their perceived distance from Rome. Roman civilization‚Äôs purported Europeanness thus became justification for Indigenous genocide, mass African enslavement, and colonialism.
As their empires grew, Europeans constantly invoked Rome to prove white supremacy. In the eighteenth century, the Grand Tour ‚Äî an educational journey that terminated in Rome or Naples ‚Äî became an important way for wealthy Europeans and Americans to see themselves as the heirs of Rome. While in Italy, Johann Joachim Winckelmann (1717‚Äì68), clearly unaware of ancient polychromy, saw the whiteness of Roman sculpture, including copies of Greek originals, as proof of European racial supremacy. As the historian Nell Irvin Painter argues, ‚ÄúWinckelmann elevated Rome‚Äôs white marble copies of Greek statuary into emblems of beauty and created a new white aesthetic.‚Äù
Winckelmann‚Äôs contemporary, Edward Gibbon (1737‚Äì1794), saw Rome as a moral lesson for contemporary Britain. In his History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, Gibbon argued that the Roman Empire fell due to a lack of civic virtue and the onset of barbarism, i.e., foreign invasions. His now famous motivation from his memoir for writing captures the essence of white men thinking about Rome: ‚ÄúIt was at Rome, on the 15th of October, 1764, as I sat musing amidst the ruins of the Capitol, while the barefooted friars were singing vespers in the Temple of Jupiter, that the idea of writing the decline and fall of the city first started to my mind.‚Äù
This linkage between Ancient Rome, imperialism, and white supremacy informed the new American Republic and how Europeans ran their empires. The Founders were obsessed with Rome and Greece, often citing ancient authors in their debates of what the United States would look like. This use of classically-inspired architecture, which has a long history, also appeared in Washington, D.C., plantations across the American South, and scores of other structures, linking the United States to Ancient Rome. As Lyra D. Monteiro shows, this neoclassical obsession is grounded in a racially-exclusive vision of the ancient past used to justify American settler colonialism, slavery, and white supremacy. Similarly, in European empires across the globe, perhaps most notably Britain‚Äôs, visions of empire and white supremacy have been mediated through antiquity. In French colonial North Africa, agricultural planning was based not on environmental realities, but on French attempts to revive North Africa as Rome‚Äôs breadbasket. Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy also put antiquity front and center in their supremacist ideologies.
Since Petrarch, the study of Rome has been tied to imperialism and white supremacy. We have to confront this reality and find new ways to show that the study of Rome need not be a project of whiteness or simply a passive exercise in drawing parallels between our world and theirs simply because we see ourselves in the Romans. It‚Äôs important to remember, as Keith Hopkins quipped, ‚ÄúRomans were dangerously different.‚Äù
But as teacher-scholars of antiquity and its reception, we face an uphill battle on two fronts. First is the belief that studying the past against the grain of whiteness is an attack on Western Civilization, which, as Kwame Anthony Appiah reminds us, doesn‚Äôt even exist. The School Choice Movement and the Classical Learning Test aim to shield students from a more critical study of the past, opting to celebrate antiquity as the font of Western Civilization. They want us to think more about Rome. I love Rome. Having spent a significant part of my life there, I am immersed in the practice...but how we think about Rome is where the problem lies.
The other battle is the increased neoliberalization of higher education and the shift toward job training and more ‚Äúrelevant‚Äù and presentist topics, even within the humanities. At the time of writing, there are only twenty-nine tenure track searches in classics nationwide. Ancient history and premodern history in general ‚Äî where classical reception emerges ‚Äî are faring far worse. According to the American Historical Association, only thirty-seven (about 8%) of all full-time history positions in 2022‚Äì23, both tenure track and non-tenure track, were in premodern history.
But if people are thinking about Rome every day, then it‚Äôs clearly relevant. Therefore, we should invest in research and teaching about Rome, its impact, and its reception in ways that change the narrative about its meaning. To be sure, scholars in ancient studies as well as in premodern critical race studies have been working hard to detach views of Ancient Rome from white supremacy. For example, two recent special volumes of the American Journal of Philology have tackled the legacy of white supremacy in the study of ancient literature. And I think there is an opportunity to capture the attention of students who think about Rome. I mean, who doesn‚Äôt want students who think about the topic of their class daily?! Courses on Greece and Rome are very popular, and my Renaissance class usually fills within twenty-four hours. When I take undergraduates to Rome, they are blown away by the heterogeneity of the city‚Äôs people, food, art, and history.
Because this pervasive white supremacist image of Rome doesn‚Äôt actually reflect any truth about the Roman Empire and its impact on the world, we have a responsibility as scholars and teachers to cultivate a deeper understanding of Rome in all its diversity and richness. It‚Äôs a job for all of us ‚Äî from classicists to modernists and everyone in between ‚Äî to help students abandon simplistic and often racist views of Rome and instead see its complexities, contradictions, and nuances. And thinking about that Rome every day is never a bad thing.
Robert Clines (he/him) is Associate Professor of History and International Studies at Western Carolina University. He is a literary historian of race, religion, and cross-cultural encounters in premodern Italy. His first book, A Jewish Jesuit in the Eastern Mediterranean, was published in 2019. He‚Äôs received research support from the Bogliasco Foundation, the Arizona Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies, the American Academy in Rome, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, and the US-Italy Fulbright Commission. His most recent essays have explored anti-Blackness and white femininity in Petrarch‚Äôs Africa and Orientalism and Roman ruins in fifteenth-century antiquarianism. He is currently completing a book manuscript entitled Ancient Others: Race, Empire, and the Invention of the Italian Renaissance.

I think about Rome all the time. Specifically, I think about the big-budget HBO drama Rome that ran from 2005‚Äì2007. That magnificent series was a richly realized historical epic that mixed sex and violence and back-stabbing political intrigue and served as a blueprint for the mega-hit series Game of Thrones, which was vastly inferior to its prototype in every way.
Rome was a show about power, loyalty, and betrayal set against the greatest empire in human history. Game of Thrones was lots of drinking from goblets, whispering secrets and dragons, and other childish bullshit. Game of Thrones was great fun, but it was always a naughty fairytale for adults.
Rome, on the other hand, explored big themes like ambition, love, and nudity.
I‚Äôm not the only person who thinks about Rome‚Ä¶ and Rome. According to a recent social media trend, men think about Rome daily. The hashtag #RomanEmpire leads to videos with millions of views of women asking the men in their lives if they think about Rome and the men usually say ‚Äúyes.‚Äù Let‚Äôs agree that social media trends are usually short-lived, superficial call-and-response games where someone, somewhere, posts an opinion or a hot take and then the entire internet, a‚Ä¶

Title: Hidden Rome: A New Way to Explore the City
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Bay Area Travel Writers tell stories through media, old and new‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänewspapers, magazines, broadcasts, blogs, videos, books, and online publications.

--
3
Listen
Share
How to slow down on your post-Pandemic trip to Rome. Do not rush to the famous sites, because the city has plenty of hidden, underrated monuments that give you an equal ‚Äî and sometimes a better ‚Äî taste of Roman art and history.
I n June 2021, Italy opened its borders to tourists from a range of countries, including the U.S., and allowed the vaccinated arrivals to skip quarantine. Soon afterward, I flew straight into Rome because after all, who knows how long the window of opportunity may last. After eighteen months without an international trip, I walked out of my guesthouse at Piazza di Spagna and began staggering around the hot streets of Rome, not knowing how to travel anymore. Should I immediately start taking photos as usual, or should I run to the Colosseum just to cross an item off a list? The confusion began to feel like a hangover after a long delirium. The kind of hangover that makes you want to start a new life. And with that, I made a decision ‚Äî no return to the pre-Pandemic way of traveling; no hunt for pictures that are considered iconic; no visiting of the famous sites, or at least, not only the famous sites. I was in Rome, and I was craving to feel it, explore it, and learn from it. But how to turn the lofty sentiment into reality? Maybe by turning the trip into a search for hidden Rome, as I began to call the most underrated places in the city.
Just as it seems that luck begins to favor you as soon as you make the right decision, I quickly found out about another recent opening in Rome; one that received much less attention, but would let me step under the surface of the city ‚Äî literally. On June 23, 2021, for the first time after many years, members of the public could enter Domus Aurea, the ancient palace of Emperor Nero. This could be my first foray into the realm of hidden Rome. For a reason unclear at first, however, the advertisement for the tour featured Raphael as well.
Traveling in the time of the pandemic
The walk to the palace leads around the Colosseum, where I reluctantly paused to take a picture after all. But while I was doing that, there was an unusual sound ‚Äî the sound of the Italian language. Who would expect so much Italian at prominent tourist sites? Well, that was the Pandemic Rome. It is too soon to have meaningful figures, but my eyes estimated that the tourist numbers were at about a half of the pre-pandemic level, a rough figure in line with taxi drivers‚Äô experiences, restaurant occupancy, and affordable hotel prices, even in the most central locations. Crucially, however, the new visitor demographics included much fewer inter-continental arrivals and somewhat more domestic ones, which created an atmosphere very different from from the 2010s, the decade of the world tourism explosion.
If you assume that having fewer visitors around means easier access into the Colosseum or the Vatican, you will be sorely mistaken. Yes, pandemic rules reduced the tourist figures, but they also limited the numbers of admissions into museums, galleries, St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, and all the sites. Since the operation of some ticket offices was restricted as well, the most efficient way to see Rome in 2021 is to book all visits and tours online, at least several days in advance ‚Äîas before the pandemic.
Narcissist‚Äôs house
At Domus Aurea, I joined a small group, and we were greeted by our guide Marcella because the only way to visit the palace is with a guided tour, provided in English as well as in Italian. Marcella is an archeologist, who worked directly on excavations of the elusive structure. She had a joy in her eyes, with the rest of her face behind a mask, when she saw us. She explained: ‚ÄúWe have been restoring the palace for a long time ‚Äî we have even excavated new rooms that no one had ever seen before. But then, there were no people to see it! So, it‚Äôs great to finally show our work to someone.‚Äù And with that, our group stepped into a large tunnel leading into the Esquiline Hill.
Since Domus Aurea lies underground now, the temperature hovers around 10¬∫C (50¬∫F). Soon, some fellow visitors began to put on sweaters. New lamps, installed during the period of closure, produced only a dim light for esthetic and conservation reasons. I had zero right to complain; this was my new way to see Rome, with the cold air of the city‚Äôs soil on my skin and limited opportunity to take well-exposed photos. The mysterious lighting made it indeed feel like we were discovering hidden Rome.
Nero built his palace on a plot in the heart of Rome, which was rather conveniently cleared up by the Great Fire. Given that previous emperors lived in what still resembled villas, Nero‚Äôs new residence caused outrage for its location and opulence. Many rooms had their walls covered with marble that sparkled in yellow color on contact with sunlight. Together with decorations of golden leaves, these effects gave the palace its name ‚Äî the Golden House, as Domus Aurea translates.
So, why did we find ourselves underground? Marcella pointed to the bricked-up windows: ‚ÄúTrajan wanted to erase the memory of Nero, so he had the palace sealed off, covered with earth, and incorporated into the hill. That way, he created a platform on which he could build new baths ‚Äî Trajan‚Äôs Baths, of course.‚Äù Unfortunately, the art and the marble were mostly ripped off from the palace and reused in the baths upstairs, which have eventually become ruins, too. But we do not need to feel bad because Nero did not get to enjoy his Domus Aurea either. During the construction, he toured Greece to participate in singing competitions ‚Äî yes, he won all the first prizes ‚Äî and after he returned to Rome, he was forced to commit suicide just six months after moving into the palace.
A hole in the ceiling
Precisely because we were underground, cut off from the honking and bustle of the streets, the immersion in the world of Ancient Rome was complete, or almost complete, because it still required a lot of imagination, aided by several new multimedia projections on the walls and by Marcella‚Äôs stories. We walked through tens of rooms. My neck began to hurt because I kept staring at the vaulted ceilings, some of which were 11 meters (36 feet) high. Those were made possible only because Romans, unlike Greeks, mastered the use of concrete. The remains of the artwork were sparse, but we did see ancient frescos of Trojan War scenes, painted columns showing off the art of perspective, and sketches of fantastical creatures. As history flows in waves, none of these paintings could have been made in the Middle Ages, by which time the required skills and creativity went into decline.
We ended the tour in the most famous of the rooms, the octagonal hall, and left the palace through another tunnel, which has a new ramp designed by the architect Stefano Boeri. The most intriguing spot of the tour was in one of the less important rooms, however. Neither a fresco nor a piece of marble. Marcella alerted us to a hole in the ceiling that someone dug out with simple tools, centuries after the palace was buried into the hill. That hole was an opening expanded by Renaissance artists who scaled down into what looked like a grotto with paintings. The grotto was discovered by accident when a 15th-century young Roman just fell into it while on a stroll.
These grotto visits left the artists in awe that turned into inspiration. One of the motifs they began to replicate was the painted frames around main frescos, full of small, fanciful creatures with animal bodies and human heads, or completely random shapes, made ‚Äúwithout any rules,‚Äù as art books say. Such a style of art became known as the ‚Äúgrotesque.‚Äù The octagonal hall had a special exhibition on this connection between the Ancient and Renaissance eras. Given that Raphael was one of the painters who lowered himself into Domus Aurea, the theme of the whole tour became finally obvious.
A banker and his friend
Raphael created such an amount of art over his twelve years in Rome that even some of his more exquisite work is not well known. Visitors usually get to see the frescoed Raphael Rooms in the Vatican Museums, but then, in a book on Raphael, I read about Villa Farnesina, a suburban palace hidden in a park on the right side of the Tiber, which I identified as another potential hidden treasure. The walk to the villa turned out to be a pleasant, fresh air escape from the narrow streets of the city. You can cross the river on the Ponte Fabricio bridge built in 62 B.C., the oldest one standing in Rome, and take in the view of the surrounding greenery.
Villa Farnesina was built as the main Roman residence of one of the richest men of the Renaissance, Agostino Chigi, who was a banker from Siena and the papal treasurer. While architecturally the building met all the symmetry and elegance requirements of the era, its central room, the loggia, needed an eye-catching decoration. That was when Chigi reached out to Raphael, who was not only a fellow member of the Roman elite but also a close friend of the banker. Raphael got to work, which moved, however, at a suspiciously slow pace‚Äî at least according to Giorgio Vasari. The frustrated patron found out that the reason was Raphael‚Äôs frequent absence due to ‚Äúthe pursuit of carnal pleasures.‚Äù To ensure the painter would stay close to his work, Chigi allegedly asked Raphael‚Äôs mistress, with some reluctance, to move into the villa.
But after all, Vasari‚Äôs story might be just another example of Roman gossip blown out of proportion because Raphael‚Äôs workshop was so established that his assistants could paint by consulting the master‚Äôs drawings only, without requiring his presence. Even if Chigi had a lot of hassles with the artist, the result was more than worth it. The large ceiling fresco of Cupid and Psyche, with a blue background and a plethora of figures, many of them naked, of course, represents Raphael at the height of his career. Actually, he passed away only two years later. As I was admiring the work, with only one more visitor around, I also knew to look at the arches on the walls. There they were; the playful, abstract shapes of the grotesques ‚Äî Raphael‚Äôs variation on what he had seen in Domus Aurea.
While I was on the right side of the river, I climbed up through a park to Gianicolo Hill, which stands above Villa Farnesina. The terrace at the top provides a panoramic view of the city, even though, unlike Paris, Rome does not have a single dominating structure. You can see the top of the Colosseum, the National Monument, Spanish Steps and domes of many churches, but none of them stand out, which makes the city appear uniform in the diversity of its architecture. The view is made scenic, nonetheless, thanks to the green skyline of the Sabine and the Alban Hills in the distance.
My view was suddenly interrupted by a guitarist on the terrace, who began playing romantic tunes for the Italian couples enjoying the panorama and gelatos. I got the memo ‚Äî that spot is more for a Raphael and his mistress than for me and my geographic musings. The only problem was that all great terraces in Rome serve as rendezvous places, whether the Pincio Hill terrace or my favorite archeological viewpoint at the back of the Capitoline Hill.
La Papessa
A higher-than-usual number of people was storming through the streets on scooters and they were carrying Italian flags. The reason turned out to be simple ‚Äî while I had already forgotten that the country won the Euro 2021 cup in soccer several days before, many Italians had not. Both the night of the final and the subsequent celebrations brought hundreds of people out, with pizzerias putting television sets on the streets and the city putting up a gigantic screen at the Colosseum. The ripples of cheers when Italy scored went through the narrow streets like a tsunami. There was a downside, however. Locals and visitors alike were religious about wearing masks indoors ‚Äî in restaurants, museums, trains, shops ‚Äî but then, some let their guards down at the crowded soccer-watching parties, which might have helped fuel an increase in the Covid-19 cases in Rome, leading to new rounds of restrictions.
Although it is romantically simplistic, I like to think that Romans took the pandemic on the chin because, in the end, their city is one big monument to a millennia-long history of fires, sackings, and much, much deadlier plagues. The Antonine plague of the 2nd century A.D. is thought to have contributed to the decline of the Empire. But there were many others. In 1657, a wave of plague claimed the life of the most formidable woman that Rome ever had ‚Äî Olimpia Maidalchini Pamphilj, who was responsible for another hidden place in Rome that I was going to visit.
Under the right circumstances, Olimpia might have been a ruler in her own right, but in the Rome of her time, the only way to channel her ambition was through a man. Incredibly, that man was the brother of her deceased husband; she dragged the brother up through the hierarchy of the Church until he became Pope Innocent X. It would not have been a Roman story, however, if it did not include a spicy twist, which was easy to conjure up in their case. The city took it for granted that Olimpia was the pope‚Äôs lover. Even if that claim proved an exaggeration, no one can dispute that she became the power behind St. Peter‚Äôs throne. She made personnel appointments and decided on important issues ‚Äî so much so that she got a derogatory nickname ‚ÄúLa Papessa‚Äù, or the female pope.
The hidden worlds behind the doors of Rome
Olimpia knew how to leverage her position to amass a fantastic fortune for the Pamphilj dynasty. Fortunately for us, they invested a large chunk of it into something tangible ‚Äî an urban palace stuffed with a world-class art collection, which survives to this day as Palazzo Doria Pamphilj, with its Galleria. In any other city, the gallery would be a top attraction. But in Rome, it must compete with other shrines of Baroque art, like Villa Borghese. If you plan properly and book a ticket in advance ‚Äî the gallery is open only on limited days ‚Äî you will be treated to a spectacle. The pale grey fa√ßade of the Palazzo hides behind scaffolding on the shopping avenue, Via del Corso. As with Domus Aurea, stepping inside means entering a completely different world. There is a quaint, green courtyard with a fountain in the middle and then a series of lavishly decorated rooms where the family lived. The highlight comes in the gilded Hall of Mirrors, with a grandeur that would make it shine even in Versailles.
The collections of the gallery, displayed throughout the Palazzo, include a Raphael, but the Pamphiljs represent a different era ‚Äî theirs is the Rome of Bernini, Vel√°zquez, and Caravaggio. The first two artists sculpted and painted Innocent X, and those works are exhibited in the Palazzo. Caravaggio was somewhat of a different story, given that he passed away thirty years before the ascent of the Pamphiljs. Even so, they spotted potential in the paintings of the forgotten artist and bought three pieces for their collection. The family was far-sighted in another aspect ‚Äî they forbid their descendants to sell any works from the gallery, thus preserving this mini-Louvre behind an inconspicuous Roman door.
Once you start searching for hidden and underrated places in Rome, you will find them everywhere. One small door close to Piazza de Navona led me to the Chiostro del Bramante, a courtyard of a perfectly squared shape and with perfectly symmetrical columns. I chose that place to unwind after long walks because there was a caf√© on the upper floor, with a view. While sipping my Americano, I watched people downstairs lining up for a Banksy exhibition inside the cloister. I was, however, more incited by the upper-floor door to the lounge of the coffee shop. I ended up walking in there, and once I got past the sofas occupied by youngsters with laptops, I reached a window that did not lead into a street but into a church. Inside, I could see a beautiful fresco on the wall. The fresco is called Sibyls. It was commissioned by Agostino Chigi, created by Raphael, and, apparently, evaluated by Michelangelo for the patron, so that the right amount could be paid to the painter. Is there any other city in the world where even an attempt to have a quiet coffee in a hidden spot turns into a preview of some of the most magnificent artists in history?
IF YOU GO

Title: What became of Rome‚Äôs last emperor after the fall of the empire
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Many rulers throughout history were given epithets by their subjects, such as ‚Äúthe Terrible,‚Äù ‚Äúthe Great,‚Äù or even ‚Äúthe Holy‚Äù and ‚Äúthe Divine.‚Äù The Romans were no exception, though they generally preferred less flattering nicknames derived from some article of clothing favored by the emperor ‚Äî like Caligula, meaning ‚Äúlittle soldier‚Äôs boot,‚Äù or Caracalla, ‚Äúthe Gallic cloak.‚Äù
The same Romans gave their final emperor a rather disparaging nickname. In the best case, Flavius Romulus Augustus was referred to as ‚ÄúAugustulus‚Äù (‚Äúlittle Augustus,‚Äù ‚Äúminor Augustus‚Äù), and in the worst case, ‚ÄúMomillus‚Äù (‚Äúlittle disgrace,‚Äù ‚Äúshameful trifle‚Äù). Were these nicknames justified? If we speak of the unfortunate Flavius Romulus as a person, most likely not. He could not distinguish himself by either good or bad deeds. His father, General Orestes Flavius, put him on the throne when the lad was about fifteen years old. His reign ended ten months later, with Orestes‚Äôs overthrow and the abdication of his son. In reality, during all that time, Flavius Romulus did not rule personally ‚Äî his father did.

Content:

As long as the Coliseum stands, Rome shall stand; when the Coliseum falls, Rome will fall; when Rome falls, the whole world will fall.‚Äù ‚Äî Venerable Bede
Being thirty minutes late is considered normal here, while punctuality feels inappropriate.
Rome is a city where food is a religion. Here, people argue about the best carbonara with the same passion as they do about football. Where coffee is not just a drink but a way of life.
I was there in the summer, the air thick with the scent of espresso and the distant hum of vespas weaving through the streets. The sun hung high over the Eternal City as I made my way to the Colosseum, I ran my hand over the weathered stone. The heat was rising from the ancient cobblestones beneath my feet. With every step, history wrapped itself around me like a well-worn toga, heavy with the weight of emperors‚Äô ambitions and gladiators‚Äô final breaths.
These walls have seen emperors rise and fall, gladiators meet their fate, and crowds roar with bloodlust. They have witnessed the grandeur of Rome at its peak and its slow decline. Every stone here tells stories of the past, if only one could listen closely enough. The underground hypogeum, now exposed to the sky, once was full of life. Hidden‚Ä¶

Title: 7 Reasons Why You Should Visit Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Also known as the Eternal City, Rome is home to some of the most historic monuments, art, and architecture in the world. Harking back to a time when gladiator fights were the daily form of entertainment, the city is bursting at the seams with fascinating things to see and do.
If you‚Äôre not yet convinced, here are 7 reasons why you should visit Rome.
The central Trevi Fountain is one of the most famous fountains in the world. Tourists gather around its impressive carvings every single day to throw coins into the clear water and make a wish.
But it‚Äôs not just the Trevi Fountain that promises a showy display of water and statues. In fact, Rome has a lot of access to water thanks to the Roman aqueducts, and the Popes of the Renaissance and Baroque eras tried to outdo each other with the fanciest fountains, many of which you can still see around the city today.
Italian food is renowned for being delicious, but Rome boasts some of the most delectable dishes in the country. Roman artichokes are a firm favourite by locals and tourists alike, while the world-famous spaghetti alla carbonara was born in this wonderful city.
The Vatican (which sits snug in the confines of Rome) is bursting with works by Michelangelo. The ceiling of the Sistine Chapel is doused in his colourful artwork, while the sculpture of Pieta sits pretty nearby.
As well as these, you can also see his sculptures of Christ the Redeemer and Moses elsewhere in the city.
Despite being one of the best-known cities in the world, Rome isn‚Äôt particularly big. In fact, it‚Äôs small enough that you can see all the attractions on foot (even on the same day), but sizeable enough to find somewhere that nobody else has found, even during the busier periods.
Rome‚Äôs history game is incredibly strong ‚Äî probably one of the strongest in the world, in fact. The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and there are a jaw-dropping number of monuments, ruins, artworks, and feats of architecture to enjoy.
Keep an eye out for the many well-preserved ruins that date back to the Roman Empire, including the Colosseum, the Forum, and Palatine Hill.
Thanks to its location, Rome enjoys a particularly mild climate throughout the year. In the summer months it is gloriously warm, but it‚Äôs also extremely pleasant in the winter months, too. This means you can enjoy the sights at any time of the year and feel comfortable venturing there in low-season.
The city itself was founded on Seven Hills, many of which boast incredible views over Rome and its surroundings. For the ultimate hilltop experience, watch the sunset over the ruins of the city.

Content:

Rome is a city that captured my heart in ways I never expected. From the moment I arrived, I knew it was a place I would want to return to. The city‚Äôs remarkable blend of ancient history, rich culture, stunning art, and lively modern life creates a unique atmosphere that is unlike any other. It‚Äôs one of those cities that leaves an impression on you, with its timeless beauty and endless opportunities for exploration.
What impressed me the most was how history is alive in every corner. Walking through the ancient streets of Rome felt like being in an open-air museum. The majestic Colosseum, the impressive Pantheon, and the beautiful Trevi Fountain are not just stones; they are living testimonies of civilizations that shaped the course of humanity. Rome‚Äôs history is written in its ruins, its squares, but also in its people, who continue to live in a city full of symbolism and tradition.
Roman culture is equally fascinating, with a rich mix of influences from the Roman Empire, the Renaissance, and the Baroque era. I was in awe of the Vatican Museums, where the works of artists like Michelangelo and Raphael are found around every corner. The Sistine Chapel left me speechless, as if I were in the presence of one of humanity‚Äôs most important masterpieces.
What surprised me most about Rome is how it successfully blends its glorious past with a dynamic, modern life. Cafes, fashion boutiques, and lively squares filled with people made me feel that Rome is not only a historic city but also a place that is very much alive in the present. Every afternoon, I enjoyed strolling through its narrow, cobblestone streets, where I encountered a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the vibrant rhythm of the city.
Another aspect that made my experience in Rome even more special was the food. Roman pizza is something you must try, with an impressive variety of ingredients and styles. From the classic Margherita and Capricciosa to more innovative creations, pizza in Rome is a delight with every bite. I also couldn‚Äôt resist trying the famous Italian gelato. Roman gelato is an experience in itself ‚Äî creamy, refreshing, and with flavors I didn‚Äôt find anywhere else. Every afternoon, I made it a ritual to enjoy a gelato while walking around the streets, which quickly became one of my favorite activities.
All in all, Rome has a unique magic. It‚Äôs a city full of history, art, and culture, but also a city that knows how to enjoy modern life. What impressed me most was how it manages to keep its ancient essence alive while moving toward the future. It‚Äôs a destination that is definitely worth visiting over and over again. There‚Äôs always something new to discover, and each visit leaves you with the feeling that there‚Äôs so much more to explore. I can‚Äôt wait to return!

Ukranian girl, currently living in Spain. Journalist, writing about life by heart, cat-lover. I believe that the words can change the world for better.

When I visited Rome in May 2024, I kept a diary. This is my first attempt at travel writing and also a way for me to document my experience, since I‚Äôm not on Facebook or Instagram.
7th May 2024
This morning I woke up in Rome for the first time. I am also unemployed for the first time in my adult life, since I left my last job last week and I won‚Äôt start my new one until the 20th. This is also the first time I‚Äôm traveling alone and staying in a hostel (the Jo&Joe Roma, where I am currently writing from).
I arrived yesterday afternoon and I was equally excited and nervous about this solo trip. I enjoy my own company and the freedom of deciding how I spend my time, but I always missing having someone to talk to after spending too long alone. But the nervousness is gone now. It left me somewhere between the second and third glasses of wine I had at a restaurant called Da Edy last night, alongside the best carbonara I‚Äôve ever had.
After that meal, I walked up to the Enni Morricone auditorium to see the Brad Mehldau Trio perform. On the walk, many of the walls were covered in Italian political posters. I occupied myself by looking at each of these and guessing whether the smiling candidates were left-wing, right-wing or centrist based on their appearance alone. I never looked up the answers‚Ä¶ for all I know they were estate agents.
The concert itself was impressive. I saw Brad Mehldau a few years ago at the Barbican in London as a solo pianist. Compared to the delicate subtlety of that performance, the trio (which consisted of a pianist, bassist and drummer) was a jazz assault on the senses. The standout track was ‚ÄòBoomer‚Äô, which Mehldau was quick to clarify was named after his dog, rather than the maligned generation.
Rome is undoubtedly a touristy city, but that concert felt strangely provincial considering that Mehldau is an American musician. During my time there, I didn‚Äôt hear a word of English and not even a whisper of an American accent (which are usually hard to miss on the streets of Rome). After a whopping three encores, I walked back through a sleepy Rome. My mind was filled with the logistics of going to bed in a hostel for the first time‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhen I had checked in earlier, it was clear that I would be sharing the room with three others, but I hadn‚Äôt met them yet.
When I got back to my room, I was greeted by the sound of some deep snoring. I discreetly gathered my toiletries from my locker (which was located beneath the bed of the snoring stranger) and then I clambered up into my top bunk. The whole process reminded me of that scene in Toy Story 2 when Buzz and Woody are trying to sneak through a maze of cheetos without waking a dozing man. Later that night, when I was woken by another roommate turning the big light and stumbling around as they arrived, I realized that I had probably been overthinking it.
This morning, I met two of my roommates‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääan Aussie and a Russian who were both nice enough. The Aussie is half way through traveling the world after graduating university. The Russian is a little bit older and was less clear about his travels‚Ä¶ I wanted to ask if he was dodging the draft for the war but, since we‚Äôd be sharing a bedroom for the next few days, I decided not to raise that topic.
I then left to visit the Barberini palace, which was stunning. The highlights were a medieval painting of Saint Jerome trampling on a cartoonishly devilish Lucifer and another which featured two cherubs trying to share a papal hat. But the best of them all, undoubtedly, was Judith Beheading Helofernes by Caravaggio. Maybe I‚Äôm just a fanboy but I found it astounding how much better his painting was compared to the work of his contemporaries. The chiaroscuro, facial expressions, depth and resonance completely outshined every other painting in the room.
In a couple of hours I‚Äôm heading to the capuchin catacombs. Until then, I think I‚Äôll sit in the hostel courtyard with a book and a red wine.
8th May 2024
I was spending this afternoon with a book and a red wine in the courtyard (yes, again) but I have been chased inside by a downpour, so here I am writing.
The catacombs yesterday did not disappoint. It began with a museum which took me through the history of capuchin monks, from when St. Francis first founded the order in the 16th century through to the modern-day. There is something about their asceticism and devout poverty that I find fascinating‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämainly because I cannot relate whatsoever. I do doubt somewhat whether they practiced what they preached‚Ä¶ who knows what they actually got up to beneath those oversized robes.
The catacombs themselves were a series of six rooms which literally took my breath away. They featured intricate sculptural displays built from pelvises, skulls and every other bone in the body‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätogether forming the shapes of flowers, crests, chairs etc. These sat alongside dismantled corpses, some of which were mummified. Some bodies lay in coffins which were themselves built from various bones while others sat upon thrones built of skulls. This seemed contrary to what little I know about Christian burial rituals and I asked myself whether these friars had consented to having their skeletons on display, and whether they had any idea that tourists (like myself) would be ogling at their corpse hundreds of years later. I‚Äôve told people that I don‚Äôt care what happens to my body after I die (since I‚Äôll be dead) but now I will add the caveat that I‚Äôd rather not have my skeleton dangling on display in a popular tourist destination.
After the catacombs, I decided to wander over to the Borghese gardens. I didn‚Äôt bother with the Borghese gallery itself since half of it is under renovation. Instead I bought a couple of cans of Peroni and lounged in the park. After that, I stumbled upon the National Gallery of Modern Art, an impressive classical building. I wandered in. The art was generally good but unremarkable but I was surprised to stumble upon ‚ÄòFountain‚Äô by Marcel Duchamp, which simply consists of a signed urinal presented in the middle of a room. My surprise was dampened when I realised that this was one of many replicas (the original is lost) though it still reminded me of my Masters degree, when ‚ÄòFountain‚Äô came up in a module titled ‚ÄòThinking With Things‚Äô. The whole point is that we perceive a urinal differently when it has been displaced from its typical surroundings‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwe would never consider pissing in a urinal when it‚Äôs presented as a piece of art. Context transforms our perspective and ‚ÄòFountain‚Äô demonstrates that more clearly than anything else. It spurred a lot of art criticism and debate but still, I bet Duchap couldn‚Äôt believe that he got away with that one.
When I got back to the hostel I bumped into my Aussie roommate who, like me, was exhausted and hungry. Neither of us wanted to walk very far, so we stumbled into a random touristy restaurant near our hostel. He had carbonara while I went for the rogue choice of steak tartare with a side of artichoke. The artichoke was delicious, soft and garlicky, while the tartare was quite underwhelming ‚Äî much chunkier than the typical French-style tartare which I adore.
We finished the night at a nearby ‚ÄòIrish pub‚Äô called ‚ÄòThe Flann O‚ÄôBrien‚Äô. Like most continental Irish pubs, it was nothing like an Irish pub. But I was drawn there when I spotted Hop House 13 on their menu (a lovely pale ale made by the Guinness brewery which is no longer sold in the UK) while the Aussie was drawn to the football. We had a wide-ranging chat ‚Äî I was thankful when it moved from football on to politics and cultural differences. Later that night, when I was in bed, I heard the Aussie get up from his bunk and vomit in the bathroom. I worried that the restaurant was to blame and that my steak tartare would soon reemerge, but thankfully I got a decent sleep.
I didn‚Äôt have much of a lie-in, as I was up at 6:30am to get to the Vatican museum in time for my 8:30am tour. I had been told that the crowds are a lot more manageable at this time but, when I arrived, I was amazed at the length of the queue that was already forming around the ancient walls of the Vatican. Thankfully my tour ticket meant that I could bypass this queue completely, and I felt quite smug as I waltzed past those tourists who lacked my advance planning skills.
I didn‚Äôt know whether an actual tour guide or audio guide awaited me so I was pleased and impressed by Antonio, our tour guide who had an infectious enthusiasm for the place. We moved through the halls of the Vatican like a slow tide of tourists ‚Äî it was already heaving at that early hour. But Antonio did a great job of pointing out the most impressive sights as we were shepherded along by the Vatican guards. Without a guided tour, I imagine it would be nearly impossible to appreciate the art and architecture while trying to battle through the crowded maze of corridors. Antonio abandoned us in the galleries that precede the Sistine chapel, giving us the option to march on to the chapel or peruse the artwork first. I was seemingly the only person to choose the latter option, so it was nice to wander the relatively empty galleries (featuring Picasso, Francis Bacon, Van Gogh) after having spent a couple of hours within a horde of tourists.
I headed back into the throng as I made my way into the Sistine chapel. Michelangelo‚Äôs frescoes were impressive, as expected, but I was struck by how garish I found the chapel, with every inch of wall dedicated to another saint or bible story. Unlike other impressive churches I‚Äôve seen, where artwork has room to breathe, it was hard to appreciate ‚ÄòThe Final Judgment‚Äô or ‚ÄòThe Creation of Adam‚Äô when my peripheral vision was so crowded with various depictions of different popes and apostles. Arguably the biggest takeaway is sheer astonishment at how Michaelnagelo managed to paint the frescoes directly on those high ceilings ‚Äî achieving such a delicate touch while balancing on shaky scaffolding high above the ground.
It was around midday when I left and I was hungry. I headed towards Trattoria Der Pallero, which had been recommended as a traditional Roman restaurant with a set-menu. I sat down and feasted on nine plates of food ‚Äî tomatoes, beans, anchovy salad, suppli, two pastas, cured meat, mozzarella, crisps (strangely) and cake. It was absolutely glorious ‚Äî maybe one of the most satisfying meals I‚Äôve ever had. It was serene to sit beneath the awnings with a carafe of wine and a good book as a friendly Roman man brought me dish after dish. All that for just 30 euros‚Ä¶ if I lived in Rome I would be there every week.
The meal and my morning in the Vatican City exhausted me, so I‚Äôm going to take it easy this evening. Tomorrow, the Colosseum.
9th May 2024
Last night I got back to the room and the Aussie (whose name I now know is Alec) was there. I said I was looking for a light dinner so he suggested Pinsallegra, a fast food place around the corner which serves pinsas, a type of light crispy pizza. It hit the spot. After that, we headed back to the hostel and had some pints while chatting about traveling and reality tv. We were both exhausted so it was an early night. He left the following morning at 7am to catch a train to Florence ‚Äî I happened to be up for a wee as he was leaving, so I said bye.
I got up proper a couple of hours later and headed to the Colosseum. There were two lines snaking around the arena, one for ticket holders and one for those without. Thankfully I spotted a sign between the two lines which said ‚ÄòFull Experience Tickets‚Äô and that‚Äôs exactly what I had. After a quick security check, I was in. I soaked it all up for a bit before heading to the underground, an area which my semi-exclusive ‚ÄòFull Experience‚Äô ticket gave me access to. I don‚Äôt know whether it was a logistical mistake or as planned, but at this point I was unexpectedly welcomed into a tour group. Our guide brought us through the ‚Äòbackstage‚Äô of the Colosseum ‚Äî the rooms and corridors where the gladiators prepared before boarding the rudimentary lifts which would carry them up into the battleground. Obviously it‚Äôs a ruin so, while the magnitude was impressive, it takes some imagination to transport yourself back to gladiatorial times. Apparently, over 400,000 people have died fighting in the Colosseum, making it one of the bloodiest square miles in the world. That thought contrasts against the modern-day reality of the Colosseum: an icon for Rome and a backdrop for selfies.
I had spent about three hours in the Colosseum, so I was hungry and ready for lunch. I made my way across the Tiber into the trendy Trastevere district, where I gorged myself at Sesamo, which serves these odd burger-pizza hybrids. I sat down to eat in their small dining space and next to me was a family from East London. It almost felt like I was back in London, sat in a chicken shop after a night out.
After lunch, I made my way to the Forum, stopping midway for a delicious red berry gelato. When I arrived at the Forum, I was awed. The columns, temples, ruins and gardens were sprawling. It‚Äôs baffling how so much (or anything at all) has survived almost two millennia of warfare, plundering and natural disasters. I had no tour or audio guide as I wandered around the Forum so, while I was relatively less well-informed than I was for the Vatican and Colosseum, I had more freedom to walk around at my own pace and soak it all in. The sun was shining and I had a lovely afternoon exploring the Forum while listening to Cassandra Jenkins on my headphones.
After a few hours at the Forum I was tired and, though there was undoubtedly more to see, I knew I had reached my fill of Roman antiquity. I headed back to the hostel. I have not been disappointed by pasta and pizza in Rome, but tonight I fancied something different. I settled on Prosciutteria Cantina dei Papi, a charming spot specializing in cured meats, cheese and wine. I took my seat and asked for a nice wine and a large platter ‚Äî no menu necessary. It was a feast and probably the best wine I‚Äôve had in Rome. I had a nice seat where I could watch tourists wander the streets while I snacked away.
It was relatively early in the evening, so I was the only person in there except from two young Polish women a few tables over. They made an odd couple, one quiet and reserved and the other one full of energy. At one moment the energetic one convinced the young Italian proprietor to dance with her. He lasted just a few seconds before turning to me with a desperate look and asking ‚ÄúWould you like to dance with her?‚Äù. After I declined, I got chatting to the other Polish woman, who became the second person on this trip to tell me that I don‚Äôt sound like I‚Äôm from London. I asked her what I sound like to her and said ‚Äònormal English‚Äô before putting on her best Dickensian cockney impression to show me what she expected from a Londoner.
That place was just around the corner from the Trevi Fountain, so I headed over to tick it off my list. I had been hugely underwhelmed by the Spanish Steps (it is literally just a staircase) so I wasn‚Äôt expecting much. But I was actually blown away by the majesty and intricacy of it ‚Äî the pristine marble sculptures and the crystal blue waterfall ‚Äî I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt miss it. As I stood there, I started to hear clapping and whooping and spotted a man down near the front of the fountain getting down on one knee to propose. The entire crowd cheered as she said yes. It was a lovely moment of collective celebration‚Ä¶ though I wouldn‚Äôt personally pick such a busy touristy crowd for a proposal.
I‚Äôm back at the hostel now, writing this with a beer by the fountain. The cinema across the road is showing the film Wicked Little Letters in English with subtitles in an hour, so I think that‚Äôs a good idea to unwind for the night.
11th May 2024
The Italian cinema was surprisingly different from what I‚Äôm used to. You cannot be late. As soon as the film starts, the doors seemingly lock, with a light turning ominously from green to red. Also, instead of showing over 30 minutes of advertisements, there are just four or five trailers before the film gets started. The auditorium was quite empty when I arrived so I took a central seat. Minutes later, someone came up and sat right beside me. I don‚Äôt know whether they valued the best view or were just committed to the seat on their ticket but this would never happen in the UK where we are much more precious about our personal space (unless you‚Äôre on the tube).
The film was fine but unremarkable. It did a good job of making me sleepy and ready for bed. In my half-dazed state, I was surprised to see the other cinemagoers head to a back door rather than back the way we entered. This took us straight through to an alleyway which led to the street. I had only seen this system before in old American movies and I found it oddly charming.
In the morning I made my way to the Vatican City. I had a ticket for the Castel Sant Angelo that would allow me entry at any time, so I planned to hit St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica early in the morning, while the sun was still low and the crowds still slim. I was making my way down the Borgo Santo Spinta, the wide road leading towards St. Peter‚Äôs Square. I found it strangely quiet and I noticed that the road itself was roped off, with policemen standing alert every few meters. Then a convoy of three or four cars started rolling slowly down the road from the direction of the Vatican. A thought briefly crossed my mind before I dismissed it but then‚Ä¶ there he was: in the front passenger seat of one of the cars was the pope himself in full regalia and with a preoccupied look on his face. I was surprised that he was so visible ‚Äî sat upfront in a slow car rather than hiding in the back behind tinted windows. A group of American tourists behind me shrieked in ecstasy and I made my way to the Basilica.
Even though it was only about 8:30am (no lie-ins for the pope either), the crowd was already vast. It took some time simply to discover where the queue that snaked around the square ended. I eventually joined it and questioned whether to stick it out ‚Äî I had just seen the pope himself after all, it would be hard to top that. This seemed to be the one queue in Rome that I couldn‚Äôt avoid with a premium ticket. Entry to the Basilica is free, so everyone queues together. Even the tour guides with groups of 10‚Äì20 tourists had to endure the long queue ‚Äî I watched as they struggled to keep their guests occupied and interested by sharing little bits of trivia about the Vatican.
I endured and, after almost two hours, I was in. The Basilica is undoubtedly impressive (and much less gauche than the Sistine chapel). It is intricate and vast, with walls and columns that stretch so far and high that it almost feels like you are standing within some kind of microclimate. While I was impressed by the baroque art & sculptures I did find it hard to appreciate them. I much prefer the Gothic atmosphere that you find in cathedrals like Durham. After thirty minutes or so, I had my fill and headed out.
I headed to Castel Sant Angelo (which is also known as Hadrian‚Äôs Mausoleum). It was immediately impressive how many different roles this building has played throughout history ‚Äî mausoleum, papal residency, prison, fort and now a museum ‚Äî it is the swiss army knife of antiquity. Like a palimpsest, there are visible layers of development. History is visible through the distinct layers of bricks and the slight changes to the architecture as you move from floor to floor. I enjoyed wandering its grand halls and admiring the views across Rome. But after five days of sight-seeing, it was clear that my patience for admiring art and reading my way through museum exhibitions was thinning.
I headed back to the hostel to do some laundry and pack for my departure the next day. I realized that I had just one sight left unticked on my list: the Pantheon. When I arrived, I found it almost cute how the ancient Pantheon is tucked away in a modern bustling Roman square. Rather than standing proud upon a hill (like some of the ruins in the Forum), it shyly sits amongst hotels and restaurants. When I entered, it was hard not to stare up constantly ‚Äî the dome is an incredible sight and, for the first time on this holiday, I was hoping it would rain so that I could witness the rain fall through the hole in the dome and down into the building.
I found the interior disappointingly Christian ‚Äî I would have preferred hellenistic statues and relics over the pulpits and crucifixes which greeted me. Like a dog pissing on a lamppost, the Catholic church have crudely claimed the Pantheon as their own. This isn‚Äôt an exception in Rome ‚Äî I had noticed the day before that they had even literally planted their flag in the Colosseum by displaying a large modern crucifix in the middle of the arena. I suppose I should be grateful. These sights wouldn‚Äôt have survived to this day if the Christians hadn‚Äôt laid their claim, protecting them from being deconstructed for materials or caught in the crossfire of war.
After the Pantheon, I headed to Pompi, a takeaway tiramisu place which had been recommended by a work colleague who is from Rome. It was ok ‚Äî it had been made without alcohol so it was missing a certain depth of flavour.
I retired to the hostel for the evening, where I sat in the courtyard sipping wine for the last time. I was joined by Dan, the new Aussie who had replaced Alec in the bunk below me. He‚Äôs the head chef of a fancy restaurant in Melbourne, so I enjoyed quizzing him on the restaurant business: ‚ÄúAre specials really just a way to get rid of excess ingredients?‚Äù (sometimes) ‚ÄúDo celebrities get better treatment?‚Äù (Yes). It was the right way to end my time in Rome ‚Äî sat in the evening sun sipping wine, eating pasta and talking about food.
That concludes my time in Rome. The food, history and culture did not disappoint. I also discovered the joy of solo travel for the first time ‚Äî enjoying both my own company and brief encounters with fellow travelers. That said, five days was the perfect amount of time and I would always rather share the experience. As I write, I am speeding towards Naples on a train. I can‚Äôt wait to spend a few days with Ashley in the sun.
--

Commissioning Editor in the publishing world. Writing about writing, publishing, travel, music. Mattjameseditorial.com.

Walk down the jet bridge in your comfy cute style, ready for your first day in Rome. Just skip packing your Gucci python print heels on this escapade.
You can look stylish wandering Rome by looking at number-two of these 12 Rome tips without looking like the goofy tourist in your wanderlust.
We chose to fly to Roma on Easter weekend for our very first time. I‚Äôm in-touch with the crazier ideas when it comes to traveling and now know how to keep you from looking the out-of-sorts maniacal traveler.
Easter weekend ‚Äî in the Catholic capitol ‚Äî we thought, ‚ÄúLets visit Rome!‚Äù
One-step-nuttier‚Ä¶We added a tour of the Vatican on the list!? {Go off the high dive of nuts ‚Äî or don‚Äôt go at all!}
If you knew my Hubs, this sort of crazy optimism wouldn‚Äôt be so shocking. He‚Äôs an ‚Äúall-in‚Äù, ‚Äúit‚Äôll be fine‚Äù kinda guy.
And if you don‚Äôt make it into Vatican City, there‚Äôs always a gelateria nearby ready to serve it‚Äôs oh-so-sweet-goodness. Gelato makes everything better!
On to the gelato! {Plus the 12 tips}
If you‚Äôre traveling to Rome, these are the 12 best travel tips to keep you from looking like the nutter tourist‚Ä¶
The midday rest hours is a thang in Italy, but slowly drinking your coffee is not. Order your frothy cappuccino or caff√® macchiato {an espresso with a splash of milk} at the bar, take your receipt to pick up your cuppa, and drink up. Sitting down at a table to leisurely drink can double your bill {table service fee}.
The cobblestone streets of Rome are part of its old world charm. You‚Äôll be doing a lot of walking along those cobblestone streets, and heels don‚Äôt fit this trip {they do fit nicely in the cobblestone cracks and break your heels though}. Save your cute spikes for your Asheville weekend.
There are good walking-around stylish shoes to pack for walking Rome::
When you pop into the small boutiques or family-owned shops, greet the owner {most small shops or artisan workshops are operated by the owners}. Greet them with ‚ÄúBuongiorno‚Äù {good day} until afternoon and ‚Äúbuonasera‚Äù {good evening} after. {Ciao is an easy hi/bye, if that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre looking for}.
No need to rattle off Eat, Pray, Love in Italian, but making an effort to speak the language goes a long way in ANY COUNTRY you visit {except for maybe France. Depending on who you try it with, they can get a bit testy}.
As with ANY TRAVELING, keep an eye on your bags. In crowded areas {and all of Rome‚Äôs popular sites are overflowing with people}, carry your bags on your front or use a protected travel backpack like this one.
SIDE STYLE TIP:: Belt bags are the new fanny packs üòâ I bought mine in the wine color because it‚Äôs purty. But turns out it‚Äôs a BRILLIANT CHOICE if you‚Äôre a wine spiller too üôãüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è {anyone else raising their hand?}
We are walkers most of the time, but getting to certain places in Rome requires wheels. The city buses were those wheels that Easter trip. Buy your tickets ahead of time because they DO NOT sell tickets on the bus.
Buy tickets at any tabaccheria in the city. Shops are designated with a large ‚ÄúT‚Äù. Tickets are ‚Ç¨1.50 each, or choose a 24-hour, 48-hour, or weekly ticket for a discounted price. Tickets are valid for all public transportation in Rome (bus, metro, tram and local train).
Bypass the lines and purchase tickets to the more popular sites AHEAD OF TIME. Many of these sell out quickly. Do a little planning ahead and buy your tickets online before your trip. { Vatican and Sistine Chapel, Colosseum, St Peter‚Äôs Dome & Basilica tour are big hits}
You don‚Äôt need a ticket to visit Trevi Fountain, but it‚Äôs wildly popular and not much fun squishing your way through a ka-jillion of your closest strangers. Grab your cappuccino and make that your first view of the day.
OORRRR, make a night stop to see it under all the beautiful lights. We did both, and 18/19 tourists agree‚Ä¶nighttime viewing is best, mainly because‚Ä¶fewer peeps standing around in your photos üì∑
We ran out of time, but one tour that‚Äôll be on our 2024 trip itinerary is the traditional pasta-making and wine tour in Frascati {40-min train ride from Rome}.
Since the pandemic, credit cards aren‚Äôt the frowned upon payment they once were, but good ol‚Äô coin still reigns supreme ‚Äî especially in smaller-run businesses.
Keep some on hand during your trip.
One of THE BEST parts of foreign travel is the exposure to other cultures. Dinner in Rome might be one of those adjustments, unless you‚Äôre a snacking queen like myselfü§ó
Dining and drinking are rituals in Italy. Don‚Äôt rush. First, enjoy an aperitivo. You‚Äôre meeting up for a pre-dinner drink and light eats {similar to Happy Hour} at 7pm, after a day of sight-seeing.
However, don‚Äôt eat too much Italian deliciousness, because dinner follows around 8, 9, or even 10pm.
Might want to grab an extra caff√® macchiato for your long Roman days to keep moving until dinner, or take a midday rest {riposa} like the locals, from 1‚Äì3-ish.
This Art of Aperitivo post will help you fit in with the locals at aperitivo time.
Anytime + all-the-time is when you look for your next gelateria to try a new flavor. DO NOT LEAVE ROME without trying at least one flavor, no, five‚Ä¶maybe six. Depends on the season, since they keep rotating.
Order the house wine ‚Äìyou‚Äôll love it‚Äì and don‚Äôt expect pizza drowning in sauce.
It‚Äôs the simple cooking that makes Italian foods mouth-watering, along with the extra pounds you‚Äôll pack home with you. üò¨
Enjoy it the way it comes. Don‚Äôt ask for sauces {I see you, ranch lovers} or try to salt your capressi or bruschetta into a cardiac arrest.
Yes, Italians love their pastas, pastries, and pizza {as well as coffee, wine, and gelato‚Ä¶}. But believe it or not, there are also salad and vegetable options. Look under ‚ÄúCONTORNI‚Äù on the menus {their side dishes}.
Always, always, for the love of Italy, save space for dessert + your after-dinner-sip of limoncello.
That said, you‚Äôll want to put foreign phone service on at least one phone in your party. Wi-fi can be spotty at hotels and caf√©s.
If you‚Äôre using your phone for directions on your trip, pay extra to add on foreign service {or check out the BONUS TIP BELOW}.
Whenever we‚Äôve gone international with our teens, they didn‚Äôt have phone service. I‚Äôm a mama who has her kids back! No Snap notifications, texts, games‚Ä¶ BEST TRIPS EVVV-ER!
Did you know you can download Google Maps to use offline?
Touring the Colosseum today?
When you type in ‚ÄúColosseum, Roma, Italy‚Äù click one of the options that populates, then the three dots ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ {upper right corner on iPhone}.
Tap ‚Äúdownload offline map‚Äù
