Title: Roman Holiday
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Sharing escapades with an eager audience is every traveler‚Äôs dream

--
Listen
Share
Vatican City, the smallest sovereign state in the world, is a walled enclave in the city of Rome
Rome, the capital of Italy, is a multi-faceted place. From the erstwhile Roman Empire to the present day capital of modern Italy, Rome has been among the big names in must see places in Europe. It has been in literature in the form of all time famous maxims: ‚ÄòRome was not built in a day‚Äô, ‚ÄòWhile Rome was burning, Nero was playing his fiddle‚Äô and ‚ÄòWhen in Rome do as the Romans do‚Äô and on the Hollywood film scene with block busters like ‚ÄòFall of the Roman Empire‚Äô and ‚ÄòRoman holiday‚Äô. Roman English is also in common use. Rome is not burning any more and the infamous Nero is long gone. Unlike the Mughal and the Soviet Empires the Roman Empire re-emerged from the ashes and the Roman holiday is very much on. A trip to Italy, in this context, will be long remembered.
Far from stereotypical Mediterranean, Italy‚Äôs climate varies from place to place. We landed at Rome International Airport under a heavily overcast sky. It was actually a light drizzle that we encountered on arrival from Athens and that reminded me of a friend who had visited Rome a couple of years ago but could enjoy it only from his hotel window. He believed in the famous verse:
Aaye kuchh abr kuchh sharaab aaye
Being averse to sedentary life style and drinking, I was really worried about the impending continuity of the inclement weather in the next few days. Though the sun remained under the cloud cover during most of our stay in Italy, to our good luck, the rain did not disrupt our programme any further and we moved around at will.
A Republic since 1946, Italy consists of the mainland Italian peninsula and two large Mediterranean islands namely Sicily and Sardinia further south and enclaves the sovereign states of Vatican and San Marino, the later, lesser known to the outside world, being the 5th smallest state both by area and population. After the conquest of Constantinople in 1453, the victorious Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II was the first of the rulers of the Ottoman Empire to assume the title ‚ÄòCaesar of the Roman Empire‚Äô.
We had planned a trip to about half a dozen European destinations in slightly less than four weeks time and had to budget-plan our outings. A friend very kindly handed me a book ‚ÄòEurope 20 Dollars a day‚Äô (It was an old addition, the latest being Europe 50 Dollars a day) and this book really proved very handy with the minutest of the travel details and tips. We booked a place in a pension, French style boarding house, at competitive rates, on the National Street, mid way between the city centre and the Rome railway station. There could not have been a better location to see the historic city.
Sprawling over seven hills, the city of Rome has River Tiber flowing through the city centre. Incidentally most of the heritage sites were located close to where we were staying and when the tour operators gave a strike call, on the fateful day we had reserved for the city tour, we made good use of the book mentioned earlier. Taxis with English speaking cabbies were very expensive so we used public transport for site seeing. The bus tickets were not sold on board but had to be purchased from the ‚ÄòT‚Äô shops (tobacco shops) in the side streets. Language being a big barrier I was fooling around looking for the ‚ÄòT‚Äô shop when an Italian lady came to our rescue. Attracted to my wife‚Äôs Pakistani dress she told us that her spouse was from Bangladesh and offered any possible help which we gratefully accepted. Her guidance was of extreme help and from then on we went around the metropolis with utmost ease.
Piazza Venezia, the main city square, and former dictator Mussolini‚Äôs official quarters were just fifteen minutes walk from the National street. It was where Poet of the East Allama Iqbal had met the then strongman on his European tour. There were three concrete maps drawn on a wall near this imposing building and they showed the expanse of the Roman Empire in three different eras. It looked as if half of the world, at one point, was under the Roman rule. What a glorious past? Coliseum, the largest amphitheatre in Europe which could accommodate around 50000 spectators, was close by and a monument to see. Trevi fountain, frequented by the tourists in colossal numbers, is a place where one could wish, by throwing a coin into the water, for anything, except the proverbial free ride horses (for the beggars to ride). There were a large number of coins shining in the water on the floor of the fountain, each showing somebody‚Äôs secret wish. Following the tradition we too wished for the moon and got rid of some coins in the process.
Walking on a footpath one fine morning in the city centre we heard police cars with screeching tires and blowing sirens and assumed that some film shooting was going on. It was only the following day we came to know that some outlaws were being chased by the law enforcing agencies and a German tourist was killed in the cross fire. It was really hard to digest that such things could happen in a European capital in broad day light.
Vatican City, the smallest sovereign state in the world spread over an area of 44 hectare (108.7 acres), is a walled enclave in the city of Rome. It houses St. Peter‚Äôs church and Papacy. Created in 1929 the papal city state has its own postal services, a heliport, radio station and a publishing house. It issues its own coins though, like in Italy, Euro has replaced the age old Lira. Its population is just over 800 persons but millions of visitors throng the place every year. Vatican has the highest per capita crime rate in the world including purse snatching and pick -pocketing. At the church entrance it was interesting to see a notice reading; ‚ÄòPlease cover your legs and heads before entering‚Äô. Such rules always sanctify the place.
Pisa was our next destination. We undertook a four hour long train journey to the city of the famous tower through the picturesque landscape with the Mediterranean Sea on one side and vast fruit orchards on the other. Large motor car carriers were seen plying in large numbers on the express way with locally manufactured cars loaded on them in tiers. We took a bus from the railway station to the leaning marble structure which is a free standing bell tower of the cathedral of the city of Pisa that would have collapsed long ago had it not been for the support of the millions of visitors who get themselves photographed with the tower as if they were preventing it from crumbling to the ground. We too did our bit towards supporting the sinking monument and took photographs as a testimony. I once saw a cartoon in the famous Punch magazine which showed the under construction (then vertical) tower of Pisa with scaffoldings all around and the architect telling his colleague: ‚ÄúThere is a small defect in the foundation but rest assured nobody is ever going to notice it‚Äù. Fifty-six meters high, this 12th century building leans at an angle of just 5.5 degrees but at the top it measures 4.5 m from where it used to stand vertically.
Historically Galileo did his experiments by dropping two cannon balls from the top of the leaning tower to augment his theory of speed vs. mass, the Nazis used it as an observation post during WW II and Mussolini ordered it to be returned to its normal vertical position albeit without success. In 1964 the Italian government decided to keep the tilt for the promotion of tourism and kept it closed for the visitors for almost a decade to reinforce its foundations from sinking further. The heavy bells, seven in number, were removed to shed the extra load and it was declared stable for another 300 years.
The vehicular traffic in Pisa was somewhat more disciplined than that of Rome. An article in the Readers Digest titled ‚ÄòDriving Italian style‚Äô eulogized that driving reflected the character of a nation and the painting supporting the article was no different than the one we see every day in our motherland except that the vehicles on the roads in Rome were cent per cent mechanized, unlike Pakistan where stone age animal driven carts are still plying side by side with the modern automotives. The city fathers in Rome are trying to device ways to overcome the traffic congestion and parking problems by disallowing the unauthorized traffic from the central part of the city during work days from 6 am to 6 p.m. We in Pakistan too will have to think of sorting this problem out sooner than later.
Latin, the original language of the Empire, was changed to Italian in the middle ages. Italian is a confluence of various regional dialects and in that respect has some theoretical semblance with Urdu, which itself is a conglomerate of different expressions. The Islamic community has grown significantly since the ‚Äònot very distant‚Äô past due to immigration from North Africa and the Middle Eastern countries and Rome can boast of the largest mosque in Europe built in 1995. We also came across Arab vendors selling their merchandize, especially semi precious stones, on the foot paths in Rome. The string of these multi coloured gems lent further hue to the already colourful side walks.
Our memorable trip to the historic city came to a close and we boarded Alitalia for Orly international Airport, Paris.
Written by Shahid Qayyum
Published by Alisha Khuram

Originally published at https://shegowandering.com on November 9, 2019.
Rome is the place where you need to get lost! The city that‚Äôs full of surprises, history, charm, and colors. Put away your map, and roam around the historic center of Rome to discover beauties, that you couldn‚Äôt imagine! That‚Äôs the only way to really experience the eternal city, and the beautiful streets to see in Rome!
Even if you‚Äôve been in Rome, you‚Äôve never actually seen Rome if you didn‚Äôt get lost on those colorful cobbled streets. That‚Äôs a fact! After 9 visits, I can tell you, that I still didn‚Äôt see it all! And believe me, I‚Äôve spent way too many hours roaming around already! Let‚Äôs see now some highlights!
Via della Reginella & Via dei Pastini
Those incredible little streets are one of the many reasons I love the Italian capital so much! It‚Äôs all about experiencing, breathing it in, enjoying it. Rome is not the place where you should be running with a tourist bus around. Rome is the city that you have to experience, to feel!
As simple as that. This is also the reason why each blogger and travel expert is suggesting to WALK when you‚Äôre visiting Rome! There‚Äôs so much more than the main landmarks, so much more hidden beauty!
This is very common in many big cities‚Ä¶ to not have the opportunity for any memorable street experience. But Rome, Rome has the most beautiful streets to wander around for as many hours as you can!
If you‚Äôre a frequent visitor on my blog or my Instagram, you may already know that I have an obsession with colorful streets‚Ä¶ Well, that obsession started in 2015 here, in the Eternal city!
Via del Governo Vecchio is the street where I spend most of my time when I‚Äôm in Rome. I discovered it back in 2015, and ever since that, this is my favorite street in Rome! Via del Governo Vecchio runs from Piazza Navona almost to the Castel San Angelo, parallel with the main street of Corso Vittorio Emmanuele II.
My favorite bar, the Bistro and Wine Bar Pasquino, and one of my fav restaurants, the Ristorante Pasquino is located on this street. They are both steps away from Piazza Navona. Also, one of the best gelaterias (ice cream shops) called Ice cRome is located right opposite these restaurants. Besides the charm, that really Italian narrow, cobbled street vibe, the buildings are beautiful as well!
Via del Governo Vecchio also offers a variety of bars, restaurants, shops, more gelaterias, art galleries, and antiquity stores all along the way! There‚Äôs no way to not find something you like on this street!
Find details about this area, Piazza Navona and it‚Äôs a neighborhood in my previous article: BEST NEIGHBOURHOODS IN ROME: NAVONA
Each big city has its fashion street where you can find all the famous luxury brands. In Rome, this street is called Via dei Condotti. A street linking Via del Corso with Piazza di Spagna, where you can find the famous Spanish Steps.
If you‚Äôre heading from Via del Corso through Via dei Condotti, you‚Äôll gain an amazing view of the Spanish Steps and the church of Trinita dei Monti. So even if you‚Äôre not interested in shopping, or admiring the shopfronts, this view is worth a walk through Via dei Condotti!
Via Condotti features all the famous Italian brands like Armani, BVLGARI, Versace, and Prada. Though, you will find others like Chanel, Luis Vuitton, Swarowski, or Cartier to. When I‚Äôve first walked down this street I was still at university. That day I‚Äôve promised myself, that if once I‚Äôll buy a luxury item, I will do it on this street! Still preparing for that‚Ä¶
Via del Moro & Via della Pelliccia
Trastevere is my second favorite neighborhood in Rome after the Navona neighborhood! It is located south of the Vatican city, near the Tevere river. One of those things I love the most in this area is the streets. Colorful, cozy, vibrant, and VERY ITALIAN. You‚Äôre bumping into traditional bars and restaurants on every step, literally! Colorful buildings, the flowers, the cobblestone roads‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs just enchanting and fascinating.
Vicolo Moroni
In the past two years, I‚Äôve been always booking my hostels/hotels/b&bs in Trastevere. One of my favorite places, while I was traveling alone, was the Orsa Maggiore Hostel for Woman Only. There‚Äôs nothing better than going out in the morning for a cappuccino and having it in such a beautiful atmosphere!
Trastevere is a bit outside the center of the city, which explains why is still much more traditional, and Roman, than other sides of the historic center. For a real Italian experience in Rome, definitely try to stroll around the streets of Trastevere!
Via Margutta runs between Piazza di Spagna and Piazza del Popolo. It‚Äôs a more hidden street, but with Google Maps you‚Äôll find it easily. Originally, Via Margutta was home to various stables and workshops. It changed its face in the 20th century though!
It became famous after the premiere of the Roman Holiday movie. As you may know, Joe Bradley (Gregory Peck) in the movie was living on this street of Rome, on Via Margutta. Thanks to the success of the Roman Holiday movie, many famous people moved here afterward.
This is how the neighborhood slowly became an exclusive, really expensive neighborhood in Rome. Today Via Margutta is hosting numerous art galleries, luxury shops, and restaurants. The neighborhood is still the residence of a wealthier layer of Romans.
This street goes parallel with the Tevere river in the historic center of Rome. It‚Äôs really close to Piazza Navona, Corso Vittorio Emmanuele II, and Campo di Fiori. Via Giulia was one of the first projects of Renaissance Rome. The street was designed by Bramante, who at the same time was working on the St Peter‚Äôs Basilica.
The street links the Ponte Sisto Bridge with the San Giovanni di Fiorentini church. Back in the 16th century, it was Rome‚Äôs most fashionable street, where merchants and bankers lived. It‚Äôs still considered a really elegant side of Rome, though it looks like it‚Äôs not as popular as a couple of years ago. Via Giulia, the past decades was really popular for its antiquities and fashion boutiques, but today you won‚Äôt find many of these open.
However, this street of Rome is still considered significant because of the amazing renaissance artist, Michelangelo! He had a plan to connect the Palazzo Farnese which can be found on this street, to the Farnese Villa in the Trastevere district. You can still see this arch leaning over Via Giulia on its southern end.
Vicolo del Malpasso & Vicolo della Scimia
Some of my favorite hidden streets are in the neighborhood of Campo di Fiori. As this side of the Corso Vittorio Emmanuele is not that overwhelmed with visitors, the streets are much nicer, calmer, charming. As I was staying mostly in the Trastevere neighborhood, the easiest way to get there was always through the cobbled streets. This is how I discovered both Vicolo del Malpasso and Vicolo della Scimia between many others!
Vicolo della Scimia got burned into my brain because I had to pass through it every single time I was going to or from the historic center of Rome. This one street couldn‚Äôt be replaced with another, and I was always freaking out on it. Don‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs a safe street! Otherwise, I wouldn‚Äôt be suggesting seeing it!
The reason I was freaking out, because I‚Äôm terribly afraid of rats, and Rome has a great population of them. On this vicolo, there‚Äôs no place to go right or left, and it has no doors. So you get on it on one side of the palazzo block and you get out on the other side. So I was always stressed out, that what if a huge rat will walk against me?!? Where I‚Äôm going to run? What if one walks onto the street from one side and the other from the other side? I can‚Äôt escape!!! Of course, that never happened, but when someone‚Äôs this terrified, our brain can play with us a lot.
So, don‚Äôt worry, just put away your map, and head on to explore the streets of Rome. Discover the magic, find the hidden gems, and just breathe the atmosphere in. Rome has unbelievable magic, that you need to experience yourself!

‚ÄúYou packed what for Rome in March?‚Äù
That was the customs officer, eyeing my linen jumpsuit and flip-flops as if I‚Äôd just stepped off a cruise ship in the Arctic. To be fair, I thought March in Italy meant early spring. Blossom-scented breezes. Aperol spritzes under the sun. The Colosseum is adorned with charming gowns.
Instead, I stepped into what felt like a chilly Roman version of Seattle. The wind whipped through my bones. Locals wrapped themselves in puffer jackets and scarves. And there I was, dragging my tiny carry-on and an overinflated ego through cobblestone streets in socks that were basically social distancing from warmth.
Let me save you the frostbite. Here‚Äôs what I wish someone had told me before that first trip.
Italy in March sounds like a dream: off-season travel, fewer crowds, blooming landscapes, cheaper everything. And yes, that part is true.
But what your dreamy Pinterest boards don‚Äôt tell you? March in Italy is moody. One moment you find yourself soaking up the golden sunlight on the Spanish Steps, and the next, you find yourself sprinting through an unexpected downpour. The weather changes its mind more often‚Ä¶

Title: 5 Reasons Why Rome is the Best City in the World
Content:

Listen

I have said this many times before and will say it again- Rome is my favorite city in the world. Why? Because it‚Äôs the perfect blend of history and the modern world. It has it all- beautiful historical sites, amazing shops and of course; the perfect pizzas ever.
So here‚Äôs my experience of Rome and why it‚Äôs soo awesome:
Italian hospitality is unbeatable. The Italians treat you like long lost buddies right from the moment you first meet. The hotel staff are extra nice and attend to your complaints within seconds. But the best about Italians is the way they speak. Their language comes out like a sweet song. It so adorbs that I wouldn‚Äôt be able to guess even if they were swearing at me.
If you think you have eaten the best Italian food ever in your own countries, you‚Äôre gravely mistaken my friend. The best Italian food comes from the source‚Ä¶which would be Italy in this case (well obviously). These Italian restaurants/cafe‚Äôs serve the most scrumptious ravioli, epic mouth-watering risottos and pizzas to die for. I would make a trip back to Rome simply for the food if I could.
Rome‚Äôs history is divided into two parts. The Roman Empire and Medieval history. The architecture of each era is spread out into two distinct areas. The walk to the Colosseum is one of the most enchanting walks I have ever taken. There are ancient relics on either side of the pathway adding to the charm. The Medieval historical sites give off a very ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù vibe.
This mini-city on its own would make a trip to Rome worth-it. The Vatican some of the most beautiful frescos ever in the Sistine Chapel. You will find hundreds of tour guides right outside the Vatican who will give you a tour of the church and museum. Just make sure that you don‚Äôt get ripped off!
Milan is technically a major fashion capital but Rome isn‚Äôt far behind. The shopping here is marvelous from boutique brands to mainstream brands. There‚Äôs a Zara store that‚Äôs four stories high (I spent around two hours there I think). After a day of hard-core shopping you can relax in a nice spot, having street-made square pizzas and watch the sun setting over the beautiful historical ruins. Bliss!
Fun Fact: The Trevi Fountain‚Äì a must see site- has magical powers. Apparently whoever puts a coin in there is sure to come back to Rome one day. My mom put the coin twice and has visited Rome twice ever since. I put it as well and I sure do hope to go again someday!

Title: Rome Or How to Drink Coffee Like An Italian
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
Random thoughts about technology
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúAll roads lead to Rome‚Äù ‚Äî Romans have built one of the most sophisticated road networks, and all of them ended in the heart of the Empire ‚Äî the City of Rome. I‚Äôve cheated and took a plane, but eventually made it to one of the most interesting cities in the world.
‚ÄúAll roads lead to Rome‚Äù ‚Äî you‚Äôve heard this expression before. Maybe in the history class, maybe in the tourist guide. It comes from Roman Empire times. Back then, they built one of the most sophisticated road networks, and all of the roads led to the heart of the Empire ‚Äî the City of Rome. I‚Äôve cheated and took a plane, but eventually made it to one of the most interesting cities in the world.
There are two main reasons why you want to visit Rome: history and food. Guilty as charged, I have a soft spot in my heart for both of them. Growing up I have read numerous books on the history of Ancient Rome and have always been drawn to it. Romans made a huge contribution to our everyday lives: their political, economic, cultural and social norms had set the precedence for quite a lot of ways in which our modern society works. Food is amazing and available pretty much everywhere.
Also moving forward I will start to feature some music from the country I‚Äôve visited to set your mood while you are reading the blog. The first are italo disco heroes Marvin & Guy.
When you start planning your trip, keep in mind that you will be walking a lot. Most attractions and sights are fairly close to each other and easily accessible by foot. Although Rome has public transportation and taxis/ridesharing services, I would recommend staying in central areas and just walk around. There is nothing like getting lost in the small ancient cobblestone streets of Rome‚Ä¶ well, as long as you have comfortable shoes ;)
With that in mind I‚Äôve ended up choosing the hotel in the Prati neighborhood, which is located halfway between the Vatican and Historic Center. I didn‚Äôt want to be in the midst of touristy areas but still appreciated an easy access to all sights. It worked out perfectly. I would also recommend Trastevere for good nightlife. Otherwise, most areas in Historic Center will provide you with numerous accommodation options. The only exception is the area around Termini ‚Äî city‚Äôs main train and bus station, it seems to have a bad reputation.
Rome has 2 international airports but you most likely will arrive at Fiumicino Airport (FCO). It is the largest airport in Rome and Italy. Technically its official name is Aeroporto Leonardo da Vinci. From there you can take an express train or bus to Termini station, the ride will take you about 30‚Äì40 mins. I‚Äôve chosen to take a bus because it had a stop near Vatican about 5 mins away from my hotel. I was advised against taking a taxi from the airport since they tend to overcharge tourists regardless of the mandated fixed fee. Unfortunately, you can‚Äôt order Uber from airport. In general Uber allowed in the city but only for premium cars/vans. If you want a regular UberX/Lyft experience, download MyTaxi app.
Start your trip from Colosseum. It is an amphitheater built in Ancient Rome times, which used to hold 50,000 spectators. Throughout times it was modernized, rebuilt and upgraded, all the while remaining a world-famous landmark. It hosted gladiator fights, animal hunts, mock sea battles, and executions. Colosseum is the symbol of Imperial Rome and one of the New 7 Wonders of the World.
Because of its popularity, it‚Äôs a major tourist trap. If walking around as a part of the crowd where everybody is trying to take a picture of every stone is not your thing, play smart. Rule #1: buy the ticket in advance here, the same ticket will get you to the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill ‚Äî all while avoiding the ticket line. Rule#2: get there super early and ideally on the workday, drink espresso in the morning (we‚Äôll come back to that) and head over right away. You goal is to be done with all of this by early afternoon and switch to drinking Aperol Spritz somewhere.
Roman Forum is the plaza in the center of Rome next to Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Back in the days it was a center of Roman life, and now surrounded by the ruins of the several ancient government buildings. But even ruins give you an idea of the majestic importance and the spirit of the place.
Palatine Hill is one of the oldest parts of the city and the original location of imperial palaces. You can walk around the territory and learn about ancient buildings. Now remember my previous point of getting there earlier. Well, we didn‚Äôt. For some reason we‚Äôve decided to grab lunch after Colosseum and do the rest after. Rookie mistake. Don‚Äôt be like us. That Aperol Spritz not going to drink itself.
Actually, let‚Äôs talk about Aperol, Campari and all other good stuff. Italians have a strong culture of aperitifs ‚Äî drinks served before the meal. Aperol is an orange liquor, and Campari is a blood orange liqueur. Both are very popular aperitifs and bases for popular aperitif cocktails: Aperol Spritz (Aperol+Prosecco+club soda) and Americano (Campari+sweet vermouth+club soda) respectively. Needless to say, there‚Äôs nothing better than sipping one (or more) of them on a warm sunny day while enjoying the view after some touristy activities. Mark my words. You‚Äôre welcome.
Finish the walk at Piazza Venezia ‚Äî the home of Vittorio Emanuele II Monument. It is a monument built in honor of the first king of unified Italy in 1919. It is one of the most amazing Roman buildings and just a colossal piece of architecture, which simply hypnotizes you. That‚Äôs probably one of the reasons Mussolini used it as a place for the military parades and public speeches.
It is the second day and you‚Äôre a bit tired from walking yesterday (or drinking last night), so you need a little pick me up. Now let‚Äôs pause here for a second. Coffee is somewhat a religion in Italy, and they take it seriously. There are also some rules, which you might consider even weird, but it‚Äôs their country and their rules. Rule #1: cappuccino (and other milk espresso-based drinks) or espressos with some pastry (croissant) in the mornings, only espressos in the afternoons. Rule #2: you order coffee at the bar and drink it quickly while standing. There is also the specific way to order it: you pay first, then take your receipt to the barista, who then will make it for you. Now you‚Äôre not the first foreigner who visited Italy, and most likely you will be near the major touristy area. So, nobody will really care, if you sit down in the afternoon with a cup of latte. But it‚Äôs generally a good idea to be aware of the local customs, so you don‚Äôt look like a complete idiot in their eyes.
Once you‚Äôre energized and ready to do, start from Piazza Navona. It a famous square of three fountains: Fontana del Moro, Fountain of Neptune and Fountain of Four Rivers. You would probably recognize them from various movies or famous photos.
Your next stop is The Pantheon. It‚Äôs a former Roman temple turned to church. It‚Äôs one of the best preserved Ancient Roman buildings because of its extensive use over the years. Interesting fact: its ceiling is done in the form of a dome, and till this day its world‚Äôs largest unreinforced concrete dome, and of course there are rumors of gods helping out there.
The Trevi Fountain is the largest Baroque fountain in the city and another world-famous piece of architecture. Rumor has it, you have to drink a glass of water out of it in order to come back to Rome. Today you‚Äôll have to put some work in to get to it through the crowd of tourists. If you do so, there‚Äôs a pretty good chance that you‚Äôll come back.
The Spanish Steps is another iconic sight, which was originally built to connect Spanish embassy with the church on top of the hill. By then you are probably a little tired and want to sit down, relax and eat gelato. Steps sound like a perfect place to do it. Wrong. The majority of the people sitting on the steps are tourists. Italians are not huge fans of sitting on the historical monument. Recently they‚Äôve passed a law that allows police to give out tickets up to 400 euros to ppl sitting there. It might be a very expensive gelato after all. If you‚Äôre still full of energy you can walk up to Villa Borghese Gardens, which is a public park on top of the hill.
Vatican is an independent city-state within Rome borders. It‚Äôs the smallest sovereign state in the world by area and population, and primarily exists under the governance of the Catholic Church. Again, follow the rule: sightseeing in the morning, relaxing in the afternoon. Beat the crowds by arriving earlier. Vatican‚Äôs main sights are St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, the Sistine Chapel and Vatican Museums.
St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica is the largest church in the world and one of the holiest Catholic shrines. The entrance is free, but if you want to go up to its top and enjoy the amazing view, you‚Äôll have to join the separate dome line and pay the fee. The Sistine Chapel is the official residence of Pope in Vatican City. The Vatican Museums are Christian art museums, which display works collected by popes over the years.
From Vatican walk to Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelo. It‚Äôs cylindrical building on the right bank of the Tiber. It was originally built as a mausoleum and later used as a fortress or castle. Inside there‚Äôs a museum and you can also go to its roof and grab a bite while enjoying the view.
While doing all of the discussed sightseeing, you should not forget the second reason why you are in Rome: food. You will see it everywhere. The rule of thumb: if you see a lot of tourist crowds, do not buy food there. Walk a couple of blocks, look where locals eat. Also embrace carbs, carbs, carbs.
Several dishes you should absolutely try in Rome:
Generally, I would recommend to explore Trastevere neighborhood, which is famous for its nightlife: restaurants and bars.
Ciao!

Mille viae ducunt homines per saecula Romam
(A thousand roads lead men forever to Rome)
‚Äì Proverb.
I have been reading and hearing much about population decline in the last months ‚Äî except for Israel. India takes over from China as the largest population, since it is less urbanized. Homes are found empty in Japan for years now. Predictions are made for war and growth with a declining population. Schools are shut with no students. And there lies the prophecy of Universe 25.
For those of you who do not know, Universe 25 is the 25th iteration of a behavioural study on rodents. The premise was simples: you have some rats in a utopia designed to feed and house then to perfection, no luxury spared. Having reached 2200 mice, the population founds its way to decline in less than 2 years, and it eventually completely died out.
For those who observe the unprecedented prosperity humanity has reached, Universe 25 may seem like a Morgana‚Äôs prophecy: ‚Äúhe is your destiny, and he is your doom‚Äù. Thankfully, we are far more complex than mice, we are not confined in an experimental setting (unless you count the planet as confined, while we do not even know the whole of it yet) and we have a knack for developing ‚Äî our not-so-utopia was not handed down to us by some ET.
I would submit we have far too many differences, and though we may share in a certain decline, the history of humanity is lined with ascent and descent: empires, tribes, families, armies and much more. And as I could not keep out of everything‚Ä¶ this has everything to do with Ancient Rome. As a matter of fact, I continue to agree and expand on prof. Oliveira Martins‚Äô quote (translated from Portuguese): ‚Äúthe history of the Roman Republic is the paradigm of all known histories‚Äù. Though I would say: the history of Ancient Roman is the known paradigm of all known histories. And in that I mean the empire, the republic, the kingdom, the city, the economy, the politics, the rivalries, and everything else.
And, in this too, Rome has already declined and mostly faded, buried under the sands of time; the city has suffered an unprecedented demographic collapse from the height of what could have been a hugely dense 1.5 million people metropolis[*] by the year 100 A.D. to a few tens of thousands by the start of the Middle Ages. Adding the Western Roman Empire‚Äôs downfall to external conquest and the Byzantine slow, thousand-year, decline: one can only say the answers also lie in Rome.
When we talk about the ancient city of Rome, it is difficult to know exactly what we are talking about. That is, the city changed so much from the kings to Odoacer that one would. Are we talking about the near-empty thatched huts before the Sabine women, are we talking about unprecedented marvels of marble and stone from all over the Mediterranean or are we talking about the mythical decadent figure bestowed unto us by artists and thinkers from the Renascence onward?
Well, we are talking about all of that, of course, but we cannot properly talk about all of that at the same time, lest we lose chronological sense.
Keeping that in mind, let us be orderly and start at the beginning. Rome would not look like a booming metropolis at the time of the kings. It had not sprawled over the seven hills, it had no Egyptian grain to distribute, no treasures of the mysterious East and none of the major marks (the Flavian Theatre, the Therm√¶, the temples built by the greatest generals and so on). We are talking about a civilisation that is, in sooth, yet to be ‚Äî though now we know it indeed was.
We may consider that the challenge posed to the Roman Kingdom and most of the republican times was there. A mission existed, be it to overcome Carthage, to attain general success or to rule the Sea. What I mean is: there is no place here for a weak, young society to ever act like a decadent empire. The opposite, in fact. There lies no path to power in imitating power. Brazil is an example of such a failure in our times: a country that looks up to ‚ÄúScandinavian socialism‚Äù[‚Ä†] and seeks to spend just like Sweden, while providing zero of the ambiance that gave way to Swedish prosperity ‚Äî and we are not talking about an empire here. Needless to say, Brazil is not in the highway to prosperity, but threading the dangerous road to serfdom.
At any point, the fact is Rome stood far from the spoiling utopia of Universe 25 at this moment of its history.
After the fall of Carthage, we might say Rome has become the leading empire of its time, and of all time, we might add. That is, taking on the mantle of the cosmopolis, Rome is the universal empire that weaves the very legitimacy of the concept. And it did enjoy its time in the Sun, much like the USA after World War Two. Using the population of the actual city of Rome as a proxy, we must note that the population seems to have peaked by the end of the first century A.D., according to some estimations.
The precise movements of Roman prosperity are yet not detailed to be discussed, and are also not the main point of this essay, so here comes the question: what happened after that? Well, my readings indicate that the population fell just as quickly as it grew. It is important to observe that this was not a childless society. Romans died from plague and war; they moved back to the rural areas as Rome was politically and economically voided ‚Äî and it would be possible that those who remained had less children, but who knows.
The point is: the urban population fell, and by the end of Antiquity, many estimates agree that it would not have even a hundred thousand people ‚Äî and that it would continue to dim well into Medieval Times. We are talking here about a much more dangerous city, abandoned by the imperial structure, lacking a Senatorial class (or any such wealthy people who could turn anywhere they went into Monaco), partially abandoned and materially depreciating. This is no city of wonders, commerce, and opportunity. It is a hollow dream, voided by the decay and overextension of empire.
And for more than a thousand years, Rome would remain the seat of the papacy, de facto and de jure a Christian City (identified more by the Church than with the Byzantines over the Adriatic), mostly reduced to minor Italian squabbles, and depending on greater kingdoms to call upon its influence.
It is no mystery what the ancient Romans did: they fled to their farms. Large and small, senator or bum, the wandering search of safety, shelter and a life led the Romans to the countryside ‚Äî and led properties to the hand of powerful men, who could defend the land/fiefs and the previous owners, now their servants or vassals. One might take note of the wording, but it is better to say it fully: feudalism had kicked down the door.
It is thus that some questions arise:
i. What was happening to population and fertility when feudalism began?
ii. Did moving away from Rome make less babies or more?
iii. How relevant was the barbarian influx?
iv. How and why did things change again?
One might observe that these are not trivial questions. To answer them accurately would require precise data from more than a thousand years ago, and we do not have that. In many ways, that may be a problem since the absence of this information makes way for all sort of fantasy storytelling, but let us propose some thoughts:
It is likely that fertility fell by the end of Antiquity, as that trend is observed for general times of crises, but it is unclear if that had any meaningful role to play in the social or economic setting. We know, as an example, that individual wealth grew at the time of the Black Death, since it led to concentration of inheritance and the scarcity of labour. It would be interesting to see how that would have worked out a thousand years prior. It is also not clear if there was a difference in urban and rural fertility, as there exists nowadays.
[*] 1.5 million people is the highest number found during my research on the topic, but I am not subscribing to that number, just using it as a reference for the scale of the collapse.
[‚Ä†] It is unfortunately the case for Brazilian politics, that the Marxist/socialist left (allied to Maduro, Cuba, Ortega, ‚Ä¶) conflates the Scandinavian political and economic setting with ‚Äúsocialism that works‚Äù, at the same time using the ludicrous claim that the USSR, Cambodia, and other such bloodthirsty regimes were not ‚Äúreal socialism‚Äù (at best, there are times when we can hear people defending gulags or saying they never existed in the first place). We should observe that such claims have been publicly refuted not only by simple facts, but also by Scandinavian leaders, but referring more commonly to claims made by American politicians: <https://www.vox.com/2015/10/31/9650030/denmark-prime-minister-bernie-sanders>
P.S.: the above is an informal essay, please do not consider it conclusive, fully researched or based.

When I was a kid I watched a movie called ‚ÄúRoman Holiday‚Äù. The magnificent and enchanting scenery shown in the film evoked my longing for Rome.
Years later, I had the opportunity to visit the ‚ÄúEternal City‚Äù (with more than 2500 years of history). It was 2003, and my husband and I decided to take a week-long vacation to Rome.
As with my other travel stories, here I will continue to talk about some of the little things I observed and experienced in Rome.
1. The airport bus couldn‚Äôt open its door and a ‚Äòfree‚Äô subway ride
One afternoon in March, we took off from D√ºsseldorf, Germany, with our infant son, and arrived at Rome‚Äôs Fiumicino airport about two hours later.
March is the best season in Rome, the weather is neither cold nor hot. We came from still chilly Germany to warm Rome and felt comfortable. But soon we were overwhelmed by what happened next.
After waiting at the airport for a long time, the bus to the city finally arrived. Before we could react, the crowd swarmed and filled the bus in an instant.
Oddly, the middle door of the bus wouldn‚Äôt open, so our pram had to squeeze in through the narrow front door.

Title: Roman Holiday Part II: Sights to see in Rome.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
If you only have a few days in Rome, as I did, it‚Äôs important to see as much history and culture as possible. In our last post, we showed you our ideal day in the heart of Rome, Piazza Novona ‚Äî the best espresso (according to Romans) , gelato, markets, and the Pantheon. In bite-size pieces, here‚Äôs our version of the best things to do in Rome in 48 hours.
I. Piazza della Repubblica: Piazza della Repubblica is a beautiful semi-circullar piazza with the Fountain of the Naiads in the center, and the Basilica of St. Mary of the Angels and Martyrs across from the fountain. I encourage you to look inside the Basilica, inside is a beautiful bronze meridian solar line, designed by Francesco Bianchini, with marble depictions of the zodiacs.
II. The Colosseum ‚Äî because no trip to Roma is complete without visiting the Colosseum, the icon of Imperial Rome. Right next door to the Colosseum is the Roman Forum, the heart of ancient Rome. Both ruins are must see when visiting Rome, and you can purchase the Roma Pass, which gives free entry to both the Forum and the Colosseum.
III. The Spanish Steps (or the walk to the Spanish Steps): The Spanish Steps is a monumental set of 135 steps, made famous by the 1953 classic Roman Holiday, with Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck. The base of the steps can be overcrowded with tourists, so I suggest arriving north of the steps by Via Sistina and taking the time to visit the shops along the way, and admire the charming architecture of the streets of Rome.
IV. Villa Borghese: Villa Borghese is an extensive garden that was built in 1605 by Cardinal Borghese as a party villa. It has many villas built as summer residences for Popes and nobles, but is now most visited for the Galleria Borghese, which has sculptures by Bernini, and paintings by Raphael and Caravaggio. Buy tickets in advance because this is a popular museum, and aside from the Vatican, contains some of the best works in Rome. If you don‚Äôt make it to the museum, or want to spend an extra hour or so exploring the park, there is much to see, such as the Sienna Square, National Gallery of Modern Art, or the Temple of Aesculapius. My favorite part of the park was the view from the Villa Medici. which offers stunning panoramic views of Rome (above).
V. Vatican City: The Vatican can be made a half-day trip or a whole day excursion. There is so much art in the Vatican Museums, and because of the amount of tourists, I recommend allotting quite a few hours to see all the art the Vatican has to offer. There are four Sculpture Museums, a Painting Collection, a museum of Modern Religious Art, and a historical museum and art gallery. The Vatican‚Äôs extensive art collection started over 500 years ago with the purchase of Laocoon and his Sons, a marble sculpture found in a vineyard near the Basilica of St. Mary Major in Rome. The Sistine Chapel cannot be missed, I could spend hours looking up at the masterpiece of a ceiling, Michelangelo‚Äôs greatest work. The heart of the Vatican is St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, one of the world‚Äôs largest churches, and the most renowned work of Renaissance architecture. Words cannot even describe the magnificence of St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, and you must see Michelangelo‚Äôs Pieta located inside the Basilica.

Content:

When I travel, I like to seek out authentic local experiences. This time someone heard my prayers and decided to give me one of the most classic local southern European experiences ever on my first day ‚Äî a public transportation strike. So I walked everywhere.
First impressions:The area around the train station was pretty gritty, there was graffiti on every vertical surface, litter all over the ground, and‚Ä¶sketchy people standing around. But this is pretty standard around big train stations everywhere in the world, Paris North Station is also similar, but Rome definitely outperforms Paris in terms of grittiness. Unlike the perfectly manicured buildings in Paris, Rome feels more ‚Äúwild‚Äù and unrestrained.
Roman traffic deepened such an impression. Walking on a large boulevard, I reached a roundabout where many large roads met. In the middle of the road, there was a small police stop, with two middle-aged Italian policewomen directing traffic. They were doing a good job, but they were a little‚Ä¶unpredictable. Literally in the middle of a green light with cars pouring onto the intersection, one of them strolled confidently into the middle of the road, and held out her hand firmly to stop traffic. The cars stopped. They were not in straight lines. Some cars backed out of the intersection. Everything was still for a moment. And then the chaos reignited. I had no idea what was going on, and to be honest I was a little bemused, but I calmly crossed the street and kept walking. Traffic in Rome is quite a comedy. Not all major intersections have traffic lights or crosswalks, but that doesn‚Äôt stop people from darting across busy traffic; and even when there are traffic lights, that doesn‚Äôt stop cars and motorbikes from sneaking across. On paper, this sounds like Paris, but I assure you it‚Äôs different. Parisian drivers don‚Äôt open the windows to shout expressively at you with both hands gesturing wildly. Rome has a more comical disorganization, it‚Äôs like a Mr. Bean who knows what he‚Äôs doing. It‚Äôs hard to explain.
‚ÄúParla inglese?‚Äù It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve been in a country where I don‚Äôt speak the local language, and I‚Äôd forgotten how frustrating but also how amusing that can be. I‚Äôd pre-booked entrance tickets to the Coliseum, Forum, and Palantine Hill to avoid waiting in long lines. I‚Äôd read the fare conditions closely, and realized that I could get in for free with my Tufts in Paris ‚Äústudent of Art History‚Äù ID. Since mine was a discounted ticket, I had to go to the ticket office to verify my status before going in.
At the ticket office : (original conversation, imagine strong iTaLiAn accent) - Ticket lady: You reserved a free ticket, you need pay 12 euros for the adult ticket.- Me: (confused because I‚Äôd also reserved an audio guide for 7.5 euros, but in the moment I forgot what the 7.5 euros was for, and also forgot why I got a ‚Äúfree‚Äù ticket) I thought I paid 7.5 euros for a ticket, why are you saying it‚Äôs free?- Ticket lady: That is for the audio guide. For the entrance fee, you need to pay 12 euros because you are not an EU citizen. You need an ID or passport.- Me : (in my mind ‚Äî how do you know I‚Äôm not an EU citizen??? and then I remembered why I got discounted tickets and started taking out my Tufts in Paris Art History ID) I‚Äôm a student ‚Äî - Ticket lady: (interrupting) No student ticket, only adult 12 euros.- Me: But I study art history.- Ticket lady: Architecture?- Me: No, art history.- Ticket lady: Not architecture?- Me: No, art history!- Ticket lady: Ohhh ok, ~art history~ I see, sorry but only students of architecture and history of art can get free tickets.- Me: (ready to faint ‚Äî art history and history of art are the same thing!)I didn‚Äôt want to argue with her anymore so I just pressed my ID against the glass.- Ticket lady: (sees my ID that says ‚Äúl‚Äôhistoire de l‚Äôart‚Äù) Oh ok! Then that‚Äôs good!
Good thing I insisted and didn‚Äôt cave in to paying 12 euros, otherwise I‚Äôd have lost many gelatos and that would be very sad :(
After an afternoon, I have the impression that Rome is a little less organized and less glamorous than Paris, but with more character and personality. It‚Äôs like Paris is an elegant, uptight lady, whereas Rome is a carefree singing guitarist with tattered clothes. But this is just day 1, maybe my impressions will change after 5 days! :)

Content:

Dramatic titles for me are an art form and today we are about to talk about something with no relation to any of the cities mentioned above but points to critical moments in all. Abstract titles are my way of art and ironically they a mosaics that my mind paints.
Rome was not built in a day; this a saying that has been repeated for a long time, and will also be passed to generations as long as humanity remains. It is true, Rome as an empire has been around Before Christ and After Christ hence, it is obvious that it was not a day‚Äôs job. I think it is more important to take the principles of Roman Construction and apply them in our lives.
The senior Pastor at Life Church said something in a sermon I watched, He said ‚ÄúWhen we are born we look like our Parents, when we die we look like our choices ‚Äù. That word struck me and I who enjoy a largely sedentary lifestyle imposed on me by the nature of my career went for a much-needed walk. I live in Ajah (an area in Lagos) and I have lived here for a while now (except when I was in Uni), I have seen development occur with time and how places that would have you scared now look like a jewel.
However it was not always so, I recalled and remembered what it used to be like when I walked towards a now abandoned house, an abandoned site, and a poorly maintained sand-filled road. When I began to see these buildings and roads, got the burden to paint them with words as it cuts across various niches.
Knowledge is the most pleasant and annoying thing to have, it is a double edge sword. Ardan Labs a software company that has a training arm has a saying, ‚ÄúIf you think it‚Äôs expensive to hire a professional, just wait until you hire an amateur‚Äù and it is true about learning, ‚ÄúIf you think it‚Äôs expensive to train to be a professional, try ignorance‚Äù. Like every good Lawyer, I will present facts that could be misconstrued but I hope I paint pictures that will live an impression on you.
Pompei is/was a city that existed in Italy under the Roman empire that got buried under ash from an Erupted volcano called Mount Vesuvius. They thrived as a City till a threat possibly called everyone who lived in that city.
Knowledge as a double edge sword had me asking how did people come to settle around an Active Volcano. Did they have no Geophysicist, no Geologist in ancient Rome that could inform people of the threat to life? Ignorance which was not an active choice of the people of Pompeii levelled and buried an entire city.
Atlantis is presented as a lost city buried somewhere in the ocean, although scientific inquiry has presented facts that Plato‚Äôs work which mentioned Atalantis in his work Timaeus and Critias was not a total representation of life but an allegory to drive home a point. As such science concludes that Atlantis never existed. Well, I am not debating science but Intend to accept for the basis of this at Atlantis did exist.
A beautiful city that got buried as a result of earthquakes, again if Atlantis really did exist why did its people decide to settle on an Island? If they had the foresight of the future would they have settled there? I would argue and present an engineer's answer ‚ÄúIt depends‚Äù, however, the law of averages agrees that if they settled elsewhere and the earthquake happens again the island may sink or it would not, depending on its averages (in this case the intensity of the quake).
These two cities albeit one being a farce and the other did exist, are demonstrations of how knowledge gaps are our undoing. I looked at buildings that were the houses that tickled my need to be rich and a few of them looked like the have sunk. I remember coming to Dad‚Äôs house while it was constructed and its foundation was so high. My dad imagine the height of the road ( in the future ) which I felt was nearly insane. Looking at houses around that looked like they had sank and will still sink I began to understand that an intricate part of knowledge and building (not actual buildings) with it is the ability to preempt actions, develop more knowledge and respond accordingly. Today the height of the road is at least a level higher than my Dad anticipated. There are 5 new buildings around my Dad‚Äôs house and they seem taller because of the new ground level the foundation was laid, luckily for my Folks their house did not sink or sink as much, but this ability to preempt the future or an unforeseen circumstance struck me as a key to building.
Recently I switched my work codebase from an in-route logic-dependent application to a repository pattern which was initializing access to the Database (DB) in the Repositories, that was an excellent design for me at the time, the way the DB was accessed was flawless and I felt nothing could go wrong.
There has been a sprint-like approach my team had imbibed to produce the product that had been blueprinted (designed). In this fire brigade approach, I discovered that the access to the DB was a poor decision, my ignorance of this was glaring and staring me down and I had to come up with a solution. I spent 16 hours working across two days to come up with a solution that resolves the DB via the Framework‚Äôs method. I am sure it feels like I have lost you, apologies. Enough of Tech detailed talk layered with backend remarks. My ignorance meant that if this product went live based on my decision and knowledge at the time there was going to be an epic fail.
Luckily for me, I saved the day by experimenting and drawing fact-based solutions from a source of truth (FastAPI‚Äôs documentation), my teammates attested to an uptick in performance across my system. There is a word for if that situation above got to production and I have to manage the such situation and resolve it. It is called Technical debt. The lack of knowledge with regards to something intricate means that we would not deliver at the optimal mark in that regard.
A lot is happening across the world, the more we look the more we see that no one really has it all figured out, communities, countries, sports teams, people and automated processes. Knowledge is not a destination it is a continuous place. Knowledge is the refiner's fire, through its acquisition we realize how flawed our previous implementations are.
We do this by becoming like Rome.
Rome seems to be a wonder of the world, because, at some point in our lives, we hear Rome was not built in a day to persuade us to do the work. The idea however is to communicate to us the Kaizenic nature of Rome‚Äôs Architecture. There are Ancient structures that are still up today, such as the Leaning Tower of Pisa, and the Roman amphitheatre among a few which I know.
These structures are borne out of a place of improvement, the first structure architects would design would give them the cringe if they look at it after years of practice and work, this is why tech solutions are versioned, and this is why we have a Corolla 1998 and 2023 version. It is the Kaizenic nature of constant improvement, this motion is borne out of a place of constant reflection and a zest for the better.
This is why Veterans in any field are better than young blood, this is why the best coaches are people who actively did what they are coaching about (Albeit not at the grandest of stages).
The Roman buildings and the empire did not take over the whole world in one day, it was a gradual continuous action that became the empire. Some battles, some wars, some years of peace. History‚Äôs recounts are always fast and opaquely divulging to the perspective of time and timing. A good example as we ride out on the last strokes of this art, are football players.
A lot of these players dedicate their lives to this sport, childhood, teenage, and even their youth, why will Haland not be a deadly striker? Why will he also not lose a penalty, how come he could he can easily move on.
Time is an important perspective to everything including knowledge, I hated balancing chemical equations in secondary school but I loved it in the early years of Uni.
The most important thing these buildings have thought me is if we are not dead yet then we can become better, your next project should be better than the previous one, that is the only way to show growth and become Rome.
When we are born we are like our parents, but in death, we are our choices. I live you with a wise word on life, we will always have regrets in life, these are an opportunity cost of opportunities forgone. The rule is to remember regret is a feature of life, not a Bug.
Till next time.
Kaizen

Title: The ultimate guide to visiting Rome, especially in December
Content:

Before I begin, I would like you to know how why I am sharing this information with you, since each author has their purpose and I am sure that you are curious about mine. Why should you believe me, an American girl still in high school? For starters, I am not tied to any organization and I am not trying to sell you anything. I am not only writing this to make your trip planning easier, but I am also writing this for myself. I have also added my own personal experience to guide you. I hope that while recording my own memories, I can aid you in planning your trip to Rome so you can have the best experience.
Most people visit Rome in the summer months when the blazing sun illuminates the historical center. My family (of four) decided to avoid the crowds and fly to the city in late December. I was tasked with the most time-consuming but also the most important job: creating the itinerary. My job consisted of booking reservations for the famed Colosseum and Vatican Museums, finding small gelato shops and fancy restaurants, and locating more authentic Italian respites.
The biggest downside was that there wasn‚Äôt much information about what Rome was like in the winter so we didn‚Äôt know what clothes to pack. According to the weather predictors, the sun set around 5:45 pm which was very early. Also, the temperature ranged from 35¬∞F to 60¬∞F. We weren‚Äôt sure about how to dress; should we wear t-shirts? Coats? We honestly had to improvise, so we packed a bit of everything.
Now, when I was trying to plan the trip out, I did not have such a wealth of information in one place. Even more annoying, many of the websites I found were advertising tickets much more expensive than the actual ones. I spent many hours on TripAdvisor, browsing through the many forums. It was difficult to find truly unbiased information. In total, I spent many hours on hundreds of websites trying to figure out how to best visit Rome and what to know about customs in Italy. Of course, there wasn‚Äôt information about everything, so we ended up learning a lot of lessons from our unexpected encounters.
I also had a tough time with scheduling. While researching, I discovered that Italy was a lot different compared to the suburbs where I reside. It takes about an hour to walk from one end to the other. This posed a problem for me while I was planning; I wasn‚Äôt really used to city life, so I didn‚Äôt have a good sense of how long it would take to walk certain distances. I also had no ideas as to how long we would spend at each site. Would we spined at the Spanish Steps? Five minutes? One hour? What about the Pantheon? Maybe we would have extra time. Maybe we would be rushing everywhere. We really just had to wait and see. Now I know you‚Äôre curious to see how the trip turned out.
Overall, Rome was a great experience for me. I got to see the historical sites outside of textbooks and class and I was taken back by how huge everything is. You really won‚Äôt be able to appreciate the genius of the ancient Romans and the Renaissance artists until you get to observe the great works with your own eyes. Since we visited in December, we got to enjoy the Christmas lights and trees set up all across the city. And of course, the pasta, pizza, and gelato were all very delicious. There was a lot of variety at restaurants and cafes so I got to try things that were very atypical of my American lifestyle (Nutella pizza or fried zucchini flowers).
Now onto the specifics (click here to see a shortened version):
Here‚Äôs what I would advise: pack layers. We didn‚Äôt realize that most of the time we would be out when it was cold, so we didn‚Äôt pack very well. Only my mom did, so I had to borrow some of her clothes. It is really cold in the morning up to about 10 am and after sunset around 6 pm. Here‚Äôs what kept me warm:
This guide should have covered extensively all the little things you know about visiting Rome. Should you have any more questions, do let me know. Otherwise, I do hope this helped and safe travels!

From Bari I headed across Italy to Pompeii and an overnight stop in the Bay of Naples.
There‚Äôs not much that can be said ‚Äî at least, not much that‚Äôs profound ‚Äî about Pompeii that hasn‚Äôt been said, better, a dozen times before.
It‚Äôs been a world-famous tourist destination for literally centuries ‚Äî an unmissable stop on the original Grand Tours.
So my main observations are pretty unoriginal.
My first: it‚Äôs big ‚Äî really big. I trudged around for five hours and didn‚Äôt see it all.
As is always the case in places like this, the choking crowds of tourists quickly thinned out, observing the inverse square law of laziness.
My other unoriginal observation is that it‚Äôs amazingly well preserved. It‚Äôs not in obviously worse nick than the 30-year-old ruins we had seen in Mostar a few weeks earlier.
In a neat parallel to the low-value service industry focus of today‚Äôs Pompeii ‚Äî surrounded by snack bars, restaurants and hotels ‚Äî the ancient ruins of Pompeii show that not that much was different two millennia ago.
The economy of Roman Pompeii revolved, clearly, around having a good time.
Leisure centres ‚Äî sorry, Roman baths. Sports centres ‚Äî sorry, amphitheatres. Takeaways ‚Äî sorry, thermopolia. Really, the tourist industry of southern Italy hasn‚Äôt changed that much in two millennia. The ancient ruined versions don‚Äôt even look that different from their modern counterparts.
After an overnight stop in Torre del Greco ‚Äî in a charming farm with half-arsed service and unannounced restaurant closure ‚Äî the car, which had been complaining of some unspecified lurgy since Albania (through the medium of beeps and a flashing orange spanner icon), finally decided that it was oil that it wanted.
The car had been bonked pretty hard on the underside in the rock-strewn ploughed field that passed for a car park at Bogove waterfall near Berat a few days earlier. Had I punctured the oil pan?
To make matters worse, I‚Äôd told a local tweenager trying to shake me down for a couple of lek to ‚Äòwatch my car‚Äô to get lost. Had he sabotaged the car in revenge?
Was the car slowly bleeding out? Was it leaving a puddle of motor oil at every stop?
Was the motor, pistons unlubricated, grinding itself down into iron filings with every mile driven?
Being prone to anxiety, this is not the sort of thing I am particularly good at remaining relaxed about.
The anxiety was not improved by noticing liquid dripping from the underside of the car while waiting outside the gates of the guest house (the manager taking his sweet time ‚Äî more than half an hour ‚Äî to actually come and let me in).
Leaving a tarpaulin under the car overnight calmed nerves somewhat when it emerged the next morning without any oil stains at all. The dripping was‚Ä¶ water from having cleaned the windscreen.
And, using a dipstick for the first time since my driving test, I concluded the oil level in the engine was just about tolerable ‚Äî admittedly when parked on a slope.
My mind put slightly, if not entirely, at ease, I powered north towards Rome, where, after some not-entirely-enjoyable traffic, and quite possibly some low traffic neighbourhood-related traffic infractions, I parked the car underground for a few days.
I‚Äôve been asked a ton of times why I can speak Italian. The answer I usually give ‚Äî my dad‚Äôs a retired Italian literature professor and I grew up hearing it ‚Äî isn‚Äôt really true, or at least, it‚Äôs far from a full explanation.
It‚Äôs not like hearing grown men talking about Dante, Petrarch and Boccaccio is a great draw for a kid.
And I hardly ever went to Italy in childhood either ‚Äî aside from two trips to Veneto, summer holidays were always in France.
It‚Äôs when I was a student that I became obsessed with Italy.
Over a couple of summer trips, I came to love all the ways in which it‚Äôs the best country in the world by a country mile. Nowhere else packs in as much good food, history, architecture and culture.
I came to love, too, all the other ways in which Italy powers through its manifest dysfunctions, shaking off flaws that would condemn lesser countries to failure and obscurity. I even enjoy ‚Äî no, enjoy isn‚Äôt quite the right word, am entertained by ‚Äî Italian politics.
And so, at a loose end the summer after graduating, having failed to line up a job (worse was to come when I lined up one I hated), I signed up for introductory Italian classes.
My ear trained by hearing the tedious Dante talk, my interest piqued by summer trips, and with the headstart that comes from French grammar and vocabulary, I found Italian ridiculously easy to learn.
After a couple of terms and fairly minimal effort, I was speaking far better Italian than I ever did German, despite six years‚Äô hard slog through school.
I‚Äôve been to Italy most years ever since.
Which makes it all the more odd that this was actualy my first trip to Rome.
It didn‚Äôt disappoint.
Not just because St Peter‚Äôs is every bit as extraordinary as its reputation. It feels corny to say, but it‚Äôs a genuinely awe-inspiring and ‚Äî whisper it ‚Äî spiritual place.
Not just because the ancient sites ‚Äî the Forum, the Colosseum, Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelo ‚Äî are so impressive.
Not even because the Pantheon is even more astonishing than I expected, and the architectural highlight of the entire trip.
In addition to that, it‚Äôs also everything I usually like about Italy ‚Äî from the great food, to the nice atmosphere, to the walkable cityscape.
It‚Äôs also got the distinctive typography on its shop signs that you see everywhere in Italy and nowhere outside it.
(It‚Äôs also while in Rome that I got the good news about a funding bid I‚Äôd written just before heading off. This prompted an ill-advised but enjoyable number of Campari spritzes on a very nice caf√© terrace in Trastevere, and a well-earned headache the next morning.)
After resting the ailing car for a few days, I made a detour to a Peugeot garage in the suburbs for the oil it was demanding, then headed north.

Content:

Listen
Share
New theories about a mystery hundreds of years old and a secret known to few Romans that was not meant to be revealed
It was 8 a.C. when the famous poet Ovid fell out of favor with the Emperor Augustus, who exiled him, without the confiscation of his goods, to Tomis (now Costance), a small port on the Black Sea.
But what was the cause of this great punishment for such a famous and important character for Rome?
Let‚Äôs try to give an answer to this question, taking into account the new theories.
Publio Ovidio Nasone was one of the most important Roman poets, one of the main exponents of Latin literature and, above all, of the elegiac poetry.
- Elegiac Poetry: lyrical composition united by specific metric form and by arguments that were opposed to the epic with a subjective and autobiographical setting, interpreted as a lament.
Ovid was the author of many works and his fame was as great during his lifetime as afterwards: his style and his themes were taken up by Dante, Petrarca, Shakespeare and many other.
His most famous work is ‚ÄúThe Metamorphoses‚Äù whose the best known story is Apollo and Daphne‚Äôs myth.
So, what was the reason for his RELEGATIO (exile)? It still is a mystery today as the clues we have come almost exclusively from Ovid himself: what we know for sure is that the poet was exiled by the Emperor Augustus, but his successor, the Emperor Tiberius, maintained the punishment.
The fame of Ovid, as mentioned, during his life was very great and therefore the reason behind his exile must have been very serious.
Let‚Äôs see here what his ‚Äúerror‚Äù may have it been, according to the scholars, ‚Äòtill recent times.
- An illecit relationship with Giulia Maggiore, the daughter of the Emperor Augustus, of which he sang in the ‚ÄúAmores‚Äù, under the pseudonym of ‚ÄúCorinna‚Äù
- Perhaps he favored the relationship between Giulia Minore, granddaughter of Augustus and daughter of Giulia Maggiore, and Senator Decimo Giunio Silanus, causing them to commit the crime of adultery
- He discovered illecit dealings of Emperor Augustus at his court
- He snooped about the private conducts of Livia Drusilla, wife of Augustus
- He partecipated in a conspiracy against Tiberius
It was precisely in the year of the exile that Ovid had achieved his maximus success thanks to ‚ÄúThe Metamorphoses‚Äù, his masterpiece, in which he recounts the transformation of the protagonists into plants, animals or objects.
Ovid was considered a libertine and wasn‚Äôt well seen by the Augustan political side, very traditionalist and conservative, because he used to criticized the two fundamental pillars of the Roman society: Religion and Family.
But it was not this that caused the exile, but something that as a punishment had the ‚Äúcapital punishment‚Äù which, however, Emperor Augustus commuted into exile (as Ovid himself tells us).
But it really was one of the aforementioned actions that condemned Ovid? What about the ‚Äúcarmina‚Äù?
As mentioned before, the reason we have listed ahve been proposed by scholars until recently, almost forgetting the ‚Äúcarmina‚Äù implied and the fact that this could be connected to the ‚Äúerror‚Äù and not be a separate thing.
At the time of his exile, Ovid was writing the ‚ÄúFasti‚Äù, an epic poem aimed at revisiting Roman festivals and rites: there would have been 12 books, one for each month of the year.
Halfway through the work, the order for the RELEGATIO arrived and the work was interrupted, nver to be resumed again.
- A clue -
At the beginning of the fifth book, where the poet researches the etymological origins of the name of the month of May and at a certain point, Ovid has the Muse Calliope (the poetry‚Äôs muse) tell the backgrounds of Rome‚Äôs foundation and she speaks of the constellation of the Pleiades.
In Latin literature, the importance that Ovid gave to this constellation when speaking about Rome‚Äôs origin is unusual: no one before him had mentioned neither Maia nor teh Pleiades in this context.
Certainly Ovid would never have allowed himself to invent something extraneous to the tradition regarding the birth of Rome (neither did the non-romans writers or Rome‚Äôs enemies).
- Was, therefore, a forbidden subject that Ovid wrote about? -
We must now take a step back and tell talk about an event that took place about 100 years earlie: the story of Quinto Valerio Sorano who was senteced to death for revealing the secret name of Rome.
Servius and Plutarch too wrote of the sacrilege commited by Soranus, a tribune of the plebs, poet and grammarian of vast erudition, dear friend of Cicero, whose sentence was death by crucifixion.
A certain reason, that we know for sure, for which the Romans kept the real name of the Urbe (other latin name for Rome) hidden and secret is the EVOCATIO (evocation), a rite for which the patron god of a city was invoked, pronouncing its name, in front of its walls during a siege: knowing the name of the god was the equivalent to seizing the essence of the city and subduing it.
- The Pleiades -
The Pleiades are a cluster of stars located in the constellation of Taurus, 440 light years away from the Earth and includes about 3000 stars, but the eye can see only 6 to 12 of them.
These stars are mentioned by many ancient peoples and it is considered that they thought there were 7 of them. They are found depicted in the Nebra Disc, the oldest surviving depiction of the night sky, dating back to 1600 b.C. .
Also according to the Greeks, the Pleiades were 7: Daughters of Atlas and Pleirone (daughter of Tetis and Ocean) their names were ‚ÄúAlcione and Merope, Celeno and Taigete, Elettra and Sterope, together with the most holy Maia‚Äù. (Cicero, ‚ÄúAratea‚Äù)
At this point a consideration needs to be made.
In the ancient world what was sacred on earth was often a reflection of what was in the sky: for example, Mount Taigete (Sparta) took its name from the Pleiade mother of Sparta‚Äôs ‚Äúfounder‚Äù, Lacedaemon.
Here, as the Roman encyclopedist Marcus Terentium Varro: ‚ÄúWhere now stands Roma, there was once the Septimountius, so called for the number of mountains that the city later included within its walls.‚Äù
We know that the Septimountius does not correspond to the Seven Hills of Rome, but the concept of the Seven Hills could itself be the result of a schematization that reduced the number of the hills of the territory that extends on the left bank of the Tiber.
This semplification would seem pointless, but perhaps the aim was to make the hills correspond to the Seven Pleiades; in fact, even the arrangement of the hills seems to respect that of the ‚Äúseven stars pleiades‚Äù.
The Palatine Mount, on which Romulus traced the furrow of the Urbe, corresponds to ‚Äúthe most holy Maia‚Äù.
In the story of the foundation, we find another probable allusion to the Pleiades: Remus on the Aventine Mount and Romulus on Palatine Mount saw, respectively, 6 and 12 bird flying (as mentioned 6 and 12 are the Pleiades visible from the Earth by eye).
We must remember that the Pleaides are part of the constellation of Taurus, whose zodiac sign begins on April 21st‚Ä¶ The foundation of Rome has as date April 21st 753 b.C. .
It cannot be excluded that even the number of the Seven King of Rome originated, rather than from a historical foundation, from the need for sacred numerology in which the number ‚Äúseven‚Äù holds a prominent place.
A small detail to keep in mind, is that Ovid was originally from Sulmona, a city at the feet of the Maiella Mountain Massif, consacrated preciselt to the Pleaide Maia.
It is therefore possible that an educated Roman, starting from the passage written by Ovid, was able to understand that the city born from Romulus‚Äô furrow, was consecrated to the Pleiade Maia, considered by Ovid himself, the most beautiful one.
For the ancient Romans, the Lares were divinities who protected and safeguarded the individual, the family and the home. The divinity that is introduced in the verses is called ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù (good goddess) and it too had a protective function.
Even the real name of the ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù was never to be spoken; the first to reveal it, was Macrobius in the V century a.C. by whuch time the pagan world was almost at an end.
Macrobius confirms that behind the ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù was hidden Maia.
It is therefore no coincidence that Ovid dedicates the opening line of the book of and about May to her.
The sentence in the graphic specifies a relationship between Vulcan and Maia, in which the god offered a pregnant sow as a sacrifice to Maia, every 1st of May, so that the earth would be pregnant with fruit.
Vulcan represented the protective fire; this places him at Maia‚Äôs service in the defense of the city.
The juxtaposition between Maia and the ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù allows us to see from a new perspective an episode that took place decades earlier, which involved, among others, Cicero and Cesare.
P. Clodio. Pulcro, one of the most discussed characters in the entire Roman history, on the night of the 4th of December in 62 b.C., disguised himself as a woman to secretly participate in a very secret ritual of the cult of the ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù to which the women of the aristocracy were responsible, which was carried out privately in the residence of a high magistrate‚Äôs wife and in the presence of the latter and the Vestals (thus indicates the importance of this rite): that night the rite took place in the home of Cesare, that at the time was Pontifex Maximus.
Pulcro was discovered and underwent a trial in which he risked the death penalty, whilst against him testified Cicero.
Cesare, who as Pontifex Maximus, was one of the few who knew the truth about Rome‚Äôs secret name, divorced his wife after that deplorable episode. This shows how important the rite was.
If naming the true patroness of Rome was such a serious crime, why didn‚Äôt Augustus kill Ovid?
Calliope‚Äôs speech seems to have been cut: in fact, she never mentions Romulus, while the other two muses whom Ovid makes speak before her, do it.
It is therefore possible that Emperor Augustus had the compromised verses eliminated. Those were the verses in which it was stated that Romulus gave the secret name to Rome (a fact present in many latin and non-latin sources), following the prophecy on the place where Rome would be born.
In conclusion, Emperor Augustus granted clemency because Ovid, it seems, never mentioned Maia‚Äôs name directly.
But there were, probably, also political reasons for this choice.

Content:
