Classics without fragility.
Follow publication
--
1
Listen
Share
Migrants poured over the southern border. Many came for jobs after employment options in their home regions had dried up; others were attracted to the excitement and glamour of their destination. Soon the influx began to worry leading politicians, who authorized a series of enforcement actions against select categories of immigrants. Deportations, they believed, would put an end to the mess. No luck: undeterred, the immigrants kept coming.
At last, one politician ventured a proposal. Why not extend the citizenship? Not to all non-citizens, of course ‚Äî just to one specific, carefully circumscribed subset. But one party was having none of it: ‚Äúif you give them citizenship,‚Äù the party‚Äôs spokesman insisted, ‚Äúyou assume (I think) that you‚Äôll still have the same political rights and worship in the same way as you do now. But don‚Äôt you realize that those people will take over everything?‚Äù The proposal withered on the vine.
The speaker of these lines was Gaius Fannius, consul in 122 BCE and a dogged opponent of Gaius Gracchus‚Äô proposal to extend the citizenship to Rome‚Äôs Latin allies. For all its celebrated inclusivity, ancient Rome had residents and leaders who were none too pleased about the continuous stream of immigrants: Fannius‚Äô warning is a distant echo of Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúwe either have a country or we don‚Äôt have a country.‚Äù Romans were as willing as many Americans are today to give this displeasure political and legal expression.
But why undertake this rewriting of late republican Rome in the first place? Partly because in doing so I join a modern conversation about immigration that ‚Äî in both Europe and America ‚Äî regularly and explicitly adduces parallels from the ancient world as justification for various kinds of immigration policy. In this article, I‚Äôll examine the sentimental and rhetorical configurations through which ancient Rome (and Greece) are put to work in contemporary discussions of immigration and outline how Romans themselves perceived and responded to immigration during the Republic and Empire. In a second, follow-up article, I‚Äôll explore how mobility in the ancient Mediterranean structurally mirrored 21st-century migration towards Europe and the United States. Ancient history can clarify how we think about recent developments, just not in the way(s) normally assumed.
Let me stress that my own perspective as a formerly undocumented immigrant with emphatically pro-migrant political commitments informs what and how I write. No Tacitean disavowal of bias for me. But I hope that even those who do not share my views on immigration will consider how antiquity can be repurposed in modern conversations about immigration.
Writing in the pages of The Wall Street Journal, Cambridge classicist Mary Beard recently asserted that the Romans ‚Äúwould have been puzzled by today‚Äôs hostility to migrants.‚Äù Well before the publication of the op-ed, Beard made use of her status as one of Britain‚Äôs foremost public intellectuals to offer a liberal perspective ‚Äî sometimes greeted with viciously misogynistic hostility ‚Äî on contemporary migrant and refugee matters.
The tradition of roping the ancient world into assessments of modern immigration has been a fixture of British political and cultural discourses for quite some time: Enoch Powell‚Äôs infamous 1968 ‚ÄúRivers of Blood‚Äù speech (complete with Vergilian allusion) standing at one end of the political spectrum, with Boris Johnson‚Äôs 2006 Dream of Rome closer to the other. As Mayor of London, Johnson has continued beating the classical drum, issuing warnings that Britain will turn into the ancient state least like Rome in its treatment of foreigners ‚Äî Sparta ‚Äî should it adhere to plans to reduce its net migration.
On the other side of the Atlantic, another professional classicist has intervened in the immigration debates: Victor Davis Hanson. Not one to be deterred by the prospect of controversy, Hanson waded into the immigration-policy waters with his 2003 hybrid-genre book Mexifornia. After first observing that ‚ÄúAmerica is what Rome once was to hustling Jews, Greeks and Numidians‚Äù (p. 51), Hanson goes on to claim in his epilogue that the ‚Äúfreedom and material dynamism of the West are drawing millions to its shores ‚Äî in the manner that Athens once attracted metics from Asia, and Rome drew Africans, Jews and Armenians‚Äù (p. 142). (And as proof that classicists holding forth on immigration can irritate members of the political establishment, one need look no further than Hanson: after introducing himself as a ‚Äúclassicist‚Äù at a Capitol Hill briefing the year of his book‚Äôs publication, Hanson was reportedly accosted by a Congressional staffer who thought he had heard Hanson term himself a ‚Äúclassist‚Äù; the face-off ended with the staffer exiting the briefing in anger.)
Comparisons of modern America to ancient Rome are, of course, nothing new, and so hackneyed by now as to inspire a book-length rebuttal. But in recent decades many of these comparisons have been fueled by anxieties about immigration, particularly of the illegal/undocumented variety. Actress and conservative politician Clare Boothe Luce expressed concern in a 1982 Washington Post interview that the United States might be headed ‚Äúfor the fate of ancient Rome ‚Ä¶ a city of pollution and noise and foreigners, [that] collapsed under the weight of the barbarians.‚Äù
Since 9/11, the argument that a lax immigration policy will hasten the United States‚Äô Rome-like demise has steadily gained traction. A 2004 Florida Times-Union editorial on ‚Äúillegal immigration and the problems that go with it‚Äù ended on this ominous note: ‚Äúancient Rome couldn‚Äôt, or wouldn‚Äôt, stop the influx of barbarians across its border.‚Äù Taking to The Washington Post in 2007 to outline a ‚Äútolerant but also tough‚Äù vision for US immigration policy, Yale Law School professor Amy Chua reminded her readers that the ‚Äúgreatest empire in history, ancient Rome, collapsed when its cultural and political glue dissolved ‚Ä¶ [i]n part, this fragmentation occurred because of a massive influx of immigrants from a very different culture.‚Äù Three years later, Stevens Institute of Technology professor Silvio Laccetti argued that Rome‚Äôs extension of its citizenship through the Edict of Caracalla had precipitated an ‚Äúerosion of civic pride and responsibility‚Äù in the course of outlining his own proposal of a tolerant but tough immigration scheme. And in undoubtedly the most entertaining riff on the Rome conceit, Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas) went full Cicero on the Senate floor ‚Äî framing Obama as Catiline ‚Äî following the President‚Äôs November 2014 announcement of an executive order deferring the deportation of undocumented parents of American citizens and permanent residents.
You wouldn‚Äôt be wrong to suspect that the genealogy I‚Äôve charted so far has an even deeper history: the practice of invoking the Roman Republic and Empire‚Äôs treatment of immigrants as paradigmatic and/or cautionary is already on display in the state- and nation-building discourses of the early modern period. Edward Gibbon‚Äôs Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire reserves the purplest of its purple prose for the barbarians at the gate and the Fifth Column of immigrant slaves and domestics waiting to welcome them. (Last year, a lengthy rumination ‚Äî sprinkled with block quotations from Decline and Fall ‚Äî on Gibbon‚Äôs continuing relevance was posted to breitbart.com under the pseudonym ‚ÄúVirgil‚Äù and triggered over 1400 comments, mostly effusions of agreement.) Before Gibbon, Montesquieu had sketched the contribution of foreigners and barbarians to Rome‚Äôs imperial dissolution in chapter 16 of his Considerations on the Causes of the Greatness of the Romans and their Decline.
But well before either, Machiavelli had taken a somewhat different line on immigration in Discourses on Livy, praising Rome‚Äôs openness to foreigners as integral to the amassing of the military and economic power through which the republic set itself apart from Athens and Sparta (II.3). Machiavelli wasn‚Äôt just anticipating Boris Johnson‚Äôs evaluation of Roman greatness as a consequence of open migration. Diligent reader of Livy that he was, Machiavelli was putting his finger on a line of argument that reached back to the ancients themselves.
The history of rhetorically positioning Rome‚Äôs treatment of immigrants really begins in antiquity, with both Greeks and Romans chiming in on the fluctuating ‚Äî and at times very divergent ‚Äî trends in the Republic and Empire‚Äôs openness. Having worked our way backwards in time to the ancients, we should now pause and ask: how open were Romans to foreigners, really? It turns out that Romans were far more ambivalent about immigration than some moderns give them credit for.
In the first decade of the war with Hannibal, a Macedonian king turned Roman adversary praised the Republic‚Äôs free and easy bestowal of citizenship in a letter exchange with a Greek city-state. In a world where city-states could be quite stingy with grants of citizenship ‚Äî especially Sparta, notorious for its deportations ‚Äî Rome had so succeeded in marketing itself as exceptional that even an enemy felt compelled to take notice. This marketing took several forms, and the one that has left the most durable imprint on literary and non-literary sources alike is Rome‚Äôs origin myth.
In contrast to the Greek city-states whose origin stories indulged the fantasy of autochthony (according to which a community and its members sprang up from the earth in the place they inhabited), Rome promoted itself as the product of immigrants. Molded during the turbulent centuries of Italian and Mediterranean expansion, Rome‚Äôs legendary history began with an illegal immigrant: pious Aeneas, fleeing with his family and friends from the devastation of Troy household gods in hand, elderly father on his back, young son by his side.
As canonized in the Aeneid, the challenges faced by the founder of the Roman race include some of the traditional (epic) dilemmas of travel ‚Äî where to go and how long to stay, whose hospitality to accept and whose to decline ‚Äî Homeric effects translated for a Roman audience. And once Aeneas and his band do arrive on Italian shores, they are denied the happily-ever-after outcome. Their lot is to contend with belligerence, grief, early death.
Some months ago, Michael Fontaine proposed in this publication a reading of the Aeneid‚Äôs second half that aligns rather felicitously with contemporary geopolitical events. On one level, the Aeneas myth internalizes the plight of immigrants/refugees (fato profugi); at the same time, it gives form to the mirror anxiety of those native residents who from the first encounter feel that the new arrivals will take their land and resources and women.
Spinning out this thread further, I‚Äôd add that the ambivalence towards refugees and immigrants woven into the Aeneas legend reflects centuries of unease at Rome about the presence and role of foreigners. The unease was embodied in the mythic personas of Aeneas, Romulus, and Remus, all three of whom were remembered as thieves, rapists, and murderers. Here comparison with the modern myth of the immigrant as criminal is instructive. Earlier this year, to thumps and cheers, Trump laid out his campaign platform on immigration:
‚ÄúThe U.S. has become a dumping ground for everybody else‚Äôs problems‚Ä¶When Mexico sends its people, they‚Äôre not sending their best‚Ä¶They‚Äôre sending people that have lots of problems, and they‚Äôre bringing those problems with us [sic]. They‚Äôre bringing drugs. They‚Äôre bringing crime. They‚Äôre rapists. And some, I assume, are good people.‚Äù
Trump and his partisans seem to have a complementary myth at hand: the ‚ÄúEllis Island‚Äù arrivals of virtuous character and exemplary work ethic (unlike today‚Äôs purveyors of drugs and crime). Much the same conflict between these two alternate ideals of the immigrant played out in ancient Rome. As Rome expanded, nativist and xenophobic discourses proliferated, with consequences for the waves of immigrants settling down in Rome in the last centuries of the Republic and first few centuries of the Empire.
These discourses had sharp legal teeth. On top of the targeted removals and expulsions of groups identified as religiously and/or philosophical suspect ‚Äî the Bacchants in 186 BCE, philosophers in 161 and 154, Chaldaeans and Jews in 139 ‚Äî immigrants hailing from communities elsewhere in Italy were deported on multiple occasions in the years 187‚Äì172 (citations and discussion: Noy, Foreigners at Rome, pp. 37‚Äì47). Sometime in the 120s, a law was passed expelling all foreigners from the city of Rome; another version of the law was passed in 65 BCE. Thanks to the Severan-era historian Cassius Dio, we know something of the reasons for the second law‚Äôs passage (37.9): not only were foreigners believed to be too numerous, it was worried that they weren‚Äôt suitable enough (epitedeioi) to live alongside Romans.
It‚Äôs worth remembering that throughout this entire time Rome still had a republican system of government. These laws were ratified by popular will and not autocratic imposition. Since foreigners couldn‚Äôt necessarily be identified on sight (any romano di Roma stood a decent chance of being physically indistinguishable from an immigrant), it is anyone‚Äôs guess how these laws were enforced. The association of specific neighborhoods with certain groups of immigrants may have played a role in the orchestration of round-ups.
We do know that one Roman witness to the law of 65 did not like what he saw. Characterizing this law and its predecessor from the 120s as designed not only to deny foreigners access to Rome but to deport those already living there (eosque exterminant), Cicero declares in the De officiis that ‚Äúdenying foreigners access to our city is patently inhumane‚Äù (3.11.47). Although he managed to successfully defend the poet Aulus Licinius Archias from deportation, Cicero laments in a letter to his friend Atticus that the same law had been deployed, out of spite, to condemn (and presumably deport) a freedman assistant to the politician and former consul Aulus Gabinius after Gabinius beat charges of political corruption.
Neither the moral nor rhetorical authority of Cicero could halt the policing and deportation of certain categories of immigrants; the practice persisted well into the Empire. Yet immigrants kept on coming. The satirist Juvenal‚Äôs bombastic xenophobe Umbricius couldn‚Äôt abide their presence: ‚ÄúRomans, I can‚Äôt tolerate the city being Greek. Yet what portion of the shit is really Greek? For a long time now the Syrian Orontes has poured into the Tiber‚Ä¶‚Äù (Sat. 3.58‚Äì60). But for the Greek-speaking author of The Learned Banqueters, it was precisely Rome‚Äôs embrace of different immigrant populations that enhanced its glory: it was a heavenly city, encompassing so many foreign populations as to defy enumeration (Deipn. 1.20b-c).
We should be careful to respect the differences between ancient Rome and the modern US (or Europe). For example, the preoccupation with ‚Äúborder enforcement‚Äù wasn‚Äôt quite as intense among the Romans ‚Äî though perhaps the time has come to read Augustus‚Äô reported advice to Tiberius to ‚Äúkeep the empire‚Äôs borders secure‚Äù (my consciously tendentious rendering of Tacitus‚Äô enigmatic coercendi intra terminos imperii) and/or Aelius Aristides‚Äô praise of the Empire‚Äôs walls in his Roman Oration as implicated in a kind of border politics. And at no point in its trajectory from Republic or Empire was Rome a nation in the modern sense.
But with these caveats out of the way, I want to underline a few fundamental similarities between the immigration sensibilities of ancient Rome and those of 21st-century America. Then as now, foundation myths about the state as the creation of immigrants articulated and projected deeply felt anxieties about the legacy of past immigrants and the presence of current ones. Then as now, some of those anxieties were worked out through legal-administrative means, with deportation privileged as a technology of control. Then as now, foreigners stood to lose the most in confrontations between political elites ‚Äî think back to Gabinius‚Äô freedman. Then as now, the immigrant influx could inspire despair over the country going to rot or euphoria at its cosmopolitan inclusivity. Then as now, immigrants were vulnerable to hate crimes.
Hate crimes, you say?
Earlier this year, ‚ÄúDeath to Islam‚Äù was spray-painted on the wall of the Bosnia and Herzegovina Heritage Association center in Spokane, Washington. Thousands of hate crimes are reported in the United States each year. These figures ‚Äî dismayingly consistent from year to year ‚Äî probably underrepresent the true number of hate crimes perpetrated. Setting aside for now the reliability of the FBI statistics, I want to concentrate on the graffito as medium for xenophobia. Even for the spray-painter, there is ancient precedent.
At some point during the second century CE, a tombstone was set up in Rome under the supervision of a certain Charitonius Mercurius for a deceased cavalry officer. From the tombstone we learn that the officer ‚Äî whose name is not preserved in what remains of the inscription ‚Äî was of Arabian extraction (natione Arabus); he‚Äôd lived to the age of 35, soldiering for 16 of those years and attaining the rank of eques singularis along the way. Many examples of this type of inscription survive, but in this case the real kicker comes in the form of a Greek graffito left behind by someone, possibly a fellow cavalry officer, that reads: Œò. ·ºåœÅŒ±œÄœÉŒπ (‚ÄúDeath to the Arabs!‚Äù).
The cultural and linguistic complexities of xenophobic resentment in Imperial Rome were such that a Greek-speaking resident of Rome could scrawl an ethnic taunt on a monument to a Latin-speaking native of the Near East. Romans were quite skilled at the use of graffiti to mock the immigrant Other: the late second/early third-century CE graffito from the Palatine featuring a donkey on a crucifix and the tag (again in Greek) ‚ÄúAlexamenos worships God‚Äù may be the earliest example of such visual denigration being applied to Greek-speaking Christians residing in Rome ‚Äî and takes us back to the anxiety voiced by Gaius Fannius that immigrants would menace religious practices at home.
But my interest in summoning up the ghost of the graffito artist who marked up the tombstone has to do with the fantasy of violence folded into the tag. The cavalry officer was already dead, else he might have had a thing or two to say to the violator of his memorial. Alive and far more vulnerable was the homeless Mexican man recently beaten by two Boston men, one of whom claimed as his inspiration Donald Trump‚Äôs call to deport the undocumented.
Trump‚Äôs rhetoric justifies the commission of acts of violence against immigrants by characterizing them as inherently violent. On the stump, he has bemoaned the scourge of rapists, murderers and thieves originating not only in Mexico but ‚Äúcoming from all over South and Latin America and ‚Ä¶ coming probably, probably, from the Middle East.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt seem to register among his fans that the ‚Äúproblem‚Äù of immigrant crime is a fiction: multiple studies carried out over the past century have repeatedly confirmed that immigrants commit crime at lower rates than the general population. What does register is the fear-mongering, especially among those already inclined to believe that white Americans are endangered: in July a petition was posted to WhiteHouse.gov asking President Obama to honor Trump ‚Äúfor opposing white genocide.‚Äù
Once the immigrant is construed as an existential threat, xenophobic sentiment rallies around the idea of removing that threat by any and all means necessary. Both in ancient Rome and in modern America, the fear of immigrants activates not only the desire to remove their bodies from sight through deportation, but to deprive them of life ‚Äî to destroy them.
eidolon.pub
Trained as a Roman historian at Princeton (A.B.), Oxford (M.Phil.), and Stanford (Ph.D), DAN-EL PADILLA PERALTA is a Mellon Research Fellow in the Society of Fellows and Lecturer in Classics at Columbia University, where he researches and writes on a variety of topics. In the fall of 2016 he will begin a tenure-track appointment in Classics at Princeton. Undocumented, his memoir of growing up without legal immigrant status in New York City, was published in July by Penguin Press. His monograph on Roman Republican religion is under contract with Princeton University Press.
The author would like to thank Michael Fontaine for comments on an earlier draft and a warm and engaged audience at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln for their immensely stimulating feedback.

Title: Why the Journey to Christmas Begins in Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Weekly sermons for those who have a complicated relationship with the church.

--
Listen
Share
December 1, 2024First Sunday of Advent, Year CSt. Stephen‚Äôs UMC, Burke, VARomans 8:18‚Äì25 (NRSVUE)**A Sermon Series on Fuquay‚Äôs The Way to Bethlehem
For this season of Advent ‚Äî a time of anticipation and preparation for the coming Christ ‚Äî we will base our sermon series on Rob Fuquay‚Äôs book titled On the Way to Bethlehem: An Advent Study.
Throughout this series, we will visit four key places, starting with Rome, then moving to Jerusalem and Nazareth, and finally arriving in Bethlehem. My prayer is that as we embark on this journey together, the Spirit will guide us closer to the humble manger in Bethlehem, where we encounter Love Incarnate ‚Äî God-with-us ‚Äî the one named Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, and Prince of Peace.
You may wonder why we start with Rome. All the other locations seem straightforward. The Gospel of Luke begins in Jerusalem, where the angel announced Elizabeth‚Äôs pregnancy to Zechariah who was serving in the temple. Then it moves to Nazareth, where the same angel announced the pregnancy news to Elizabeth‚Äôs much younger cousin, Mary. Afterward, Mary and Joseph had to travel to Bethlehem, where Jesus was ultimately born.
So, why does this Advent journey start in Ancient Rome?
Just like how people consider Washington D.C. as a focal point of America‚Äôs power and influence, Rome symbolizes the power and influence that makes up its empire which stretched vastly across Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East, including the regions of Judea where much of the New Testament narrative takes place.
This Roman Empire is often regarded as one of the most successful civilizations in human history. During the period of the Pax Romana, which means ‚ÄúRoman Peace‚Äù in Latin, the empire experienced centralized governance, economic prosperity, cultural flourishing, and relative stability ‚Äî all the things we, humans, across time, hope for in their governments.
A key factor contributing to the period of the Pax Romana was the infrastructure developed under the reign of Caesar Augustus. During his forty-year rule, Augustus oversaw the construction of approximately fifty thousand miles of highways, creating an extensive network of roads that facilitated travel and communication. This network boosted trade, streamlined administration, and enabled the spread of ideas across the empire. Additionally, these roads allowed Roman legions to move swiftly, ensuring rapid responses to uprisings and external threats, thereby solidifying Rome‚Äôs control over its vast and diverse territories.
While the Pax Romana brought unprecedented peace and prosperity to Roman citizens, it came at a steep cost for many, particularly noncitizens and marginalized groups. High taxes were levied to sustain Rome‚Äôs massive military and ambitious infrastructure projects, disproportionately burdening conquered peoples and lower classes. Enslavement was widespread, with millions of individuals from conquered territories forced into servitude to fuel the empire‚Äôs economy and labor needs. Noncitizens lacked the legal protections and privileges of Roman citizens and were frequently exploited or oppressed under imperial rule. For many, the Pax Romana was not a time of peace but one of subjugation, inequality, and suffering under the heavy hand of empire.
Mary and Joseph were among those living under Roman occupation as Jews, part of the conquered peoples and noncitizens of the empire. And their journey to Bethlehem was not one of choice but of obligation, prompted by a decree from Caesar Augustus, calling for a census. And this census was a common tool of an empire, often used to increase tax revenues to support its vast ambitions.
So, imagine how these conquered people, including Mary and Joseph, felt as they trudged toward Bethlehem. There might have been a sense of helplessness as they complied with orders, knowing they had no choice. Perhaps there was skepticism and fear, wondering what new demands or hardships might further complicate their already difficult lives. Perhaps they felt resignation and complacency, accepting their reality that the only way to survive was to serve the empire without resistance. Or maybe they felt the weight of defeat and hopelessness, quietly echoing the psalmist‚Äôs cry: ‚ÄúHow long, O Lord?‚Äù (Psalm 13).
Although we are no conquered people, perhaps we can relate to them in some way ‚Äî especially to the feeling of helplessness before the forces that shape our lives. On a systemic level, we recognize policies and systems beyond our control that bring harm, prioritize profit over people, and perpetuate inequality or suffering, impacting countless lives, especially those who are marginalized and voiceless. On a personal level, we acknowledge forces that harm us and leave us feeling defeated, despite our deep longing for change ‚Äî whether it be chronic illness, long-term addiction, destructive habits, abusive relationships, or loneliness. Scripture calls these forces, which operate on personal, systemic, and cosmic levels, ‚Äúprincipalities and powers‚Äù (Eph 6:12). These forces can feel like chains of bondage and captivity, leaving us yearning for liberation and longing for a hope that can break through and set us free. This is the very starting point of our journey: Rome represents the seat of these principalities and powers, a place where ‚Äúour hopes and fears are released and sometimes collide.‚Äù Thus, Advent begins with longing ‚Äî longing for change, longing for freedom, longing for justice, longing for peace, longing for deliverance, longing for salvation, longing for the Savior.
Out of Israel‚Äôs longing for a Savior, Jesus Christ was born.
But that is only half of the Advent story.
The other half of the story is
that out of our longing for a Savior, Jesus Christ will come again.
Isn‚Äôt that the mystery of faith we proclaim?
Christ has died; Christ is risen; Christ will come again.
So, let me ask you:
The Apostle Paul speaks to our experience of longing in today‚Äôs scripture, written to the house churches in Rome who were expecting Jesus‚Äô return within their lifetime. Their waiting for the coming of Christ met with the harsh reality of suffering. As you know, they were the church in Rome, the very seat of principalities and powers. Once again, in the midst of suffering, they longed for change, redemption, and restoration; they groaned for their Savior.
Paul writes to their experience, emphasizing that it is not just they but the whole creation that groans together for salvation, as if enduring the pains of labor. In other words, their shared suffering is not the end ‚Äî it is a hopeful anticipation of new birth and new life. Although all they could see and feel now is indescribable pain, Paul encourages them to wait in eager longing and hope, for a wonderful gift of future glory is on the way.
And this expectant groaning of labor pains still applies to us today. We continue to wait in hopeful anticipation for new birth and new life, even in the face of the present sufferings in our world, which we experience and for which we intercede. And we remain hopeful because of the first fruits of the Spirit: the glimpses of God‚Äôs kingdom, the moments when the Holy Spirit moves among us, and the gifts of grace we witness every day through Christ. In other words, we remain hopeful because our God intercedes for us in our collective suffering.
Consider the glimpses of God‚Äôs kingdom, the moments when the Holy Spirit has moved among us, or the gifts of grace we have witnessed. These phrases often describe experiences that exceed our expectations and understandings. These capture divine surprises that defy our skepticism and cynicism. These embody the extraordinary love we receive from those who reflect Christ. These first-fruit experiences are what keep us hopeful in our suffering. And our state of hopefulness in labor pain produces in us not only trust and firmness in the faith, but also a different way of living. Through our words and actions, we reveal an alternative way of being in the world through sharing the gifts of the Spirit with those around us.
Again, I find Paul‚Äôs metaphor of labor pain brilliant. I remember being in a delivery room for almost twenty-four hours, being next to my wife as she endured intense pain and extreme fatigue. And we were there pushing for this baby to come out in hopeful anticipation, without any idea of what this baby would become, what gifts she would bring to our family, or how her presence would alter our lives.
As Paul writes in today‚Äôs scripture, hope that is seen is not hope, but we hope for what we do not see. And we do so with endurance, steadfastness, and perseverance ‚Äî which are what the translated word patience tries to convey. I think this is both the most beautiful and frustrating part of our Christian journey: we do not hope for what is seen but for what we do not see. Our hope lies not in absolute certainty but in humble mystery. Our hope flourishes not in human preference but in divine imagination.
This is the very movement of our faith journey, revealed through the story of Advent. Out of Israel‚Äôs longing for a Savior, Jesus Christ was born in the most unexpected way possible ‚Äî in a lowly manger as a helpless baby. Out of Creation‚Äôs longing for a Savior, Jesus brought salvation to us in the most unexpected way possible ‚Äî through death on a cross and resurrection. Out of our longing for a Savior, Jesus has and will continue to reveal himself to us in unexpected ways. And out of the whole Creation‚Äôs longing for a Savior, we believe Jesus Christ will come again in the most unexpected way possible.
Dear church, let me ask you these questions once again:
Whenever we think about these things, we often wish ‚Äî perhaps most of the time ‚Äî that God would just act like a human empire, issuing decrees to put a swift end to our misery and all human sufferings. We wish God would just tell us imperatively what to do so we no longer have to deal with all these problems.
But, as the book On the Way to Bethlehem beautifully describes,¬π
God does not decree. Rater, God births. God sends a baby, a Son. A Son who would be killed by the empire under which he was born, suffering a Roman crucifixion. Why? So that something new could be birthed in our hearts. Whatever change needs to happen in our world begins with our being born again. For what does creation wait for with eager longing? ‚ÄúFor the revealing of the children of God.‚Äù [That‚Äôs] us, born again.
Despite how much we might wish the church could operate like an empire, the church is called to be more like a harvest field ‚Äî patiently spreading the seeds of God‚Äôs kingdom in all soils, with hope that those seeds will sprout and grow in our hearts. Only then can we be born again, yielding a harvest of fruits to be shared with the world.
As we begin this Advent season, I pray that seeds of divine imagination take root in our hearts. May the story of Christmas be more than an occasion to revisit an old tale. May it become an invitation to leave behind our ‚ÄúRome‚Äù with hopeful anticipation. As we draw closer to O little town of Bethlehem, may Christ be born anew in our hearts, and may we, too, be renewed and born again in Christ.
In the name of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. Amen.
¬π Rob Fuquay, On the Way to Bethlehem: An Advent Study, 21‚Äì23.
Rev. Minoo Kim is an ordained elder in the United Methodist Church, currently serving in the Virginia Annual Conference. Follow his Medium publication to receive his latest sermons or check out his website minoowkim.com for his latest content. Peace!

What to read before your Italian adventure!
There can‚Äôt be a definitive list of books to read before going travelling to a glorious new destination, but I tried to find and read as many recommendations as I could before my trip to Florence and Rome, and here are the books that I found most enjoyable and interesting.
My top choice funnily enough, was from a series of books called Horrible Histories that I read when I was younger, and found that it had the most comprehensive whistle-stop tour of ancient Rome presented in an entertaining manner for a busy but curious traveller.
The Ruthless Romans is full of jokes, anecdotes, and important historical figures. It covers Ancient Rome from 1000 BC - 476 AD and is shockingly dense and informative for such an easy read. If you don‚Äôt have any time at all, try reading this on the plane to da Vinci airport.
Between the collapse of the Republic and start of the Roman Empire is a key piece that I read in high school: Julius Caesar by William Shakespeare. I don‚Äôt think you need to read Shakespeare before a trip, but if you like me have fond memories of sitting in class mesmerized by a political conflict written four centuries ago about a historical event from a couple of millennia ago, then you‚Äôll remember the irony that in killing Caesar for his assumed monarchic intent, the Senate all but ensured that ‚Äúanother Caesar‚Äù would eventually take over Rome as its first emperor: Augustus.
To go off on another minor nostalgic tangent, if Shakespeare is too much of a commitment before a trip to Rome, Asterix hilariously covers the Roman campaigns that lead to the events in Julius Caesar.
For some real, serious history, these two were the most recommended:
Unfortunately I only managed to dip my toes in them before my trip and they were very dense and informative.
On a lighter note, I did breeze through Angels and Demons. It was an action-packed thriller that plays fast and loose with facts.
I liked that it covered Vatican City, which none of the previous books do, and touched on the works of Botticelli and Dante, who were both all over especially Florence and Rome.
For Florence, I‚Äôve been reading The Enchantress of Florence that does an incredible job setting the stage for what the world was like in the 16th century and how interconnected Italy, Turkey, India and everything in between were by trade links and travellers.
Some other books by Italian authors and set in Italy that I didn‚Äôt have a chance to read but would like to in the future are:
And to throw it in there because it was everywhere, especially in Florence where Dante‚Äôs bones aren‚Äôt: The Divine Comedy.

A glass of red wine, a seat outside, and a bit of people-watching paired with a book. It‚Äôs a great exercise to avoid reaching for your phone when you‚Äôre sitting alone.
The caf√© held me for about half an hour, soaking in the buzz of the street and the taste of the wine.
Once the last sip of Italian red was gone, I headed back to the Bulgari hotel to get my power bank. Yes, I was staying at the Bulgari hotel, and no, I can‚Äôt afford it. That‚Äôs a story for another time.
As I approach the reception, five people in uniform turn to face me.
I ask if I can grab something from my bags, which were stored in the luggage room, and a beautiful young man smiles at me, ‚ÄúOf course. Follow me.‚Äù
We walk into the room, and he leads me to my things.
‚ÄúOh, so you don‚Äôt need this. You know which ones they are.‚Äù I say quietly, as I glance down‚Ä¶

I first visited Rome with my family a few years back. We were planning to do the main touristy things, but when faced with the endless queue in St Peter‚Äôs Square, we had a change of plan and a wander down to the river instead.
I‚Äôd not done much research for the trip, unusual for me, but I wasn‚Äôt organising it ‚Äî my role was just to turn up and enjoy! So I had no idea what other attractions were within walking distance. But we were pretty sure there would be a cafe where we could sit and watch the world go by fairly close by.
We walked past the street sellers, their souvenirs spread out on tarpaulins, and approached the river. My attention was drawn to the building on my left, first the light stone walls, then the darker brick of the heart of the castle, and I was hit by the strangest feeling of d√©j√† vu. I knew this building, it‚Äôs curved ramparts, the flagpole on top. But this was my first trip to Rome. Why was a place I‚Äôd never been to so familiar?

Title: Bringing Antiquity Back to Life
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

üåπ Jakarta-based independent online magazine ran by a few folks squeezed on time but a ton of interest. Featuring analyses in English and Indonesian.

--
Listen
Share
Rizky Bayuputra for LC Life
LE CITOYEN ‚Äî Ancient Rome is undoubtedly a civilisation to be looked upon. Albeit known for their ‚Äòpagan extravagance,‚Äô the ancient Romans did, however, conquer and create a nation state that ranged from the borders of Scotland to the deserts of Arabia, reaching its height in the 2nd century CE and influence modern western life more than any other ancient civilisation (alongside the Greeks). However, there are only a few good examples of films and TV series that depict Roman life as it should. Films such as Gladiator, despite its well-written plot, presented a lot of inaccuracies. Meanwhile, TV-series such as Spartacus were, well, rather vulgar ‚Äî not saying that Roman society wasn‚Äôt like that ‚Äî but for a historical TV show, it showed parts of Roman culture that should have been, let‚Äôs say, set behind curtains and exaggerated at that! However, one TV series has put me, as an avid enthusiast of all things Greco-Roman, to stop my various nitpicks and just sit down and enjoy. With an unbelievably stellar plot and deep research into Roman life, the HBO Series Rome (first launched in 2006), terribly underrated in comparison to the likes of Game of Thrones, is what I could say (and most historians do agree) a highly-authentic depiction of Roman life.
Albeit historians having pointed out a few inaccuracies (especially in the timeline), what HBO‚Äôs Rome brought was much better: authenticity. It immersed yourself into the world, made you care about the characters, and anxiously sit on your chair as you watch the series go on, waiting for what other secrets of Ancient Rome might be uncovered.
Overview
Over two seasons, the TV miniseries Rome follows Lucius Vorenus (played by Kevin McKidd) and Titus Pullo (played by Ray Stevenson), two soldiers of the Roman legion and therefore Roman citizens, as they go through turbulent times in Roman history. Vorenus and Pullo are both members of the plebeian class‚Äìor the common citizenry‚Äìof Rome back in the dying days of the Republic and so gives us a lot of new perspectives on ancient Roman life. While also following the high politics of Gaius Julius Caesar (played by Ciaran Hinds, who later featured in Game of Thrones as the wildling King, Mance Rayder), and his civil wars against Pompey, which is already a recurring theme as depicted by popular media, such as multiple films on the life of Caesar and most well-known the plays written by one William Shakespeare, it does not relieve us of the grit and severity of the common man‚Äôs life.
Historically, the Romans operated on a not-so-rigid class system dictated by ancestry and wealth. The three classes of Roman citizens, which are the Patricians, Equites (or Knights, who became important mid-level civil and military officials as well as cavalrymen), and Plebeians (common citizenry, who became tradesmen, merchants, artisans, rank-and-file soldiers), lived very different lives and worked different livelihoods. The Patricians, or the senatorial class, act as the primary ruling class during Republican times. Patrician families were allowed entry into the senate on the basis of their wealth and ancestry. Some Patrician families claim descent from the Gods (Caesar‚Äôs family, or the Julii Caesaris, claim their descent from the goddess Venus) despite their claim to a seat of senator is mostly based on their ancestry, drawing back to early or pre-Republican times. Famous senatorial ‚Äúgentes‚Äù (or clans) include that of the Cornelii (for¬†example, Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus, the victor of the Battle of Zama against Hannibal Barca in c. 202 BC), Junii (for example, the overthrower of the last King of Rome, Lucius Junius Brutus), the Porcii (Marcus Porcius Cato, famous Roman orator, though the younger one live in Caesar‚Äôs times).
Not surprisingly, descendants or the adopted benefactors of said gens lived in the timeframe depicted in Rome, represented by members of the Optimate faction, which consisted of traditionalist Roman senators who wanted to preserve oligarchic rule in defence of Republican institutions, including Scipio Metellus, Marcus Junius Brutus (descendant of said Brutus, played by Tobias Menzies, later as Edmure Tully in Game of Thrones), Gaius Cassius Longinus, and Marcus Porcius Cato the Younger, all serving under the charismatic brilliance of Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus, Caesar‚Äôs once-ally and nemesis. These characters go up against, in the damnably byzantine politics and battlefields of antiquity, the Populares faction, with Gaius Julius Caesar at its head, and Marcus Antonius (popularly known in his anglicised form of ‚ÄòMark Antony,‚Äô depicted as a fantasist, narcissist, brutal and temperamental soldier by Antony Purefoy‚Äôs brilliant acting) by his side.
The two main protagonists, Centurion Lucius Vorenus and Legionary Titus Pullo, are members of the Roman Thirteenth Legion, of whom Caesar led through his long Gallic wars. Rome goes through the plebeian lives of the two soldiers, introducing not only events in history, but also of Roman culture through daily life, something I found very interesting. As there are too many aspects of Roman life depicted within the HBO Series (and thus the corresponding budget, which was the reason why it was cancelled after its second season), we will take it from a few aspects and how every film set in a historical background or piece of literary fiction should take into account to bring said world into life.
Traditions and Religion
Roman religion and tradition is deeply ingrained within its society. Notably, the Roman state and religion were never seen as two different things by Roman society. The various cults and sects of the Roman pantheon, along with the various deities of Jupiter (the king of the gods, lord of the sky and thunder), Dis (god of the underworld, most notably used by soldiers and fighters especially in damning a certain thing), and even Vesta were depicted with superlative¬†detail. Note the sacrifices conducted in some episodes, the reading of omens, the praying to small figurines in a homely shrine, and the entry of one of Vorenus‚Äô daughter into the Vestal Virgins later on in the season.
The Vestal Virgins themselves were one of the most interesting parts of Roman tradition and religion; they were selected from highborn women at a very young age to enter priesthood and vowed to be chaste for the next 30 years in order to cultivate the sacred fire, located in the temple of Vesta. Vesta herself was the Roman goddess of the hearth, marked by the existence of Vesta‚Äôs sacred fire which must not be let out under any circumstances. Superstition was, that if the fire died, it meant that the goddess had abandoned her protection of Rome‚Äìmeaning that the infernal city itself was under grave danger.
Aside from religion, Rome also depicted many other Roman traditions, such as the patricians‚Äô obscene eating habits of lying down on sofa-like furniture while conversing and getting absolutely drunk as well as exceptionally extravagant, drug-filled orgies. One other interesting event in Rome was the marking of the coming-of-age. Every male Roman citizen was given the right to wear a toga at the age of sixteen (or seventeen, depending on which is closest to 15 March of the year) and therefore participate as adults in civil society. The depiction of Octavian‚Äôs (the future Roman Emperor Augustus) coming-of-age rite of passage was depicted at the near-end of season one, something that would drastically change his way of thought and vibrate his transition from boy to man so visible in the transition of seasons.
Also quite interesting was the portrayal of tradesman guilds. In the series, the Herald (the rather bulky fellow with iconic hand gestures) in the forum of Rome mentions in an ‚Äòadvertisement‚Äô of sorts, the Roman Guild of Bakers, while mention of guilds of smiths of some sort took place throughout the series.
Aside from Roman religion, Jews were also featured. Timon (Lee Boardman), one of the supporting characters, is depicted as a cutthroat sellsword serving Atia of the Julii (Polly Walker), in more than one way. He is dragged in a conspiracy when the Tetrarch of Galilee (Jewish Royalty) arrives in Rome for ‚Äòadminsitrative business.‚Äô
Military Service and Tactics
Military service was a large part of Roman life. Soldiering was considered honourable and serving Rome was, after all, a citizen‚Äôs unwritten obligation. In the dying days of the Republic, the Romans had already established a professional volunteer army (in comparison to levied troops, which was the system that prevailed up into the 18th century), allowing the fighting of successive wars all across her borders and the gradual expansion of the Pax Romana. Citizen-soldiers like Pullo and Vorenus were obliged with 20 years‚Äô service and were entitled to a percentage of booty and war prizes. After retirement, ‚Äòold legionaries‚Äô may sign up again to become evocati, or veteran troops, serving as the crack troops held in reserve in battles, who earned multiple times the wage of a normal soldier and were immune to menial duties. This took place when Vorenus decided to take Mark Antony‚Äôs offer to join his army as a ‚ÄòPrefect of the Evocati Cohort,‚Äô a traditionally equestrian position, of which Vorenus had achieved (Equestrian status was achievable after the ownership of 10,000 sesterces in assets, after all). He also had to go through an interesting rite of passage to get it.
Roman military tactics were depicted according to commentaries of the time, such as the Comentarii de Bello Gallico by Caesar. Roman legionaries fought in close formation, standardly going in formation 10-across and 8-deep (in a rectangular formation of 80 men each, called a century). With shields raised, legionaries covered their sectors, and watched for each other. Upon a certain amount of time, the centurion would blow a whistle to signify the change of the foremost front man, and the first-ranker quickly switched to the man behind him. This allowed equal distribution of the fighting, thus allowing Roman legionaries to fight longer than their counterparts. This was depicted well in the opening scene (perhaps the Battle of Alesia) and the epic Battle of Phillipi (in the second series) between Brutus and the second Triumvirate (Octavian Caesar, Antony, and Lepidus). Uniforms and arms were also accurate to the era, with the Roman soldiers wearing in variation of military tunics in scarlet and off-white (undyed) colours, while wearing lorica hamata or mail cuirass, instead of the inaccurately portrayed lorica segmentata (segmented plate armour cuirass) often used in games and films. This type of armour was not used in the time of Caesar, however, and came in the later Imperial period of the first century to third century AD, in limited use. The ‚Äòsquare‚Äô Roman shield (scutum), the pilum and pila (throwables or javelins), and the gladius hispanensis (Spanish sword), the Celt-inspired republican helmet (galea) along with the not-so-famous Roman sarcina, or luggage, which each legionary brought their own, were also pictured widely.
Turmoil and Squalor
Viewers could often see the tough-living, dirty, and ragged streets of Rome, then one of the most populous and advanced cities throughout the Mediterranean. Even the home of the Vorenii, where Lucius Vorenus and his family lived, was not as fancy as one would think of the ‚Äòextravagant‚Äô Romans. Many of the citizens of Rome lived in poverty and in a state of squalor; murder was not uncommon, and gang fights over disputes were perhaps the way most citizens preferred it to be finished. Courts of law did exist in Rome, but not really portrayed within the TV series.
Another interesting fact was that the Romans often used grafitti to express themselves. Naturally, due to this, the walls of the small streets in Rome were decorated with entertaining, and sometimes perverse, pictures courtesy of Your Fellow Citizen.
Clothing and Fashion
Roman society also had its dress codes. Formal occasions were marked by the wearing of the toga (broad, purple-stripe for senators, two stripes for equestrian/knights, and a plain white for plebeians) for men, although in day-to-day life, a tunic‚Äìa piece of cloth that went down to above the knees‚Äìwere worn. For the regular citizen, these tunics were mostly plain and sometimes dyed, though for nobility, the tunic was often decorated with embroidery to display status. The Romans did live by the code ‚Äòyou are what you wear‚Äô‚Äìperhaps something that lives down to Italians today.
For women, the stola was the most common dress, in tandem with the toga. Stolae were somehow a timeless piece, with variations worn from the times of the mid-republic (3rd century BC) up to the late Byzantine Empire (15th century AD). Women who wore the stola were seen as graceful and honourable, and this was depicted in the various forms of the stola, from a light, near-transparent garment to the rich deep red and/or other colours of whatever Atia of the Julii (a depiction of a woman of extravagance) wore throughout the series. Stola were mostly worn by married women, to display modesty and maturity. Younger women often wore tunics inspired by the Greek chiton (as were many parts of Roman culture).
Despite in a short space of two seasons, it was remarkable how much of ancient Rome was able to be portrayed by the series. The antics of Titus Pullo, the stoicism of Lucius Vorenus, the extravagance of Mark Antony, the grace and shrewdness of Cleopatra, the smart power-plays of Caesar, and the idealism of Brutus were all depicted well within Rome. Although it was cancelled, it had managed to amaze many ancient history enthusiasts with its authenticity and exploration of each character through personal and interpersonal conflicts. If you want to create a period drama, just write for fun, or want to binge watch something exceptionally, and I say again, exceptionally, good, Le Citoyen highly recommends HBO‚Äôs Rome.
Plus, if you‚Äôre waiting for Game of Thrones‚Äô final season, and want to watch a series of a such (but based on real events), go watch it. Wherever you can. Go! Go!
Salutations.
RB.

Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus.
I know what you‚Äôre thinking.
What a name!
I agree.
Sadly, the man with this name is responsible for a lot of naughty nonsense.
First off, he murdered his own mother.
If that wasn‚Äôt enough, he also murdered his first wife.
And his second wife?
Kicked her to death while she was pregnant.
Yeah, we‚Äôre dealing with a monstrosity.
Sadly, his cruelty wasn‚Äôt just reserved for his close family members.
He also used to host parties where he‚Äôd light people on fire (usually Christians) while he and his guests would frolic to fiddle music.
All while, Rome was engulfed in flames.
The guy was a psycho.
And in this article, I‚Äôm going to go all in on the lad known as Nero: Rome‚Äôs most notorious emperor.
Nero was the fifth Roman emperor, ruling from 54 AD to 68 AD.

Listen, I love Rome. I really do but now that we‚Äôre more or less free to travel again, I feel compelled to fill you in on the Eternal City. Masochists will love it. So will anybody else drawn to stress and anxiety. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, Rome has a lot of things going for it. Historical buildings, pizza, magnificent museums, pizza, stunning churches, pizza. Yet there are a few trouble spots that can turn a Roman holiday into a Roman nightmare.
Rome is always crowded and those walking tours led by tour guides with flags or umbrellas only make things worse. These human centipedes shuffle, and I do mean shuffle, along the sidewalk and hold up the rest of us with places to go. Title: Book Review: Are We Rome? The Fall of an Empire and the Fate of America by Cullen Murphy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Is America the new Roman Empire, and if so, will it meet the same fate? This book argues that America and Rome are similar in terms of their psychology and soft power, from the way Washington and Rome view themselves as the center of their worlds, to the global and historical impacts of their cultures. In the beginning, Murphy notes Freud‚Äôs comparison of the human psyche and the ruins of Rome, the possibility of histories existing simultaneously rather than one after the other. It‚Äôs a theme that runs throughout each chapter as Murphy compares the militaries, borders, people, and cultures of Rome and America. Considering how much Roman culture and iconography shape the ways Americans symbolize and discuss their own power, it really does seem like Rome and America exist together. However, Murphy posits that America‚Äôs capability for relatively rapid social transformation (especially in just two centuries) is what separates it from its doomed predecessor, and what will save it from the same fate. I‚Äôd pick this book up if you‚Äôre interested in learning how the cultural and psychological power of empires expands beyond centuries. In the end you‚Äôll definitely wonder if Rome ever did fall.

Rome is a city of amazing pizza, pasta, and gelato, but if you‚Äôre looking for a healthy break from all those delicious carbs, here are 4 great places where you can get fresh juices and smoothies:
Esco Sazio ‚Äî This adorable little shop offers completely organic juices and smoothies, in addition to healthy sandwiches and salads. Swing on one of their wooden swings as you drink your juice and enjoy the chalkboard-meets-chandelier ambiance. Our girls loved the chocolate banana protein smoothie, and I enjoyed my tropical juice with pineapple and guava.
Via dei Banchi Vecchi, 135, 00186 Roma, Italy
Pronto ‚Äî We stumbled across this restaurant in Rome‚Äôs Monti neighborhood, near the Colosseum, and stopped in when we saw their ‚Äúfresh juices‚Äù sign. Their fruit is freshly chopped, juiced, and blended (if you get juice with pears in it) right in front of you, and the three juices that we tried were all fantastic. You can take your juice outside and hang out at the fountain with the locals while you drink it and take in the area‚Äôs energetic vibe.
Via dei Serpenti, 163, Roma
Aromaticus ‚Äî This restaurant is also in the trendy Monti area, and they serve fresh juices and clean, mostly raw and unprocessed foods (salads, hummus, beef tartare, etc.). The shop itself is cute and hip, decorated with vintage cookbooks and selling potted herbs and gardening supplies, and the food and juice are excellent. The pineapple-mint juice was one of the best juices I‚Äôve ever had, so perfectly sweet and delicious, and Joshua loved his Greek salad with pita bread, hummus, cherry tomatoes, olives, and feta cheese.
Via Urbana, 134, 00184 Roma, Italy
AllBiOne ‚Äî Self-described as ‚Äúorganic street food‚Äù, AllBiOne serves organic juices, cut-up fresh fruit, and 14 different kinds of organic meatballs‚Ä¶ everything from beef and tomato or chicken and curry to vegetarian eggplant parmesan or ricotta and pecorino cheese balls. Everything we ate was tasty, but I highly recommend the cheese ‚Äúmeat‚Äùballs, and the juices we got were fresh and delicious.
The restaurant is a short walk from the Colosseum, and the owner is really friendly ‚Äî he overheard us talking about wanting strawberries in a juice for the girls, and he offered to make a strawberry-apple-orange juice for them that wasn‚Äôt listed on the board; it turned out to be perfect for them!
Largo Corrado Ricci, 34, Roma, Italy

Title: Did the Founders of Rome Really Come from Troy?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
As is well-known, Rome was founded by the legendary brothers Romulus and Remus, who originated from Alba Longa and belonged to one of the Latin tribes. However, as Rome grew into a vast and powerful state, the Romans decided having only local Italian shepherds among their ancestors wasn‚Äôt very prestigious. It would be much cooler if the Romans descended from a well-known, celebrated people in legends, even better ‚Äî from a great hero. And they found such a heroic ancestor. He was Aeneas, a hero from Troy who left his homeland after the city‚Äôs fall.
This legend did not immediately become widely accepted among the Romans. The 1st-century BC Greek historian Dionysius of Halicarnassus presents three versions of the Roman origins he knew: Italy, Libya, and Greece. In the last case, he refers to Greek colonists who had long lived on the Apennine Peninsula. However, Dionysius favored the view that the Romans were of mixed Greek-Italian origin. At the same time, Dionysius mentions the Roman version that Romulus and Remus were sons of Aeneas, implying that Rome was built by the second generation of Trojan refugees.
