Title: Buried Alive: What Happened When a Vestal Virgin Broke Her Oath of Chastity in Ancient Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

For now, a place to collect my own writings about the ancient Mediterranean, aka The Classics. I may soon aim to expand it into a multi-writer publication. For lovers of ancient Rome and Greece.

--
2
Listen
Share
The Vestal Virgins inhabited a unique space in Roman society. They were the most prominent women in Rome, heavily revered and with privileges no other woman was given. But they also lived with extreme duties and restrictions. Their most famous restriction is obvious from their title: every Vestal was unmarried and pledged to remain a virgin through her thirty-year term of service. And a Vestal who broke her oath of chastity was buried alive.
But how often was this extreme measure used? And when it was, what did it look like? I have been researching Vestals for a few years as I work on a historical fiction novel centered around one (coming soon, I hope), and I‚Äôve had to get into the nitty gritty details. Here‚Äôs what we know about the ultimate punishment for Rome‚Äôs most sacred virgins.
Before we bury one alive, let‚Äôs make sure we know who the Vestals were.
People ignore Vesta, but she‚Äôs one of my favorite goddesses, and was one of the Romans‚Äô favorites too. Her duty doesn‚Äôt sound like a big deal today ‚Äî goddess of the hearth, the fireplace. Modern people tend to think, ‚Äúwhy have a goddess for that?‚Äù But for the ancients, the fireplace wasn‚Äôt just something to get cozy by to drink hot chocolate. It was the source of fire for the house, meaning the light for their lamps and the heat that cooked their food. Without Vesta‚Äôs flame, a house was vulnerable and unlivable. Vesta made a house into a home.
Sure Vesta isn‚Äôt as splashy as some other deities ‚Äî she‚Äôs a virgin goddess so she doesn‚Äôt have relationship drama, and she‚Äôs a guardian of the home so she doesn‚Äôt leave to have adventures. But to the ancients she was steadfast and ever-present, a goddess without whom life would have been impossible.
Vesta‚Äôs private role as protector and life giver to the household was reflected in her public worship. There was a shrine to Vesta in the Forum Romanum¬π tended by the Vestal Virgins, who kept her sacred flame burning. Just as a house must have a hearth to make it a home, Rome was not Rome if the eternal flame was not burning ‚Äî the flame represented the safety of Rome, and the favor of the gods that allowed Rome to hold its vast conquered empire. It took 24-hour maintenance to keep the sacred flame from going out. The Vestals also prepared the sacred grain/salt mixture that was sprinkled on the head of every sacrificial animal, so in a real way, Roman religion would have been nothing without them.
This legal status of the Vestals was unlike any other woman‚Äôs in Rome. For the ancient Romans, one of the essential characteristics of a woman was male control: she belonged to either her father or her husband. Widows with no living father had to pass into the legal control of a living male relative.¬≤ Unfortunately, the notion of women belonging to men is not strange to us. But male control of women was much more deeply entrenched in the Roman legal code than it ever has been in ours, and freeing the Vestals from that control put them into a shadow category, a zone that was neither masculine nor feminine. They could make wills and testify in court, which other women could not because they weren‚Äôt considered autonomous. They were also sacrosanct ‚Äî it was illegal for men to touch them ‚Äî and bizarrely sacred ‚Äî if a Vestal accidentally met a man on his way to execution, his life would be spared.
After their thirty years were up, Vestals could do as they wished. Many chose to marry (and apparently men really loved marrying former Vestals, which seems like a lot we could unpack but I‚Äôm choosing not to). But many chose to continue their legal limbo ‚Äî if she married, the former Vestal rejoined Roman society as a wife, reentered male control in the household of her new husband. An unmarried former Vestal was still a woman apart, the only truly autonomous woman in ancient Rome.
In short, Vestals were separate from Roman society, even as they lived in the middle of it. They were separated legally, and they were separated from close contact. They were not Romans really, but something else‚Ä¶ they were representatives of all Romans, and of Rome itself.
medium.com
But I promised I‚Äôd tell you what happened when a Vestal Virgin was convicted of violating her oath of chastity. For a Vestal, having sex was a betrayal of her promise to Vesta, an act which would put the safety of Rome in jeopardy. The virginity of average Roman girls and women was controlled in similar (though not identical) ways as in many societies today, but that‚Äôs not really what was going on with the Vestals. A Vestal‚Äôs purity was supposed to be a requirement for the proper public worship of Vesta, and Vesta‚Äôs worship guaranteed the safety of Rome. So an ‚Äúimproper‚Äù Vestal would lead to a loss of favor with Vesta for all of Rome ‚Äî big trouble.
The accusation of inchastity could come in a few forms. It might come from a man ‚Äî from someone who had heard of an affair, or maybe (though less likely for reasons that will soon be obvious) from the man who‚Äôd had sex with her himself, in a moment of repentance.
But, since a Vestal having sex was supposed to be an affront to the gods, the accusation might also come in the form of prodigies. Prodigies were messages from the gods in the form of unexplainable and supernatural events ‚Äî calves born with two heads, lightning striking prominent monuments, etc. Two examples that stick in my mind are a soldier‚Äôs shield falling from the sky and a fully intact human head being found in the ground when digging a foundation. Prodigies sent the Romans to their priests, who would interpret the message and tell the citizens what action the gods required from them.
Some prodigies were good, but many (perhaps even most) threatened doom unless the gods were appeased. And sometimes the omens pointed a finger at the Vestal Virgins, and one or more of them would be accused of violating their oaths without any earthly evidence.
After the accusation, a trial. This was not the same as the trial of a citizen: it was a religious trial with the Pontifex Maximus as judge and the Pontifical College as jury.¬≥ The priests would vote to convict or acquit. If they convicted her, the Vestal would be executed.
The doomed Vestal was carried, gagged, through the streets in a litter that had its coverings fastened down with cords; she could be neither seen nor heard. Crowds followed the litter, but it was apparently a solemn and silent occasion. She was brought to a tomb buried under a ridge of earth near the Colline Gate, on the north side of the city. Paradoxically, the tomb of disgraced Vestals was the only tomb allowed to be inside the city walls.
The tomb was stocked with provisions: bread, water, milk, oil, a lamp, and a bed, as if the Vestal was expected to go on living inside. Her litter was unbound and she was led, heavily veiled, to the steps to her tomb. Then the Pontifex Maximus said a prayer, and all the pontifices would avert their eyes as the Vestal went down, to avoid witnessing the moment of shame.
The tomb was buried, and the Vestal was left to die down there, no grave marker to commemorate her improper death.
The Vestal‚Äôs lover would then be subjected to a public flogging. Whipping was a common punishment ‚Äî the pain was part of the point, but it was more about the public shaming. These floggings could leave the man alive, or they could be carried to the point of his death. Or, if her lover saw all this coming, he might just flee into self-imposed exile.
It was common for upper-class men in Rome to escape into exile if they knew they were about to receive a punishment that would either a) permanently mar their reputation or b) kill them. Rome tolerated this sort of thing and made no effort to hunt down the fugitives ‚Äî a man who saw a trial turning against him would often leave town at night and face no consequence other than his loss of status. In the eyes of the ancient nobility, that loss of status was punishment enough‚Ä¶ but when you put it on a scale next to ‚Äúburied alive,‚Äù yeah, not so much. It was very possible for a man to escape with his life if he were accused of sleeping with a Vestal, and very difficult for the Vestal herself to do the same.
medium.com
The live burial of a Vestal was, importantly, bloodless. The Romans didn‚Äôt kill the Vestal ‚Äî they put her in a room with the essentials of life to sustain her, and she died without their intervention. (Yes, I am aware they buried her in there; this is ritual, not logic.) It also offered the convenient out that the goddess could, if she so chose, save her priestess and prove her innocence. (I‚Äôm not sure if this was something the ancient Romans thought or just a modern supposition.)
The burial can also be meaningfully thought of as a human sacrifice. The gods were upset, and the Romans were offering up one of their holiest priestesses to soothe them. Human sacrifice was unthinkable to the Romans of classical times, but many of their religious rituals had much older roots in prehistory. Meanings got twisted and lost. The Vestal Virgin might originally have been a scapegoat, which would explain why she was kept so carefully between categories: she was no one‚Äôs wife and no one‚Äôs daughter, so she had no family to demand retribution for her death.
This quality of being outside categorization, and thus available as a sacrifice, might also explain why the Vestals had to be virgins in the first place. In a society in which a woman‚Äôs identity was totally dependent on her relationships with men, the sacred virgin stood apart. When they worshipped Vesta, the Vestals acted for the entire city: they could not represent the daughters, wives, or mothers of Rome (as other priestesses did); they had to be blank slates, to represent all Rome. Virginity meant lack of connections.
In short, a properly chaste Vestal was Rome itself. For the Romans, her purity was the safety of Rome, and when she lost it ‚Äî when she slipped out of her symbolic role and back into worldly society by coming under the sexual ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù of a man ‚Äî she had to forfeit her life as a sort of sacrifice to appease the gods. This she did in a method devoid of the kind of violence that would have sullied her further.
The immurement of a Vestal was a very rare occurrence. We only know of a few instances in all of Roman history.
Most of the Vestals who went on trial in the historical record were acquitted, not executed. In early history, we get the story of two Vestals who miraculously saved themselves from accusations of wrongdoing. When Vesta‚Äôs flame went out (usually interpreted as a sign of Vestal wrongdoing), the Vestal Aemilia threw her sash on it and it miraculously roared back to life, saving her. And a Vestal named Tuccia in the 3rd century BCE cleared her name by carrying water across the city in a sieve without spilling a drop. Vestals, as holy women, were supposed to be able to work miracles. Continuing to work miracles proved the continuing favor of Vesta, meaning they must still be virgins. (How or if these magic tricks fit into the formalized trial structure, I‚Äôll never know.)
In 114 BCE came a bizarre prodigy: the young daughter of a prominent Equestrian was struck by lightning while riding her horse, and was found dead with her tongue sticking out and her dress hiked to her waist. Officials interpreted this as a sign of a scandal between an Equestrian and a Vestal Virgin. (Obvious, right?)
Three Vestals were accused: they said that Aemilia (not to be confused with the earlier miracle-worker) had become corrupt herself and then led the other two, Marcia and Licinia, into vice with her. Aemilia was convicted by the Pontifical College and executed, but the other two were acquitted.
What followed was outrage. The Roman people were convinced that there was a conspiracy of priests covering up the widespread corruption of the Vestal Virgins, and that the other two Vestals were also guilty. So in 113, a Tribune held another trial for the other two Vestals, moving it out of the Pontifical College and into the traditional court system. This trial resulted in a guilty verdict, and Marcia and Licinia were also executed.‚Å¥
Emperor Domitian executed four Vestal Virgins starting in 87 CE. This was part of a push toward cracking down on public morality: like many reformers before and after, Domitian believed that people‚Äôs morals weren‚Äôt what they used to be, and that he could bring back the good old ways by punishing people for acting wrong. (Yeesh.) Domitian was also notoriously hostile toward the senate,‚Åµ and since the Vestals were the daughters of senatorial houses, killing them was a way to show the nobility who was boss. Since the emperor was always Pontifex Maximus, Domitian ran the trials and had no trouble securing convictions.
The first three convicted Vestals were actually not buried alive. Domitian allowed them to choose their method of execution. Only for the last, the Chief Vestal Cornelia in 91, did he insist on the ancient punishment. Which makes for an interesting point: we don‚Äôt know if the Vestal executions I described earlier were by burial. As far as I can tell, Cornelia is the only verifiable instance we have of a Vestal being buried alive. We know that the Romans considered this the ancient, traditional punishment, but we don‚Äôt know of anyone else it happened to.
Cornelia used the big public spectacle of her immurement as a platform. She announced to the crowd before the descended the steps: ‚ÄúCaesar thinks me unchaste, me who performed the sacraments under which he won, he triumphed?‚Äù Because, of course, a successful Domitian meant the favor of Vesta; if the empire was doing well, then surely that meant Cornelia was actually innocent.
On her way down, Cornelia stumbled, and the soldier accompanying her put out a hand automatically to help her. But Cornelia kept her balance without him and shied away from his touch ‚Äî a sign to those watching (according to Pliny the Younger who recorded the incident) that this Vestal was so chaste she would not even accept the sacrilege of a man‚Äôs touch on the way to her execution.
And that‚Äôs about it for historical examples. There are vague insinuations of other Vestal executions, and concrete details of many other trials that resulted in acquittals, but we only have that handful of confirmed Vestal deaths, only one of them definitely by live burial. So though this sensational and very public punishment cast a long shadow over the lives of thousands upon thousands of Vestals who would never experience it, actual instances were vanishingly rare.
Which leaves us with two possibilities:
I‚Äôm inclined toward option 1 ‚Äî probably there were instances of option 2, but the Rome I know was sincere enough in its religious beliefs that I have a hard time believing they were all openly flaunting tradition but not writing about it. I also think that the Roman men who wrote the histories had a hard time believing in a group of women who are uninterested in sex, and felt it necessary to imply that there had to be something going on there (when really, the something was worshipping Vesta). But historically, of course, it‚Äôs unknowable.
The Vestals were women who lived outside Roman society even in its very heart. From them we can learn much about Roman religion and Roman womanhood ‚Äî and we can glimpse the sinister reasons for the policing of their virginities. The Romans held the Vestals up high when they were shining examples of Rome‚Äôs piety, and struck them down as low as they could when they became evidence of Rome‚Äôs corruption. The Vestal Virgins may have been the six most important women in all of Rome.
¬πWe usually call it the Temple of Vesta, but a Roman temple had to be planned out by augury (which Vesta‚Äôs wasn‚Äôt) and traditionally contained a statue of the deity (which Vesta‚Äôs didn‚Äôt). It was also rather small.
¬≤In actual practice, such widows were usually fairly independent. But the fact remains that there was a legal requirement that they be in a man‚Äôs control.
¬≥The Vestals were part of the Pontifical College, so the Vestals who had not been accused would have voted on the guilt or innocence of their colleague. Roman juries did not have the same ideas around impartiality as ours ‚Äî in fact, it was considered an advantage if members of the jury to know the accused well, since their opinion of their character had weight in the case!
‚Å¥This was a big move, the imposition of the civil government into what was supposed to be a religious matter. The boundaries between state and religion were a lot more porous than they (ideally) are today, but still ‚Äî it was an insult to the priests, whom the politicians accused of not being able to handle their duties.
‚ÅµThere‚Äôs a probably-untrue anecdote in Cassius Dio in which Domitian invited senators to dinner and had gravestones for each of them made to put in their seats.

A Place to Be Funny Without Being a Jerk

Member-only story
--
Share
January 2, 2022|Italy
Today was a quiet day. We said goodbye to granny‚Äôs apartment in Assisi and boarded the train to Rome, our final stop in Italy.
The train trip from Assisi to Rome is not nearly as picturesque as the trip from Florence to Assisi. Fewer vineyards, fewer olive groves, fewer castles, no snow-capped peaks in the distance. We did see a few notable sites, however. In particular, we passed by Trevi (the town, not the fountain) which is one of those classic medieval towns where the church is on the peak of a hill and the rest of the town seems to tumble down the hillside.
We also passed by some random towers and fortifications that don‚Äôt seem to be guarding anything more interesting than a parking lot and a smattering of houses these days.
As we approached Rome, the surroundings, unsurprisingly, got more industrial and grittier. We passed by nondescript apartment blocks and graffiti that could have been in almost any city in the world.
We arrived a Termini station and seemed to walk for a mile to get to the exit. Then we hopped into a cab which proceeded to gouge us unconscionably. I‚Äôm too irritated to go into detail but it‚Ä¶

Title: 3 Days in Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
TLDR; I describe only this first stop of a recent 2-week trip to Italy ‚Äî partly because of the initial strong and quintessential impressions I formed in this my first-time trip to Italy, and partly because the other dozen or so cities I visited which the reader can probably guess mostly echoed and nuanced these impressions.
Disclaimer: this is not meant to be fully representative of what you should expect when travelling in Rome. In fact it is probably a quite biased series of observations privy to my own meanderings, but I must say these feel very genuine and idiosyncratic of the city. All photos are unedited originals, and no AI was employed in the writing of this article. So Italians, feel free to bawl me out in the comments!
I am not an untraveled citizen of the world ‚Äî ‚Äî I‚Äôve lived and toured all over Russia and China for years, for example ‚Äî yet there are hundreds of countries I‚Äôve never been to. Italy, for example! I realize this may be the exception to the rule for most Americans who can afford to cross oceans for travel, as Europe is a ready destination, whether to enjoy a summer out of school or participate in an exchange program because the cultural and linguistic barriers are lower than for Asia or Africa, for example.
Yet, I did not take preparation for this trip lightly. As I had done in my previous travels, I prepared as much as I could for the language, as I feel it is best to try to speak the local tongue not only out of respect for the people but also to enrich your own experience. Before traveling to Russia and China, for example, I had become fluent in those languages by my tried and true method. But for those I had a few years to spend, whereas this time I had just a few weeks. After skimming a long treatise on Italian grammar, I decided it was hopeless to memorize all the rules. I figured I would be best served in this time frame getting the gist of pronunciation and some basic phrases: what seemed to work well was opening up Google Street View to random locations in Italy, trying to guess the meaning of any signs or writing (graffiti included!) and speaking into Google Translate to check my pronunciation. Sometimes I was way off, but this made it fun! I also got some ‚Äòstreet smarts‚Äô of what to expect in random city locations. (Later on I had fun actually doing this live when traveling through city streets:
)
More formally, I transcribed Youtube videos (with captions to check my work) to polish listening comprehension. This is so much better than the old days of transcribing radio, and there‚Äôs a semi-infinite supply of great captioned videos out there. It‚Äôs nice that the graph shows, umm, statistically detectable progress over time!
I was still, however, pathetically prepared for the language. Luckily it is a Romance Language and thus not too far from English and Spanish, of which I know a little, so I could in principle struggle by. BUT, most importantly, essentially everyone we met in Rome spoke English! And when English didn‚Äôt pass the bar, they spoke Chinese! No joke, there is a sizable Chinese population in Rome running hotels, restaurants, taxis, and small shops, and I could converse with them absolutely fine!
Now the reader can imagine the usual hassle of international travel culminating in a teleportation to another reality outside the Fiumicino Airport. It looked not too dissimilar from JFK, to be honest. A Chinese driver picked us up, and we grilled him on all the ins and outs of living in Italy what with driving, shopping, eating, avoiding pick-pockets, etc. (he in fact spoke absolutely no Italian despite living there 14 years ‚Ä¶ that just shows you how strong the Chinese community is there!).
And I now transition to a series of disconnected, but in my view very profound, observations during my travel in Rome. What you will not see is any canned, touristy photos of say, the Colosseum.
Ah well, you‚Äôll forgive me that one.
Every city has history, but in Rome it stares you in the face at every street corner. I mean, you‚Äôre walking along the street minding your own business and then the Pantheon is just there in front of you!
And plenty of modern shops and restaurants surrounding it from which to enjoy the view! (NB: these are usually not the better, more authentic restaurants).
Now this one really gets me, I mean is it just improbable or does this kind of thing happen every day: I‚Äôm walking through the park next to the Roman Forum, in the baking sun with my sandals feeling very historic and all, on a wide, dusty dirt path that must be trodden daily by thousands of tourists, and look down to pick up a dirty penny. I‚Äôm joking to myself, naw, could it be? Rubbing off the dirt, it is indeed no ordinary penny: it looks ancient! Well after some Google Image search it looks quite possibly to be not thousands of years old, but at least 200‚Äì300 years (a Vatican copper Quattrino from 1745?). Could also be a forgery to dupe stupid tourists like me, but I‚Äôve been shown plenty of forgeries in my travels and they generally look good, with letters clearly visible and such, whereas this one looks a little too worn and bent by thousands of people stepping on it to make the trick worth it (probably about $10 by my reckoning based on eBay offers for ones in much better condition). Not a treasure exactly, and in its current foot-abused state of negligible archeological value (else I would have, ahem, turned it in to the authorities) but to grasp history serendipitously, and why me? Why now? This just made my day!
There‚Äôs no way I can do justice to the sheer volume of Classical Art in Rome, so I won‚Äôt even try. The Capitoline Museum, Borghese, countless cathedrals, ‚Ä¶ you will be overwhelmed by it, eyes and soul beaten to pure submission so you can barely issue a yelp of protest at the beauty in which you‚Äôre drowning. I will only say that on my first day in Rome I waited 2 hours in line to get into the Vatican Museum, and I have absolutely no regrets. Seeing this was an absolute ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù moment for me:
And sorry, no pictures of the Sistine Chapel (it‚Äôs forbidden) to which this mere hallway led ‚Äî ‚Äî when you emerge into it you simply gawk in awe upwards at Adam touching the hand of God and the surrounding universe of imagery and forget where you came from.
Hidden Gems
Walking through the streets of Rome is like no other city I‚Äôve been in. I mean New York is fast and vibrant, San Francisco friendly and upbeat, but Rome surprises you in a very peaceful, contemplative way. Like casually looking to your right, you see an alleyway entrance to an apartment building, and there‚Äôs a classical statue at the end in a little garden. Very nice!
Now this building across the street is most interesting, and the guard looks rightly serious about his job:
My usual gripe on the shortage of public restrooms in modern cities applies, but if you‚Äôre thirsty there‚Äôs a very nice thing in Rome: public fountains!
It has admittedly been decades since I dared drink from a public water fountain in the U.S., where the stale metallic quality in e.g. Central Park is like from a gym locker, but the water out of those Roman fountains is definitely decent! (after observing many others drinking first, of course).
I have to say I was not impressed with many of my compatriots (surmised by their accents) along the way ‚Äî ‚Äî one family accused us of ‚Äòcutting the line‚Äô at the Colosseum, which was patently false, and quite publicly made a ridiculous holier-than-thou scene of it. At restaurants there was almost always a very loud table of Americans with the worst language I have heard outside a drunken frat party. And at the Pantheon one very American-looking woman marched right up to the guard well after closing time and demanded ‚ÄúI want to go in there!‚Äù If the patience of the Romans hasn‚Äôt caved in by now, it must only be due to the compensating dollars rolling in, but that makes me a bit ashamed.
All I will say is I had pizza every day and never got sick of it! And that was of course just 1% of what we enjoyed ‚Ä¶

Title: Great Runs in Rome
Content:

Ultimate Guide to the Best Places to Run in the World's Major Cities and Destinations. www.greatruns.com @greatruns by Mark Lowenstein

--
2
Listen
Share
Rome is one of the world‚Äôs great cities to visit. Filled with antiquities, wonderful historic sites, lovely old neighborhoods and great restaurants, it‚Äôs also a fantastic walking city. The running scene has been improving. Yes, there are busy, traffic-choked roads, tangled lanes difficult to navigate, and the air quality can be poor in the summer ‚Äî but there are great places to run within proximity to where most travelers stay. Highlights of Rome running include a nearly 9-mile ‚ÄúRome Sights‚Äù tour, including some of the principal landmarks and historic sites (go early or on Sundays!). Running along the Tiber River can be a pleasure, especially since a bike path along part of it was put in a few years ago. Rome‚Äôs three largest parks - Borghese, Ada, and Pamphili are also terrific for running. And running on the historic Via Appia Antica and the Parco de Caffarella is one of the most unique runs in the world.
Running in Rome will undoubtedly incorporate some of its famous ‚Äúseven hills‚Äù east of the Tiber, as well as Vatican Hill and Janiculum northwest of the river. In terms of public transport, there is are two metro lines, which go round rather than through the historic city. There‚Äôs an extensive bus system.
Rome‚Äôs weather is Mediterranean. Summers are hot and dry and can be uncomfortable for running. Spring and fall is almost perfect for running. Winters are mild to cool but rarely cold, with moderate rain. Snow and freezing temperatures are rare.
8.6 miles,with options. Start: near St. Peter‚Äôs Square or any point. MAP
This is an attempt to put together a tour of some of Rome‚Äôs principal sights. Best to do it early before the streets get crowded and to beat the heat. See this as a ‚Äòcity tour‚Äô, and take your time! The map starts at Ospedale Santo Spirito, right near St. Peter‚Äôs Square, or at any point convenient to where you‚Äôre staying. The route follows the outskirts of St. Peter‚Äôs and Vatican City (without going into it). Then, just off Via Crescenzio is Castel St. Angelo. Cross the Ponte Cavour, over to the Spanish Steps and the Piazza de Spagna. Then, over to the Trevi Fountain and the Piazza Venezia & Piazza St. Marco. Skirt the Capitoline and the Roman Forum by running along Via dei Fori Imperiali to do a tour of the Coloseum, and then through the Circus Maximus.
Shorter option: take a right out of the Circus Maximus and head over to the famous Ponte Palatino. Cross the bridge and return to St. Peter‚Äôs along the river path.,Longer option: takes you through the Trastevere area, near the Passeggiata del Gianicolo, and via Garibaldi back down to the river. Add on even more by going up to Villa Doria Pamphili park.
7 miles ONE-WAY. MAP Start: North: Stado Olimpico. South: Ponte Guglielmo Marconi
Running along the Tiber River in Rome is a great way to go for a run and see the city without dealing with traffic and intersections. Several years ago, the city completed a bike path that runs nearly 7 miles from near Olympic Stadium to Ponte Guglielmo Marconi.
The trail runs through the heart of the most visited sections of the city, but below the roads. It‚Äôs a great way to do a dedicated run or to use it as a link to other sites or routes. Note that the path can get flooded fairly easily, often leaving behind a muddy mess. The northern section of the path officially starts south of Olympic Stadium but we start the run at the stadium, since it‚Äôs a thrill to see it and do a lap around the track. The southern section concludes at the Ponte Guglielmo Marconi. It is also possible to run on the eastern section of the Tiber.
7 miles Out and Back. Start: Circus Maximus Metro Station. MAP
The Appian Way is one of the earliest and most strategic roads of the Roman Republic. Sections of it remain, and it makes for a one-of-a-kind run. Even the marathon in the 1960 Rome Olympics had a section on this road. On a map, it is called ‚ÄúVia Appia Antica‚Äù. The surface is the original stone slab, which can be a challenging surface after a time. However, there is a path alongside for much of the way to ease the run. It is possible to run about six miles south to the perimeter road. The road is generally quiet and is closed to cars on Sundays. Our route starts at the Circus Maximus metro station. A nice option is a loop around the Circus Maximus or use the river path. Viale delle Terme di Caracalla is a good option on the return.
A great option is to combine the Appia with the miles of paths in gorgeous Parco Della Caffarella, where you can combine a run with a visit to the Catacombs. The park is more rural and agricultural in nature, with dirt paths though gorgeous green fields. A very different feel than the busy center city or the more manicured Roman parks such as Villa Ada.
~3 miles. Start: Piazza del Popolo, or Spanish Steps/Porta Pinciana. MAPAdd-Ons: Villa Ada Park, or paths along Tiber River.
At 148 acres, this is the third largest park in Rome. It is centrally located and makes for a great run. It‚Äôs possible put together a run of about 3 miles along the paths of the Villa Borghese. Sites include the Villa Borghese Gallery, lovely gardens, Museum of Modern Art, boating lake, and Piazza Napoleone. The paths are wide and gravel, and fairly shaded. Due to its central location, Borghese can be accessed via the Piazza del Popolo or the Spanish Steps/Porta Pinciana, among other options. A nice add-on/combination run is Villa Ada, which is another large park in Rome, less than 2 miles away. Use Via Salaria or Viale Romania. Guided walking tour here.
3 miles of paths. Start: Piazza Bligny. Easily accessed via bus. MAP
At 450 acres, this is Rome‚Äôs second largest park. It is more wooded and less finely manicured than Borghese or Pamphili. A private area is under control of the Egyptian embassy. The park has an artificial lake, a public swimming pool, and one can rent canoes, bikes, or horses. In summer there‚Äôs the Rome Meets the World Music Festival and numerous other outdoor concerts. For running, there are numerous paths throughout the park, including the perimeter of the fort, totaling ~3 miles. For a longer run, combine with Villa Borghese Park, taking Via Salaria, Via Panama, or Villa Romania to Via Giaocchino Rossini.
~10k of trails in the park. Start: in park,or accessible from St. Peter‚Äôs Square or Trastevere area.
Rome‚Äôs largest park, Villa Doria Pamphili, contains a stunning, mid- 17th century palace surrounded by garden mazes, jogging trails, fabulous fountains, a superb grotto, and pine lined views of Rome from atop the Janiculum hill. Note that there are not maps inside the park. Your best bet is to run the perimeter paths, which add up to ~10k. There are bathrooms and water fountains near the park entrances.
Good running options to/from the park: From Ponte Sisto, Via Garibaldi, passing through the Trastevere neighborhood and by important landmarks such as the Piazza de Santa Maria, Basilica di Santa Maria, the floodlit Fontana dell‚ÄôAcqua Paola, and the Garibaldi statue. Mix it up by going through the Passeggiata del Gianicolo monument with the cannon that goes off at noon, or the switchback road, Passeggiata del Gianicolo. This makes for a ~2.5 mile loop, to and from the park.
2‚Äì3 miles within site. 2 miles to sea and then along water for 1‚Äì2 miles.
Ostia Antica was the harbor city of ancient Rome. It is now a well-preserved archaeological site, about about 18 miles northeast of the city and 2 miles from the Mediterranean. It is a popular tourist destination due to its ancient buildings, frescoes, and mosaics. It‚Äôs also easily reachable from Rome via a 1/2 hour train ride and is only a few km from the airport. Ostia Antica makes for a good running option along its ancient roads. The stone surface is similar to the Appian Way, although there is grass/dirt on the side as well. It is about 1.2 miles from one end to the other in the Ostia Antica site (admission required). There are numerous add-on options. There are lovely farm fields on either side of the Antica site. Or, run to the sea, about 2 miles, and then along the water, where there is a separated bike path from Faber Beach to the port, and then a nice jaunt out to the harbor.
Like any major European city frequented by tourists, there is a huge choice of places to stay. Pretty much anywhere you stay in the most visited parts of Rome will provide access to some of the runs in this guide. A few recommendations, for runners.
There are not as many specialty running stores in Rome as in other cities of its size. Each of the major running companies ‚Äî Adidas, New Balance, Puma, and Nike has a store neat the Villa Borghese. A few of the specialty stores.
Footworks. Centrally located in San Giovanni area. Also close to Villa Ada and Parco Caffarella.
Born to Race. 2.5 miles south of Vila Doria Pamphili
LBM Sport. 1.5 miles north of the Via Appia
Rome has guided tours. And here.
AUR Runs Rome. The American University in Rome has an active club and meets regularly for group runs.
A.S.D. Roma Road Runners Club
Rome Marathon. April. Gorgeous race through the heart of some of Rome‚Äôs great sights.
Ostia Half Marathon. The varied course ROUTE is a fast one with some light up-and-down hill stretches. Starting near Palazzo dello Sport, the route runs in Rome, through the entire length of via Cristoforo Colombo then up and down the seafront, 280m each way, to the finish line at the round-about. (La Rotonda).
Rome Appia Run. April.

Hey there, fellow history enthusiasts! Today, I want to take you on a journey through time and explore the forgotten history of one of the most legendary cities in the world ‚Äì Rome. So grab a drink, sit back, and let's dive right in!
When you think of Rome, you probably envision grand architecture, gladiators, and legendary rulers like Julius Caesar. But did you know that Rome's history stretches far beyond the commonly known spectacular ruins? It's time to unveil some fascinating forgotten secrets!
To start, let's talk about the early beginnings of Rome. It all began as a small village on the banks of the Tiber River in the 8th century B.C. As I'm sure you can imagine, it's come a long way since then!
One of the most significant periods in Roman history was the establishment of the Roman Republic. It was a time of ambitious politicians, mighty generals, and the birth of true democracy. The Romans were all about the law and order, and they did it with style!

Nima: Yeah, sure.

They‚Äôve been adopting and co-opting and misunderstanding the aesthetics of Ancient Rome, kind of as a rule, but as a distinct part of their fascistic political project. Musk has a long history of referencing the Roman Empire. God, that‚Äôs sad. You didn‚Äôt write that, that‚Äôs me, sorry.
‚Ä¶and cooking up theories about why Ancient Rome fell (answer: severe decline in birth rate). He thinks about it every day.
End quote. So let‚Äôs begin. I want to sort of bring in Sarah here.
Nima: Yeah, let‚Äôs do it.
Adam: We‚Äôve set the table. Before we get into the questions about the actual book you wrote, forgive us, I want you to sort of comment on this piece, what you think superficially people find attractive. I know the elements are kind of obvious, but I want you to kind of dive into why you wrote this piece, why you think it‚Äôs important to engage as a historian of Rome with this seemingly popular current on the Nazi, or Nazi-adjacent Right.
Sarah E. Bond: Right, so the piece that I wrote for Hyperallergic, I wrote with Stephanie Wong, who is also a professor of history. She just graduated from Brown. And we write a lot together, because I think that our perspectives are very aligned, and we‚Äôre good at writing together, but we had been for years now, because we‚Äôve been, gosh, we‚Äôve been writing and collaborating for six years together, and so we decided that we were going to just collect all the things that he said since about 2020, about Ancient Rome, because I have just a gigantic digital folder of references to Ancient Rome that politicians have made over the years. And many of us who do a lot of reception history, which is just a fancy word for saying how things are repackaged and reused from the ancient world. We had been keeping track of it, and we had written an article together for MSNBC a few years, let‚Äôs see, a year and a half ago, on that meme about why people think about the Roman Empire.
And the person that Elon Musk thinks about the most seems to be Sulla, who was a dictator in the middle and early first century BCE. And Sulla eventually does give up power and is not assassinated. He eventually gives it up and retires and hands what‚Äôs left of the Republic over to Crassus and Cicero, I‚Äôm sorry, Crassus and Pompey, essentially, as the next consoles. But he‚Äôs obsessed with Sulla, and that really set off alarm bells in my head, because Sulla wiped out all of his political enemies by the hundreds. Nima: It feels like it‚Äôs been 2,000 years.
Sarah E. Bond: It has been four weeks of nonstop layoffs and nonstop purging of the federal government. And I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs the same in any way as killing people via the proscriptions, but I do think that Elon Musk likes to make people vulnerable to attack.
Adam: Yeah. Unless you fly a plane. Or rather fly on a plane, I should say.
Sarah E. Bond: I should just say with Elon Musk that we‚Äôre talking about aesthetics and idealizing. But I just want to point out something really huge here that was covered by Maya Pontone on Hyperallergic as well, with background from many researchers, myself included, is that Elon Musk has started to give money specifically to archeological projects and projects focused on the ancient world, and that there is a pipeline that is being created from the world of classics into, directly, the world of Elon Musk and this DOGE palace that he‚Äôs creating for himself, that we can‚Äôt just say that this is a fantasy that he‚Äôs playing out, that he gave over $2 million to the Vesuvius Challenge, which decoded a small amount of the papyri from Herculaneum and gave prize money to a young AI engineer named Luke Farritor. And Luke Farritor now works with DOGE and was one of the six engineers that originally went in with Musk a few weeks ago. So it‚Äôs not as though we can say, in the world of classics, Oh, we‚Äôre just, you know, he idealizes us, but we‚Äôre mutually exclusive. We‚Äôre in a bubble out here. What can we do about it? It‚Äôs like, No, we have people who are taking the money of Musk, the Vesuvius Challenge, as well as, there‚Äôs another called the AIRC in Rome, who has also taken money from Musk, and so he‚Äôs funding cultural heritage and AI as a way of accessing people that are involved with the ancient world. And you know, it matters who we take money from. It very much matters.
Adam: There‚Äôs a risk there, because, again, he did this. He‚Äôs obviously done this for years with STEM, where he throws so much money around that your favorite science channel will do these sycophantic reports on him. Science media will do sycophantic reports on him. They‚Äôll get an interview with him and gush over him, even this is, like, sort of post-overt Nazi stuff. And so, yeah, I mean, when you have, again, $400 billion in debt worth, obviously, it‚Äôs not totally liquid, but it‚Äôs, you know, he could, he could take a loan against it anytime he wants. And, you know, controlling the past is, is because not to be too sort of, you know, I don‚Äôt want to be too overly precious‚Äì
Nima: You can rage against the machine. It‚Äôs okay.
Adam: Well. I mean, you know, He who controls the present controls the past. He who controls the past controls the future. I do think it matters, because then we‚Äôre going to be curated. It‚Äôs going to be curated, presented in a way that flatters his ideological dispositions.
Sarah E. Bond: Yeah, and we‚Äôre already seeing that. We have Trump firing the archivist of the United States after she had already deleted and moved around parts of an exhibit that was within the National Archives. And he still fired her. But she had gone in and edited parts of history that were negative, right? And so the presentation of history and the people that are in control of it is what he wants access to, and he wants good press for sure, and he‚Äôs trying to buy himself a connection to antiquity in order to conjure legitimacy that we‚Äôve already seen. This is the same MO that Mussolini took to legitimize his power and his rise within fascist Italy.
Adam: He‚Äôs basically‚Äì
Sarah E. Bond: All you have to do, yeah, you just rebuild the Ara Pacis, right? Rebuild the Res Gestae Divi Augusti, which is exactly what Mussolini does, is invest so many thousands and millions of dollars into the rebuilding of the Roman Forum and the rebuilding of the Roman senate house. This is a playbook we‚Äôve already seen before, because he has no legitimate status within the federal government. So he‚Äôs clinging to what he perceives as the only legitimacy that he cares about, which is power from the ancient world.
Nima: Talking about preserving the past and also, you know, as we‚Äôre going to get into kind of who is allowed to control our understanding of the past. And we‚Äôre going to get into this, this idea of, you know, whether from imperial historians kind of empowered and sponsored to tell the official history of Rome, to this kind of idea of history from below, which you tell through your work, Sarah. I‚Äôd love to kind of discuss the overall thesis of your book, which really shows how class conflict and the organized withholding of labor was a consistent feature of Roman life, as were slave revolts, military strikes, other forms of resistance, much of which has been erased or at least reduced to individual stories of heroism in kind of broader ancient, historical retellings, and certainly in the popular mind. How those who don‚Äôt study this so closely kind of understand the ancient world, and then certainly Ancient Rome. So what compelled you to write this new book Strike, and what broad image of Rome, both in our pop culture and in kind of more historical consensus, were you attempting to illuminate and edify for us?
Sarah E. Bond: I was going back and re-reading an economic history of Rome from a guy named Tenney Frank, and he was a racist from the turn of the 20th century, like into the 20th century. And, I think it‚Äôs 1920, he writes an economic history of Rome, and he thinks that strikes cannot happen because of the number of enslaved people within the Roman Empire. And we do know that within the Italic peninsula, for instance, up to 25% of the population, especially during the the period of the High Roman Empire, so the first two centuries CE, have a large number of enslaved people. And even prior to that, there was a large number. And so he thought that because there were enslaved people, there could never be strikes, because every time you would have artisans going on strike, why wouldn‚Äôt you just replace them with other enslaved persons? And that really discounted the professionalization of enslaved people as potters, as weavers, as textile workers, as carpenters, as tavern workers and owners. And his belief that there weren‚Äôt strikes kind of infuriated me, and led me to read more about what people thought about strikes, about withholding labor, and what it might have been called in the ancient world.
And it was surprising to me that there just had been so little written on collective action and the withholding of labor in the ancient world, because many people, both Marxists and non-Marxists, had thought that there really weren‚Äôt a lot of instances of it. And so in the 19th century, Marx and Engels had believed that the first strikes ever had been the plebeians during what we call the Struggle of the Orders, which really starts in 495 BCE. And if we‚Äôre trying to place that, that‚Äôs about 15 years after the start of the Roman Republic. So 509, the Roman Republic starts. The last king of Rome is ousted, and we have the start of something we call the res publica, or the republic. And a few years after that, we have the plebeians and the patricians fighting against each other because the patricians are extremely wealthy and they have a lot of power, but also they have a lot of both soft and hard power, in that they monopolize all the magistracies, the consulship, the pontifical colleges, all of the major magistracies, the patricians are, are really dominating.
And so I looked at the Struggle of the Orders, but thought to myself, I think there has to be many more instances of this happening. And so starting to look through things that really didn‚Äôt make it into the traditional literary historical record, like papyri and inscriptions, really was the access point to find out that, especially in the Greek world, and going all the way back to the Egyptian world, this had been happening for many thousands of years. And so I started tracing backwards and forwards and finding that there were a lot more instances, because a strike by any other name is still a strike. And so even though the word is not coined until the 18th century in England, because it‚Äôs referring to the striking of the top sails of merchant ships in the 18th century, even though that word does not exist in Ancient Rome, that you still have the withholding of labor and the boycotting of certain assigned things like the military levy through calling it a secessio, where we get, for instance, the word secession from. But then when you look in the Greek papyri, they‚Äôre calling it an anachoresis, which just means a withdrawal. And for many hundreds and thousands of years, we‚Äôve had workers, especially in Egypt, refusing to work unless they were given emmer and wheat and the right amount of staples to keep working. Sometimes they would just go sit in the back of a temple.
And so for me, it was saying modern people think that strikes are a development of the progressive modern Western civilization post-Industrial Revolution, and as is my wont, I usually like to say to most things, Well, that sounds like bullshit, that that we have created this idea of progressive structure to get to the period that we are now, even though it does not feel that we are in a progressive moment in the least, and to try and unpack why we think that unions and strikes and labor withdrawals, that all of these things are a much more modern development in order to really make us feel a little bit more successful as individuals. And I think we just have to give more credit to the Romans.
Nima: Yeah, I love the idea that, like, a strike by any other name is still a strike that, even if they don‚Äôt use that term, because, you know, you actually start your book by talking about how the term was coined, the striking of sails in a British port. But then going back to Deir el-Medina, the strike in Egypt, and then kind of tracing that up through history is just, I think, really, really fascinating to see how, in a world that is built on the on the backs of laborers, the power that is held through withholding labor, has been recognized, not just, you know, since the Industrial Revolution, but you know, for thousands and thousands of years.
Adam: On some level, the idea that people around the world would withhold labor is, it does seem sort of self-evidently obvious, because what other leverage do you have as a laborer? And 99% of humans throughout history have been laborers, typically exploited in any kind of semi-developed sense that would be exploited by some rich asshole who lived on the hill. It doesn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs not a huge leap to say that this is a kind of universal, that there‚Äôs an evolutionary convergence to land on some form of strike, right? And what you argue is that while that is true, there was also more sophisticated antecedents that made these more coordinated, more and more sophisticated than we maybe thought.
And one of the things we talk about is these associations, which were both kind of, which were not these kind of perfect Marxist organizations, in the sense that they were oftentimes kind of business trade groups. They didn‚Äôt fit along these kind of perfectly, you know, Maoist lines, but in many ways they what you do argue is that they could be instrumentalized to carry out something we would recognize as a labor strike, and that because of the way history is written, you specifically talk about Levy and others, because of the inherently elite nature of reading and writing and how history is created, the first draft, second draft, third draft, that those stories get flattened or obscured.
And you even have this great section, I won‚Äôt read it back to you, because I‚Äôd like you to talk about it, about the ways in which mob violence is flattened. When you say that oftentimes, as a class dimension, that is fairly obvious, but in the history books, it‚Äôs kind of written off as just mob violence. And you even draw some parallels to current examples, when mass unrest is sort of stripped of its ideology, which I thought was a really fascinating, really interesting part of the book. Can you talk about the ways in which‚Äì
Nima: Cicero was just doing what the New York Times does now.
Adam: Well, yeah, by the way, I found out he did, The the shrimp store called and they‚Äôre running out of you, The jerk store called, where he would, I didn‚Äôt realize this until I read Mary Beard‚Äôs book, that he would write what he said on the Senate floor later on, which seems like cheating. And then people presented it as like, He‚Äôs this great orator, and it‚Äôs like, You just got to go back and rewrite it. Anyway. Talk, if you could, about the these associations, how they provided the kind of framework to make a more sophisticated form of labor unrest, and if you could also talk about the ways in which historians, for obvious reasons, who were wealthy or patrician or what have you, decided to kind of say, Oh, that was just mindless, ideology-free violence.
Sarah E. Bond: I think when we create homogenous groups, when we call everybody a mob, that‚Äôs already a pejorative, it‚Äôs already casting them into negative rhetoric. And the Romans are no different. They like to use very large, amalgamous nouns, a turba, a multitudo, that is to just say, a gigantic negative word for a crowd, right? And when you just say crowd, you aren‚Äôt allowing for organization, you aren‚Äôt allowing for hierarchy, you aren‚Äôt allowing for structure. And although we don‚Äôt get a ton of anatomies of crowds from the ancient world, we can see, especially in the late Republic, that a lot of groups that are coming together, what we call collegia, and that‚Äôs where we get the modern word college from. A collegium, in the singular, is just a group of people. In Roman law, you have to be three or more people to be considered a collegium. And we have about 3,200 inscriptions in papyri that give reference to these various groups that really grow in number in the early Hellenistic period forward.
So from the death of Alexander the Great forward, people increasingly are creating groups for various reasons. So you could have a group that is focused on Dionysus, because who doesn‚Äôt want to get together and drink some wine and have a nice bacchanalia? But you could also form a group, if you were merchants or trades people living on the island of Delos, and you‚Äôre human traffickers, and you need to have a workflow, essentially, that moves people throughout the Mediterranean. So, I mean, I think Spartacus deserves all of those kudos, but we also have to ask ourselves about other enslaved people into the period of the Empire, and part of that is looking at enslaved people that rebel against Rome, whether they‚Äôre mint workers, whether they‚Äôre charioteers, whether they‚Äôre bear trainers, that we never have a slave revolt that is to the level of Spartacus that we know of within the Roman Empire for the rest of its existence, there‚Äôs never a rebellion that is to the degree that Spartacus inspired and carried out, but that there are still enslaved people that went on strike and that engaged in joining collegia.
And so circling back to that first thesis that I was talking about, just because enslaved people exist within a society does not mean that there cannot be labor organization and that there cannot be people working together for a higher purpose, right? And so sometimes that purpose is manumission, and sometimes that purpose is to get higher wages. But just because they‚Äôre enslaved does not mean that they‚Äôre completely impotent or without any power within this labor economy.
Nima: Well, I think that is a perfect place to leave it. Sarah, this has been so wonderful, and thank you, everyone, for joining us on this Citations Needed livestream Beg-a-Thon. It has been truly wonderful to talk to you, Sarah. We have been speaking with Dr. Sarah E. Bond, Associate Professor in the Classics at the University of Iowa. You do have, like, a longer title: Erling B. ‚ÄúJack‚Äù Holtsmark?
Sarah E. Bond: I‚Äôm an endowed chair in the history, I‚Äôm technically in the History Department with an appointment in Classics. I have a chair. It does not matter.
Nima: I feel like I need to read that title. It‚Äôs very prestigious.
Sarah E. Bond: It doesn‚Äôt, well, it doesn‚Äôt mean that much, except for, you know, that I feel very lucky to have the job that I do, that this is my job, that I get to do all day. So that‚Äôs good enough.
Nima: Yeah, that‚Äôs very Stoic of you.
Sarah E. Bond: I see what you did there. I see what you did there.
Adam: She‚Äôs the emperor, though. That‚Äôs objectively a great job.
Nima: Sarah, of course, is the author of the incredible new book. Adam and I both read it.
Adam: We actually read it. We didn‚Äôt fake-read it. We actually read it.
Nima: Man, is it fucking great. So please pick it up. The book is, of course, Strike: Labor, Unions, and Resistance in the Roman Empire, out now from Yale University Press. But Sarah, thank you so much for joining us today on Citations Needed. It has been amazing to have you.
Sarah E. Bond: Thank you for having me. Hopefully, I‚Äôll see you again.
Nima: Indeed.
Sarah E. Bond: Maybe in five years, but hopefully sooner.
Nima: Hopefully much sooner. But that will do it for this Citations Needed livestream Beg-a-Thon, thank you all for listening. Of course, you can follow the show on Twitter and Bluesky @citationspod, Facebook Citations Needed. If you have not, please do consider signing up to support the show through Patreon.com/CitationsNeededPodcast. All your support through Patreon is so incredibly appreciated, as we are 100% listener funded, but that will do it. Stay tuned for more full-length episodes and News Briefs from Citations Needed. Plenty to discuss. So more coming your way, but until then, thank you all for listening. Of course, I am Nima Shirazi.
Adam: I‚Äôm Adam Johnson.
Nima: Citations Needed‚Äôs senior producer is Florence Barrau-Adams. Our producer is Julianne Tveten. Production assistant is Trendel Lightburn. The newsletter is by Marco Cartolano. The music is by Grandaddy. Thanks again, everyone. Have a wonderful night. We‚Äôll catch you next time.

Title: One Life Is Not Enough: Reading Anthony Doerr‚Äôs Four Seasons in Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúThough you are a whole world, Rome, still, without love, the world‚Äôs not the world, and Rome cannot be Rome.‚Äù ‚Äî Goethe
This book. I had this idea of traveling based on the books I was reading, and after nearly four years in Rome, I realized I had never read a book about the city itself. Perhaps I was too caught up in my daily struggles ‚Äî and let me tell you, my life in Rome hasn‚Äôt been easy. Maybe my expectations were too high, or, as Goethe said, love was simply absent, and Rome wasn‚Äôt truly Rome to me. But this isn‚Äôt my story. Let‚Äôs get back to Anthony Doerr‚Äôs memoir.
As I write my humble thoughts on this memoir, I find myself flipping through its pages, revisiting the passages I underlined ‚Äî the moments that touched my heart, the parts where I saw my own Roman story reflected. To be honest, Doerr‚Äôs first impressions of Rome mirrored how I felt after a year, maybe a year and a half, of living here.
I came to Rome for my master‚Äôs degree ‚Äî my second one, actually ‚Äî not just for academic reasons but as a way to escape Istanbul, to finally do something I had long felt was inevitable. I had always known my story wasn‚Äôt meant to unfold in just one city or country, though I had imagined it would be London, not Rome.
And yet, when I finally opened my eyes and truly started feeling Rome, it was exactly as Doerr described: noticing the endless sea of scooters, marveling at (or being horrified by) Italian driving, being simultaneously enchanted and frustrated by the city. In those early days, I was also angry ‚Äî maybe disappointed ‚Äî by what I had found here. And as I read through the beginning of Four Seasons in Rome, I could feel that same unease in Doerr‚Äôs words.
Throughout the pages, you experience what it‚Äôs like to be a parent to newborn twins ‚Äî and, honestly, I‚Äôd much rather live that experience through his eyes than my own. But being in a foreign country doesn‚Äôt make it any easier. Even though our circumstances were different, there was one feeling we both shared: navigating this city while feeling lost ‚Äî most of the time.
The missing piece, though, is love. I‚Äôm not sure if I should call myself fortunate, but in that regard, I‚Äôve been quite lucky ‚Äî if letting my heart get broken over and over counts as luck. I found real love here and lost it here. I cried here. I lost hope here. And yet, to truly experience Rome, love wasn‚Äôt necessary. As Doerr writes:
‚ÄúAnd what about Rome? Rome is beautiful, Rome is ugly. Something about this city exacerbates contrast, the incongruities and contradictions‚Ä¶‚Äù
Rome has a way of filling that void in its own way, making sure you feel everything ‚Äî whether you want to or not.
In the beginning, or let‚Äôs say during Fall, the book feels more factual, focused on adjustment. Doerr shares details about Rome, its quirks, its history. But as we move into Spring and Summer, we witness ‚Äî or at least I felt ‚Äî his gradual acceptance of the city, his growing appreciation for its beauty. And in these later chapters, the book shifts into something deeper. Not overwhelming, not philosophical, but it subtly invites the reader to take a step back, to ask certain questions, to reflect.
You should take note of the places Doerr mentions in this book ‚Äî mostly around Monteverde, one of my favorite areas in Rome.
I‚Äôm not sure if anyone would be interested, so I won‚Äôt be sharing my full Roman guide, but I do want to give a shoutout to my favorite restaurants for the best carbonara. Why?
When I first moved to Rome, I was almost vegetarian ‚Äî pescatarian, to be exact. While my friends indulged in legendary plates of pasta alla carbonara, I could only watch and wonder what all the fuss was about.
Then, for love, I started eating meat again. To be precise, I now eat guanciale, Italian cold cuts, poultry, and seafood ‚Äî so really, there‚Äôs not much left off the menu, is there?
Naturally, my return to the eating-it-all era had to start with the famous carbonara. This passion quickly turned into a habit ‚Äî I now order pasta alla carbonara every time I dine out. Here are some of my favorite spots to enjoy it:
I could go on forever ‚Äî food is my passion, after all. But I suppose this article was meant to be about a book.
Okay, back to the book:
I‚Äôm so envious of Doerr for writing such a brilliantly pure, beautifully written book. No flashy marketing of la dolce vita ‚Äî God knows I‚Äôm tired of the glossy image of Rome when the reality is far from dolce. He presents it all in a way that feels honest, and I couldn‚Äôt help but see parallels between the way Rome made him feel and the way I‚Äôve felt since moving here.
I envy him even more because he came to Rome for a set period, with no trouble finding an apartment (thank you, Pope, honestly), which gave him the opportunity to experience the city without the complications that often come with living here. Or maybe the struggle is the true Roman experience. I‚Äôm not sure‚Ä¶ Rome is my great dilemma and paradox.
Overall, I‚Äôm glad I don‚Äôt have to experience this city with newborn twins. I‚Äôm grateful for the daily challenges of living here and for the chance to experience life in its raw, unfiltered form. Rome is a beautiful city, though flawed in many ways. I can‚Äôt see myself growing old here ‚Äî but that‚Äôs for purely professional reasons.
Finally, the author‚Äôs writing is captivating. Whether you live here or not, perhaps in another place, you‚Äôll find yourself immersed in his story through his eyes. I absolutely loved this memoir, and it‚Äôs definitely a must-read. As he wrote:
‚ÄúRoma, they say, non basta una vita. One life is not enough.‚Äù

Title: 30 Days in Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When I tossed a small Italian lira coin into the Trevi fountain back in June 1987, it was to ensure my return to Rome someday, in accordance with the famous legend. On the cusp of turning 17, I had all the optimism in the world that I would indeed be back. And I was right. It just took a few decades. But lucky for me, Rome is known for being eternal and was waiting here for me.
A lot has changed since I was last here. My sunken coin is, of course, long gone. The lira isn‚Äôt even Italy‚Äôs currency anymore, having been replaced by the euro in 2002. Most importantly, I now have a greater appreciation of history than I did as a teenager. Back then, I just wanted to meet European boys, get served alcohol underage, and go out dancing with my friends. My pictures were mostly of our silly fun in hotel rooms or on the bus, and my more serious scenic ones came out dark, blurry, or had my finger in them.
This time around, I plan to mix sightseeing and trying to live like a local for a month, much like I did when I spent 30 days in Paris working remotely last summer. Exploring all of the Roman ruins there inspired me to head right to the source. My great-grandparents came to the United States from Italy, so I also want to soak in the Italian culture on a deeper level and make time for some quiet moments sitting in parks just observing people or while walking ancient roads like the old Appian Way.
I only had a few days to see the famous Roman sites that summer of ‚Äô87 so long ago. I was on a ‚ÄúDiscovering Europe‚Äù group tour of around 50 people, mostly high school students and some parent-chaperones, which was arranged by my high school Spanish teacher. We had 24 days to see nine cities in four countries. Rome was a blur. I mainly remember our tour of the Colosseum, seeing where the Pope lives, and not liking the pizza.
I actually still have the travel journal I kept on that trip and dug it out of storage recently so that I could refresh my memory and maybe have a few laughs. It did not disappoint. Page after page of black cursive handwriting captured my deep teenage thoughts.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like Rome at all. Our hotel room is right by a busy street. And just like in Paris people drive like maniacs beeping horns all the time.‚Äù
‚ÄúToday sucked! We had to get up early to see the Palace of Versailles. It was a boring tour.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe went to a fast food place called Burger Quick. I only got a soda (6 francs) but the hamburgers I saw were gross! They were so rare!‚Äù
‚ÄúIn Venice we went on the most boringest walking tour ever! I was so tired I tried to sleep as I walked.‚Äù
I imagine my dusty travel journal being found a hundred years from now by my great-great-grandchildren in an attic somewhere. They would flip through the pages and marvel at the indecipherable writing. Thinking maybe it‚Äôs cuneiform or ancient Sanskrit, they take it to an antique dealer to see if it‚Äôs worth anything. Maybe even pay to have the cursive ‚Äútranslated‚Äù to see what profound insights were captured so painstakingly by hand. I imagine the translator gently revealing the contents to them.
‚ÄúWell, she talks a lot about long bus rides, gross foreign food, and having to wake up too early for boring tours of churches and palaces. But, you know, things were hard back in the 20th century.‚Äù
I might not have had a big interest in art, culture, food, or history during that high school trip, but it did definitely awakened my curiosity about the world and gave me insight into how people in other countries lived. It even opened my mind to the world of politics a bit. In Italy, for example, I saw political graffiti, some of it anti-American, spray painted in English as our bus drove through the busy Roman streets. One night after dinner we strolled through St. Peter‚Äôs Square in Vatican City and came across a candle-holding procession of people. Our guide told us that they were protesting the Pope‚Äôs election of a man who was believed to be an ex Nazi war criminal. I filed these and other important learnings away in the back of my teenage brain since the highlight of that particular evening (according to my journal) was hanging out on the steps of a church near our hotel, listening to a portable radio and dancing around until our curfew came.
In my first Paris article, I talked about all of the funny mistakes I made on my first trips to Europe, such as washing my underwear and socks in a bidet in my Paris hotel room because I thought it was just another sink. Well, the faux pas streak continued a week later in Rome when I again used the sink to wash my shirts and shorts (a real one this time, not a bidet). I decided to hang them to dry over the railing of my partial balcony, which faced a busy Roman street. When I came back hours later, my clothes were hanging in various spots around the room, still wet. A chaperone soon told us that hanging clothes outdoors so close to the Vatican was forbidden and not to do it. My not-so-bright idea didn‚Äôt sit well with housekeeping, nor the papacy, apparently. Who knows though, I bet when no one‚Äôs looking, the Pope puts his big pointy hat on his window ledge every once in a while to air it out.
I grew up on the East Coast of the United States, so to me ‚Äúold‚Äù was something that was built a few hundred years ago, not thousands like you see in Rome. My hometown of Bristol, Pennsylvania, was founded in 1681. That‚Äôs pretty old for a town in the United States, though it‚Äôs certainly not the oldest. For comparison, Philadelphia traces its roots back to 1682, New York City to 1624, and Boston to 1630. St. Augustine, Florida, has them all beat, though, having been continuously inhabited since 1565. Of course, if you head to the Southwest, you‚Äôll find even older places that native Americans built.
One of my favorite places to eat in Bristol is the King George II Inn & Tavern, which is the oldest continuously operating inn in the country. I always thought it was cool that some of our founding fathers came through its doors, including a young George Washington, John Adams, and James Madison. Even France‚Äôs Marquis de Lafayette ate there, probably munching on an early variation of a burger and French fries (well, to him it would just be ‚Äúfries,‚Äù I guess). That early fascination is probably why I tend to seek out pubs and restaurants that are considered ‚Äúthe oldest‚Äù in the cities I visit, and why I love to stay at historic hotels.
I remember the first time I encountered something much, much older and how it made my head spin with awe. I was working temporarily in London and took a day trip to Warwick Castle one weekend. At 23, I still wasn‚Äôt much into history, but since we did a lot of date memorizing in history classes, I remembered distinctly that in 1066 that famous William guy did his conquering thing and became King of England.
While walking around the grounds of the castle he had built, I became fixated on the dirt path I was following, imagining how he might have walked this same dusty path. I could literally be walking in William the Conqueror‚Äôs footsteps, I thought excitedly. History really came to life for me at that moment. If only teleportation were a thing, field trips for World History class would be way more interesting.
It‚Äôs even more amazing when something so old is still in use. Once when I was in Adana, Turkey, in the late ‚Äô90s, my husband and I were in a cab sitting in rush hour traffic and were amazed when the driver told us that the stone bridge we were stuck on was built by the Romans in the 2nd century. Imagine a structure surviving nearly 2,000 years intact possibly being taken down by a distracted driver on their cell phone or fumbling with the radio. I was happy to read years later that they banned cars on it in 2007, and now it‚Äôs open only to foot traffic.
The Romans sure knew how to build things to last. The Colosseum would be completely intact today if it wasn‚Äôt for earthquakes and people in the Middle Ages pillaging its stone blocks to use for other buildings. Then there‚Äôs the old Appian Way. I can‚Äôt wait to walk along what‚Äôs considered the oldest road in the world (that‚Äôs still visible). That expression ‚Äî ‚ÄúAll roads lead to Rome‚Äù? Well, this road is the mother of them all. It‚Äôs so old, some of the stones still have grooves in them from chariot wheels (and we think potholes are bad). I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll have a time-travel mind melt when I imagine myself walking in the footsteps of historical heavyweights such as Julius Caesar and Spartacus. Though not literally: Caesar‚Äôs feet probably never had to touch the ground, being a conquering dictator and all, and well, poor Spartacus was crucified on the old Appian Way along with thousands of other rebellious gladiators.
Starting in late May, I‚Äôll be trying to live like a local while staying at an apartment in the Monteverde neighborhood, just south of Trastevere. It‚Äôs about an hour walk from my place to the Colosseum, so I definitely hope to be living away from the tourist crowds, especially since this is a Jubilee year for the Catholic Church, which happens only once every 25 years. There‚Äôs no metro stop on my side of the river, but there are buses, trams, and of course my two feet. I‚Äôll need to get in as many steps as I can if I‚Äôm going to eat all of the things on my checklist.
I need to redeem my teenage self‚Äôs dislike of the one pizza experience I had in Rome, so there will be lots of pizza tasting of all shapes and sizes. I‚Äôm not really into meat toppings, so I‚Äôll probably just do plain, but there are some interesting veggies to try on pizza like radicchio, zucchini flowers, and squash blossoms. And of course there‚Äôs the pasta. I learned that there are four classics I have to try in Rome: Gricia (ancient), Amatriciana, Carbonara, and Cacio e Pepe. I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôll work up the courage to try the specialty dishes made with offal (intestines, stomach lining, etc.). Though I‚Äôm willing to try meatballs made with cow tail (oxtail) and the famous Saltimbocca alla Romana (veal). There‚Äôs also a fancy bologna-like lunchmeat called mortadella that looks interesting.
I‚Äôll also of course make time to do some sightseeing when I‚Äôm not working. So much time has passed since my last visit to Rome there‚Äôs even been a new exciting discovery. In my teenage travel journal, I wrote that I had visited the Forum ruins where our tour guide Ned told us Julius Caesar was assassinated. But turns out that was wrong. Excavations in 2012 uncovered markings by Caesar‚Äôs successor Augustus where he designated the exact spot. Turns out, it happened in the Curia di Pompey, a meeting place within the Pompey Theater complex that the Senators were using while the Senate House was being renovated. In 2023 a raised walkway was built over the excavation site so that visitors could get a closer look.
I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll have many moments where I try to imagine myself living among the ancient Romans. Like Russell Crowe‚Äôs character Maximus did in the Gladiator movie, I like to run my hands along tall grasses and plant leaves within my reach. It‚Äôs something I do no matter where I am walking, but in a place with lots of history, it helps me to feel connected to the people who were there centuries before me. It‚Äôs the same with touching walls, trees, and stones (when it‚Äôs allowed). Though my hands won‚Äôt be going anywhere near the stone latrine seats of the ancient communal bathrooms that I hope to see when touring the nearby ruins of Ostia Antica. I don‚Äôt need to imagine that part of ancient Roman life.
I am, however, open to the idea of using a bidet. In a kind of weird, come-full-circle plot twist, the apartment I‚Äôm renting has a bathroom with a bidet right next to the toilet. The place does have a washer and dryer, so don‚Äôt worry ‚Äî my underwear and socks will be properly laundered this time.
Eventually, I plan to document here on Medium how it all went. Until then, follow my stories and posts on Instagram (@pammypez).
--

An aspiring travel writer who pays the bills as a remote technical writer. Currently based in the Atlanta area, USA.
