For now, a place to collect my own writings about the ancient Mediterranean, aka The Classics. I may soon aim to expand it into a multi-writer publication. For lovers of ancient Rome and Greece.

--
Listen
Share
The problem is well-known enough to be a cliche: ancient history is exclusively focused on the lives and perspectives of aristocratic men. Sorting through this bias to recover the stories of other types of people ‚Äî whether they be lower-class, enslaved, or in my case, female ‚Äî is an inexact art. But allow me to try it for you. Here are 8 ancient Roman women you should know from history.
A word of caution before I begin: I am using Roman histories and literature here, not archaeological evidence or other ways we have of knowing about the Romans. That means I am filtering through the biases of aristocratic male writers. To the ancient Romans composing the histories, women could be roughly filtered into two categories: good women (wives and mothers who devote their entire beings to the benefit of the interests of their husbands, sons, fathers, etc.) and troublesome women (women who dare to become famous in their own right, and thus must have Something Wrong With Them). A troublesome woman was assumed to fit a certain stereotype: she was a conniving woman trying to use the powerful men in her life to her own ends; she did not observe the proper sexual boundaries (adultery, but also often incest); she killed men with poison (the woman‚Äôs murder method as it involved sneaking around and no face-to-face violence). Some of the women on this list will fit the Roman ‚Äúgood woman‚Äù mold, but most will be troublesome ones. So Roman writers ‚Äî already notorious for their problematic relationship with facts ‚Äî frequently reported rumors as fact or outright lied to make these women fit their stereotype better. Take everything you read about these women (including in this article!) with a healthy grain of salt.
It‚Äôs the middle of the second century BCE. New wealth has been pouring into Rome from its recent conquests, from Spain to Carthage to Greece, and tastes among aristocrats are shifting accordingly. The ruling class of Rome used to pride itself on austerity, dressing plainly and maintaining simple lifestyles. But an abundance of foreign gold has tempted the aristocracy into gaudy, Eastern-style displays of wealth. Fine fabrics, gold, and jewels are everywhere.
Cornelia, the daughter of Scipio Africanus (the general whose conquests helped generate all this wealth), is entertaining a friend at home. The friend has just been showing off her jewels to Cornelia, then asks, ‚ÄúWhat about you? Where are your jewels?‚Äù
Cornelia, who is dressed simply despite her wealth, summons her two young sons, Tiberius and Gaius. She smiles serenely as she displays her sons to her friend: ‚ÄúThese are my jewels,‚Äù Cornelia says.
Cornelia was a paragon of virtue, an example to all Roman women of correct matronly behavior. She was well educated in both Latin and Greek. She was an accomplished writer: she published a set of her letters that were apparently widely read and studied by girls wishing to be as good as her. (These writings, unfortunately and predictably, are long lost.) She was devoted to her sons and remained faithful to her husband even after his early death: Cornelia was an univira, a woman who had had only one husband. She even turned down a marriage proposal from the king of Egypt. (Remarriage after widowhood or divorce was widely accepted and even encouraged, but the Romans reserved a special reverence for a woman who refused it ‚Äî an univira showed a restraint and devotion to her deceased husband that surpassed even social expectations.)
As I mentioned, Cornelia was the daughter of Scipio Africanus, the vanquisher of Hannibal, who was undoubtably the most important Roman of his age and certainly one of the most consequential in all Roman history. But Cornelia raised her sons with a mission: she wanted them to be so successful that she would be remembered more as their mother than as Scipio‚Äôs daughter. This came true, but not in the way she wanted.
Cornelia‚Äôs sons, Tiberius and Gaius Gracchus, were Rome‚Äôs first populist reformers in centuries. Tiberius became a tribune of the plebs (the voice of the common people) at a time that the office had lost its radical edge. Tiberius brought populist rhetoric back after centuries of aristocratic dominance, demanding land reform to benefit the poor. The aristocracy did not take kindly to the proposition and murdered Tiberius Gracchus. A decade later, his brother Gaius came back with an expanded list of demands and an illegal private army to defend him from his brother‚Äôs fate. It took longer, but the aristocracy brought in the actual army and Gaius Gracchus took his own life once his defeat was certain. But the aristocracy could not silence the demands the Gracchi had stirred up. The Gracchi mark the beginning of an era of popular unrest and frequent uprisings, a period that ends with the aristocracy destroying the republic and establishing autocracy. They begin a violent epoch in Roman history that changes the very fabric of Rome.
If Cornelia had any aristocratic reservations about her sons‚Äô political careers, we don‚Äôt know it: in public, Cornelia was an energetic supporter of her sons. Remember that, in the Roman view, a good woman supports the men of her family. By supporting her sons‚Äô political ambitions even at the expense of her own social class, Cornelia again shows the Roman ideal of womanhood. Even her own ambition ‚Äî to be more famous for her sons than for her father ‚Äî shows the proper sort of ambition for a woman: desire not for her own elevation, but for the success of her menfolk.
Cornelia was both an old-fashioned scion of idealized Roman matronhood and an unusually learned and accomplished woman. She was highly respected in her own time and remains well remembered by history today.
It‚Äôs the first century BCE, and a more modern sort of woman is in vogue. The docta puella (‚Äúeducated girl‚Äù) is more independent: she‚Äôs witty and worldly, she mingles with poets and philosophers as an equal, she takes lovers without shame. Men write about her love as a revelation, her rejection as the worst imaginable calamity. The docta puella holds a power that is most unladylike.
The foremost of the early doctae puellae was Clodia Metelli. She was a daughter of a heavily distinguished household who became infamous for a pair of affairs: one with a poet who damned her as eagerly as he had praised her, and one with a politician that ended in an accusation of poisoning.
Clodia was descended from one of the noblest families in all of Rome, the gens Claudia ‚Äî among other famous ancestors was Appius Claudius Caecus, who built the first aqueduct and the most important Roman road, the Via Appia. (Most of the women of the family would have been named Claudia, but Clodia used an alternate spelling of the name that was briefly fashionable in her time.) She was married to Quintus Caecilius Metellus Celer, an aristocratic optimate. But when her brother, the infamous populist rabble-rouser Clodius Pulcher, came into political conflict with Metellus Celer, Clodia publicly supported her brother over her husband. This might seem surprising, but though it was mildly scandalous, it was also seen as typical at the time: marriage ties were weaker than ties to natal families, and many Roman women supported brothers and fathers over their husbands.
We can‚Äôt know for sure, but we are pretty sure that Clodia was the lover of the poet Catullus whom he called ‚ÄúLesbia‚Äù in his poems. His poetry is the only evidence we have of their relationship, and we can safely say that Catullus‚Äôs poetry prioritizes melodrama over factual accuracy. Still, the outlines of the relationship are clear: Catullus was a young upstart poet, Clodia an established, fashionable socialite. He followed her like a puppy, and she kept him around as long as he amused her, then discarded him in favor of other lovers. In a series of poems, Catullus bitterly attacks Clodia and the men he suspects of being her lovers until one begins to wonder what Clodia ever saw in him.
We are certain that Clodia had an affair with Marcus Caelius Rufus, an orator and up-and-coming politician younger than she was. Their relationship ended, and Caelius made his way firmly into political circles that opposed Clodia‚Äôs, so in 56 BCE Clodia accused Caelius of trying to poison her at the end of their relationship. Her motivation was political, to tank Caelius‚Äôs career and harm his allies ‚Äî whether there was a grain of truth to the poisoning story is unknowable, but either way, her aim was political, not personal.
In the trial for the alleged poisoning, one of the members of Caelius‚Äôs defense team was Cicero, widely considered the greatest of all Roman orators and a longtime political opponent of Clodia‚Äôs brother Clodius Pulcher. Each member of the defense team had his own job, and Cicero‚Äôs was solely to shred Clodia‚Äôs credibility. This tactic would not be allowed in a modern courtroom, but in a Roman one it was fair game. Cicero would augment his colleagues‚Äô claims of Caelius‚Äôs innocence with claims of Clodia‚Äôs debauchery and wickedness of spirit.
Cicero‚Äôs speech (called the Pro Caelio) is a masterwork of invective, and a catalog of Roman insecurities about women in general and doctae puellae in particular. He depicts Clodia as an amoral seducer of younger lovers who bought a house overlooking a bathing spot so she could pick out her victims. He accuses her of poisoning her husband and of having sex with her brother, two ridiculous charges that he knows he can‚Äôt prove, so he brings them up through backhanded hints instead of directly. He even assumes the persona of her famous ancestor Appius Claudius to tell her how disappointed he is in her and how she is tarnishing her family‚Äôs reputation. It‚Äôs a brutal, no-holds-barred takedown. Clodia loses the trial.
Yet we get the smallest hint that Clodia and Cicero didn‚Äôt take this political feud personally. In a letter from well after the trial, Cicero mentions speaking with Clodia about buying some land from her. It‚Äôs such an offhand, casual mention that it seems that they were on perfectly normal speaking terms. It certainly shows that both continued to move in the same social circles even after the trial. Maybe they were even friendly. It is this detail more than any other that suggests Clodia as an equal to the men of her time: that, just like men in politics, she was perfectly capable of having vitriolic public clashes with someone, then meet them later at a party and leave it behind.
In the end, Clodia was a socialite. She mingled with the men of Rome‚Äôs aristocracy as an equal, had affairs at will, involved herself in drama both personal and political, and remained part of her social circles regardless. She was a renowned beauty, an occasional political operator, and the very model of the docta puella.
medium.com
Clodius Pulcher, like the Gracchi before him, was a populist rabblerouser. He‚Äôd risen to power by orchestrating huge amounts of mob violence and had a loyal group of supporters who were about to drive him to higher and better offices. Unfortunately, he has just been undone by the very force that created him: his gang and one led by a rival named Milo clashed in the road just outside Rome, and Clodius has been murdered. It‚Äôs 52 BCE, and Rome is at a crossroads.
Clodius‚Äôs supporters have brought his body to his widow, Fulvia, who cries publicly in her doorway. According to ritual and tradition, these should be her next steps: Fulvia needs to have the body cleaned and dressed, then leave it lying in the atrium so visitors can pay their respects before the funeral. Then in a few days, she must gather the family for a funeral procession through the city, which will include representations of Clodius‚Äôs famous ancestors (of which he has very many ‚Äî see the description of his sister Clodia‚Äôs family above). The procession will stop at the Forum, where a distinguished male family member or friend will give a funeral oration in her husband‚Äôs honor. Then all will proceed to the family tomb outside the city walls, where the body will be cremated and placed in an urn inside the mausoleum. This is the procedure, and though it can be fraught with emotion, it is orderly and time-honored.
Fulvia does not do this.
She allows Clodius‚Äôs supporters to take his body, still broken and mangled by the street fight that killed him, directly to the Forum. There they lay him on the Rostra and give his impromptu funeral oration ‚Äî mere hours after his death instead of days ‚Äî in a way that whips the common people into a frenzy at the loss of their hero. The mob takes Clodius‚Äôs body and decides to cremate it on the spot, but by tradition all crematoria are outside the city walls. So they use the Senate house instead. The Curia Hostilia, the senate‚Äôs meeting place for at least 500 years, burns to the ground.
It is a horrifying parody of a Roman funeral. Fulvia at least allowed it to happen, and quite likely encouraged it ‚Äî it was the role of a good Roman wife to enhance the legacy of her husband, and Fulvia was consistently a funhouse-mirror version of the good Roman wife.
In the aftermath of Clodius‚Äôs funeral, Milo goes on trial for his murder, and even a court stacked with his allies knows better than to acquit him in the face of such popular unrest. Cicero doesn‚Äôt even risk giving the defense speech he‚Äôs written for the occasion. The burning of the Senate house was a message no one could ignore, and the Senate takes immediate steps to bring back stability. The march toward a civil war that will destroy the republic continues ‚Äî and this isn‚Äôt the last role Fulvia will play in it.
Fulvia was married three times, all of her husbands ill-fated. Her first, Clodius, was the most successful populist politician in all of Roman history, until he very much wasn‚Äôt. Her second, Curio, had been a close ally of Clodius during his life and inherited Clodius‚Äôs supporters. Curio, however, didn‚Äôt have the reformist spirit of Clodius ‚Äî he threw in his lot with Julius Caesar, and died in Africa during Caesar‚Äôs civil war. We hear nothing about Fulvia in this period. It is Fulvia‚Äôs third husband who will throw her back into the public spotlight almost a decade after Clodius‚Äôs death ‚Äî another partisan of Caesar named Mark Antony.
In the aftermath of Caesar‚Äôs murder, Antony is one of few men in a position to try to seize his supporters and become the next Caesar. The next decade is chaos, with alliances and rivalries shifting constantly. Antony‚Äôs most consequential sometime-ally-sometime-rival is Octavian, the great-nephew and official heir of Caesar. Octavian is much younger than Antony and has no military experience while Antony is a seasoned and respected general. But Octavian has something Antony never does: he is an incredible propagandist.
Fulvia first enters Octavian‚Äôs propaganda by way of Cicero, who attacks Antony in a blistering set of speeches called the Philippics during a period of hostility between Antony and Octavian. As Clodius‚Äôs old enemy, Cicero can‚Äôt resist also attacking Fulvia, wife of Antony and widow of Clodius. He calls her a deadly thing that has destroyed both her previous husbands and is about to destroy her third. He simultaneously questions Antony‚Äôs morality by bringing up his many affairs and paints Fulvia as a controlling woman whom Antony slavishly obeys.
Fulvia‚Äôs response to Cicero‚Äôs attacks is emblematic of the actions of a Roman politician‚Äôs wife. Since Antony is away in the East and unable to respond, Fulvia circulates the city with Antony‚Äôs mother, meeting with senators and solidifying alliances that would protect her husband. Wives were the original lobbyists ‚Äî prominent Roman men relied on their wives to set up their social calendars in ways that would further their careers, and when they were out of the city, their wives were among their most important advocates. Some accounts have Fulvia falling at the feet of senators and weeping to convince them to spare her husband. She is successful.
Soon, the rift between Antony and Octavian is brushed away in favor of a renewed alliance ‚Äî and a proscription list. Proscription is a method of sanctioning political murders; Antony and Octavian offer rewards for killing their political enemies, then use the resources of the dead to fund their war on the conspirators who killed Caesar. Since Cicero attacked Antony, he makes it onto Antony‚Äôs list, and Octavian does not object. Cicero is murdered while fleeing the city. Many wish to see Fulvia‚Äôs hand in this murder: she exacts delayed revenge on behalf of her first husband Clodius (who had been Cicero‚Äôs staunchest opponent), and on her own behalf after Cicero dragged her name through the muck. But Cicero was at least as much Antony‚Äôs enemy as he was Fulvia‚Äôs, and the Philippics had been much crueler to him than to her. Still, the legend goes that Fulvia took out her hairpins and stabbed the tongue on Cicero‚Äôs severed head.
As I mentioned, Antony spent much of this period in the East, while Octavian kept firm control of Rome in the West. Fulvia stayed in Rome, putting her (again) in the position of defending Antony‚Äôs interests in his absence ‚Äî even as he infamously had very public affairs with a Cappadocian princess named Glaphyra, then with the Egyptian queen Cleopatra. Inevitably, Octavian turned against Antony again, and Antony dithered about his reply. But Fulvia felt no need to wait for him.
In 41 BCE, Fulvia allied with Antony‚Äôs brother, Lucius Antonius, to raise an army and oppose Octavian. She helped raise troops, an atypical role for a woman to play. But her involvement proved helpful to Octavian‚Äôs propaganda: he painted the rebellion as the work of Antony‚Äôs out-of-control wife, who was just jealous because her husband was sleeping with other women. He said Fulvia had strapped on a sword and armor and led troops herself (which she almost certainly did not do, to my everlasting disappointment, because I adore this image for all the same reasons Octavian hated it). It fit well with Cicero‚Äôs earlier characterization of Antony as weak and controlled by women, and would transfer well to Octavian‚Äôs later war against Antony and his lover Cleopatra. We still have to contend with Octavian‚Äôs exaggerated image of Fulvia when we consider her, because his messaging was very successful ‚Äî it has made a larger impact on history than Fulvia herself ever did. Octavian‚Äôs soldiers even inscribed sling bullets with sexual insults aimed at Fulvia before lobbing them at her and Lucius‚Äôs troops ‚Äî in the propaganda war, this battle was Octavian vs. Fulvia, not Octavian vs. Lucius Antonius or Antony himself.
Lucius Antonius and Fulvia lost their battle in the Italian town of Perusia. (The incident would be called the Perusine War after this town.) Mark Antony disavowed the entire incident, and Octavian viewed his shaky alliance as worth maintaining, so he exiled Lucius and Fulvia instead of having them executed. Fulvia went to Athens to reunite briefly with Antony, but she died of an illness not long afterward. She did not live to see Antony and Cleopatra become so close they might as well have been married, or their unsuccessful last stand in 31 BCE against Octavian, the future Emperor Augustus.
Fulvia‚Äôs legacy is complicated. She was certainly politically savvy and capable, but as much as she did not fear to flout convention, everything she did was in service of her husbands‚Äô interests. Ultimately, there is much about her that is unknowable. Clodius and Antony were on the losing sides of their conflicts, so everything we know about her is filtered through a hostile lens; we can trust no surviving characterizations of her. This, I think, is one of Fulvia‚Äôs most fascinating aspects: we know what she did, but nothing about what she thought or how she was. Though she is often held up as the quintessential Roman troublesome woman, the real Fulvia is an enigma.
Hortensia was a female orator who spoke against a plan by the Second Triumvirate to tax noblewomen. We don‚Äôt know much about her aside from this one act, but she won great respect in oratory, a domain the Romans considered male-only.
Hortensia was the daughter of Quintus Hortensius, an illustrious orator and rival to Cicero. The backdrop for Hortensia‚Äôs speech was the civil war that destroyed the Republic, the same one that Fulvia participated in. After decades of fighting, the war chests were growing empty. Octavian, Mark Antony, and Lepidus, the Second Triumvirate, proscribed their political rivals to raise money through their wealth (the proscription list that killed Cicero), but even that wasn‚Äôt enough. So in 42 BCE, they came up with a plan to tax the 1,400 wealthiest women in Rome.
Laws targeting women in wartime had a history in Rome: during the Second Punic War two centuries earlier, huge defeats by Hannibal led to the Lex Oppia, which limited women‚Äôs wealth. The justification was that wealthy men had to contribute to war by fighting, so wealthy women had to pull their weight by paying. In the case of the Lex Oppia, there was also an unstated reason: anxiety over women holding the wealth of Roman society. The Roman aristocracy had been gutted by the disastrous victories of Hannibal of Carthage. For the first time, huge numbers of widows were inheriting their husbands‚Äô estates. Roman moralists panicked, and the senate acted to ‚Äúprotect‚Äù the fortunes of the great families from capricious women.
In the case of the Triumvirate‚Äôs proposal, the motivation was political: just as in the Punic War, the wealthy women who would be taxed were widows. Most of the widows of the aristocracy were produced by their husbands‚Äô deaths in the civil wars ‚Äî thus, taxing widows was a way of draining their political enemies‚Äô funds posthumously.
A group of noblewomen led by Hortensia appeared before the Triumvirate to argue the injustice of the proposed tax. No authentic account of her speech survives. The Greek historian Appian, writing a century later, presents a version of her speech produced by his own imagination ‚Äî this speech includes the jarringly modern argument that women were being taxed for a war that they had no say in, because they could not vote or hold public office. In other words, an ancient Roman (Greek?) version of a suffrage argument, or perhaps no taxation without representation. What the real Hortensia said is a mystery, but we hear glowing reviews from various ancient writers who did have access to the text. She was said to have resurrected the oratorical greatness of her father.
The Triumvirate tried to usher the women off the speaker‚Äôs platform, but the crowd rebelled. In the end, they reduced the list of women to be taxed to 400 and looked for other sources of revenue. Hortensia‚Äôs speech was a partial success.
Hortensia‚Äôs story isn‚Äôt as extensive as some of the other women‚Äôs on this list, but she was certainly a woman who took ownership of an issue. She stepped out of the traditional woman‚Äôs role in Rome and into the spotlight of politics, however briefly ‚Äî and unlike of the most women who did so, she won respect instead of condemnation.
Sulpicia is a true rarity: a female Roman poet. We know of a few poetesses from Roman times (one of whom, hilariously, is a Silver Age poet also named Sulpicia). But only the Sulpicia of the first century CE has a body of poems still in existence today. So what can our lone surviving female Roman poet tell us?
Sulpicia was a docta puella from a literary family: her grandfather was Servius Sulpicius Rufus, whom Cicero called the greatest orator he‚Äôd ever heard, and the uncle who raised her was the literary patron who launched the career of Ovid. It‚Äôs no surprise she became a writer. Her oeuvre is short, six poems totaling 40 lines together. Her complete collected works fit comfortably on one sheet of paper. They are elegiac poems, a Roman genre of passionate poems addressed to (usually fickle) lovers. She writes about a pseudonymous lover named Cerinthus ‚Äî her love for him, and the pain caused by both of their missteps and by other people pulling them apart. She takes on the voice of an emotional teenage girl, pouting at her uncle as he plans an inconvenient family trip, cursing herself for missteps in communication with her lover, and wrestling with questions about her identity and place in society.
For centuries, Sulpicia‚Äôs poems were not recognized as hers. They were preserved in a manuscript of Tibullus and assumed to be his. Scholarship showed her authorship in the 1800s, but for the next century, she was regarded only as a curiosity. Scholars said her poems lacked refinement, that she was a passionate, emotional amateur who didn‚Äôt merit serious study. (Gee, I wonder if her gender had anything to do with these assessments.) Only in the 1970s did scholars start to take a closer look, strip away the prejudices of the past, and begin to appreciate the talent and erudition underlying Sulpicia‚Äôs poetry.
But even if those old-fashioned scholars had been right about her, Sulpicia would still offer us something no other Roman poet can. Much Roman ink was spilled writing about men chasing after doctae puellae, but in Sulpicia‚Äôs case, the docta puella herself speaks. She has much to say about identity and social respectability from a woman‚Äôs viewpoint. Although Sulpicia‚Äôs work is not extensive and does not touch on many of the subjects we would love to know about through her eyes, still, she is an authentic female Roman voice ‚Äî one of very few we still have access to ‚Äî and thus can help us make up for some of the bothersome blind spots in our study of the Roman experience.
medium.com
Livia Drusilla was the wife of Augustus and first empress of Rome ‚Äî it can be fairly said that she set the expectations for all empresses after her. She was a close advisor and confidant of the emperor and was thus heavily involved in politics. But unlike Fulvia, she kept herself rigidly within the acceptable social boundaries set for Roman women, so her public image during her lifetime was much more positive. After her death, however, it turns out that no amount of piety can satisfy the writers of history, because she gets accused of being a conniving murderer in equal measure with her more scandalous peers.
Livia was the third wife of Augustus (the former Octavian), but seems to have been the first one he married for love rather than alliance-building. They were both married to other people when they met, and Augustus was immediately smitten. He divorced his wife Scribonia on the same day she gave birth to their daughter, and compelled Livia‚Äôs husband, Tiberius Claudius Nero, to divorce her even though she was six months pregnant with their second child. Augustus and Livia married immediately, and Livia‚Äôs ex-husband gave her away at the wedding ceremony as if he were the father of the bride. This was in 38 BCE, after the future Augustus defeated Fulvia at Perusia but before he defeated Antony and Cleopatra.
Augustus and Livia then had a happy 51-year marriage. Livia was just as careful in presenting her public image as her husband always was: she was depicted consistently as a chaste, modest, religiously reverent matron. She never produced children for him (their only pregnancy ended in stillbirth), which many Roman men would have responded to with divorce. But Augustus‚Äôs affection for Livia never seemed to diminish. According to Suetonius, Augustus kept notes throughout the day of things he meant to tell her so he wouldn‚Äôt forget anything when he saw her (which is the hardest I have ever liked or related to that slimy bastard).
It is ironic that Livia never had children with Augustus, because Augustus passed a slate of morality laws to reward women for childbearing in an effort to improve the aristocratic birthrate. The era of Augustus is a time of re-traditionalizing after the time of the docta puella ‚Äî adultery was criminalized, and women were granted certain civil rights as long as they had enough children. The Roman nobility pulled its wives and daughters back out of the public eye, and Augustus led the charge. His wife was presented as the ideal matron in public. The fact that she filled this role for him without giving him an heir is a testament that their love was real and important to him.
Still, Livia was accused by later historians of engineering the deaths of Augustus‚Äôs relatives ‚Äî and even of poisoning Augustus himself ‚Äî in order that her own son might become his heir. It is true that Augustus lost a lot of heirs before reluctantly adopting Livia‚Äôs son by her first husband, who became the second emperor, Tiberius. But modern historians reject the idea that this was Livia‚Äôs doing. It‚Äôs a bit of slander that doesn‚Äôt fit well with everything else we know about her, especially the fact that she was never as close to her son Tiberius as she was to her husband. If you‚Äôre looking for an empress willing to murder her husband for the advancement of her son, look further down the list ‚Äî Livia‚Äôs not your girl, but Agrippina is on her way.
After Augustus‚Äôs death of natural causes (no poison needed), Livia retained enormous influence as Augusta, the widow of a god. She clashed with her son, who had no desire to share power with his mother. Even as her real influence dwindled, she enjoyed the ceremony and honor her status afforded her. She died in 29 CE, 15 years after her husband, and her son Tiberius vetoed the order Augustus had left behind that Livia be deified upon her death. 13 years later, her grandson, the fourth emperor Claudius, restored all her honors and made her a god, Diva Augusta.
The age of Augustus brought a re-traditionalizing of Roman womanhood after the age of the docta puella, and Livia Drusilla was the posterchild of the proper imperial matron. Her marriage is a rare case of a happy marriage in the imperial household, and she garnered enough public respect to be honored as a god after her death.
Agrippina was another empress, the wife of the fourth emperor Claudius and the mother of the fifth emperor Nero. Like Fulvia, Agrippina is depicted in ancient histories as a scheming woman intent on exercising power through powerful men ‚Äî and unlike Fulvia, Agrippina seems to have deserved this reputation. Her story is a soap opera that involves the murder of her husband and her own murder by her son in some real Looney Tunes shenanigans.
Agrippina was a member of the Julio-Claudian family tree, which is impossibly full of cousin marriages and adoptions ‚Äî she‚Äôs related to just about anyone you can name from this period. She was the daughter of Agrippina the Elder (the well-respected granddaughter of Augustus) and Germanicus (a beloved general who was Tiberius‚Äôs heir until his own untimely death). When Tiberius died in 37 CE, it was Agrippina‚Äôs brother Caligula who took over.
Caligula‚Äôs reign is infamous, as is his relationship with his three sisters ‚Äî he was very close to them and heaped public honors on them. (Several ancient sources say that Caligula committed incest with his sisters, but this is just slander and not at all likely to be true.) The relationship soured when Caligula‚Äôs favorite sister, Drusilla, died. The other two sisters fell out of favor, and Agrippina became wrapped up in palace intrigue and possibly an assassination plot. She was forced to carry the ashes of her executed brother-in-law (an alleged co-conspirator) in his funeral procession, then was exiled from Rome.
After Caligula‚Äôs assassination a few years later, his uncle Claudius took the throne and invited his exiled relatives back. Claudius had a reputation as a weak man pushed around by freedmen and women, especially his wife, Messalina. After allegedly scheming to overthrow Claudius, Messalina was executed, and Claudius began to think about taking a new wife. He chose Agrippina (now a widow twice over with one son), possibly as a way to make peace between the feuding Julian and Claudian branches of the family. They had to get special permission from the senate to marry because Agrippina was Claudius‚Äôs niece ‚Äî ick.
As empress, Agrippina exerted huge influence, pursuing and killing personal enemies and piling honors on herself and her son. She persuaded Claudius to adopt her son, who took the name Nero ‚Äî bafflingly, this meant Claudius gave Nero precedence over his own son, Britannicus, who was a few years younger. But apparently Claudius began to get wise and to prepare to distance himself from Agrippina and Nero. So Agrippina enlisted the support of the palace poisoner, a woman named Locusta (‚Äúlobster‚Äù) ‚Äî yes, the imperial palace was the sort of place to employ a poisoner. With Locusta‚Äôs help, Agrippina killed Claudius by poisoning his mushrooms at a feast. Her son Nero remained his heir.
When Nero took the throne in 54 CE, his mother Agrippina kept a tight leash on him. She put his praetorian commander Burrus and his tutor Seneca the Younger in charge and publicly honored herself as nearly a co-ruler. Nero began to rebel, so Agrippina signaled that she might start to favor Claudius‚Äôs son Britannicus as his replacement. In response, Nero poisoned Britannicus at dinner just as Agrippina had Claudius. Picture the scene: Britannicus takes a sip of his wine (Nero put the poison into the snow used to cool wine instead of the wine itself to evade the food tasters) and drops dead immediately (Locusta had advised a slow-acting poison, but Nero had insisted on a fast one that would be obvious). His mother and all his advisers know what he has just done, but Nero says that Britannicus is only having an epileptic fit and will soon recover. The household is forced to finish their dinner with the teenager‚Äôs corpse still at the table. Nero wanted to deliver a message to his mother, and he certainly succeeded.
A few years of rising tensions later, Nero threw Agrippina out of the imperial palace. As he prepared to escape from under the thumb of the advisors she‚Äôd assigned him and start ruling for himself, he decided he should kill her too. So he offered her the use of one of his boats for a pleasure cruise to the resort town of Baiae. He had the boat rigged to sink, and had a trick awning built that could be triggered to fall on his mother and weigh her down to the deck so she couldn‚Äôt escape the sinking ship. Like I said in the introduction ‚Äî Looney Tunes shenanigans. But Agrippina is the Roadrunner in this scenario: she wrestled her way free of the awning and swam to shore. Nero decided the time for subtlety was over and simply sent soldiers to her house to murder her.
Agrippina was a cunning, ambitious woman with the same lack of scruples as the men in her family. She was the great-granddaughter, adopted granddaughter, sister, wife, and mother respectively of the five Julio-Claudian emperors. She murdered her husband with poisoned mushrooms only to be murdered in turn by the son she‚Äôd put on the throne ‚Äî no one can say she didn‚Äôt know the game she was playing.
There are many empresses who came after Agrippina and similarly played political games as wives and mothers, most notably the many Julias of the Severan Dynasty ‚Äî perhaps if I ever write a sequel to this article, I‚Äôll cover them. For now, I‚Äôd like to take you forward a few centuries‚Ä¶
Honoria was an empress of sorts in the early 5th century CE, just before the fall of the western empire ‚Äî and indeed there is an old-fashioned tradition of blaming her for the Fall of Rome itself. The Rome Honoria inhabited was very different from the Rome of all the other women on this list; one might even consider it an entirely separate society. But the woman who couldn‚Äôt follow a vow of chastity so hard she might have sent a marriage proposal to Attila the Hun about it certainly deserves a spot on this list.
Honoria was the daughter of short-lived emperor Constantius III and Galla Placidia, another woman who merits discussion. Placidia, the sister of emperor Honorius, was taken as a prisoner of war in the 410 CE sack of Rome by the Visigoths. When relations improved between the Goths and Honorius, the Gothic leader Ataulf married Placidia in 414 to cement a Romano-Gothic alliance. But relations soured again, and after her Gothic husband‚Äôs overthrow, Placidia returned to Rome as part of a peace treaty, where her brother married her off to a general who later became his co-emperor Constantius III.
Placidia had three children, including Honoria, who would have been a young child for much of what followed: Placidia‚Äôs husband Constantius III died, Placidia fell out with Emperor Honorius, and the family fled to Constantinople. A few short years later Honorius died, leaving a power vacuum in Rome, and Placidia and her children returned to join the dynastic struggle. In 425 CE, Placidia had her young son set up as the emperor Valententian III, and she became his regent, as no one expected a five-year-old to rule. Placidia held effective power as Augusta for the next 25 years.
Placidia gave the title Augusta to her daughter, presumably so she could help as regent if Placidia herself became unable for any reason. But centuries of dynastic struggle made late imperial households take some extreme measures: as Augusta, Honoria had to take a vow of chastity so that she wouldn‚Äôt produce any heirs to challenge the legitimacy of her emperor brother. She found this difficult when she matured, and became pregnant by a palace official. (Honoria‚Äôs chronology isn‚Äôt easy to pin down, but I think she was in her 20s or 30s at this point.) Her mother took away her title, executed her lover, and had her engaged to a middling senator with no ambition as a way of disarming her.
Stripped of power and prestige, Honoria chafed. She had been raised by a powerful imperial woman and expected the same life for herself. And so in 449 CE, Honoria sent a request for help ‚Äî along with her engagement ring ‚Äî to Attila the Hun. She offered him the western empire if he would extract her from her terrible engagement.
The infamous Attila had been threatening both halves of the Roman empire for some years now, but had not yet dared to make an all-out attack. Now he had received a plea and a ring from the sister of the western emperor ‚Äî whether Honoria had actually meant her gesture as a marriage proposal is unclear, but Attila chose to interpret it that way, seizing on her request for help as a pretense to invade and a marriage alliance as a possible way to hang onto Rome once he took it. He announced his intention to march on Rome and claim his bride.
Emperor Valentinian III exiled his sister Honoria ‚Äî only the influence of their mother Galla Placidia stopped him from executing her ‚Äî and had to fight the Huns in Italy in the early 450s. But Attila never took Rome or claimed his Roman bride. Though he won all his battles in Italy, external forces pulled him east again, and he died shortly thereafter.
Nothing is known of Honoria‚Äôs life after this incident. There is some evidence to suggest that she was dead six years later, in 455, but we cannot be sure ‚Äî she either died young or disappeared into obscurity.
Historians looking for a sensational story have sometimes pointed to Honoria inviting Attila the Hun to attack Rome as the cause of the final fall of the west, but the connection between those events is tenuous at best. That would imply that Attila was a primary cause of the fall, which is not a very solid argument. Attila, and by extension Honoria, merely contributed to the chaos swallowing the western empire at this time; they did not cause it.
Still, the story of an imperial woman so insulted at having been removed from power that she proposed an alliance (and possibly a marriage) with one of the most infamous so-called ‚Äúbarbarians‚Äù of all time to regain it‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a doozy, even if it didn‚Äôt actually destroy the empire. We can thank Honoria for one of the wildest, most soap-opera-like turns in late Roman history.
Socialites, schemers, pious wives, treacherous empresses ‚Äî these eight women show a range of ways an upper-class woman could penetrate the male-centric bias of ancient historians and be recorded, however imperfectly, in their annals. My goal was to focus on Roman women who appear in the histories (with one sidebar into literature), which means this list is not intersectional: the lives of lower-class and slave women are more difficult to recover, though no less worthy of the effort.
These eight women represent a variety of ways in which women were received in their own time, from admiration to horror, from crediting them for making a difference to blaming them for the fall of society. A Roman woman was expected to support her family in public, but was routinely punished if she became too visible. The experience of being a woman was, perhaps, not as different from today as we might expect.
So tell me‚Ä¶ which Roman women have I missed? Who should I cover in part 2?

‚ÄúOh, the streets of Rome are filled with rubble Ancient footprints are everywhere You can almost think that you‚Äôre seein‚Äô double On a cold, dark night on the Spanish Stairs‚Äù- Bob Dylan, When I Paint My Masterpiece
How often do I think about the Roman Empire?
As a brown South Asian man, not much. I see the Roman Empire as a distant blip- a collection of bedtime stories featuring tales of valour, romance, betrayal, political intrigue, and war. However, when surrounded by the Pantheon, Trevi Fountain, and the Colosseum, its hard not to think about the Roman Empire. The Roman Empire is inseparable from the life of the average present-day resident of Rome. The construction of the Rome Metro Line was repeatedly interrupted because every time they dug underground, they found Roman ruins. The average Italian‚Äôs regular Rome commute on the metro disobeys conventional underground train urban planning as it zigzags across the city to avoid running through Roman artifacts. The average Italian in Rome also disdains at the bumbling, clueless tourists who block the glorious Vespa‚Äôs right-of-way on the road. While the Roman Empire expanded outward from within like an amoeba conquering everything in its path, modern Rome is being conquered by tourists from without. And the reason for the tourist invasion? The gargantuan Roman artifacts that are interspersed with the average neighborhood in Rome. And of course, the food.
The word ‚Äòromance‚Äô comes from the old French word ‚Äòromanz‚Äô referring to the act of speaking in the old vernacular, more Latinized French. Romanz referred to a bygone era where Latin was the lingua franca during the Roman Empire. Stories written in the vernacular- or romanz- were action packed, chivalric, and medieval. Think Shrek, but less self-aware. These tales involved medieval knights setting off on Herculean adventures, slaying beasts, sparring with Barbarians, and winning a lucky maiden‚Äôs hand in marriage. These tales were a glimpse into the imagination of a person in the Middle Ages. It was a mythical adoration and idealization of a bygone Roman era which would be reminisced for centuries to come. The hero undertaking life threatening trials and tribulations to win the love of a beautiful maiden would- in this context- be romantic (i.e. imbued with the characteristics of a Roman). The ethos of Rome is giving Paris a serious run for its money in the title battle for The City of Love.
Another area where Rome gives Paris a run for its money is the food. We‚Äôve all had a croissant- the flaky, soft package of buttery goodness that takes on a velvety texture when dipped in a cappuccino. The croissant is quintessentially French. Liberte, Egalite, Fraternite may well be the core values of the French Republic, but the word Croissant can be added to the end of that verbiage to include another aspect of what is core to being French. But what if I told you that there is a better alternative to the croissant- an alternative that we‚Äôve all ignored over the last few centuries? Enter the cornetto, a larger, flakier, butter-ier, velvet-ier alternative to the croissant which comes filled with varieties of cream- usually, Pistachio, Chocolate or Custard. If you walk opposite to the direction of the teeming hoardes of tourists in Rome, you‚Äôll come across local Pasticcerias- local pastry shops- selling cheap cornettos out of holes in walls. Italians line up around the block to collect their daily dose of cappuccino and cornetto right before their morning commute. The combination creates an essential fuel for today‚Äôs Roman, providing them with mental acuity and patience to tolerate bumbling tourists that block the roadways. One such hole-in-the-wall is the Roscioli Caf√© Pasticceria- an iconic establishment that is always full, busy and teeming with Italians. One bite into Roscioli‚Äôs famous tent-pole pistachio cornetto expands the boundaries of what your mind thought was possible- the flaky, buttery, velvety soft texture of the cappuccino infused pastry is bombarded with the nutty, creamy, smooth, hearty textures of the pistachio crema. Now compare that with the croissant- a heap of flaky pastry that falls apart at the smallest touch. I will never see the croissant the same way again. The French have monopolized our consciousness and successfully convinced us of the superiority of their cuisine. Try one pistachio cornetto, and you‚Äôll realize that a croissant is a middle-of-the-road bland husk of carbohydrates, or as the French like to say- merde.
Similar to the croissant, the pizza that you‚Äôve been eating all your life is a lie. Pizza, once the pride of Italy, has been bastardized and appropriated by the Americans (as with all foods), and elevated to a sort of quintessentially American experience. The Pizza we eat today is what the American capitalist machine has forcefully shoved down our throats- a slab of chewy, overcooked dough, topped with excessively saucy and drippy tomaytuh sowuhss, complimented by an indistinguishable rapidly melting slop of mozzarella cheese made in a factory being operated by some poor bloke working minimum wage to mass produce a cheese purpose-built for the fastest melt rather than the best flavor. American pizza is not made with love, it‚Äôs made to suit the convenience of Americans- mass produced, characterless slop served quick and cheap, ready to reheat and eaten on the go in a Ford F-150. Italians take offense to the idea of New York Pizza. Even more offensive, are the Detroit Style and Chicago pizzas.
Romans have been consuming pizzas for centuries. Originated as a flat piece of dough topped with meat, vegetables and other accouterments during the Roman Empire, the pizza has mass appeal across cultures- take for example, the lahmacun in Turkey, the pide in the Levant, the mana‚Äôkish in the Gulf. The ancient recipe was simple- no frills, with no tomato sauce or melted cheese, providing for the best way for ancient Romans to gain energy on their long conquests, whilst maximizing flavor. Tomatoes eventually made their way into Italy in the 18th Century as a new world crop- ‚Äúdiscovered‚Äù by Spanish conquistadors in their conquest of Latin America and brought back to Europe. And so began the tomato sauce fad. Look closely at regional pizza variations, and one will notice that pizzas in Naples almost entirely comprise a layer of tomato sauce on the dough. Meanwhile, Pizzas sold by decades old vendors in Rome include the original, sauce-less variations. While Naples does indisputably take credit for being the originator of the Pizza, there is an argument to be made that vendors in Rome remained true to the Pizza‚Äôs original tomato sauce-less form. One such Roman vendor is the famous Roscioli Antico Forno (different Roscioli this time).
Roscioli‚Äôs pizza, a very archetypal Roman kind- it‚Äôs flat, crispy, and served by the slice in rectangular form. Roscioli‚Äôs pizzas vary with the tomato sauce and non-sauce variations alike, producing variations that people travel across the world for. Their most popular pizza slice is the pizza bianca- or White Pizza. While the white pizzas sold at the large American chains usually replace tomato sauce with a regurgitated toxic sludge of a bechamel that fails to obey Newtonian fluid dynamics, Roscioli‚Äôs is without a sauce- leaving the white (or bianca) base exposed like a blank canvas ripe for culinary experimentation. Their dough- a treasured family secret- does all the heavy lifting. It‚Äôs crispy and flaky, whilst being flat with the right amount of give required for the perfect chew. Their variations include one that‚Äôs topped with potatoes, olive oil, salsiccia (Italian sausage) and rosemary creating a simple yet delicious slice that‚Äôs dripping with olive oil and can be eaten on-the-go. Another pizza variation famous in Rome, is the Pizza Marinara, reproduced best by another locally respected establishment- Pizza alla Palla.
Pizza alla Palla is tucked away into one of Rome‚Äôs back alleys within a quaint residential area. You will almost hear zero English spoken within a 500-metre radius of this establishment. It‚Äôs operating space is so tiny, that it can only fit 4 to 5 diners at once. The limited seating space is not a concern to their patrons, as the pizzas fly out from behind the counter in white paper bags to be quickly engorged on by a hungry Roman while they go on to conquer the Roman streets in their crusade against pedestrians and tourists. Pizza alla Palla‚Äôs pizzas- like most Roman pizza shops- lay behind a glass wall and are illuminated by bright yellow, fluorescent lights to contrast the bright reds of the sauce.
The Pizza Marinara, is a thought experiment on what Pizza would look like without cheese. While we‚Äôve grown up eating cheesy pizza from American establishments our whole lives, the Romans have been eating Pizza without melted cheese for more than two centuries. Unlike with Roscioli, Pizza alla Palla‚Äôs pizza is carried by the sauce. My favourite variation on the marinara was a slice with anchovies, capers, olives and fresh burrata. The saltiness of the anchovies and olives when combined with the tartness of the capers and tomato sauce reinforce the hearty, fatty, and fresh burrata creating the ultimate flavour bomb that one can reminisce for years. If anchovies on pizza isn‚Äôt your cup of tea, then I suggest you go for local artisanal vendor Pizza Hut‚Äôs artful, hand-crafted, oven baked Pizza Margherita with a tomato sauce so generic that it may as well be copyrighted by Toronto based rapper Drake, accompanied by a cheese topping identical to a radioactive toxic sludge that makes Chernobyl look like a kiddie-pool.
Similar to Rome‚Äôs pizza, Rome‚Äôs pasta are quite unique and under-explored as well. The 4 pastas indigenous to Rome are: The Cacio E Pepe (Cheese and Pepper), Carbonara, Amatriciana and alla Gricia. What all these dishes have in common is the heavy-handed use of pepper to create nutty, mildly spicy notes to contrast with the fat of the cheese and guanciale (Pork jowl). Guanciale- a slab of fatty pork meat- is heavily used in the Carbonara, Amatriciana and alla Gricia and its fat often serves as a starting base for the sauces. Carbonara adds egg to this fat, Amatriciana adds tomato sauce and alla Gricia adds cheese, creating a holy trinity of Roman fat-based pasta sauces. The most common of these outside of Italy is the Carbonara, almost universally bastardized through the extra addition of cream, bacon and emulsifying agents. The universalization of American Italian food through mass production and the prevalence of American cultural exports everywhere has forced us to accept mediocre dishes as the standard. These dishes use old, chewy bacon instead of guanciale; salty, starchy, powdery parmesan with a texture similar to a social lubricant ubiquitous on Wall Street; store brought dried, chewy pasta as a vehicle for the sauce; and most importantly, xanthan gum to lend the pasta cohesion in order to hide the underpaid, overworked chef‚Äôs lack of skill in emulsifying pasta sauces.
Do yourself a favour and seek out a local Italian establishment- one that uses guanciale in the carbonara- and taste the difference between an actual carbonara and what you‚Äôve assumed is a carbonara for your entire life. As one famous quote goes, ‚Äúmediocrity is a sin‚Äù- or as I transliterate it to ‚Äúnever settle for a pasta that uses shit ingredients‚Äù. Local pasta in Rome is cheap, fresh, and even healthy given the average 10k steps-a-day mileage for the average commuter. To find the best, bang-for-buck establishments frequented by local patrons, ask the cab drivers for where they would eat. Or even go in the opposite direction to the tourist hivemind, and maybe then you‚Äôll actually experience some local culture.
Walk down any Roman street, and you‚Äôll find small, quaint trattorias selling suppli- a gooey, cheesy ball of leftover risotto or pasta that is doused in egg, coated with breadcrumbs and deep fried. You‚Äôll find this everywhere in Rome. But it is often overlooked by small-minded tourists who conceptualize Italian food as pizza and pasta. Supplis (not to be confused with the Southern Arancini) are a small snack that are a cultural equivalent of a samosa- eaten either as an appetizer or between meals to satiate one‚Äôs appetite. Suppli can be quite intoxicating, addictive and pair well with local beer creating the ideal bitter and salty-savoury combination that hits the right spot at 2 am on a Thursday night.
We think we know Italian food. But we don‚Äôt. There are so many cultural variations and dishes that we‚Äôve never tried, and that we‚Äôll probably never try. Most of these dishes never make it out of Italy because Americans haven‚Äôt yet found an efficient way to ruin them yet. To go to Italy, and look for an Alfredo with grilled chicken on menus while committing the cardinal sin of asking the waiter for chilli flakes to spice your pasta is a disservice to the centuries old Italian culture that has tried, tested and perfected their foods. If you‚Äôve ordered chilli flakes or chilli oil (as most Indians I know) at an Italian restaurant, you probably don‚Äôt deserve to go to Italy. Respect the local culture, appreciate it for what it is, and please, do NOT make the whole table wait while you immaculately position the dishes for your Instagram story. Not only are you upsetting everyone at the table, you‚Äôre also upsetting the Italians. Their dishes don‚Äôt need your Instagram story to popularize them. They‚Äôve already refined their cuisine over centuries of experimentation.
My short, 36-hour Rome stay was eventful- I explored virtually all of Rome on foot, resorting to public transport only when necessary. I‚Äôve tried everything Rome has on platter- the gelatos, the Pizzas, the Suppli, the Pastas, the coffee, the pistachio cornetto. But there is still a lot left to see- Italy is not just Rome, Venice or Milan. Italy is Sicily, Naples, Emilia-Romagna, Calibria, Lombardy, Tuscany, and so much more. To say, that I know Italian food is an injustice to Italy. I, on the other hand, can affirm that I know Rome, and I hope that perhaps one day, I will know Italy.
There is a saying in Rome: ‚ÄúThe Milanese eat to live. Us Romans, on the other hand, live to eat.‚Äù The Roman experience is derived from the food. And perhaps, there is no Rome without its food- so the Roman Empire hasn‚Äôt completely died out. Its legacy lives on through its flavours, ingredients and culinary pastiches. The Roman sculptures look on as the centuries pass by. Empires come and go, and with it, the foreigners that visit Rome to witness the greatest city ever built. Neighborhoods, metro-lines, bus routes and office buildings are continuously built and destroyed on top of the ruins of an ancient, great civilization. Rome has always been in a churn of creative destruction. And all that remains- and all that will ever remain- is the food, sculptures and the Roman sun.

By Kellie J. Wright
Working Chapters
Part I
One of my clients, Chad Fuentes, recently said something that stayed with me:
‚ÄúI feel like sometimes we romanticize the past and put undue praise on characters or people from that past, while holding the people supporting us in the present to an unfair standard.‚Äù
Yes. There‚Äôs truth in that.
I had been reflecting on something similar while watching a speech from one of our national leaders‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääperhaps the President addressing Congress or the Senate. I can‚Äôt recall the exact details, but the image was clear: the structure, the solemnity, the way history lives and breathes through these halls. And I found myself thinking, There it is. Rome. Different time, different clothes, same posture.
This isn‚Äôt cynicism‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs recognition.
We, the people, love to imagine that we‚Äôve evolved. That our systems, our sophistication, our technology have moved us forward. But have we? Strip away the gold and the marble, and we are often still functioning from the same roots. The same hunger for power. The same imbalance. The same blindness to the living beauty beside and within each of us.

Title: All Roads Lead To Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
‚ÄúMille viae ducunt homines per saecula Romam‚Äù ‚Äî Alain de Lille, Liber Parabolarum
The phrase ‚ÄúAll roads lead to Rome‚Äù is a proverb that originated from the ancient Roman Empire, reflecting the city‚Äôs central importance as a hub of trade, culture, and power.
In a broader sense, it means that there are many different paths or approaches to reach a particular goal or destination. For single mothers in Indonesia, this proverb holds a significant meaning. It represents the understanding that they often face numerous challenges and obstacles in providing for their children and ensuring their well-being. Even when it seems like there are no viable options, single mothers need to be resilient and resourceful, creating new paths to navigate and overcome the difficulties they encounter.
Their children cannot wait for a clear path to access their basic needs, such as food, shelter, and education. It is the responsibility of single mothers to provide these necessities, even if it means forging new paths and finding alternative sources of income. Single mothers cannot rely on their children‚Äôs fathers to fulfill their financial ‚Äòobligations‚Äô and give child support, so they must continue to strive for self-sufficiency and sustainability.
I cannot imagine the struggle faced by single mothers without the privileges of higher education, extensive networks, or even personal branding like mine. With a relatively high level of education, the privilege to live in the capital city, and a strong personal brand, I am currently feeling almost desperate in my search for a path to my own version of Rome. I can only imagine the challenges faced by other women who may still be recovering from the abandonment of their former husbands, having been allowed to be only housewives for years and financially dependent on them. My heart goes out to them, and I hope they are always empowered to find their own paths to Rome, their own versions of success.
For me personally, I am still navigating a path that hopefully leads to my version of Rome. I am still somewhat afraid because this time the road is dark and full of obstacles. I am still terrified because I often feel powerless, considering my age and the fact that I have a son who is still fully dependent on me. They say there are many roads to Rome, and I personally believe that. There are many ways to generate income without having to work in an office. However, not everyone can or wants to take those paths.
Some may not be able to see the options in front of them because to them, it‚Äôs too dark and eerie, for some others, they would rather close their eyes in fear of the uncertainties. If you currently feel unable to navigate these paths and want to give up, take a break, I feel you. Once you have regained some of your strength, you can continue. If you are currently closing your eyes out of fear, it‚Äôs okay to be scared. Give yourself time to muster up the courage and give yourself a chance to see what choices you have.
The important thing is not to give up. Hang in there. If you experience various rejections, it does not mean you have failed. It could be that you are being protected from a much worse condition or being redirected towards a better path to your own version of Rome.
One day, I hope you will look back and see your today as an adventure and valuable experience that you can remember with joy in your hearts. Until then, just hang in there.
I love yous!

Title: Homosexuality in Ancient Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Disclaimer: I got a little wild in this article, hide the kids.
History has a tendency to leave out very obvious same-sex relationships. We have all heard of the astute gentleman who lived with his lifelong platonic male friend in a house with one bed. You may not have heard that Hadrian was so head over heels for his lover Antinous that he declared him a god upon Antinous‚Äôs death.
I‚Äôm sure your partner is kind to you, but have they ever made you a fucking god?
The term homosexuality did not exist in the language of the Romans. So when discussing same-sex relationships in the empire, we have to do so through a lens we may not initially understand. This article will explore how Romans saw sex in general with a few notable examples.
We can only go off historical accounts, artifacts, and writings of the time when discussing civilizations as old as Rome. So while these views might be the majority opinion, there were likely severe deviations in mindset on a one-to-one level.
There was almost certainly an old bitter roman telling younger generations to pull their damn togas up.
We define homosexuality as a relationship between two people of the same gender. Romans defined sex through power and status, which means that as long as you were the dominant party, your reputation was unaffected.
To put it gently, it was admirable to be the sword and pitiful to be the sheath. Didn‚Äôt really expect to be conjuring up historical metaphors for anal sex when I woke up today, but here we are.
This could be seen at the highest level of roman society. Nero enjoyed the casual midweek orgy with men and women and did just about everything you can sexually do throughout his life. This includes dressing as an animal and attacking the genitals of tied-up men and women.
The emperor was batshit crazy, but you can‚Äôt knock his creativity. He also had sex with his mother. This fun fact isn‚Äôt relevant to the article ‚Äî but I‚Äôm telling you anyway.
Nero had a young eunuch boy as his wife named Sporus, who was supposedly the spitting image of his late wife. This speaks to the more common pederasty of the time, but we won‚Äôt be getting into that here. I don‚Äôt discuss pedophilia before noon, as a rule. This marriage was peculiar but did not hurt the esteem of the emperor; it simply hinted at his mental instability.
It wasn‚Äôt until he took the former slave Pythagoras as a husband that everyone started giving a bit of side-eye. This was made worse by the fact that they had sex in front of their wedding guests. This resentment by the onlookers was not because Romans had disdain for same-sex relations. It was because their emperor was the ‚Äúwoman‚Äù in the relationship.
This leads me to an important point, Rome was plainly misogynistic. So even though it might seem like Rome was a sexually liberated place for its time, things were far less equal when it came to women. In fact, many considered lesbian relationships an unthinkable transgression.
This did not mean people of the time did not talk about it. A notable myth is that of Iphis, who was a girl raised as a boy. She falls in love with her appointed wife and is turned into a man by Isis. There is also the fictional story of Megilla, who changed her name and wore a wig to marry a Demonassa.
Several people, including Ovid, said women being sexually active exclusively with other women was an exceedingly rare occurrence.
What is more likely is that women were far less open about it than unquestionably powerful men like Nero, Hadrian, and Elagabalus. This is reinforced by the fact that it was seen largely as very socially unacceptable. Sadly, when lesbian relationships were discussed, it was typically with a tone of shame and disapproval.
This might have been due to how Rome perceived women and sex in general. For a woman to sleep with another woman meant that there would be a dominant partner. This was seen as masculine and looked down upon by the people of the time.
Women had an incredibly restrictive life in Rome. This speaks to the intelligence of the many that did manage to rise to power, as it was a very dangerous path to walk for those not born a man. I‚Äôll cover that more when I get into Agrippina the younger, who was a fascinating figure and Nero‚Äôs mother.
Y‚Äôknow, the one he slept with.
We can draw a lot of parallels from Rome, though their society was quite a bit different than it appears on the surface. It should also be said that several of the sexual liberties given to people were reserved for the higher parts of society, with lower social classes being allowed much less personal freedom.
Stay tuned for a more in-depth look at Elagabalus, who is a fascinating character and one of the first transgender people recorded in history.
I‚Äôll drink less coffee next time.
Thanks,
Jack

Saint Cecilia in Trastevere: Patron Saint of Singers, Composers, and Musicians
A quiet Trastevere via opens to a large landscaped courtyard, which fronts this Basilica that was built over the home where Cecilia lived and died.
The courtyard is a lovely neighborhood playground ‚Äî where you‚Äôre bound to see mammas circling strollers around the central Roman urn and nuns chatting away after mass.
In third century Rome, Cecilia was known as the girl who heard angelic harmonies ‚Äî she could play any instrument or sing any song. She secretly swore to be a chaste Christian, but went through with a marriage her parents arranged anyway. On the wedding night, she broke the news to her husband Valerian, telling him the only way he could touch her was to become a Christian, so he ran off to get baptized. When he returned, he found their bridal chamber transformed ‚Äî full of flowers and Cecilia wearing a crown of lilies and roses. This miracle swept Valerian into the faith. He made it his mission to help the poor and bury Christian martyrs, and was beheaded for his belief.
Then Cecilia was tortured for her faith, forced into a tub of boiling water in her own bathtub. She sang all‚Ä¶

Title: A mobile port done right: Falling back in love with Rome Total War
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I want to talk about a recent trend in mobile gaming. It‚Äôs the trend of desktop/console games getting re-imagined and made into mobile games. We‚Äôve had all sorts; from League of Legends Wild Rift, to Call of Duty Mobile and even Nintendo getting in on the action with Mario Kart.
These games are not typically straight remasters. They are often altered versions of the original experience.
This means I have been left disappointed on several occasions as I download a game from a beloved franchise expecting the same high quality experience I‚Äôm used to on console. Only to get something very different.
Typically I have found it goes one of 2 ways with these console/desktop titles reappearing on mobile:
This is a game I loved as a child and when I realised it had got a mobile re-release I tentatively downloaded it expecting another second rate experience. O boy was I wrong, it‚Äôs brilliant!
Rome Total War is a strategy game with 2 types of game play:
So it‚Äôs not the simplest game out there. There is a lot of depth and freedom in what you can do in both the campaigns and the battles themselves. Given this, it may seem remarkable that this translates so well to mobile.
Google maps is a fantastic product, and one of the reasons for this is that it‚Äôs intuitive to use both on your phone and desktop. It is so easy to explore the world with Google Maps. Whether pinching or scrolling to zoom, clicking or tapping, there is no friction to navigation. Neither mobile nor desktop feel like imitators of the other.
Whether intentional or not, Total War has achieved the same thing with its map navigation. Creating what feels like a completely seamless experience on mobile when navigating the map, even when compared to the old desktop experience. This is hugely important as a large part of this game is about navigating 2D or 3D environments in order to make strategic decisions. It sounds so simple but getting this navigation right, to me is the cornerstone of what makes Rome such a good port.
Alongside the map navigation exploring the UI and interacting with map elements is also incredibly frictionless. With certain button sizes scaled up and freedom in how you scale the HUD I never once felt limited using a touch screen over a mouse and keyboard.
Now this is going to sound overly simplified but here it is. Rome Total War on mobile is such a great game because it is exactly the same as Rome Total War on desktop, and that was a great game.
As far as I can tell nothing is missing from the mobile version versus the desktop game. This means the same incredibly deep campaign experience is available in your pocket.
With too many mobile ports you see simplification or compromises made on the original experience. Which as mentioned before can leave you feeling unsatisfied. Rome Total War does not compromise and that is great.
The best part of Rome Total War is the campaigns. When I played Total War as a child I would play for hours on end, working my way through campaigns one turn at a time. Now if I have hours to play games typically I won‚Äôt be on my phone.
However I feel like this port has got me playing just as much as I did as a child, but in a very different way.
You see because the campaigns are turn based this means they are filled with natural pauses. Each turn still takes me 5‚Äì10 minutes but this time the game lives in my pocket. Meaning Rome Total War through this brilliant port has shifted from an experience I would settle into on a Sunday afternoon to something I can pick up here and there throughout the week.
So basically I loved Rome Total War as a kid, and now I‚Äôve fallen in love with it again.
The controls are so intuitive you would have thought the game was made for touch screens and the experience is not comprised at all when compared to the desktop version. On top of that the game being on my phone allows for a new style of play. Giving me little bursts of nostalgia throughout my week.
Overall I think Rome Total War is great example of how you can re-release old titles on mobile and breathe new life into them.

I feel like I should be documenting this somewhere. Partially because it feels too good to be true, and the other part, well‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbelieves that everyone should know what everlasting happiness is. Even if it‚Äôs just for a moment.
I just moved to a new City. And it‚Äôs a godsend. The people here look like me. They speak both my native languages, and they welcome me with their culture. Their hugs. The microcosms in their face, they express gratitude for our shared experience.
The food enriches my being in a way I have not felt in some time. Not all of it tastes like home, but that‚Äôs what makes it so familiar. Deeply nourishing to the Ori.
And then.. there‚Äôs him. I met an artist. Full of love, of life. Of pain. And also, of beauty. Everything he‚Äôs been through shows nowhere on his being. His hands are soft, like a pianist. His callouses showcase strength, fight, only present because life unfortunately placed them there. But he still smiles. He still laughs. And enjoys the little things that life has to offer him.
He‚Äôs passionate. As both a lover and a being. He‚Äôs armorous. Unshielded for selected few. Olodumare blessed me with an opportunity to see him bare. And his soul‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit lights me entirely. His rage and anger, they‚Äôre subtle and fleeting. His eyes, a golden honey. His lips, kisses wet enough to quench a thirst I never knew was lingering.
I believe that God gave me the strength and carried me through, just to bring me right here. To know a warmth so pure, so true. And know how to cherish it when it arrived at my doorstep.
And I swear on everything that I know, I would go through it all over again just to meet him once more‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääin this moment. Right here. Right now.
I‚Äôve always wanted to go to Rome. Since I was a child. Little did I know that the city would offer more than pasta and parmigiano. It would be the thing that brought colors of me back to the canvas. And ultimately, a subconscious iridescence back to life.

Content:
