Share
A Day in the Life:
When in Rome
First and foremost, if you have chosen to learn about life in Rome by reading this blog, thank you for taking the time to do so!
This region is home to my dream vacation. This is because one of my best friends, Beatrice, happens to be a Native of the region who lives there with her family. I met her during our senior year of high school (she was a foreign-exchange student) and we have been great friends communicating via Facebook and WhatsAp ever since. I promised her that some day I would go visit her in Rome‚Ä¶but for now, I am a college student attempting to make ends meet to pay for school, therefore, this blog is the closest I will get to Italy for a while. Regardless of my inability to pay the $1,000 for a plane ticket, this blog will give me the opportunity to study life in Rome so that I will know exactly what I would like to do the moment I step foot there.
My goals for this blog are both personal and involve you, as the audience. Like previously stated, I would like to learn more about the region in order to prepare myself for a future trip to visit Beatrice. On a larger scale, however, my goal is to help educate my followers through this blog so that if they plan to travel to Rome, are thinking about planning a vacation, or need an emergency get away from college/final exams, they will be adequately informed about the region.
If you know anything about Rome from your schooling, it is likely that you know Rome‚Äôs history is anything but brief. I will do my best to summarize it in a short paragraph or two for you.
Basically, Rome was one of the greatest empires there ever was- if looking at it from an ancient sort of perspective. As you can see from the timeline, Rome lasted a bit longer than the average civilization back in the day. This is largely due to the fact that Rome was home to many powerful leaders, conquerors, and other highly intelligent individuals. Just a few of these include: Ceasar (his war tactics are still studied and taught today), Augustus (built many roads, aqueducts, and buildings), and Mark Antony (had an intimate relationship with the Egyptian ruler Cleopatra-he stabbed himself for her, she let a snake bite her for him-it‚Äôs a long story for a different time). In summary, the Romans were a power you didn‚Äôt want to threaten or mess with. You would only be setting yourself up for defeat-unless, of course, you were the Franks from Germany who defeated them between AD 406‚Äì419.
So what is it with the Colosseum as a Roman symbol?
The Colosseum, as pictured at the top of this blog post, was built following the rule of Nero, an extra crazy ruler who basically ran the morale of the Roman peoples into the ground. The ruler who followed Nero, Vespasian, decided that building the Colosseum for the purpose of free entertainment (gladiator games) would benefit the people of Rome by bringing up their morale, and that it did.
Today, the Colosseum still stands with a few alterations and additions after its original design in approximately 73‚Äì75 A.D. It is noteworthy that the Roman architecture and design techniques used to build the magnificent building are still being used in various buildings in the modern world.
While ancient Roman culture is still evident in this amazing city, Rome has modernized itself to keep up with the current times. If one were to visit today, it would be something like‚Ä¶
Vatican City
Vatican City, while it is technically a city state and not a part of Rome, falls within the Roman boarder. It is home to approximately 840 people, one of those being the Pope, the leader of the Catholic Church. This city state also happens to contain some of the main tourist attractions in Rome including St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, the Sistine Chapel, and the Vatican Museums.
Shopping
According to http://www.rome.info/shopping/, when one is shopping in Rome, they can expect to break the bank. One positive side to shopping in the tourist city, however, is that leather products such as purses, shoes, and belts, are commonly found for a fair price. (Being a purse-lover myself, I now know I need to save up for more than just my plane ticket!)
Another important thing to remember if you are used to the United States‚Äô way of shopping is that the hours are generally a bit off from what you may be used to. Evidently, they open around 9:00AM and close again for lunch around 1:00PM. They then open up from 3:30PM-7:30PM. These hours are different, however, for Sundays and Monday mornings and may also be different depending on the type of shop.
*Note: If the purpose of your trip is heavily dependent upon the shopping, do not go to Rome during August. During this month, most shops and restaurants close for about a two week period while shop owners take their annual holiday.
Restaurants
Yes, Rome happens to be in Italy so you‚Äôre probably thinking, ‚ÄúWell duh! While in Italy, order Italian!‚Äù If you love spaghetti or pizza, then I can see why you would prefer to purchase the ‚Äúreal deal.‚Äù One thing I will tell you, however, is make sure to order some gelato for dessert!
Gelato, the Italian version of ice cream, is made with milk, cream, different sugars, and nut and fruit purees for flavor. Generally, the consensus is that gelato is amazing and American ice cream comes second. If you are a bit of a health nut like me, you will also be happy to know that gelato tends to contain less calories, fat, and sugar than typical ice cream.
According to http://www.expatfocus.com/expatriate-rome-language, the main language spoken in Rome is Italian. Luckily, if you are an individual who is not bilingual-like me-and English is your only language, Rome is a great place for you to travel to a different country without having to suffer the consequences of butchering a new language. (Go to Rome and you won‚Äôt have your friends laugh at you for accidentally ordering grilled guinea pig to pair with your pasta and side salad-it‚Äôs a thing!) This is because the people of Rome are aware that a large part of their economy depends on tourism so many of them living in the areas known for the tourist attractions speak English. In other words, as far as verbal communication goes you should be able to survive without hiring a translator.
If you do want to throw just a bit of Italian into your experience, however, feel free to say ‚Äúciao‚Äù (pronounced like ‚Äúchow‚Äù in ‚Äúpuppy chow‚Äù). This means ‚Äúhello‚Äù and can also translated to ‚Äúgoodbye,‚Äù depending on the context.
In terms of nonverbal communication, however, communicating in Rome is a different story. After spending much time with my friend Beatrice in high school, she became annoyed with my ‚Äúsilly American ways,‚Äù as she called them. According to her, Romans are very physical in a way that we Americans might see as boarder-line suggestive/sexual. Apparently, it is completely common to let your friends (male or female) sit on your lap when hanging out, give long hugs to friends, and the custom greeting (even with strangers) is a short embrace with a kiss on each cheek.
Another way the Romans communicate physically is by frequently motioning. Beatrice often coached me (as a bit of a joke) how to ‚Äúspeak with my hands.‚Äù If something is delicious, you indicate that with your hands because your mouth is full. If you want someone to hurry up, you tap your wrist like a watch. Basically if you want to go to Italy and your goal is to blend in, you had better learn the equivalent of sign language.
www.nytimes.com
As I sit here and finish up this blog post (while drinking a glass of wine from Italy ironically-Risata il Rosso-you should try it!), my final thoughts to you are this: if you ever want to learn about a country or a culture, the best way to go about it is to go there. Cultural immersion, as they call it, is essential to learning and life experience. While you might be held back by lack of funds or a chaotic schedule, I strongly suggest making a solid effort to get outside of your box. Force yourself to be uncomfortable but most importantly, go into any experience with an open mind. You won‚Äôt regret it.
‚ÄúYour assumptions are your windows on the world. Scrub them off every once in a while, or the light won‚Äôt come in.‚Äù‚Äï Isaac Asimov

Title: I will not visit Rome for a second time

Right at the beginning, I have to admit that I am part of the problem I am complaining about. We have visited Rome on a cruise, and I suspect that the explosion of cruise tourism has a significant role to play in the flood of tourists in Rome.
My wife and I booked the cruise almost eighteen months ago. At that time we were not yet aware of the problems caused by this form of tourism. Greta Thunberg was still an unknown student somewhere in Norway, and the cruise theme had not yet arrived in our consciousness.
Besides the vast CO2 emissions per passenger, the biggest problem of the cruise industry in Europe is the limited capacity of many ports of destination of the gigantic ships.
Places like Skala on Santorini, Venice, or Stavanger are regularly visited by large cruise ships with 2,000 to 4,000 passengers ‚Äî sometimes several in one day.
Rome is not directly by the sea, but from the nearest port in Civitavecchia, large bus fleets with cruise ship passengers drive daily to the Italian capital.

Title: Italian Night: How I Met Her in Rome and Lost Her in Florence
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Write A Catalyst and Build it into Existence.

--
Listen
Share
I moved from one cultural landmark to another, trying not to get sunstroke. The morning started with a saving cup of coffee near Tivoli station. Then, a quick escape into the coolness of the cathedrals.
I was struck by the young men and women who sat alone in churches for long periods. Some knelt in prayer. Such beautiful, delicate bodies, already asking God for forgiveness for their indulgence in love.
Here, temptation came too easily.
Having feasted my eyes on the works of Raphael and Michelangelo, I looked around, searching for someone to channel this overwhelming creative energy into. Among the group of tourists stood a petite girl in a flowing white maxi skirt.
Her hair was darker than pitch, and her blue eyes closely followed the guide‚Äôs gestures. I noticed the delicate frame beneath her light white blouse.
She noticed me too. (Of course, I had been looking at her so intently!)
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so wonderful to be here!‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm an artist! I came to Rome for inspiration!‚Äù
She didn‚Äôt even need to say it. It was obvious.
She loved life the way the great painters of the Vatican did ‚Äî Michelangelo, Caravaggio, Raphael Santi. Their works were a triumph of life itself. And standing before Peter Wenzel‚Äôs ‚ÄúAdam and Eve in the Garden of Eden‚Äù, I realized ‚Äî we were meant to meet here.
Feeling my desire to be closer, she quickly decided to make me her personal photographer to observe me better.
‚ÄúTake a photo of me by that pinecone in the Cortile della Pigna!‚Äù she teased.
She posed and turned, again and again. It was obvious ‚Äî I was already captivated.
Then she sighed:
‚ÄúHow will I go to the Villa Borghese alone now? Who will take my pictures?‚Äù
I was more than happy to go!
She sat in the metro as if in a sauna ‚Äî flushed, damp, squeezed between two sturdy men pressing against her from either side. It was a new painting ‚Äî her, in tight quarters, in the stifling heat.
But she looked only at me. Without blinking.
Melted by the art of the Borghese Gallery, she came alive. Several times, she leaned in, drowning me in the sweet scent of her perfume, explaining this or that masterpiece.
‚ÄúSacred and Profane Love‚Äù by Titian.
‚ÄúDo you see how different they are, yet they share the same painting?‚Äù she asked.
I also found myself drawn to Correggio‚Äôs ‚ÄòDana√´‚Äô. Instinctively, I compared the beauty next to me to the legendary princess, draped in nothing but fate itself. From this perspective, Cranach the Elder‚Äôs ‚ÄòVenus and Cupid‚Äô intrigued me as well.
Stepping outside, surrounded by the intoxicating scent of pine, she declared:
‚ÄúPhotograph me however you like!‚Äù
I wanted her to lie down on a stone bench, among the ancient Roman statues.
I hadn‚Äôt expected her to be so bold.
A true artistic soul. Intriguing was an understatement.
We dined at a caf√© facing the Pantheon.
After the second glass of wine, she asked:
‚ÄúHave you ever been in love?‚Äù (God, why do women always ask this question?)
I hesitated.
She downed her wine, clinked glasses with me in a brotherhood toast, and said:
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go for a walk!‚Äù
That night is impossible to forget.
By midnight, we realized that finding a taxi in Rome was nearly impossible. I felt like a gladiator, returning from a victorious battle, carrying her in my arms along the Roman Forum, nearly out of strength.
Her soft body could be traced through the gentle folds of fabric.
Strangely, she never let me kiss her that night.
Surviving, I left for Florence, but my mind stayed with her.
I visited its stunning cathedrals, the Uffizi Gallery, and Palazzo Pitti. My hotel room was small, but the bright moon watched over me, reminding me of her.
We often texted, and then, one day, she came ‚Äî for half a day only.
This time, she looked different.
She realized that Florence and Rome were two entirely different worlds.
No longer dressed in white, but in deep blue.
Her hair, once tied in a tight bun, was now let loose, cascading like the curls of Botticelli‚Äôs Venus.
Every strand carried a message ‚Äî an echo of past centuries, where every glance could become a masterpiece, every movement ‚Äî art in itself.
Two days passed, but it felt like a lifetime. We walked a little.
‚ÄúI think about you often,‚Äù I admitted.
‚ÄúSo do I,‚Äù she replied.
When I returned to Rome, I immediately arranged to meet her at the Spanish Steps.
She looked breathtaking in her evening dress and lace-up heels.
‚ÄúBy the way,‚Äù she said, ‚ÄúI was invited for a scooter ride across Rome tonight. But since you‚Äôre here, I want to spend the evening with you.‚Äù
Women love sitting in restaurants, don‚Äôt they? Have you ever noticed?
We ordered plenty of wine and braised pork in white wine.
At some point, her image started to blur in my mind, as if she had hypnotized me.
‚ÄúGod, I can‚Äôt keep up with you!‚Äù I admitted.
‚ÄúWalk me to my hotel,‚Äù she said.
Her legs rested on the red leather couch.
Looking at me intently, she spoke about random things, but in reality, she was deciding the fate of the night.
How she decided ‚Äî let that remain our little Italian secret.
What I can say is that Italy will always stay with me ‚Äî vivid, alluring, unashamedly in love with life, gifting the world its greatest art: the art of love.
Every moment spent with Ni unveils new dimensions of grace and mystery. Dive deeper into her world in:
Silent Observer
--
--
Write A Catalyst and Build it into Existence.
I stay awake through the night ‚Äî not to fight it, but to greet the morning.

Title: When in Rome
Content:

Listen
Share
To meet WHO‚Ä¶? That was the question posed to me by my mother not but a day or two ago. I‚Äôd just explained my intention to treat this trip to Italy differently and make a few unfamiliar stops in a slow arc toward the Adriatic coast from Rome as opposed to the beeline I‚Äôve been mapping religiously each visit this year. It must have seemed odd to have encouraged such wide-eyed curiosity from her.
Although I know I shouldn‚Äôt, I still find myself confused that others don‚Äôt share the love of solo travel (and especially withOUT plans) like I do.
So here I am now, at the initiation of day two in Italy, driving the hour from Poli, a small countryside village an hour outside of Roma to L‚ÄôAquila, a town in the smack center of the country, easily found by someone blindfolded and effectively the midpoint traversing from one coast to the other.
This morning as the sound of donkeys honking just outside my window nearly wake me, I choose to lay comfortably in bed a bit longer. After finally deciding to start my day remembering I‚Äôm alone in Italy‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämy ‚Äúhappy place‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäI check my phone to learn I had managed to sleep in until 11:30 in the morning. Like a madman, I think for a moment the clock is wrong. I jump to freshen up and begin my saunter to the kitchen to find coffee before beginning the journey to my next adventure.
Day one was truly a reminder that going into travel with no expectations may be the best life hack ever invented. I selected my first night in Poli purely based on the fact that it was only an hour drive outside of where I would land in Roma Fiumicino. And I know from experience that the 3-hour drive to the coast is not exactly what I enjoy doing after an 8-hour redeye over the Atlantic. So I chose the house on the hill described as the ‚Äústudio among the olive trees‚Äù from my AirBnB options. I had no idea what I was signing up for was joining a pseudo family for the night. I was greeted with offers to walk the donkeys, meet the dogs, the cat, and try foods I‚Äôd never seen in real life. I was given a private tour of a heart-stoppingly stunning municipal building covered in wall-to-wall and floor-to-ceiling watercolor-like frescoes by someone who clearly saw the interior only as an excuse for art.
Fully prepared to go out to dinner and eat alone that night, as I do quite frequently traveling through Italy by myself, I am delighted to receive an offer instead to join the family for dinner including a German friend stereotypically named Klaus. Recently in pensione, he had purchased and remodeled a villa/castle just up the road from where the couple lived. He is thrilled to have the opportunity to get back to English, a language that comes with fewer tongue ties than his intro-level Italian. We spend the evening eating chicory greens, oven-baked potatoes perfectly crisp, and some kind of delectable deconstructed meatballs so light they seem to melt in my mouth rendering chewing an obsolete ritual. We wash it down with a deliciously dry white wine from the Lazio region then a perfectly strong Grappa also from Lazio then, of course, no meal is complete without a shot of espresso. And just as I wonder whether this last sip could keep me up all night, I recall I had been traveling for over 24 hours, and everything would work out just fine.
This morning, as I wake nearly to the lunch hour, this time it is no surprise that I am invited to the adjacent kitchen to enjoy a breakfast cookie and coffee with my new family before hitting the road. I nibble on my flower-shaped homemade biscotti thinking how impossible it seems that they so easily disintegrate as they touch my tongue, overhearing conversations by the old gentleman on his phone discussing his methodology for recognizing whether or not mushrooms found in the local forests are safe and spicy or not. As he hangs up he gesture-explains the practice of taking a small nibble of mushrooms then rubbing them against his wrist as a test and how funny it is to watch people walking around biting and spitting down the line while hunting funghi through the woods.
I take my last mouthful of caff√® and wish I could steal every recipe I can get my hands on. I‚Äôm told a quick story of a local cookie made only of flour, sugar, and wine and imagine war-time Italy as a nonstop show of Chopped, only better.
Reluctantly, I say my farewells, including at least 15 to 20 thank you‚Äôs and goodbyes. I promise a future stop that might involve my real family someday for the opportunity to sit down for a grand meal again. I step into my rental car and begin my exit as the automatic gate opens slowly in front of me. My phone connects to the Bluetooth and a song sets the tone for my travels. Sia sings to me that she has no dollar bills and loves cheap thrills. I giggle realizing I hadn‚Äôt spent a penny since arrival given the way my Italian hosts had taken me in and refused me to cover so much as the one euro glass of Prosecco we‚Äôd enjoyed as an aperitivo the night before. I smirk reflecting on the fact that having a lifestyle involving a solo trip to Italy more than four times a year is nothing short of luxury.
It‚Äôs a cloudy day and I begin my drive through the seemingly hand-chiseled road from Poli to the autostrada. My soundtrack turns to classical music as my phone shuffles to the next track. I imagine being in some sort of cheeky Italian car commercial‚Ä¶ Pretty girl drives away speedily, stick-shifting through the Italian hillside as high energy strings harmonize in the background. A Lancia logo covers the scene and the tagline reads‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäYou too can be an escape artist.
It‚Äôs nearly lunch now, even though I can still taste the coffee from moments ago. I am more than ready to clean a plate or two of whatever the next trattoria I find may be able to offer. I‚Äôll stick to no expectations. All I know is that where I‚Äôm headed I‚Äôve never been. And with no one I‚Äôve ever met. Surrounded by things I‚Äôve never seen. Stepping away someone I am not now.
Andiamo.

Title: A pilgrimage to Rome
Content:

Listen
Share
‚ÄúFrom tourist to pilgrim‚Äù. This is an excellent name for a project organised by the Pantheon as a welcome service. I first visited Rome ten years ago as a reluctant tourist, fully aware that I was not ready explore its riches, and that the two days I had to spend there could not do it justice.
I return as a true pilgrim of Western Civilisation, its art and its history. Just like a pilgrim of days past, I must suffer long distances, pilfering conmen both small-scale and large, in a faraway, unfamiliar land, and deal with the vagaries of local cuisines like sugary croissants and exotic, unfamiliar pastas. Indeed it was only after travelling in Italy that I even realised what I had known as ‚ÄúItalian cuisine‚Äù hardly exists in Italy, with regional cuisines changing dramatically over just a few hours‚Äô train journey.
I had spent so much time in the last decade reading about and watching documentaries and videos on Rome and its art, it was a strange feeling to physically walk across the Tiber on the Ponte Sant‚ÄôAngelo surrounded by Bernini‚Äôs angels, gazing at della Porta‚Äôs dome of St Peter‚Äôs Basilica looming over the horizon.
The long straight sweeping boulevard makes for an imposing entry, with the view of the basilica and its dome bordered by the buildings on the side of that grand avenue. Surprisingly though, I thought it looked much smaller than expected upon reaching the Piazza designed by Bernini. As the Roman buildings fall behind and the symmetrical colonnades bracketing the vast piazza emerge, it is almost surprising to see the basilica does not extend further.
Perhaps this is an example of the mind‚Äôs tendency to exaggerate expectations of the dimensions of things it has held in high esteem, but the basilica feels dwarfed by the expansiveness of the piazza. Bernini‚Äôs use of space overshadows Michelangelo‚Äôs magnificent jewel box. Or perhaps this impact is due to the sweeping boulevard leading up to it, built by Mussolini in the age of the automobile. As one moves closer to the basilica and it looms larger, expectations crescendo, and it feels as though one is only looking at a part of it, and that the building must extend to the sides.
Once inside however, the dimensions reset, and the pilgrim is hit by the full force of the splendour of counterreformation Baroque in all its glory. It is a convincing utilisation of the power of art to dazzle 16th century Europe into accepting the Roman Church‚Äôs claims to divine authority.
St Peter‚Äôs basilica is ostensibly a shrine to the apostle Peter, or to God, or whatever the assertions of Catholic theology claim. To me, and I suspect to many modern visitors, this is a shrine to Bernini and Michelangelo, as well as the other saints of Baroque art whose genius adorns the basilica.
Is this the broader fate of churches in Europe? As the number of sincere worshippers in the pews dwindle and are replaced by tourists and pilgrims of art and history, churches are turning into living museums and art galleries. Many churches seem to be accepting of this trend, trying to indirectly monetise their art collections.
For example, the Church of St Ignatius Loyola has a mirror and coin-operated lights for visitors wanting to admire its dramatic, jaw-droppingly beautiful fresco. One would imagine the price of ‚Ç¨1 for around 60 seconds of light, must be sufficient to pay for the maintenance of the fresco and perhaps other parts of the church. When I was there, there was even soft, calming spa music playing in the background. Bernini‚Äôs magnificent Ecstacy of St. Theresa also has a similar coin-operated lighting system though it is not absolutely necessary to admire the work.
At St Peter‚Äôs and other sites in Rome, I often thought of Sir Kenneth Clark‚Äôs quips and insights in his Civilisation documentary. I tried to follow the contours of Michelangelo‚Äôs basilica that ‚Äúcarries the eye round as if it were the carving of a torso‚Äù, though I could not get very far before being herded back to the constricted tourist path by an attendant.
The Sistine Chapel is still the holiest site of Western art, and therefore perhaps of Western Civilisation itself. The thrill of seeing in real life some of the most iconic images of the world continues beyond Michelangelo‚Äôs Creation of Man as one progresses on life‚Äôs journey through the world of art and literature.
Even if you know certain works of art live in certain museums or churches, there is still a thrill when you actually encounter them, since you never know precisely where in the museum or church they are, and their first sight is always a surprise. My highlight was stumbling upon Proust‚Äôs Odette de Cr√©cy in Botticelli‚Äôs Life of Moses on the southern wall ‚Äî the melancholy face of Zipporah that makes a suave, intelligent, highly eligible Parisian dandy fall in love with a courtesan because of her resemblance to the daughter of Jethro.
I fell in love with the Baroque in the Germanic lands and made the pilgrimage to Rome in large part to visit the birthplace of the Baroque, which was born out of the Catholic Church‚Äôs resolution to use the power of art to woo back worshippers to fight back against the Protestant reformation. I was amply rewarded with its many Baroque treasures, some more famous than others.
However, I was also surprised to discover I sometimes found it more difficult to enjoy the beauty of churches in Rome, for several reasons.
Firstly, it is more difficult to overlook the destructive role of early Christianity in classical Rome and its conflicts with paganism. The majestic ruins of the Roman fora are too close to not feel them stoically bearing witness to the desecration of their holy Pantheon, where even after 1,500 years the church feels like an invasive occupier, out of place in the naturalistic, circular architecture where the oculus offers nature-worshippers a direct communion with the sky. The niches of the dome once adorned with sculptures of pagan Roman deities look achingly empty.
This sense of loss is not felt in the Germanic baroque, perhaps because either there was nothing comparable before, or if there was, it has been lost to history. There are no churches built over destroyed temples to Thor that we know of, even if there were probably Roman temples in Vindobona, the Roman military camp that became Vienna.
After all, it was at the medieval church on Capitoline Hill nearby, where barefoot friars walked in the former temple of Juno, that Edward Gibbon was inspired to write The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire.
My art pilgrimage trail took me from the Pantheon to Bernini‚Äôs fountain of the four rivers at the Piazza Navona, where I stumbled upon the basilica of St Agnes in Agone, another site whose history forces the visitor to remember the clash of early Christianity with European paganism. The baroque church is said to be built on the site of the tomb of the martyred saint, believed to have been tortured and killed by pagan Roman authorities.
Here I discovered the second reason why it can sometimes be more difficult to enjoy Roman baroque. At least in this instance, it is too transparent in its attempt to use the power of visual art to dazzle people into faith, and into submission to the authority of the Roman Church. The origin of baroque art was utilitarian, to be a tool of the counterreformation, but this seems to be one of its more crude and least convincing applications. Perhaps the Baroque had to go through these phases in its Roman birthplace before maturing into its more impressive stages. At St Agnes of Agone, a certain lack of sincerity, feeling, and faith seeps through the frescos of overly dramatic animated figures looking down at you with theatrically exaggerated emotions, matched by equally exaggerated expressions carved in marble in a grand and opulently designed space that exhibits the unmasked power and wealth of the so-called Catholic Church.
This is the third impediment to enjoying the Roman baroque: the flagrant corruption of the Roman church is so ubiquitous, it is impossible to avert one‚Äôs eyes from it in Rome. The Latin name of the Borgia family, which has become a byword for licentiousness and rapaciousness, ‚ÄúBorghesis‚Äù, is still vainly stamped across St Peter‚Äôs entablature (the technical term for the part below the pediment, the triangular gable). It makes it very difficult for any reasonable outsider to take its spiritual claims seriously, creating a dissonance with its aesthetic richness.
Palaces stamped with the names of royal families are de rigour and to be expected, but churches defaced with the names of aristocratic families?
Beauty, utility and politics
It must be one of the biggest hoaxes ever perpetrated in history. With a few exceptions, the papacy was held by the eminent Italian aristocratic families of the day, who successfully fooled all of western Europe for 300 or years, and southern Europe for another 300 odd years, into believing their claims to divine authority, in addition to the temporal authority they held as wealthy noblemen and princes, wearing not merely a crown and commanding armies, but also claiming to be the divinely-ordained representative of Christ on earth.
It is a hoax that is humoured even today by the legal and diplomatic recognition of 44ha of the Roman neighbourhood surrounding St Peter‚Äôs, as a sovereign nation state, simply because the Roman church still refuses to accept the authority of any government, and has too many devoted followers all around the world that governments need to appease.
Render unto Caesar what belongs to Caesar? Not the pope, who is still Caesar in his own microstate, which has its own train station and postal service, and where visitors without a ticket or special dispensation are only allowed as far as Bernini‚Äôs piazza and, if you ask the border guard nicely, one small street to visit a church. Countries still spend taxpayer funds maintaining embassies specifically to the Vatican, which visitors pass by on their way. Admittedly, it would be a rounding error for countries like Canada or the United Kingdom, but surely, Nigerian taxpayer funds can be better spent than on renting an office and employing staff to maintain a separate mission to the Holy See, in addition to the embassy to Italy. The Roman Catholic Church remains the only religious denomination in the world to control its own territory legally beyond the reach of any nation state.
This confrontation with the historical context of the Baroque forces me to examine my own attraction to it.
Although many centuries and a culture removed from the target audience of illiterate European peasants the art was targeted at to win over their hearts and minds , I must confess, I have always wanted to be dazzled by the power of art unleashed by the Catholic Church.
Admiring the awe-inspiring fresco of St Ignatius Loyola, I consider, why not? What‚Äôs wrong with wanting to have one‚Äôs eyes caressed by such extravagant beauty?
The mind protests nonetheless: did the Roman Church not effectively abuse art and its power to pursue its own political power? Was it that different to the propaganda of unsavoury regimes in world history? Or perhaps the use of convincing, alluring imagery used by cigarette companies in their advertising, like Marlboro Man?
Perhaps.
However, I would argue that the effect of good Baroque art, and its ability to stir awe and something deeper in us even today, shows that at a certain level, the power of art is one that cannot be controlled for human ends ‚Äî it stays with the art as an independent force, regardless of who unleashed it, or their motives.
Perhaps the artist, the creator, is more like a shaman able to invoke the spirit, the life force that true art is. Once unleashed, it retains its own power regardless of the shape it has been given, the identity of the shaman-artists or their intentions. True beauty, and the art that bears it, transcends such worldly matters.
Beauty cannot be intellectualised, rationalised or indeed even moralised, and neither can the best exemplars of art, which can sometimes almost become synonymous with beauty. It was an inspired decision for a religious authority like the Catholic Church to use this transcendental power of art to give their believers a glimpse into the afterlife.
In truth, the theology behind the art does not really matter, nor do the stories being told by the art. Rather, it is in the emotional effect these works of art have on the viewer, that the power of art lies, and which transcends the artist, patron and their motives and beliefs.
It is true that experiencing this power may have convinced many a German or Italian peasant of the very legitimacy of the political power of the Catholic Church, and helped to gloss over its corruption.
Nonetheless, I can experience the same power centuries later as a pilgrim of art, and get a glimpse into the Transcendent, or in the words of Baudelaire, get an ‚Äúinkling of the glories that lie beyond the grave.‚Äù
Western Civilisation as the Rises and Falls of Romes
Climbing Michelangelo‚Äôs staircase to the top of Capitoline Hill, one takes in a landscape drenched in history. Elegant domes of Baroque churches seem to rise phoenix-like from the vast Roman ruins, which ‚Äúeven after three centuries in which they were used as quarries, and in which our sense of scale has expanded, they still are surprisingly big.‚Äù
As the heart of the ancient Roman Empire, Capitoline Hill has retained its mystique through the centuries as a symbolic focal point of Western Civilisation, especially in its political manifestations. Even today, its memories linger on symbolically in almost every modern Western nation.
Monarchs through the last two millennia have styled themselves after the Roman Emperors, depicted with laurel wreaths in portraits, including on modern coins struck in the name of Queen Elizabeth II. German and Russian emperors literally called themselves Caesar (i.e. Kaiser and Tsar in their languages) until 1918, and Germany even called itself the Holy Roman Empire until 1806, despite never actually ruling Rome. Roman eagles are still the symbols of governments from Russia to Poland, Germany, France, and the United States of America, the republic which openly modelled itself on Rome, even building its own Capitol Hill.
Trajan‚Äôs Column stands nearby, and I notice its similarity to the column in what I think is Paris‚Äôs most beautiful and certainly most storied town ‚Äúsquare‚Äù, Place Vendome. To digress, it is technically an octagon, and Chanel‚Äôs watches pay homage to its shape. The original Trajan column in ancient Rome had a statue of Emperor Trajan, which at some point went missing and was replaced by a statue of St. Peter. Meanwhile Napoleon‚Äôs likeness still stands atop the Vendome column, dressed as an ancient Roman emperor, crowned with laurels.
Outside the world of power and politics, even Lufthansa calls one of the premium tiers of its loyalty program ‚ÄúSenator‚Äù. The list of Rome‚Äôs influence on the modern world goes on.
Rome is truly the eternal city. Arguably the ruins and the inspiration of their legacy are as historically significant as the empire itself. Ever since Rome, every time a Western polity rose to greatness or sought to project greatness in the eyes of the world, it did so in the garb of Rome. In some ways then, the story of Western Civilisation is the story of successive rises and falls of Romes in different parts of Europe and North America.
Today, it is possible to survey the sweep of history at the Capitoline hill in Rome and behold the eras that have left their signatures in the language of architecture, in this vast open-air guestbook of Time.
The sheer scale of ruins from antiquity are indeed awe-inspiring, and it is perhaps not difficult to empathise with the many generations who have felt dwarfed by its achievements. According to Christopher Clark, the people of the dark ages were crushed by the scale of the ruins left behind by the Roman Empire and could not believe they were the work of men, treating them as natural phenomena ‚Äúlike mountains, and built their huts in them, as who should take advantage of a ravine or sheltering escarpment‚Äù.
The achievements of antiquity continued to weigh on artists like Henry Fuseli into the late 18th century, as expressed in his drawing The Artist‚Äôs Despair Before the Grandeur of Ancient Ruins, depicting the colossal hand of Constantine found in the Capitoline museum.
The early Christian era is represented on Capitoline Hill by the cavernous but in the grand scheme of churches not especially impressive, Romanesque Basilica of Santa Maria in Ara Coeli, where inspiration struck Gibbon to write his Decline and Fall.
The most beautiful part of the Capitoline Hill is still Michelangelo‚Äôs circular piazza with its hypnotising, almost tantric pattern around it, and the equestrian statue of Marcus Aurelius standing in the middle, the ‚Äúonly one ancient Emperor to remain above ground in the sunshine through the centuries‚Äù.
Michelangelo‚Äôs piazza and its humanist dimensions shows the confidence of the giants of the Renaissance, who ‚Äúbursting with vitality and confidence, were not in a mood to be crushed by antiquity. They meant to absorb it, to equal it, to master it.‚Äù
Its timeless elegance, and the simplicity of its humanist splendour maintain a quiet dignity despite being overshadowed by the most recent attempt of an era to leave its mark on the Capitoline Hill, the enormous Vittoriano monument from the late 19th and early 20th century.
It still physically dominates the landscape today, newer, bigger and shinier than Michelangelo‚Äôs piazza. But in the topographical history book that is Rome, it can also look like a signpost of the wrong turn that Western Civilisation took in the late 19th century, which paved the way to the catastrophes of the 20th.
The historicist Vittoriano certainly houses many works of beauty and is like a modern rendition of an enormous marble Roman temple, dedicated to the Italian fatherland. However, it relies a bit too heavily on size to assert dominance and demand visual attention, perhaps revealing the insecurity and brashness of the late 19th century and its newly unified Italian state that first commissioned it. A cynic may even argue it was an attempt to make up in sculpture for Italy‚Äôs failures in the battlefield.
Perhaps I am too much in thrall to 19th century Italy‚Äôs arch rival, the Habsburg Empire (see my love letter to Vienna). Despite my deep love of Italy‚Äôs culture, history, language, cuisine and its people, I have always struggled to extend that awe to its history as a modern nation state.
‚ÄúGreat nations write their autobiographies in three manuscripts: the book of their deeds, the book of their words and the book of their art. Not one of these books can be understood unless we read the two others, but of the three the only trustworthy one is the last‚Äù, wrote John Ruskin.
Italy‚Äôs book of its art is the finest in Europe and perhaps the world, but if my Italian friends can forgive me for saying so, the book of its deeds is a bit less impressive
For much of its modern history, Italy lay at the crossroads of rival European powers and was always governed by a multitude of political entities, with the North often a political chessboard where the great French-Austrian rivalry played out. Metternich famously described Italy as merely a geographical expression.
Ultimately, Italy could achieve unification only as a fortuitous by-product of French and especially Prussian campaigns to weaken the Austrian Empire, with most of their own military attempts ending in failure.
What should a visitor make of the Vittoriano? It is an altar to the fatherland in the form of a memorial to Vittorio Emanuele II, whose enormous equestrian statue takes centre stage, echoing that of Marcus Aurelius in the neighbouring piazza. The Savoyard monarch became the first king of a unified Italy in 1867, but this required assistance from both France, as well as Prussia, who defeated the Austrians in the faraway Silesian plains of K√∂niggratz. As a result, they had to cede the parts of the Veneto region they had successfully defended against the Italians until then.
Ignoring the technicality that Italy has never truly unified because of the hole in its capital city from the Vatican insisting on its temporal sovereignty, the unified Kingdom of Italy only lasted 79 years, a split second in Roman historical terms, before the monarchy was abolished in a relatively close referendum in 1946, with the republicans winning 54% of the vote, mostly in the wealthy north of the country. The king was exiled, and his male descendants were forbidden from entering the country until 2002. Within another half century or so since the referendum, Italy was subsumed into the European Union, where nationalism has become a bit of a dirty word in polite society.
The prominence of the nationalistic Vittoriano on the Capitoline thus seems somewhat out of proportion with its historical relevance in the grand scheme of Roman history. A modern glass lift takes you to a terrace with magnificent views of the Coliseum, and from its top, the visitor can also admire the many domes of Papal Rome including St Peter‚Äôs across the Tiber.
With the full sweep of Western political history presented topographically in the mind of the visitor, the Vittoriano comes across as a colossal altar to a temporary burst of a very confused Italian nationalism that lurched somewhat schizophrenically between clericalism, monarchism, republicanism and with the EU, supranationalism.
The contrast is even stronger next to the lucid, harmonious expression of the timeless humanism of the Renaissance. It is worth remembering humanism is centred on the human being, and its architecture is dimensioned accordingly to accomodate humans, not to overwhelm them.
The mortal remains of Vittorio Emanuele II are buried in the ancient Pantheon, in royal tombs which are still guarded by an honour guard wearing cloaks bearing the royal coat of arms of pre-1946 Italy. By good fortune I found myself at the Pantheon on a day the guards of the royal tombs were celebrating an event, and caught a glimpse of the man who would be crown prince. He approached the Pantheon to the jubilant strains of the Royal March trumpeted by uniformed bands playing the erstwhile national anthem of Italy.
The prominence and scale of the Vittoriano would be much more coherent if the Italians had kept their monarchy in some form.
The Compost Heap of History
After some time in Rome, as you explore the ruins and discover and understand more and more layers of its history, it begins to weigh on you. You feel the weight of Rome as ‚Äúthe compost heap of history‚Äù, as described by Sir Clark.
You know you are just another one of the countless humans to have trod down these same roads and piazzas that have been around for longer than mankind can remember. You are merely the topsoil of the compost heap, that too for a blink of an eye before being buried by the future. The weight of countless centuries and their achievements impose upon the individual not only his own inconsequentiality, but even that of his entire era.
The era your lifetime affords you a glimpse of is but a tiny fraction of time in this city‚Äôs history. That too shall pass, and it will not be remembered as the era that saw the rise of Rome, the pinnacle of its civilisation, its fall, its trough, or its rebirth in the Renaissance. It is not even the era of the rediscovery of the rebirth, which inspired fresh waves of art and creativity.
You know you are walking in the shadows of Goethe on his Roman trip, who walked in the shadows of Winckelmann, the father of art history who poetically described his rapture at ancient Greek sculptures in the 18th century and held them to be the highest ideal of art.
You are dwarfed even by Rilke dismissing the reverence of Roman antiquity and its hold on the imagination, complaining more than a hundred years ago, of Rome and:
‚Äúthe lifeless and drear museum-like atmosphere it breathes, the abundance of fragments of the past (on which a tiny present nourishes itself), that have been fetched out of the ground and laboriously maintained, the unspeakable excess of esteem, nourished by academics and philologists with the help of run-of-the-mill tourists, given to all these disfigured and spoilt objects which after all are the vestiges of another age and of a life that is not our own and can never be.‚Äù
Knowing all this, is originality even possible? Or is human history just endless cycles of repetitions of the same impulses, emotions and ambitions, with only the dates and costumes changing?
Wondering how many of the masses understand the significance of what they are clicking away at with their phones, and confronting the shallowness of your knowledge even after this pilgrimage, it can be easier to sympathise with the eras that felt crushed by antiquity, than to be inspired by the Renaissance.
But then again, ‚Äúthe story of Western Civilisation is one of rebirths, so we should be encouraged.‚Äù And so we await the next rebirth, hunched over our phones.
After the cataclysms of the 20th century, which the Vittoriano reminds us of, it will likely be many more years before modern Europeans can rediscover the confidence let alone the creativity, and dare I say, spirituality, to launch the next Renaissance.
My pilgrimage remains incomplete. I know there is still much I don‚Äôt know about Rome, its history, and its art treasures, many of which I was unable to see this time, and many more whose existence I don‚Äôt yet know of, waiting to be discovered, and perhaps even more whose existence I will never know in this lifetime‚Ä¶
‚ÄúThe physical pain and the nobility of soul are distributed with equal strength over the entire body and are, as it were, held in balance with one another. Laocoon suffers, but he suffers like Sophocles‚Äô Philoctetes; his pain touches our very souls, but we wish that we could bear misery like this great man.‚Äù
‚Äî Johann Joachim Winckelmann, Reflections on the Imitation of Greek Works in Painting and Sculpture, 1755

In 2015, I celebrated my 60th birthday. I‚Äôm a sucker for celebrating milestone birthdays, so I decided it was time to take a Mediterranean cruise. I love cruising; I had already experienced cruises to Alaska and New England. And I knew from my previous trips to Italy, Germany, and Prague that I also loved Europe. So, I thought, why not meld the two with a European cruise.
I convinced my husband that I deserved to go on this cruise (which I did) and that we would start in Rome, and we‚Äôd also visit Athens and Istanbul, among other port towns and cities. I had previously visited Rome for about a week, but my husband had never been there, so we decided to spend a day in Rome before the cruise ship disembarked.
Well, the cruise ship doesn‚Äôt take off from Rome but from the port town of Civitavecchia, about an hour away from Rome. This trip represented a splurge, to say the least, so my husband decided we would take the train from Rome to Civitavecchia to save $100. When I told one of my well-traveled co-workers that we would take the train from Rome to Civitavecchia, he told me to make sure and watch out for gypsies.
I could tell he was somewhat serious, but at the mention of gypsies, my thoughts immediately turned to a Carmen-type character with hoop earrings, jet black hair, and flowing scarves and skirts‚Ä¶

‚ÄúYou packed what for Rome in March?‚Äù
That was the customs officer, eyeing my linen jumpsuit and flip-flops as if I‚Äôd just stepped off a cruise ship in the Arctic. To be fair, I thought March in Italy meant early spring. Blossom-scented breezes. Aperol spritzes under the sun. The Colosseum is adorned with charming gowns.
Instead, I stepped into what felt like a chilly Roman version of Seattle. The wind whipped through my bones. Locals wrapped themselves in puffer jackets and scarves. And there I was, dragging my tiny carry-on and an overinflated ego through cobblestone streets in socks that were basically social distancing from warmth.
Let me save you the frostbite. Here‚Äôs what I wish someone had told me before that first trip.
Italy in March sounds like a dream: off-season travel, fewer crowds, blooming landscapes, cheaper everything. And yes, that part is true.
But what your dreamy Pinterest boards don‚Äôt tell you? March in Italy is moody. One moment you find yourself soaking up the golden sunlight on the Spanish Steps, and the next, you find yourself sprinting through an unexpected downpour. The weather changes its mind more often‚Ä¶

In order to give you some input, I will explore the pros and cons of some of Italy‚Äôs most iconic cities ‚Äî Rome, Florence, Milan, Naples, and more ‚Äî to help you make an informed decision about where to call your new home.

Choosing the ideal Italian city to call home depends on various factors, including personal preferences, job opportunities, budget constraints, and lifestyle expectations. Take the time to visit and explore these cities firsthand to get a feel for their distinctive charms and see which one aligns best with your aspirations for an unforgettable Italian experience. As a French-born person. The rivalry between Italy and France has always been present in my mind.
Especially in 2006 when the Italians stole the Football World Cup (according to the French people at least).
And throughout education and media, a feeling of superiority is disseminated to the French nation:
Always look up to the Germans. Always look down on the Italians.
The Italians are also often called ‚ÄúRitals‚Äù
Paris feels less safe. For instance, there are people at the airport trying to grab your suitcase and put it in their taxis so you feel obliged (threatened?) to use their services. I‚Äôve lived this experience in Paris. But not in Rome.
The Roman transportation system and airports are less stressful. Speakers do not blast reminders every 30 seconds about pickpockets, C0vid rules, baggage security rules, etc. It is much more relaxing.

Mille viae ducunt homines per saecula Romam
(A thousand roads lead men forever to Rome)
‚Äì Proverb.
I have been reading and hearing much about population decline in the last months ‚Äî except for Israel. India takes over from China as the largest population, since it is less urbanized. Homes are found empty in Japan for years now. Predictions are made for war and growth with a declining population. Schools are shut with no students. And there lies the prophecy of Universe 25.
For those of you who do not know, Universe 25 is the 25th iteration of a behavioural study on rodents. The premise was simples: you have some rats in a utopia designed to feed and house then to perfection, no luxury spared. Having reached 2200 mice, the population founds its way to decline in less than 2 years, and it eventually completely died out.
For those who observe the unprecedented prosperity humanity has reached, Universe 25 may seem like a Morgana‚Äôs prophecy: ‚Äúhe is your destiny, and he is your doom‚Äù. Thankfully, we are far more complex than mice, we are not confined in an experimental setting (unless you count the planet as confined, while we do not even know the whole of it yet) and we have a knack for developing ‚Äî our not-so-utopia was not handed down to us by some ET.
I would submit we have far too many differences, and though we may share in a certain decline, the history of humanity is lined with ascent and descent: empires, tribes, families, armies and much more. And as I could not keep out of everything‚Ä¶ this has everything to do with Ancient Rome. As a matter of fact, I continue to agree and expand on prof. Oliveira Martins‚Äô quote (translated from Portuguese): ‚Äúthe history of the Roman Republic is the paradigm of all known histories‚Äù. Though I would say: the history of Ancient Roman is the known paradigm of all known histories. And in that I mean the empire, the republic, the kingdom, the city, the economy, the politics, the rivalries, and everything else.
And, in this too, Rome has already declined and mostly faded, buried under the sands of time; the city has suffered an unprecedented demographic collapse from the height of what could have been a hugely dense 1.5 million people metropolis[*] by the year 100 A.D. to a few tens of thousands by the start of the Middle Ages. Adding the Western Roman Empire‚Äôs downfall to external conquest and the Byzantine slow, thousand-year, decline: one can only say the answers also lie in Rome.
When we talk about the ancient city of Rome, it is difficult to know exactly what we are talking about. That is, the city changed so much from the kings to Odoacer that one would. Are we talking about the near-empty thatched huts before the Sabine women, are we talking about unprecedented marvels of marble and stone from all over the Mediterranean or are we talking about the mythical decadent figure bestowed unto us by artists and thinkers from the Renascence onward?
Well, we are talking about all of that, of course, but we cannot properly talk about all of that at the same time, lest we lose chronological sense.
Keeping that in mind, let us be orderly and start at the beginning. Rome would not look like a booming metropolis at the time of the kings. It had not sprawled over the seven hills, it had no Egyptian grain to distribute, no treasures of the mysterious East and none of the major marks (the Flavian Theatre, the Therm√¶, the temples built by the greatest generals and so on). We are talking about a civilisation that is, in sooth, yet to be ‚Äî though now we know it indeed was.
We may consider that the challenge posed to the Roman Kingdom and most of the republican times was there. A mission existed, be it to overcome Carthage, to attain general success or to rule the Sea. What I mean is: there is no place here for a weak, young society to ever act like a decadent empire. The opposite, in fact. There lies no path to power in imitating power. Brazil is an example of such a failure in our times: a country that looks up to ‚ÄúScandinavian socialism‚Äù[‚Ä†] and seeks to spend just like Sweden, while providing zero of the ambiance that gave way to Swedish prosperity ‚Äî and we are not talking about an empire here. Needless to say, Brazil is not in the highway to prosperity, but threading the dangerous road to serfdom.
At any point, the fact is Rome stood far from the spoiling utopia of Universe 25 at this moment of its history.
After the fall of Carthage, we might say Rome has become the leading empire of its time, and of all time, we might add. That is, taking on the mantle of the cosmopolis, Rome is the universal empire that weaves the very legitimacy of the concept. And it did enjoy its time in the Sun, much like the USA after World War Two. Using the population of the actual city of Rome as a proxy, we must note that the population seems to have peaked by the end of the first century A.D., according to some estimations.
The precise movements of Roman prosperity are yet not detailed to be discussed, and are also not the main point of this essay, so here comes the question: what happened after that? Well, my readings indicate that the population fell just as quickly as it grew. It is important to observe that this was not a childless society. Romans died from plague and war; they moved back to the rural areas as Rome was politically and economically voided ‚Äî and it would be possible that those who remained had less children, but who knows.
The point is: the urban population fell, and by the end of Antiquity, many estimates agree that it would not have even a hundred thousand people ‚Äî and that it would continue to dim well into Medieval Times. We are talking here about a much more dangerous city, abandoned by the imperial structure, lacking a Senatorial class (or any such wealthy people who could turn anywhere they went into Monaco), partially abandoned and materially depreciating. This is no city of wonders, commerce, and opportunity. It is a hollow dream, voided by the decay and overextension of empire.
And for more than a thousand years, Rome would remain the seat of the papacy, de facto and de jure a Christian City (identified more by the Church than with the Byzantines over the Adriatic), mostly reduced to minor Italian squabbles, and depending on greater kingdoms to call upon its influence.
It is no mystery what the ancient Romans did: they fled to their farms. Large and small, senator or bum, the wandering search of safety, shelter and a life led the Romans to the countryside ‚Äî and led properties to the hand of powerful men, who could defend the land/fiefs and the previous owners, now their servants or vassals. One might take note of the wording, but it is better to say it fully: feudalism had kicked down the door.
It is thus that some questions arise:
i. What was happening to population and fertility when feudalism began?
ii. Did moving away from Rome make less babies or more?
iii. How relevant was the barbarian influx?
iv. How and why did things change again?
One might observe that these are not trivial questions. To answer them accurately would require precise data from more than a thousand years ago, and we do not have that. In many ways, that may be a problem since the absence of this information makes way for all sort of fantasy storytelling, but let us propose some thoughts:
It is likely that fertility fell by the end of Antiquity, as that trend is observed for general times of crises, but it is unclear if that had any meaningful role to play in the social or economic setting. We know, as an example, that individual wealth grew at the time of the Black Death, since it led to concentration of inheritance and the scarcity of labour. It would be interesting to see how that would have worked out a thousand years prior. It is also not clear if there was a difference in urban and rural fertility, as there exists nowadays.
[*] 1.5 million people is the highest number found during my research on the topic, but I am not subscribing to that number, just using it as a reference for the scale of the collapse.
[‚Ä†] It is unfortunately the case for Brazilian politics, that the Marxist/socialist left (allied to Maduro, Cuba, Ortega, ‚Ä¶) conflates the Scandinavian political and economic setting with ‚Äúsocialism that works‚Äù, at the same time using the ludicrous claim that the USSR, Cambodia, and other such bloodthirsty regimes were not ‚Äúreal socialism‚Äù (at best, there are times when we can hear people defending gulags or saying they never existed in the first place). We should observe that such claims have been publicly refuted not only by simple facts, but also by Scandinavian leaders, but referring more commonly to claims made by American politicians: <https://www.vox.com/2015/10/31/9650030/denmark-prime-minister-bernie-sanders>
P.S.: the above is an informal essay, please do not consider it conclusive, fully researched or based.

Content:

‚ÄúAll roads lead to Rome‚Äù ‚Äî Romans have built one of the most sophisticated road networks, and all of them ended in the heart of the Empire ‚Äî the City of Rome. I‚Äôve cheated and took a plane, but eventually made it to one of the most interesting cities in the world.
‚ÄúAll roads lead to Rome‚Äù ‚Äî you‚Äôve heard this expression before. Maybe in the history class, maybe in the tourist guide. It comes from Roman Empire times. Back then, they built one of the most sophisticated road networks, and all of the roads led to the heart of the Empire ‚Äî the City of Rome. I‚Äôve cheated and took a plane, but eventually made it to one of the most interesting cities in the world.
There are two main reasons why you want to visit Rome: history and food. Guilty as charged, I have a soft spot in my heart for both of them. Growing up I have read numerous books on the history of Ancient Rome and have always been drawn to it. Romans made a huge contribution to our everyday lives: their political, economic, cultural and social norms had set the precedence for quite a lot of ways in which our modern society works. Food is amazing and available pretty much everywhere.
Also moving forward I will start to feature some music from the country I‚Äôve visited to set your mood while you are reading the blog. The first are italo disco heroes Marvin & Guy.
When you start planning your trip, keep in mind that you will be walking a lot. Most attractions and sights are fairly close to each other and easily accessible by foot. Although Rome has public transportation and taxis/ridesharing services, I would recommend staying in central areas and just walk around. There is nothing like getting lost in the small ancient cobblestone streets of Rome‚Ä¶ well, as long as you have comfortable shoes ;)
With that in mind I‚Äôve ended up choosing the hotel in the Prati neighborhood, which is located halfway between the Vatican and Historic Center. I didn‚Äôt want to be in the midst of touristy areas but still appreciated an easy access to all sights. It worked out perfectly. I would also recommend Trastevere for good nightlife. Otherwise, most areas in Historic Center will provide you with numerous accommodation options. The only exception is the area around Termini ‚Äî city‚Äôs main train and bus station, it seems to have a bad reputation.
Rome has 2 international airports but you most likely will arrive at Fiumicino Airport (FCO). It is the largest airport in Rome and Italy. Technically its official name is Aeroporto Leonardo da Vinci. From there you can take an express train or bus to Termini station, the ride will take you about 30‚Äì40 mins. I‚Äôve chosen to take a bus because it had a stop near Vatican about 5 mins away from my hotel. I was advised against taking a taxi from the airport since they tend to overcharge tourists regardless of the mandated fixed fee. Unfortunately, you can‚Äôt order Uber from airport. In general Uber allowed in the city but only for premium cars/vans. If you want a regular UberX/Lyft experience, download MyTaxi app.
Start your trip from Colosseum. It is an amphitheater built in Ancient Rome times, which used to hold 50,000 spectators. Throughout times it was modernized, rebuilt and upgraded, all the while remaining a world-famous landmark. It hosted gladiator fights, animal hunts, mock sea battles, and executions. Colosseum is the symbol of Imperial Rome and one of the New 7 Wonders of the World.
Because of its popularity, it‚Äôs a major tourist trap. If walking around as a part of the crowd where everybody is trying to take a picture of every stone is not your thing, play smart. Rule #1: buy the ticket in advance here, the same ticket will get you to the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill ‚Äî all while avoiding the ticket line. Rule#2: get there super early and ideally on the workday, drink espresso in the morning (we‚Äôll come back to that) and head over right away. You goal is to be done with all of this by early afternoon and switch to drinking Aperol Spritz somewhere.
Roman Forum is the plaza in the center of Rome next to Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Back in the days it was a center of Roman life, and now surrounded by the ruins of the several ancient government buildings. But even ruins give you an idea of the majestic importance and the spirit of the place.
Palatine Hill is one of the oldest parts of the city and the original location of imperial palaces. You can walk around the territory and learn about ancient buildings. Now remember my previous point of getting there earlier. Well, we didn‚Äôt. For some reason we‚Äôve decided to grab lunch after Colosseum and do the rest after. Rookie mistake. Don‚Äôt be like us. That Aperol Spritz not going to drink itself.
Actually, let‚Äôs talk about Aperol, Campari and all other good stuff. Italians have a strong culture of aperitifs ‚Äî drinks served before the meal. Aperol is an orange liquor, and Campari is a blood orange liqueur. Both are very popular aperitifs and bases for popular aperitif cocktails: Aperol Spritz (Aperol+Prosecco+club soda) and Americano (Campari+sweet vermouth+club soda) respectively. Needless to say, there‚Äôs nothing better than sipping one (or more) of them on a warm sunny day while enjoying the view after some touristy activities. Mark my words. You‚Äôre welcome.
Finish the walk at Piazza Venezia ‚Äî the home of Vittorio Emanuele II Monument. It is a monument built in honor of the first king of unified Italy in 1919. It is one of the most amazing Roman buildings and just a colossal piece of architecture, which simply hypnotizes you. That‚Äôs probably one of the reasons Mussolini used it as a place for the military parades and public speeches.
It is the second day and you‚Äôre a bit tired from walking yesterday (or drinking last night), so you need a little pick me up. Now let‚Äôs pause here for a second. Coffee is somewhat a religion in Italy, and they take it seriously. There are also some rules, which you might consider even weird, but it‚Äôs their country and their rules. Rule #1: cappuccino (and other milk espresso-based drinks) or espressos with some pastry (croissant) in the mornings, only espressos in the afternoons. Rule #2: you order coffee at the bar and drink it quickly while standing. There is also the specific way to order it: you pay first, then take your receipt to the barista, who then will make it for you. Now you‚Äôre not the first foreigner who visited Italy, and most likely you will be near the major touristy area. So, nobody will really care, if you sit down in the afternoon with a cup of latte. But it‚Äôs generally a good idea to be aware of the local customs, so you don‚Äôt look like a complete idiot in their eyes.
Once you‚Äôre energized and ready to do, start from Piazza Navona. It a famous square of three fountains: Fontana del Moro, Fountain of Neptune and Fountain of Four Rivers. You would probably recognize them from various movies or famous photos.
Your next stop is The Pantheon. It‚Äôs a former Roman temple turned to church. It‚Äôs one of the best preserved Ancient Roman buildings because of its extensive use over the years. Interesting fact: its ceiling is done in the form of a dome, and till this day its world‚Äôs largest unreinforced concrete dome, and of course there are rumors of gods helping out there.
The Trevi Fountain is the largest Baroque fountain in the city and another world-famous piece of architecture. Rumor has it, you have to drink a glass of water out of it in order to come back to Rome. Today you‚Äôll have to put some work in to get to it through the crowd of tourists. If you do so, there‚Äôs a pretty good chance that you‚Äôll come back.
The Spanish Steps is another iconic sight, which was originally built to connect Spanish embassy with the church on top of the hill. By then you are probably a little tired and want to sit down, relax and eat gelato. Steps sound like a perfect place to do it. Wrong. The majority of the people sitting on the steps are tourists. Italians are not huge fans of sitting on the historical monument. Recently they‚Äôve passed a law that allows police to give out tickets up to 400 euros to ppl sitting there. It might be a very expensive gelato after all. If you‚Äôre still full of energy you can walk up to Villa Borghese Gardens, which is a public park on top of the hill.
Vatican is an independent city-state within Rome borders. It‚Äôs the smallest sovereign state in the world by area and population, and primarily exists under the governance of the Catholic Church. Again, follow the rule: sightseeing in the morning, relaxing in the afternoon. Beat the crowds by arriving earlier. Vatican‚Äôs main sights are St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, the Sistine Chapel and Vatican Museums.
St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica is the largest church in the world and one of the holiest Catholic shrines. The entrance is free, but if you want to go up to its top and enjoy the amazing view, you‚Äôll have to join the separate dome line and pay the fee. The Sistine Chapel is the official residence of Pope in Vatican City. The Vatican Museums are Christian art museums, which display works collected by popes over the years.
From Vatican walk to Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelo. It‚Äôs cylindrical building on the right bank of the Tiber. It was originally built as a mausoleum and later used as a fortress or castle. Inside there‚Äôs a museum and you can also go to its roof and grab a bite while enjoying the view.
While doing all of the discussed sightseeing, you should not forget the second reason why you are in Rome: food. You will see it everywhere. The rule of thumb: if you see a lot of tourist crowds, do not buy food there. Walk a couple of blocks, look where locals eat. Also embrace carbs, carbs, carbs.
Several dishes you should absolutely try in Rome:
Generally, I would recommend to explore Trastevere neighborhood, which is famous for its nightlife: restaurants and bars.
Ciao!

Title: Roman Holiday Part II: Sights to see in Rome.
Content:

If you only have a few days in Rome, as I did, it‚Äôs important to see as much history and culture as possible. In our last post, we showed you our ideal day in the heart of Rome, Piazza Novona ‚Äî the best espresso (according to Romans) , gelato, markets, and the Pantheon. In bite-size pieces, here‚Äôs our version of the best things to do in Rome in 48 hours.
I. Piazza della Repubblica: Piazza della Repubblica is a beautiful semi-circullar piazza with the Fountain of the Naiads in the center, and the Basilica of St. Mary of the Angels and Martyrs across from the fountain. I encourage you to look inside the Basilica, inside is a beautiful bronze meridian solar line, designed by Francesco Bianchini, with marble depictions of the zodiacs.
II. The Colosseum ‚Äî because no trip to Roma is complete without visiting the Colosseum, the icon of Imperial Rome. Right next door to the Colosseum is the Roman Forum, the heart of ancient Rome. Both ruins are must see when visiting Rome, and you can purchase the Roma Pass, which gives free entry to both the Forum and the Colosseum.
III. The Spanish Steps (or the walk to the Spanish Steps): The Spanish Steps is a monumental set of 135 steps, made famous by the 1953 classic Roman Holiday, with Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck. The base of the steps can be overcrowded with tourists, so I suggest arriving north of the steps by Via Sistina and taking the time to visit the shops along the way, and admire the charming architecture of the streets of Rome.
IV. Villa Borghese: Villa Borghese is an extensive garden that was built in 1605 by Cardinal Borghese as a party villa. It has many villas built as summer residences for Popes and nobles, but is now most visited for the Galleria Borghese, which has sculptures by Bernini, and paintings by Raphael and Caravaggio. Buy tickets in advance because this is a popular museum, and aside from the Vatican, contains some of the best works in Rome. If you don‚Äôt make it to the museum, or want to spend an extra hour or so exploring the park, there is much to see, such as the Sienna Square, National Gallery of Modern Art, or the Temple of Aesculapius. My favorite part of the park was the view from the Villa Medici. which offers stunning panoramic views of Rome (above).
V. Vatican City: The Vatican can be made a half-day trip or a whole day excursion. There is so much art in the Vatican Museums, and because of the amount of tourists, I recommend allotting quite a few hours to see all the art the Vatican has to offer. There are four Sculpture Museums, a Painting Collection, a museum of Modern Religious Art, and a historical museum and art gallery. The Vatican‚Äôs extensive art collection started over 500 years ago with the purchase of Laocoon and his Sons, a marble sculpture found in a vineyard near the Basilica of St. Mary Major in Rome. The Sistine Chapel cannot be missed, I could spend hours looking up at the masterpiece of a ceiling, Michelangelo‚Äôs greatest work. The heart of the Vatican is St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, one of the world‚Äôs largest churches, and the most renowned work of Renaissance architecture. Words cannot even describe the magnificence of St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, and you must see Michelangelo‚Äôs Pieta located inside the Basilica.

When I was a kid I watched a movie called ‚ÄúRoman Holiday‚Äù. The magnificent and enchanting scenery shown in the film evoked my longing for Rome.
Years later, I had the opportunity to visit the ‚ÄúEternal City‚Äù (with more than 2500 years of history). It was 2003, and my husband and I decided to take a week-long vacation to Rome.
As with my other travel stories, here I will continue to talk about some of the little things I observed and experienced in Rome.
1. The airport bus couldn‚Äôt open its door and a ‚Äòfree‚Äô subway ride
One afternoon in March, we took off from D√ºsseldorf, Germany, with our infant son, and arrived at Rome‚Äôs Fiumicino airport about two hours later.
March is the best season in Rome, the weather is neither cold nor hot. We came from still chilly Germany to warm Rome and felt comfortable. But soon we were overwhelmed by what happened next.
After waiting at the airport for a long time, the bus to the city finally arrived. Before we could react, the crowd swarmed and filled the bus in an instant.
Oddly, the middle door of the bus wouldn‚Äôt open, so our pram had to squeeze in through the narrow front door.

Content:

When I travel, I like to seek out authentic local experiences. This time someone heard my prayers and decided to give me one of the most classic local southern European experiences ever on my first day ‚Äî a public transportation strike. So I walked everywhere.
First impressions:The area around the train station was pretty gritty, there was graffiti on every vertical surface, litter all over the ground, and‚Ä¶sketchy people standing around. But this is pretty standard around big train stations everywhere in the world, Paris North Station is also similar, but Rome definitely outperforms Paris in terms of grittiness. Unlike the perfectly manicured buildings in Paris, Rome feels more ‚Äúwild‚Äù and unrestrained.
Roman traffic deepened such an impression. Walking on a large boulevard, I reached a roundabout where many large roads met. In the middle of the road, there was a small police stop, with two middle-aged Italian policewomen directing traffic. They were doing a good job, but they were a little‚Ä¶unpredictable. Literally in the middle of a green light with cars pouring onto the intersection, one of them strolled confidently into the middle of the road, and held out her hand firmly to stop traffic. The cars stopped. They were not in straight lines. Some cars backed out of the intersection. Everything was still for a moment. And then the chaos reignited. I had no idea what was going on, and to be honest I was a little bemused, but I calmly crossed the street and kept walking. Traffic in Rome is quite a comedy. Not all major intersections have traffic lights or crosswalks, but that doesn‚Äôt stop people from darting across busy traffic; and even when there are traffic lights, that doesn‚Äôt stop cars and motorbikes from sneaking across. On paper, this sounds like Paris, but I assure you it‚Äôs different. Parisian drivers don‚Äôt open the windows to shout expressively at you with both hands gesturing wildly. Rome has a more comical disorganization, it‚Äôs like a Mr. Bean who knows what he‚Äôs doing. It‚Äôs hard to explain.
‚ÄúParla inglese?‚Äù It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve been in a country where I don‚Äôt speak the local language, and I‚Äôd forgotten how frustrating but also how amusing that can be. I‚Äôd pre-booked entrance tickets to the Coliseum, Forum, and Palantine Hill to avoid waiting in long lines. I‚Äôd read the fare conditions closely, and realized that I could get in for free with my Tufts in Paris ‚Äústudent of Art History‚Äù ID. Since mine was a discounted ticket, I had to go to the ticket office to verify my status before going in.
At the ticket office : (original conversation, imagine strong iTaLiAn accent) - Ticket lady: You reserved a free ticket, you need pay 12 euros for the adult ticket.- Me: (confused because I‚Äôd also reserved an audio guide for 7.5 euros, but in the moment I forgot what the 7.5 euros was for, and also forgot why I got a ‚Äúfree‚Äù ticket) I thought I paid 7.5 euros for a ticket, why are you saying it‚Äôs free?- Ticket lady: That is for the audio guide. For the entrance fee, you need to pay 12 euros because you are not an EU citizen. You need an ID or passport.- Me : (in my mind ‚Äî how do you know I‚Äôm not an EU citizen??? and then I remembered why I got discounted tickets and started taking out my Tufts in Paris Art History ID) I‚Äôm a student ‚Äî - Ticket lady: (interrupting) No student ticket, only adult 12 euros.- Me: But I study art history.- Ticket lady: Architecture?- Me: No, art history.- Ticket lady: Not architecture?- Me: No, art history!- Ticket lady: Ohhh ok, ~art history~ I see, sorry but only students of architecture and history of art can get free tickets.- Me: (ready to faint ‚Äî art history and history of art are the same thing!)I didn‚Äôt want to argue with her anymore so I just pressed my ID against the glass.- Ticket lady: (sees my ID that says ‚Äúl‚Äôhistoire de l‚Äôart‚Äù) Oh ok! Then that‚Äôs good!
Good thing I insisted and didn‚Äôt cave in to paying 12 euros, otherwise I‚Äôd have lost many gelatos and that would be very sad :(
After an afternoon, I have the impression that Rome is a little less organized and less glamorous than Paris, but with more character and personality. It‚Äôs like Paris is an elegant, uptight lady, whereas Rome is a carefree singing guitarist with tattered clothes. But this is just day 1, maybe my impressions will change after 5 days! :)

Title: The ultimate guide to visiting Rome, especially in December
Content:
