Before I begin, I would like you to know how why I am sharing this information with you, since each author has their purpose and I am sure that you are curious about mine. Why should you believe me, an American girl still in high school? For starters, I am not tied to any organization and I am not trying to sell you anything. I am not only writing this to make your trip planning easier, but I am also writing this for myself. I have also added my own personal experience to guide you. I hope that while recording my own memories, I can aid you in planning your trip to Rome so you can have the best experience.
Most people visit Rome in the summer months when the blazing sun illuminates the historical center. My family (of four) decided to avoid the crowds and fly to the city in late December. I was tasked with the most time-consuming but also the most important job: creating the itinerary. My job consisted of booking reservations for the famed Colosseum and Vatican Museums, finding small gelato shops and fancy restaurants, and locating more authentic Italian respites.
The biggest downside was that there wasn‚Äôt much information about what Rome was like in the winter so we didn‚Äôt know what clothes to pack. According to the weather predictors, the sun set around 5:45 pm which was very early. Also, the temperature ranged from 35¬∞F to 60¬∞F. We weren‚Äôt sure about how to dress; should we wear t-shirts? Coats? We honestly had to improvise, so we packed a bit of everything.
Now, when I was trying to plan the trip out, I did not have such a wealth of information in one place. Even more annoying, many of the websites I found were advertising tickets much more expensive than the actual ones. I spent many hours on TripAdvisor, browsing through the many forums. It was difficult to find truly unbiased information. In total, I spent many hours on hundreds of websites trying to figure out how to best visit Rome and what to know about customs in Italy. Of course, there wasn‚Äôt information about everything, so we ended up learning a lot of lessons from our unexpected encounters.
I also had a tough time with scheduling. While researching, I discovered that Italy was a lot different compared to the suburbs where I reside. It takes about an hour to walk from one end to the other. This posed a problem for me while I was planning; I wasn‚Äôt really used to city life, so I didn‚Äôt have a good sense of how long it would take to walk certain distances. I also had no ideas as to how long we would spend at each site. Would we spined at the Spanish Steps? Five minutes? One hour? What about the Pantheon? Maybe we would have extra time. Maybe we would be rushing everywhere. We really just had to wait and see. Now I know you‚Äôre curious to see how the trip turned out.
Overall, Rome was a great experience for me. I got to see the historical sites outside of textbooks and class and I was taken back by how huge everything is. You really won‚Äôt be able to appreciate the genius of the ancient Romans and the Renaissance artists until you get to observe the great works with your own eyes. Since we visited in December, we got to enjoy the Christmas lights and trees set up all across the city. And of course, the pasta, pizza, and gelato were all very delicious. There was a lot of variety at restaurants and cafes so I got to try things that were very atypical of my American lifestyle (Nutella pizza or fried zucchini flowers).
Now onto the specifics (click here to see a shortened version):
Here‚Äôs what I would advise: pack layers. We didn‚Äôt realize that most of the time we would be out when it was cold, so we didn‚Äôt pack very well. Content:

Dramatic titles for me are an art form and today we are about to talk about something with no relation to any of the cities mentioned above but points to critical moments in all. Abstract titles are my way of art and ironically they a mosaics that my mind paints.
Rome was not built in a day; this a saying that has been repeated for a long time, and will also be passed to generations as long as humanity remains. It is true, Rome as an empire has been around Before Christ and After Christ hence, it is obvious that it was not a day‚Äôs job. I think it is more important to take the principles of Roman Construction and apply them in our lives.
The senior Pastor at Life Church said something in a sermon I watched, He said ‚ÄúWhen we are born we look like our Parents, when we die we look like our choices ‚Äù. That word struck me and I who enjoy a largely sedentary lifestyle imposed on me by the nature of my career went for a much-needed walk. I live in Ajah (an area in Lagos) and I have lived here for a while now (except when I was in Uni), I have seen development occur with time and how places that would have you scared now look like a jewel.
However it was not always so, I recalled and remembered what it used to be like when I walked towards a now abandoned house, an abandoned site, and a poorly maintained sand-filled road. When I began to see these buildings and roads, got the burden to paint them with words as it cuts across various niches.
Knowledge is the most pleasant and annoying thing to have, it is a double edge sword. Ardan Labs a software company that has a training arm has a saying, ‚ÄúIf you think it‚Äôs expensive to hire a professional, just wait until you hire an amateur‚Äù and it is true about learning, ‚ÄúIf you think it‚Äôs expensive to train to be a professional, try ignorance‚Äù. Like every good Lawyer, I will present facts that could be misconstrued but I hope I paint pictures that will live an impression on you.
Pompei is/was a city that existed in Italy under the Roman empire that got buried under ash from an Erupted volcano called Mount Vesuvius. They thrived as a City till a threat possibly called everyone who lived in that city.
Knowledge as a double edge sword had me asking how did people come to settle around an Active Volcano. Did they have no Geophysicist, no Geologist in ancient Rome that could inform people of the threat to life? Ignorance which was not an active choice of the people of Pompeii levelled and buried an entire city.
Atlantis is presented as a lost city buried somewhere in the ocean, although scientific inquiry has presented facts that Plato‚Äôs work which mentioned Atalantis in his work Timaeus and Critias was not a total representation of life but an allegory to drive home a point. As such science concludes that Atlantis never existed. Well, I am not debating science but Intend to accept for the basis of this at Atlantis did exist.
A beautiful city that got buried as a result of earthquakes, again if Atlantis really did exist why did its people decide to settle on an Island? If they had the foresight of the future would they have settled there? I would argue and present an engineer's answer ‚ÄúIt depends‚Äù, however, the law of averages agrees that if they settled elsewhere and the earthquake happens again the island may sink or it would not, depending on its averages (in this case the intensity of the quake).
These two cities albeit one being a farce and the other did exist, are demonstrations of how knowledge gaps are our undoing. I looked at buildings that were the houses that tickled my need to be rich and a few of them looked like the have sunk. I remember coming to Dad‚Äôs house while it was constructed and its foundation was so high. My dad imagine the height of the road ( in the future ) which I felt was nearly insane. Looking at houses around that looked like they had sank and will still sink I began to understand that an intricate part of knowledge and building (not actual buildings) with it is the ability to preempt actions, develop more knowledge and respond accordingly. Today the height of the road is at least a level higher than my Dad anticipated. There are 5 new buildings around my Dad‚Äôs house and they seem taller because of the new ground level the foundation was laid, luckily for my Folks their house did not sink or sink as much, but this ability to preempt the future or an unforeseen circumstance struck me as a key to building.
Recently I switched my work codebase from an in-route logic-dependent application to a repository pattern which was initializing access to the Database (DB) in the Repositories, that was an excellent design for me at the time, the way the DB was accessed was flawless and I felt nothing could go wrong.
There has been a sprint-like approach my team had imbibed to produce the product that had been blueprinted (designed). In this fire brigade approach, I discovered that the access to the DB was a poor decision, my ignorance of this was glaring and staring me down and I had to come up with a solution. I spent 16 hours working across two days to come up with a solution that resolves the DB via the Framework‚Äôs method. I am sure it feels like I have lost you, apologies. Enough of Tech detailed talk layered with backend remarks. My ignorance meant that if this product went live based on my decision and knowledge at the time there was going to be an epic fail.
Luckily for me, I saved the day by experimenting and drawing fact-based solutions from a source of truth (FastAPI‚Äôs documentation), my teammates attested to an uptick in performance across my system. There is a word for if that situation above got to production and I have to manage the such situation and resolve it. It is called Technical debt. The lack of knowledge with regards to something intricate means that we would not deliver at the optimal mark in that regard.
A lot is happening across the world, the more we look the more we see that no one really has it all figured out, communities, countries, sports teams, people and automated processes. Knowledge is not a destination it is a continuous place. Knowledge is the refiner's fire, through its acquisition we realize how flawed our previous implementations are.
We do this by becoming like Rome.
Rome seems to be a wonder of the world, because, at some point in our lives, we hear Rome was not built in a day to persuade us to do the work. The idea however is to communicate to us the Kaizenic nature of Rome‚Äôs Architecture. There are Ancient structures that are still up today, such as the Leaning Tower of Pisa, and the Roman amphitheatre among a few which I know.
These structures are borne out of a place of improvement, the first structure architects would design would give them the cringe if they look at it after years of practice and work, this is why tech solutions are versioned, and this is why we have a Corolla 1998 and 2023 version. It is the Kaizenic nature of constant improvement, this motion is borne out of a place of constant reflection and a zest for the better.
This is why Veterans in any field are better than young blood, this is why the best coaches are people who actively did what they are coaching about (Albeit not at the grandest of stages).
The Roman buildings and the empire did not take over the whole world in one day, it was a gradual continuous action that became the empire. Some battles, some wars, some years of peace. History‚Äôs recounts are always fast and opaquely divulging to the perspective of time and timing. A good example as we ride out on the last strokes of this art, are football players.
A lot of these players dedicate their lives to this sport, childhood, teenage, and even their youth, why will Haland not be a deadly striker? Why will he also not lose a penalty, how come he could he can easily move on.
Time is an important perspective to everything including knowledge, I hated balancing chemical equations in secondary school but I loved it in the early years of Uni.
The most important thing these buildings have thought me is if we are not dead yet then we can become better, your next project should be better than the previous one, that is the only way to show growth and become Rome.
When we are born we are like our parents, but in death, we are our choices. I live you with a wise word on life, we will always have regrets in life, these are an opportunity cost of opportunities forgone. The rule is to remember regret is a feature of life, not a Bug.
Till next time.
Kaizen

From Bari I headed across Italy to Pompeii and an overnight stop in the Bay of Naples.
There‚Äôs not much that can be said ‚Äî at least, not much that‚Äôs profound ‚Äî about Pompeii that hasn‚Äôt been said, better, a dozen times before.
It‚Äôs been a world-famous tourist destination for literally centuries ‚Äî an unmissable stop on the original Grand Tours.
So my main observations are pretty unoriginal.
My first: it‚Äôs big ‚Äî really big. I trudged around for five hours and didn‚Äôt see it all.
As is always the case in places like this, the choking crowds of tourists quickly thinned out, observing the inverse square law of laziness.
My other unoriginal observation is that it‚Äôs amazingly well preserved. It‚Äôs not in obviously worse nick than the 30-year-old ruins we had seen in Mostar a few weeks earlier.
In a neat parallel to the low-value service industry focus of today‚Äôs Pompeii ‚Äî surrounded by snack bars, restaurants and hotels ‚Äî the ancient ruins of Pompeii show that not that much was different two millennia ago.
The economy of Roman Pompeii revolved, clearly, around having a good time.
Leisure centres ‚Äî sorry, Roman baths. Sports centres ‚Äî sorry, amphitheatres. Takeaways ‚Äî sorry, thermopolia. Really, the tourist industry of southern Italy hasn‚Äôt changed that much in two millennia. The ancient ruined versions don‚Äôt even look that different from their modern counterparts.
After an overnight stop in Torre del Greco ‚Äî in a charming farm with half-arsed service and unannounced restaurant closure ‚Äî the car, which had been complaining of some unspecified lurgy since Albania (through the medium of beeps and a flashing orange spanner icon), finally decided that it was oil that it wanted.
The car had been bonked pretty hard on the underside in the rock-strewn ploughed field that passed for a car park at Bogove waterfall near Berat a few days earlier. Had I punctured the oil pan?
To make matters worse, I‚Äôd told a local tweenager trying to shake me down for a couple of lek to ‚Äòwatch my car‚Äô to get lost. Had he sabotaged the car in revenge?
Was the car slowly bleeding out? Was it leaving a puddle of motor oil at every stop?
Was the motor, pistons unlubricated, grinding itself down into iron filings with every mile driven?
Being prone to anxiety, this is not the sort of thing I am particularly good at remaining relaxed about.
The anxiety was not improved by noticing liquid dripping from the underside of the car while waiting outside the gates of the guest house (the manager taking his sweet time ‚Äî more than half an hour ‚Äî to actually come and let me in).
Leaving a tarpaulin under the car overnight calmed nerves somewhat when it emerged the next morning without any oil stains at all. The dripping was‚Ä¶ water from having cleaned the windscreen.
And, using a dipstick for the first time since my driving test, I concluded the oil level in the engine was just about tolerable ‚Äî admittedly when parked on a slope.
My mind put slightly, if not entirely, at ease, I powered north towards Rome, where, after some not-entirely-enjoyable traffic, and quite possibly some low traffic neighbourhood-related traffic infractions, I parked the car underground for a few days.
I‚Äôve been asked a ton of times why I can speak Italian. The answer I usually give ‚Äî my dad‚Äôs a retired Italian literature professor and I grew up hearing it ‚Äî isn‚Äôt really true, or at least, it‚Äôs far from a full explanation.
It‚Äôs not like hearing grown men talking about Dante, Petrarch and Boccaccio is a great draw for a kid.
And I hardly ever went to Italy in childhood either ‚Äî aside from two trips to Veneto, summer holidays were always in France.
It‚Äôs when I was a student that I became obsessed with Italy.
Over a couple of summer trips, I came to love all the ways in which it‚Äôs the best country in the world by a country mile. Nowhere else packs in as much good food, history, architecture and culture.
I came to love, too, all the other ways in which Italy powers through its manifest dysfunctions, shaking off flaws that would condemn lesser countries to failure and obscurity. I even enjoy ‚Äî no, enjoy isn‚Äôt quite the right word, am entertained by ‚Äî Italian politics.
And so, at a loose end the summer after graduating, having failed to line up a job (worse was to come when I lined up one I hated), I signed up for introductory Italian classes.
My ear trained by hearing the tedious Dante talk, my interest piqued by summer trips, and with the headstart that comes from French grammar and vocabulary, I found Italian ridiculously easy to learn.
After a couple of terms and fairly minimal effort, I was speaking far better Italian than I ever did German, despite six years‚Äô hard slog through school.
I‚Äôve been to Italy most years ever since.
Which makes it all the more odd that this was actualy my first trip to Rome.
It didn‚Äôt disappoint.
Not just because St Peter‚Äôs is every bit as extraordinary as its reputation. It feels corny to say, but it‚Äôs a genuinely awe-inspiring and ‚Äî whisper it ‚Äî spiritual place.
Not just because the ancient sites ‚Äî the Forum, the Colosseum, Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelo ‚Äî are so impressive.
Not even because the Pantheon is even more astonishing than I expected, and the architectural highlight of the entire trip.
In addition to that, it‚Äôs also everything I usually like about Italy ‚Äî from the great food, to the nice atmosphere, to the walkable cityscape.
It‚Äôs also got the distinctive typography on its shop signs that you see everywhere in Italy and nowhere outside it.
(It‚Äôs also while in Rome that I got the good news about a funding bid I‚Äôd written just before heading off. This prompted an ill-advised but enjoyable number of Campari spritzes on a very nice caf√© terrace in Trastevere, and a well-earned headache the next morning.)
After resting the ailing car for a few days, I made a detour to a Peugeot garage in the suburbs for the oil it was demanding, then headed north.

Title: The Secret Name Of Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

1
Listen
Share
New theories about a mystery hundreds of years old and a secret known to few Romans that was not meant to be revealed
It was 8 a.C. when the famous poet Ovid fell out of favor with the Emperor Augustus, who exiled him, without the confiscation of his goods, to Tomis (now Costance), a small port on the Black Sea.
But what was the cause of this great punishment for such a famous and important character for Rome?
Let‚Äôs try to give an answer to this question, taking into account the new theories.
Publio Ovidio Nasone was one of the most important Roman poets, one of the main exponents of Latin literature and, above all, of the elegiac poetry.
- Elegiac Poetry: lyrical composition united by specific metric form and by arguments that were opposed to the epic with a subjective and autobiographical setting, interpreted as a lament.
Ovid was the author of many works and his fame was as great during his lifetime as afterwards: his style and his themes were taken up by Dante, Petrarca, Shakespeare and many other.
His most famous work is ‚ÄúThe Metamorphoses‚Äù whose the best known story is Apollo and Daphne‚Äôs myth.
So, what was the reason for his RELEGATIO (exile)? It still is a mystery today as the clues we have come almost exclusively from Ovid himself: what we know for sure is that the poet was exiled by the Emperor Augustus, but his successor, the Emperor Tiberius, maintained the punishment.
The fame of Ovid, as mentioned, during his life was very great and therefore the reason behind his exile must have been very serious.
Let‚Äôs see here what his ‚Äúerror‚Äù may have it been, according to the scholars, ‚Äòtill recent times.
- An illecit relationship with Giulia Maggiore, the daughter of the Emperor Augustus, of which he sang in the ‚ÄúAmores‚Äù, under the pseudonym of ‚ÄúCorinna‚Äù
- Perhaps he favored the relationship between Giulia Minore, granddaughter of Augustus and daughter of Giulia Maggiore, and Senator Decimo Giunio Silanus, causing them to commit the crime of adultery
- He discovered illecit dealings of Emperor Augustus at his court
- He snooped about the private conducts of Livia Drusilla, wife of Augustus
- He partecipated in a conspiracy against Tiberius
It was precisely in the year of the exile that Ovid had achieved his maximus success thanks to ‚ÄúThe Metamorphoses‚Äù, his masterpiece, in which he recounts the transformation of the protagonists into plants, animals or objects.
Ovid was considered a libertine and wasn‚Äôt well seen by the Augustan political side, very traditionalist and conservative, because he used to criticized the two fundamental pillars of the Roman society: Religion and Family.
But it was not this that caused the exile, but something that as a punishment had the ‚Äúcapital punishment‚Äù which, however, Emperor Augustus commuted into exile (as Ovid himself tells us).
But it really was one of the aforementioned actions that condemned Ovid? What about the ‚Äúcarmina‚Äù?
As mentioned before, the reason we have listed ahve been proposed by scholars until recently, almost forgetting the ‚Äúcarmina‚Äù implied and the fact that this could be connected to the ‚Äúerror‚Äù and not be a separate thing.
At the time of his exile, Ovid was writing the ‚ÄúFasti‚Äù, an epic poem aimed at revisiting Roman festivals and rites: there would have been 12 books, one for each month of the year.
Halfway through the work, the order for the RELEGATIO arrived and the work was interrupted, nver to be resumed again.
- A clue -
At the beginning of the fifth book, where the poet researches the etymological origins of the name of the month of May and at a certain point, Ovid has the Muse Calliope (the poetry‚Äôs muse) tell the backgrounds of Rome‚Äôs foundation and she speaks of the constellation of the Pleiades.
In Latin literature, the importance that Ovid gave to this constellation when speaking about Rome‚Äôs origin is unusual: no one before him had mentioned neither Maia nor teh Pleiades in this context.
Certainly Ovid would never have allowed himself to invent something extraneous to the tradition regarding the birth of Rome (neither did the non-romans writers or Rome‚Äôs enemies).
- Was, therefore, a forbidden subject that Ovid wrote about? -
We must now take a step back and tell talk about an event that took place about 100 years earlie: the story of Quinto Valerio Sorano who was senteced to death for revealing the secret name of Rome.
Servius and Plutarch too wrote of the sacrilege commited by Soranus, a tribune of the plebs, poet and grammarian of vast erudition, dear friend of Cicero, whose sentence was death by crucifixion.
A certain reason, that we know for sure, for which the Romans kept the real name of the Urbe (other latin name for Rome) hidden and secret is the EVOCATIO (evocation), a rite for which the patron god of a city was invoked, pronouncing its name, in front of its walls during a siege: knowing the name of the god was the equivalent to seizing the essence of the city and subduing it.
- The Pleiades -
The Pleiades are a cluster of stars located in the constellation of Taurus, 440 light years away from the Earth and includes about 3000 stars, but the eye can see only 6 to 12 of them.
These stars are mentioned by many ancient peoples and it is considered that they thought there were 7 of them. They are found depicted in the Nebra Disc, the oldest surviving depiction of the night sky, dating back to 1600 b.C. .
Also according to the Greeks, the Pleiades were 7: Daughters of Atlas and Pleirone (daughter of Tetis and Ocean) their names were ‚ÄúAlcione and Merope, Celeno and Taigete, Elettra and Sterope, together with the most holy Maia‚Äù. (Cicero, ‚ÄúAratea‚Äù)
At this point a consideration needs to be made.
In the ancient world what was sacred on earth was often a reflection of what was in the sky: for example, Mount Taigete (Sparta) took its name from the Pleiade mother of Sparta‚Äôs ‚Äúfounder‚Äù, Lacedaemon.
Here, as the Roman encyclopedist Marcus Terentium Varro: ‚ÄúWhere now stands Roma, there was once the Septimountius, so called for the number of mountains that the city later included within its walls.‚Äù
We know that the Septimountius does not correspond to the Seven Hills of Rome, but the concept of the Seven Hills could itself be the result of a schematization that reduced the number of the hills of the territory that extends on the left bank of the Tiber.
This semplification would seem pointless, but perhaps the aim was to make the hills correspond to the Seven Pleiades; in fact, even the arrangement of the hills seems to respect that of the ‚Äúseven stars pleiades‚Äù.
The Palatine Mount, on which Romulus traced the furrow of the Urbe, corresponds to ‚Äúthe most holy Maia‚Äù.
In the story of the foundation, we find another probable allusion to the Pleiades: Remus on the Aventine Mount and Romulus on Palatine Mount saw, respectively, 6 and 12 bird flying (as mentioned 6 and 12 are the Pleiades visible from the Earth by eye).
We must remember that the Pleaides are part of the constellation of Taurus, whose zodiac sign begins on April 21st‚Ä¶ The foundation of Rome has as date April 21st 753 b.C. .
It cannot be excluded that even the number of the Seven King of Rome originated, rather than from a historical foundation, from the need for sacred numerology in which the number ‚Äúseven‚Äù holds a prominent place.
A small detail to keep in mind, is that Ovid was originally from Sulmona, a city at the feet of the Maiella Mountain Massif, consacrated preciselt to the Pleaide Maia.
It is therefore possible that an educated Roman, starting from the passage written by Ovid, was able to understand that the city born from Romulus‚Äô furrow, was consecrated to the Pleiade Maia, considered by Ovid himself, the most beautiful one.
For the ancient Romans, the Lares were divinities who protected and safeguarded the individual, the family and the home. The divinity that is introduced in the verses is called ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù (good goddess) and it too had a protective function.
Even the real name of the ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù was never to be spoken; the first to reveal it, was Macrobius in the V century a.C. by whuch time the pagan world was almost at an end.
Macrobius confirms that behind the ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù was hidden Maia.
It is therefore no coincidence that Ovid dedicates the opening line of the book of and about May to her.
The sentence in the graphic specifies a relationship between Vulcan and Maia, in which the god offered a pregnant sow as a sacrifice to Maia, every 1st of May, so that the earth would be pregnant with fruit.
Vulcan represented the protective fire; this places him at Maia‚Äôs service in the defense of the city.
The juxtaposition between Maia and the ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù allows us to see from a new perspective an episode that took place decades earlier, which involved, among others, Cicero and Cesare.
P. Clodio. Pulcro, one of the most discussed characters in the entire Roman history, on the night of the 4th of December in 62 b.C., disguised himself as a woman to secretly participate in a very secret ritual of the cult of the ‚ÄúBona Dea‚Äù to which the women of the aristocracy were responsible, which was carried out privately in the residence of a high magistrate‚Äôs wife and in the presence of the latter and the Vestals (thus indicates the importance of this rite): that night the rite took place in the home of Cesare, that at the time was Pontifex Maximus.
Pulcro was discovered and underwent a trial in which he risked the death penalty, whilst against him testified Cicero.
Cesare, who as Pontifex Maximus, was one of the few who knew the truth about Rome‚Äôs secret name, divorced his wife after that deplorable episode. This shows how important the rite was.
If naming the true patroness of Rome was such a serious crime, why didn‚Äôt Augustus kill Ovid?
Calliope‚Äôs speech seems to have been cut: in fact, she never mentions Romulus, while the other two muses whom Ovid makes speak before her, do it.
It is therefore possible that Emperor Augustus had the compromised verses eliminated. Those were the verses in which it was stated that Romulus gave the secret name to Rome (a fact present in many latin and non-latin sources), following the prophecy on the place where Rome would be born.
In conclusion, Emperor Augustus granted clemency because Ovid, it seems, never mentioned Maia‚Äôs name directly.
But there were, probably, also political reasons for this choice.

An Italian Summer ‚Äî Part I
This is Part I of my travelogue An Italian Summer ‚Äî starting with the eternal city of Rome.
Rome was not built in a day. No surprises ‚Äî it took us four days to visit it and we were left wanting for more.
Rome is a veritable explosion of ancient history, art and culture. That also means it is thronged by enthusiastic tourists throughout the summer, and it is wise to plan in advance in order to avoid long queues and inconvenience.
The central location of our hotel ‚Äî the Westin Excelsior ‚Äî ensured we could reach most places of interest on foot, and get public transport for the others with ease. You will spend a lot of time outdoors in Rome, so choose location over amenities while picking a place of stay.
Let me walk you through our itinerary, answering some of the why‚Äôs and what‚Äôs alongwith.
We landed in Rome past noon-time on 3rd September and got ourselves a local SIM card and picked up our Roma Pass at the Airport.
There are a lot of posts on the internet debating whether the Roma pass is a good investment. Unless you are planning to vegetate at the Hotel, it is a no-brainer. It includes entry to the Colosseum & Forum, plus unlimited access to the public transport (Metro & Bus).
Get a cab from the Airport to the city centre, usually costs about ‚Ç¨50‚Äì60. We freshened up at the Hotel, got ourselves a light lunch and started walking where our feet would take us.
The evening brought about an array of flavours. We ambled across the cobbled streets, got hold of every photo-op against pretty street cafes, saw miniature and life-size versions of wooden Pinocchios, and got our first lick of authentic Italian Gelato.
By the way, amidst all this, we also saw the Trevi fountain and climbed up the Spanish steps and saw a lovely sunset with a street musician singing Ed Sheeran in the background. The city of Rome is a gigantic museum ‚Äî you just cannot stay away from history and architectural beauty.
We trooped back to the hotel early. Streets in Rome get rather desolate by about 9 pm, and roaming around on foot is not advisable.
The Roma pass includes priority access to the Colosseum (‚Ç¨18, otherwise). However, the authorities have placed a concurrent visitors restriction due to which one must also reserve a time slot at a cost of ‚Ç¨2 per person here.
We had a slot for 12 noon so we had a relaxed start to the day. We had breakfast this day, and also the next 2 days, at this handy cafe called Xtra One Coffee at Via Lombardia. At our designated time, we entered the Colosseum through a priority channel, smirking at the long queues sweating it out for an entry. GET PRIORITY ENTRY EVERYWHERE YOU GO!
It is an awe-inspiring visual as one enters the colossal stadium. Though, thanks to repair work in arena area, there were steel scaffolds which ruined the authenticity of the surroundings. We plugged into Rick Steves‚Äô audio tour as we entered and, while listening to its ‚Äòbloody‚Äô past, we roamed around its many tiers.
After a wholesome tour, we stepped out across the road to Ristoro Della Salute. And we were back in the queue for the Roman Forum by half past two. We spent a good half an hour waiting here (there‚Äôs no skipping this line). But it was well worth it.
Having read Julius Caesar as part of my ICSE syllabus, I was thrilled to be where it all transpired. The Via Sacra, Caesar‚Äôs grave, the Rostrum where Cicero and Antony spoke, the Vestal Virgins ‚Äî it was like reading a book. and Rick Steves‚Äô guide did complete justice to the experience, yet again.
Our next stop was the adjacent Palatine Hill (that‚Äôs where the word palace comes from) housing lush gardens and remnants of Rome‚Äôs glorious history. To be honest, if one intends to get into the details of the monuments scattered on this hill as well, it would be hard to do it the same day as the Colosseum and the Forum. The place shuts at 6pm, a fact that deprived us of a potentially lovely sunset from a vantage point situated inside.
After a long day, we headed to the nearby Gran Caffe Martini & Rossi to get an early dinner and some Sangria. What followed ranks among our top memories from the trip: a view of the Colosseum by night. That surreal picture summed up almost everything anyone asks for from Rome.
And that was Day 2.
This was our day of casual ‚Äòwalking around the city‚Äô in between visits to the Colosseum and to the Vatican the day after. The idea was not to burn ourselves out in the first few days of the trip.
Rick Steves came to our rescue again. We picked up his walking guide ‚ÄúHeart of Rome‚Äù and headed out on the streets of Rome with our backpacks.
A bus ride from Bissolati to C.so Vittorio Emanuele, and we were at our first stop ‚Äî Campo de‚Äô Fiori, a lively market square with a dark history of public execution.
The colorful, busy market made for a great start. From here, we meandered through tourist laden streets, with historical nuggets strewn all around, to a centerpiece of Baroque art and architecture ‚Äî Piazza Navona. The vast plaza is adorned with three majestic fountains including Bernini‚Äôs Fountain of Four Rivers, and Boromini‚Äôs imposing church facing them.
It was lunch time. While the piazza is lined with restaurants, we resisted the obvious options and walked into one of the adjacent lanes, and didn‚Äôt regret it one bit. As we walked the Via di Tor Milina, we bumped into merry accordion players, street bands playing with gusto and enthusiastic restaurant waiters offering us a ‚Äòbetter‚Äô deal. We chose a place closest to the music and downed some food with a serving of the much talked about Aperol Spritz.
With a fuller belly, we moved on to the iconic Pantheon, a monument preserved exceedingly well for its ~1900 year old history. Rick Steves has a dedicated audio tour of the Pantheon ‚Äî you don‚Äôt need any guide thanks to that.
From here, Rick Steves was egging us to head to the familiar Trevi & Spanish steps area, so we looked beyond. Close to the Pantheon lies Largo di Torre Argentina, an important ruin and site of the murder of Julius Caesar ‚Äî the senate was meeting across town on the day he was slain. Close to this was the Campidoglio ‚Äî a hilltop square designed by Michelangelo with a statue of Marcus Aurelius on his horse marking the center and facades of conservatories marking its periphery. We spent some time visiting some of the relics housed in these buildings. These are covered under the Roma pass and could consume a good two hours if you are really into ancient relics.
Stepping out of the Campidoglio, we walked up the Altar of the Fatherland built in honor of Victor Emanuelle II in the early 20th century and boasting of an impressive facade. We could only spent about 20 minutes here since they evacuate tourists at 6pm.
Late evening took us back to the Spanish steps (a steep climb again!) and then to the Trevi fountain for a night time view which is highly recommended. We had an early start for the Vatican next day and we hadn‚Äôt really gotten rid of the jet lag, so this ended up to be another early night.
We had booked an escorted priority entrance to the Vatican on headout.com at 8am! While Vatican is accessible by train (Ottavio metro station), we took a cab and grabbed breakfast on the way. We made it in the nick of time only to be told that we were the only 2 people booked for the slot, and we could wait 30 minutes and join a full guided tour with 6‚Äì7 other folks, at no extra cost. w00t w00t!
Surely, the Gods had intervened. I have rarely ever gone for human guides, but the Vatican is a giant maze and it is highly recommended to book a full tour. It helped that our guide was knowledgeable and witty to match.
Keep a good 3‚Äì4 hours for a full tour of the Vatican, the Sistine Chapel and St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica (perhaps more if you want to climb up the Basilica‚Äôs steps to the dome). Even as you step out to the Vatican square, the plaza looks resplendent with fountains and an array of statues lining the surrounding buildings‚Äô rooftops. Covering your knees and shoulders is advisable.
As we stepped out of the Vatican, we spotted a McDonald‚Äôs and that was lunch because, well, we needed a break from pizza & pasta. Already.
Before heading to Trastevere for our last evening in Rome, we did a detour to the Chiesa di Santa Maria della Vittoria which houses Bernini‚Äôs sculpture The Ecstasy of Saint Teresa ‚Äî a statue you might remember from Dan Brown‚Äôs Angels & Demons. It is a church as grand as any other and an item checked off the bucket-list.
Trastevere is the trans-Tiber section of Rome. Due to its quaint and bohemian buildings and houses, Trastevere is pretty Instagram-friendly. There is an audio tour by Rick Steves on Trastevere as well, and we spent the first hour or so getting to know the history of the commune, walking the neighbourhood, and visiting the Church of Cecilia & that of Santa Maria.
It was Friday evening and weekend revelry was in the air. We passed a number of piazzas where locals had got together to enjoy some food, drinks and music. As the evening set in, we went back to Piazza Trilussa and saw an exhilarating band performance. Ponte Sisto ‚Äî the bridge in front of the Piazza was also abuzz with street artists and beat boxers. It was a far cry from the vibe of central Rome, and it won‚Äôt be far-fetched to say that this was indeed the Heart of Rome.
We found a quieter alley for dinner at a fine restaurant called Latteria Trastevere. And with a long-ish goodbye walk, we boarded the tram from Trastevere to Venezia, where, to our surprise, there was a traffic stop due to a night marathon. So, we had to wait for half an hour under the Roman night-sky before taking a cab back to the hotel.
It was our last night there. We weren‚Äôt complaining.
Rome is a city that keeps giving. Every day spent, even visits to the same sites, at times, offered us a fresh perspective or a yet-unseen relic.
It is a modern capital city with its roots firmly planted in its past ‚Äî be it the well-maintained ancient monuments, the social piazzas or the water pumps providing water to passersby ‚Äî each one of them telling tales from a history as old as time itself.

Title: Rome sucks
Content:

AOG, Sitges
Word of advice number one: when you next go on vacation, don‚Äôt wear new shoes on the flight.
Why? Well, it could be that the airline looses your luggage and you are doomed to wear the same pair of new shoes for days on end. And your feet will not forgive you.
Word of advice number two: Never, ever, go to Rome in August. Not if you value your life and well being in general. And especially not if you are adverse to high temperatures.
Our friends had warned us against this.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt go, it is too hot!‚Äù, they said.
‚ÄúNever in August. You‚Äôll die from the heat!‚Äù, they warned.
Did we listen? Well, of course not.
Our logic?
‚ÄúWell, we always say we won‚Äôt go in August and that we‚Äôll go some other time, but then we never go‚Äù, said my partner. I agreed. My partner was right. We always say we‚Äôll go some other time, but then we never do.
So a couple of years ago we decided to go to Rome and check out the Eternal City.
E t e r n a l mistake on our part!
After paying Vueling Airlines (a low cost airline) for 2 pieces of luggage, we arrived at Rome‚Äôs Fiumicino Airport with a slight delay, but no suitcases.
We only discovered this after waiting for our bags for over an hour at belt #9.
I went to the baggage handling company in charge of our flight (turns out there‚Äôs more than one. Blessed capitalism!) and they told us they had no record of our bags on their system.
Yes, having been to the country in the past, in fact, as recently as last June, my first thought was ‚Äútypical Italian efficiency‚Äù, but I was wrong to think that. The problem was not typical Italian efficiency, it was typical Spanish negligence.
As we would find out the next day, the bags had never left Barcelona.
The Italian handler made us fill a form; he put our details into the computer, and sent us off on our less than merry way with a reference number which, we would later discover, was incorrect.
Although no consolation at all, we were not the only people without luggage on our flight, there was, at least, one other.
So there we were at Rome‚Äôs airport with a driver waiting to take us into town for 50 Euros, something we thought would be a good idea since we didn‚Äôt know the city and we wanted not to worry about the bags.
He was very nice, and if he was upset at having waited for over an hour, he didn‚Äôt let on.
We got into his Ford Focus and made our way to the Citt√† Eterna.
I have to say that the drive went pretty well, and that the country side was not exactly very pretty. It was, all in all, a bit odd.
First we were on a highway, then, after a while, we found ourselves in what can only be describe as ‚Äòleafy suburbs‚Äô.
He didn‚Äôt take any major roads and, instead, chose one-way roads with large, tall, walls, behind which I can only imagine must hide beautiful private villas.
It was a long while before we approached something which resembled the outskirts of a large city.
Once there what we saw first was the usual dim urban landscape, typical of any major European city post 1950.
Large, ugly, square, brick and concrete buildings, with many stores along the way selling mostly urban goods: fast food joints, urban clothing stores, ugly furniture shops, and the odd newspaper stand.
Still, we were excited to be in Rome.
I mean, R O M E !!
Right?
Then, suddenly, something which would happen again and again -though we didn‚Äôt know it at the time- occurred: when we least expected it, and just before we entered a tunnel, out of the corner of our left eyes, we caught a glimpse of St. Peter‚Äôs, in The Vatican.
This was unexpected because we had thought that we would view that particular monument going up the Via Della Concilliazione and into St. Peter‚Äôs Square, like almost everyone else.
But it was not to be. We quickly crossed the Tiber and drove down the Corso Vittorio Emanuelle II and into our hotel near the Campo de Fiori.
We paid our driver, gave him a tip, then checked in.
The hotel was ok. The recepcionist was not really friendly and did that thing which so often happens in Europe, he spoke as if HE was doing you a favor.
As if HE was paying for you to stay at the hotel. Not rude, just a bit‚Ä¶what‚Äôs the word‚Ä¶ condescending and aloof.
Regardless, we had gone to Rome to enjoy the place and that is what we wanted to do. So we quickly forgot about him.
We had asked for a room with a balcony, and they gave us that, which was nice. But we soon discovered that the a/c was, well, less than able. It made a lot of noise, but gave out little cold air. But I would only realize this later in the day. And especially so at night.
We were starving by now and wanted to a) see the city and b) get some clothes. We had nothing to wear. Only the clothes we had on and which, by now, were very sweaty. Did I mention Rome was hot?
We left the hotel, which was, it seemed, used to situations such as ours. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll get your bags tomorrow‚Äù, said the receptionist/owner, and off we went to eat and do some shopping.
We found a small restaurant about 3 minutes away and sat down. We ordered one pizza for the both of us and something to drink. It was the best pizza we would have during the whole trip. It was that good.
The service, however, was pretty bad. I wouldn‚Äôt say it went downhill from there, but rather that the service in Rome was consistently bad day in, day out.
Our waiters over the next few days, it would seem, would find new and creative ways in which to outdo their colleague‚Äôs ‚Äòperformance‚Äô throughout our stay. And no, we hardly spent a penny on tips while in Rome.
So, after having lunch and stopping off at the local grocery shop where we got basic eating and drinking supplies, as well as some toiletries, it was back to the hotel, quick shower, and out before the stores closed.
Rome was baking under the sun, and us with it.
Out we went into the Corso Vittorio Emanuele II and started walking East, with no particular place to go. Also, we didn‚Äôt really know which way to go. We were torn between wanting to see the sights, and our clothing needs, so we tried to concentrate very little on what we saw, hard to do since if you‚Äôve never been to Rome, everything is new to you, even when nine or ten centuries old. Or more.
Eventually, we got to Via del Corso, but not before we stumbled on the Piazza Venezia and the enormous marble and stone behemoth to our right: the monument to King Vittorio Emanuele II, first King of Italy.
This is one of the monuments on my list which I would not really arrive at the way I had expected. When I say we stumbled, I mean it. It is gigantic, but it is not exactly by a major road, it is on a major square, but off to the right, so if you happen to be on the street and not turn right, you might not exactly see it. But then, once you do, you can‚Äôt see anything else.
I wanted to go to it (yes, its array of classical columns was calling me) and bask in its classical ‚Äòinterpretative‚Äô colossal beauty, but it was not to be on that first day.
We had no time, it was hot, and we needed clothes.
We turned into the Via del Corso, and forgot about it.
Via del Corso is one of those major shopping streets in central Rome. Many of the major brands, and others not so major, are there. Although Rome‚Äôs high class shopping strip is the Via Condotti, which is further down the Via del Corso, to the right.
On the corner, just as you go into Corso, there is the Doria-Pamphilj Palace.
Serene and decorated in a wedding cake style, I was immediately drawn to it.
But didn‚Äôt go, and would, unfortunately, not get to go during the trip.
And that pretty much sums up the entire trip. I didn‚Äôt get to see, go or do many things.
So back to the Via del Corso, and our shopping. We had nothing to wear the next day, and clothes were urgently needed. So we spent the best part of the afternoon traipsing from store to store, looking for garments, and missing out on Rome altogether.
On a side note, I must point out that, by now, my partner and I were wondering how the people of Italy reproduced since, it was very obvious, all the men in that country were gay.
But I digress‚Ä¶Clothes-wise, our main hope turned out to be H&M, but, once we got there, almost at the end of the Corso, we discovered, much to our dismay, that there was no Men‚Äôs section there.
Can you believe it?
We had walked the entire length of the Corso in the hope of finding a place which might have something -overpriced- but my size. Fat chance.
Since at that point we were only about two blocks from the Piazza del Popolo, we decided to go there.
I have to say that by now, I was ready to be impressed, or something, and impressed I was.
I had long wanted to see the twin churches of Santa Maria in Montesanto (1662-75) and Santa Maria dei Miracoli (built 1675-79). And there they were, in all their Baroque beauty. I think this is the one time Rome got interesting that day. I would say it made the whole thing worthwhile, but it isn‚Äôt true.The day had sucked all along from the minute our luggage went missing. But that moment, when we walked into that space, covered in fatigue and sweat, the city seemed beautiful, the tourists a mere nuisance, the heat (and it was around 8:30 PM) almost tolerable.
It was magic. Rome was magic.
We stopped at the obelisk in the middle of the Piazza, an original comission of Sety I (later erected by Rameses II) from Heliopolis which stands in the centre of the Piazza, inside a fountain, and is the second oldest and one of the tallest obelisks in Rome (some 24 m high, or 36 m including its plinth).
It was brought to Rome in 10 BC by order of Augustus and originally set up in the Circus Maximus.
Once there, a tourist girl asked her friend if she could drink from the fountain. My partner overheard her and told her that he‚Äôd read that you could drink from any fountain in Rome, unless it specifically said not to.
She was happy about this, and we spoke with her for a couple more minutes. Turns out she was from Spain, and was there on holiday with a couple more friends from school. She must have been in her very early 20s. And she was lovely.
It was starting to get dark, and we decided to get back to the hotel. We couldn‚Äôt decide between catching a bus, taking the subway, or walking. So we walked back along the dark and not too busy streets of, as it turns out, downtown Rome. Soon we were back at the hotel, where there were no news about our luggage.
The hotel‚Äôs concierge really couldn‚Äôt care less, so we went to our room, had a shower and went out to have dinner, not too sure about where to do this.
We decided to follow the incoming crowd down one of the streets, and ended up at the Campo dei Fiori. It was teeming with life: children playing, musicians, flower vendors, Indian or Pakistani salesmen of trinkets.
In short, Touristland right there in front of us. The only Italians being the waiters at the Campo‚Äôs many restaurants. So in we walked, and decided that the one on the right, on the other side of La Carbonara Restaurant, where we should have dined, just as you walked in, would do. Mistake. The food, although ok once we got it, did not surpass the bad service of a place which doubled as a drinks bar and dance club after 11PM.
We kept getting food meant for other tables, everything arrived at odd intervals, drinks had to be ordered more than twice. In short, a mess.
But given the day‚Äôs big story, it really paled in comparison. We didn‚Äôt mind much that the service was so bad. I think we were relieved it was over more than anything else!
Afterwards, we went for a walk on the Tiber, and saw that, at night, it really came alive. What a beautiful city this is.
It seems like the good citizens of Rome have allowed for bars and stands to be set up alongside the banks of the river. We were immediately drawn by the music and the bright, intermitent, lights of the marquees.
We crossed the bridge, and went down to the riverbank. We saw a couple of small stands which were a sort of Godsend since they had one of the items we needed most: a phone charger!
Yes, ours were safely (we hoped) stored inside our suitcases, and these, somewhere in Europe. We then decided to go to one of the ‚Äúbars‚Äù. A rugby-themed bar by the side of the Tiber showing New Zealand‚Äôs Rugby matches.
Yes, slightly surreal, but then Rome is slightly surreal.
We would have stayed longer, but we were beat. We had had a long day and were yearning for sleep.
So after a couple of drinks, we headed back to the hotel. The room was not exactly cold, although the imitation a/c had been on all afternoon, so we agreed to sleep with the balcony window open. And the air con on. So our first day in Rome ended.

January 4, 2022|Italy
As expected, very late last night, Boo and I got our test results back for the PCR tests we took late yesterday afternoon. Negative for COVID. So yay!
Except . . . when I went to wake up Boo this morning, she told me that during the night, she had a headache and sore throat. She had taken ibuprofen and the symptoms went away And she felt fine this morning.
So we went about our day as planned. We took a walking tour through Ancient Rome. We met the group near Trajan‚Äôs column then walked past ‚Äùthe wedding cake,‚Äù the monument to the king who united Italy.
Our guide was OK. Informative but not that entertaining. On the upside, he didn‚Äôt sing, so that was a blessing.
The guide took us up the hill behind the wedding cake where we had a glorious view over the rooftops of Rome. We were there at the stroke of noon, so we could hear bells peal across the city.

7

I first visited Rome back in 2015, and it remains my favourite European city to this day.
Mainstream, I know. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your favourite song, Wonderwall?‚Äù, I hear you ask.
Well, no (although I do love Oasis). Just hear me out.
I‚Äôm a firm believer that Rome‚Äôs reputation has suffered because it‚Äôs so popular. It‚Äôs as though people refuse to judge the city on its merit, so widespread is the knowledge of its undeniable appeal. Sometimes it‚Äôs important to take a step back, and to try and refresh one‚Äôs perspective.
I often struggle with cities. I don‚Äôt understand the appeal of London, living some 90 minutes away from it myself, and I‚Äôve found the energy of big cities a little oppressive at various times in my life.
That wasn‚Äôt the case in Rome, though.
Down every street, and round every corner, there‚Äôs something to marvel at ‚Äî some unwavering reminder of what our species has achieved, and how it has evolved.

Title: Europe 2016 ‚Äî Rome, Italy
Content:
Sign up

Keenan‚Äôs Adventures, travels, and wordly outtings

--
Listen
Share
The day out of Levanto was an early morning because of the train tickets we‚Äôd booked in Venice. We took a regional train to La Spieza, south of Cinque Terre and then a direct train to Rome. This train was different in that it had booths of 6 seats each. I asked Yuki if she felt like she was going to Hogwarts.
We arrived in Rome and had to walk 2km to the Airbnb apartment. We were surprised that a city steeped in such history would be covered in so much graffiti. It covers a lot of buildings, most train cars, all municipal work vehicles, and any spot like tunnels or under bridges that are easily accessible and discrete. At the same time, the cobblestone streets made it difficult to drag our suitcases and the narrow sidewalks littered with garbage were a constant obstacle course. For all the problems, it is perhaps surprising that the drivers almost always stop for you to cross the road if you step out in front of them. They don‚Äôt try to ignore you or speed behind you like in Canada. So at first we were hesitant to cross the road but soon became accustomed to finding a break in traffic and forcing the next car to slow down and stop for us.
We were pleasantly surprised that the Airbnb apartment was actually a one bedroom place and that we got our own room again.
Probably my favourite part of Rome is that there are ruins everywhere. We went out to see one attraction and on our way to finding a subway line we stumbled upon the Piazza di Porta Maggorie. There is a tram station beside the ruins of what use to be Rome‚Äôs old city wall where an aqueduct cuts through at 30m high and one of the gates to the city was a tomb to a slave that was freed and became wealthy as a baker.
Further on we walked beside the remains of an aqueduct, one of 11 that use to feed the 1 million inhabitants of ancient Rome. The aqueduct and city walls have openings which have roads going through them. Some of them are the original gates repurposed for roads but others are just large demolitions cut out of the wall.
Our attraction of the day was the Spanish Steps, located in the North East of the city. Photos made it look appealing but when we arrived around dinner time the square was packed with tourists and the stairs had become a de facto public bench. We walked up and read that the stairs were significant for connecting two parts of town at different elevations. Otherwise, there isn‚Äôt much to them and we were less impressed.
Surprisingly, we found a family run restaurant with an enthusiastic and very happy greeter and waiter. This fun meal would be an abnormally of our time in Rome where the restaurant was happy, joked around, and cared about the service and food that they served. For the remainder of our time in Rome, we would have difficulty finding good food and service.
Our day of sight seeing in Rome began later than expected but we took a tram and one of two subway lines to the Colosseum. There are hawkers everywhere trying to get you to join a tour group. They offered entrance in the next few minutes for 30 euros and said that the line was 2hr. In reality, the line was about half an hour and admission without any guide costs 11 Euro. It would seem, however, that tour groups would be the normal for all of Italy. Everywhere we went, we were mobbed by tourist groups, whether formed by a company or a sole person at the entrance. Some of the larger attractions also have self-guided audio tours and many people can be found standing awkwardly around the attraction holding half of a phone up to their ear.
Needless to say, Yuki and I didn‚Äôt use any guides. This meant that we didn‚Äôt actually learn anything while visiting the historic sites as there aren‚Äôt really any display boards. The only learning we did was by reading up on wikipedia after the fact.The tour groups looked slow and the tour guides seemed to drone on and on so it was nice to be able to go at our own pace and wander around instead of being stuck to a set path.
I wasn‚Äôt all that impressed by the Eiffel tower in Paris but the Colosseum was massively impressive. Stepping out of the metro station, the scale and size of the Colosseum is enormous. Even in ruin, it is wonderful in shape and form. From the outside, the form of the Colosseum is beautiful, with each successive arch and while deteriorated and broken, it is easy to image how much grandeur there would have been back in ancient Rome.
Entering the Colosseum was also spectacular. It is interesting to note that tickets to events at the Colosseum were free but seating was arranged by social standing with the wealthiest at the lower bowl and the poor, furthest at the top. Each of the arches at the base of the Coliseum was an entrance that lead directly to the intended seats. This eliminated cross contamination between social classes but also was incredibly efficient in moving people in and out of the stadium.
We walked around the lower bowl for photos and peered down into the galleries below the originally wood arena. The signboards said how there use to be mock naval battles but stopped after a renovation. it wasn‚Äôt clear if that renovation had to do with adding the basement or a perimeter wall. I cannot imagine how they would be able to flood the arena with a wood floor and not only support the weight of the water but also be waterproof at the same time.
After the Colosseum we had to wander around for a bit to find a place to eat, which was the normal Italian food, and then we sat outside the Basilica di San Pietro for a while because they close for lunch. Of note, there are some religious artifacts, including chains that held Saint Peter and a statue of Moses by Michelangelo. There were also some other tombs adored with skeletons which we found odd and the roof had a nice painting on it.
Then we walked back to the Coliseum to visit the adjacent Roman Forums. The ticket to the Colosseum includes the Roman Forums and Palatine Hill across the street. This is where the Roman government buildings were located and is nearby to a wealthy neighbourhood. What is most impressive about the forums is the height of some of the ruins, indicating that some buildings were huge.
The Forums are mostly ruins now but I was struct by how a much of it is brick. It seems that the romans built predominantly in brick and covered the structures in a concrete paste or marble. I‚Äôd known about the romans and concrete before but I didn‚Äôt realize that it was used as mortar between bricks and not contemporary concrete with aggregates and moulds. Only certain buildings, or parts of buildings, are constructed from stone.
By the end of the forums we were too tired to walk up Palatine Hill so we planned on coming back the next day because the tickets are valid for two consecutive days.
The next item on our list of places to visit was Trevi Fountain. We found a shop before the fountain where we bought postcards for 0.4 euro each. We thought this was pretty good because they can be as high as 1 and are usually 0.5 or above but we found another store later that had them for 0.3 euro. Oh well.
The fountain is probably the most photographed in Rome. It was also crowded and so it felt like a lot of the other attractions where we only had enough time to get in, take our photos, and get out. There didn‚Äôt seem to be any time to appreciate or enjoy each place, especially with the crowds.
From Trevi fountain we walked to the Pantheon, passing the Piazza Colonna, which is significant because the tall round marble Column of Marcus Aurelius recounts the conquest of the Emperor in relief carvings that spiral up to a statue at the top.
The Pantheon was as large as I‚Äôd expected it to be and enormously voluminous inside. Looking at the roof, we knew that the square recesses were to reduce the weight of the roof but we wondered instead why the roof couldn‚Äôt be thinner. Like the Colosseum and the Roman Forums, the exterior was all brick. Apparently it used to be faced in marble but over the centuries that was scavenged away.
After the Pantheon we walked to the Piazza Navonna which has another impressive, but smaller fountain. We took a peak inside the Saint Agnese but there was a Sunday service in progress and the space was surprisingly small, although ordinate.
We had our worst lunch lunch afterwards at a restaurant just outside the square. The service was terrible and the food wasn‚Äôt that great either. The worst part was that the waiter tried to take 5 euros tip from us and I had to yell at him to get all our money back. For hearing that Paris waiters were snobs, we didn‚Äôt have a problem there and found that Italy was generally much worse in the tourist areas but very good in the local parts.
We were going to take the bus back to Palatine Hill but we couldn‚Äôt find a place to buy tickets so we decided to cheap out and just walk back. Along the way we stopped at the Piazza Venezia and took photos of the Altare della Patria. This monument is a modern symbol to the city of Rome and has some newer statues.
There are a lot of steps to climb on the way up and the view from the top is okay, but not great. It‚Äôs possible to go to the top by elevator but it cost 7 euro and we didn‚Äôt think it was worthwhile. In some ways, this building gives an idea to the grandeur of ancient Rome and what it must have been like in the past.
At the edge of the Roman Forums we realized that we‚Äôd forgotten yesterday‚Äôs tickets so we weren‚Äôt able to get back in. Instead we walked around to the Circuit Maximus but I was disappointed to find a sloping field with barely any trace of a race course. The Circuit Maximus use to be the largest chariot race track in the Roman Empire and was also used for many ceremonies and parades. Today, it could be mistaken for an undeveloped site as there‚Äôs nothing but a walking path.
For dinner we tried to go to Sushi but it was a high class place with a long line up. Instead we went to a take-away shop but it took an hour for them to prepare it. Still, Yuki got her much desired sushi and we have a good dinner at home of the type of food we wanted to eat.
Yuki‚Äôs Dad wanted to visit the Vatican so we went there. It took us a long time to get through security because I picked the wrong line. There was a mass of people that split into four lines. The first two lines had a security checkpoint each but the second two lines funneled into a single checkpoint. We were in the second line and the people around us were quite aggressive to get to the front of each other.
Saint Peter‚Äôs Basilica, had been described to us as a lot of dead saints. Like all the other religious sites, it was highly decorated in gold paintings and large but wasn‚Äôt that interesting to us. Turns out, there are a lot of dead saints. We considered visiting the Sistine Chapel but it seemed far and likely to have a long line so we walked through the Basilica‚Äôs grotto and then went for lunch.
Everyone looked forward to lunch at McDonalds because it is a dependable staple to be the same everywhere in the world. At least, almost the same. The taste was slightly different but it was a welcome relief to all the plain food we‚Äôve been having lately. We never thought that we would be so eager to eat at McDonalds for lunch.
The last place to visit in Rome was the Baths of Caracalla which we discovered was very close to the Circuit Maximus we visited the day before. We had to transfer between the two subway lines at the Rome train station so we also used that opportunity to buy tickets for Yuki‚Äôs parents to get to the airport as they would be going alone the next day. As with all things family related, it took a lot of explaining in three different languages to get the message through to her Dad who speaks English and Japanese and her mom who speaks Japanese and Thai. Yuki‚Äôs patience seem almost angelic for all the explaining and translating she has to do.
Frustratingly, the Baths closed early on Monday so we walked to them for nothing. Frances, who had visited Rome in August, recommended going to the Pyramide metro station and Eatalia, a department store of restaurants. It turned out to be a station beyond Pyramide so we had a tiresome walk and the building was actually more of an expensive health food store. There were three levels with restaurants but the main business was selling healthy foods and the restaurants looked posh. Dejected, we backtracked to a Ramen restaurant we‚Äôd passed walking there and ate a small early dinner because we were all still full on McDonalds for lunch.
--

To celebrate my 50th birthday, my best friend and I embarked on our first European adventure, with Rome as our initial destination. Upon our arrival, we were immediately struck by the city‚Äôs incredible scale and beauty. ‚ÄúEverything is so grand!‚Äù became our catchphrase ‚Äî and it truly was. Down every street and around every corner, something extraordinary awaited. In the open-air museum that is Rome, forget the car, put on your walking shoes, and get ready to log 15,000 steps/day discovering the city‚Äôs landmarks and hidden treasures.
Before experiencing Rome in person, we‚Äôd spent months laying out our itinerary, starting with a Google map where we pinpointed the places we wanted to visit and marked the center with a figurative X. When we arrived in Italy, what had appeared on the map as a web of gray lines connecting landmarks was transformed into living, breathing Roman arteries bursting with vibrant culture and sensory delights. Serendipitously, the focal point marked by an X landed us in the heart of Rome at the Palazzo Navona Hotel, situated next to the Piazza Navona. It proved to be the perfect launching point for our three-day exploration of the Eternal City.

Title: When in Rome‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäMy Experience in Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I took a three-day trip to Italy on New Years. It was always my dream to visit the great Ancient Rome, so you can imagine how excited I was for this trip. Throughout my visit, I experienced some wonderful places, great food, and met new people. I want to share with you the rookie mistakes that I made, the things I did right, and ultimately what I learned from this experience. Here are some tips for navigating your way through the beautiful city of Rome.
Pack well (and right!!): Extra clothes, check, portable charger, check, type C, F, and L power outlet plugs, not check. Seriously, I spent the first half of my day there looking for electronic stores with the correct power outlet adapters. I made a rookie mistake, and hopefully, you will not have to.
Don‚Äôt pay extra. If anyone tries to convince you that you have to pay to get into the Vatican, I will assure you that you don‚Äôt. As soon as I arrived at the Vatican, I was unpleasantly approached by a man who apparently had only two tickets left to sell for the Vatican. Most might think that they ‚Äúgot lucky‚Äù and that they had just made it there in time before tickets were sold out, but that isn‚Äôt the case at all. Just keep your head up and walk right into the Vatican. It‚Äôs free. Thankfully, binge-watching travel videos on youtube helped me with that one.
Take lots of pictures. If you are traveling along, you can even ask tourists to take photos of you! As a solo traveler, I had plenty of time to soak in all the views and take my time appreciating all the sights and wonders. It is nice to take some pictures so you can reminisce later (who knows when you‚Äôll be back). If you want to take some pictures of yourself, ask tourists if they‚Äôd be willing to take it for you, you‚Äôd be surprised how much photography talent there is in the crowd. If you see someone who could use a hand, offer to help them take their picture, they might offer to take yours back. Well, hey, it worked for me.
Plan well! I packed my day with wonderful sightseeing adventures and activities. It is crucial to check openings of the different places, especially on holidays. Unfortunately, I missed out on the great opportunity of seeing the Sistine Chapel because it was closed on the new year.
Throw a coin (or two) into the Trevi Garden. Legend has it that if you throw a coin over your head into the Trevi Fountain, chances are, you will return to Rome. If you throw two, you will return to Rome and fall in love, and three, you will return to Rome, fall in love, and get married there. I don‚Äôt know if this has been proven correct, but it can‚Äôt hurt to take your chances either way. Unluckily, I didn‚Äôt get to throw coins into the fountain, but have no doubt; I shall return.
Check out what Italy is known for, then make sure not to miss out. I enjoyed some delicious Italian Ice Cream, Pizza, and House Wine. The wine is incredibly affordable in Italy. While in the restaurant, don‚Äôt rush to receive the bill. It is customary in Italy to stick around and have a conversation after a nice meal.
Fly Ryanair! This one is a little bit controversial. If you asked me then if I would fly Ryanair again, I would have said that I would absolutely not. Looking back though, I realize how convenient it was to have a cheap flight from London to Rome. Just make sure you read exactly what you need to do when buying the ticket so they won‚Äôt charge you extra for late check-in or carry-on bags. If you don‚Äôt want to experience flight delays though, don‚Äôt fly with Ryanair. They might have cheaper flights, but that doesn‚Äôt mean they come without a cost.
I hope asome of these travelling tips helped you out! I know that I need to take some of my own advice on my next trip to Rome.
Edit: This blog is a repost from 3 years ago when I first visited Rome. Hope you enjoy!

Content:

Alun‚Äôs personal blog now on Medium
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
The OUP blog has an excerpt from Bryan Ward-Perkin‚Äôs The Fall of Rome.
It is currently deeply unfashionable to state that anything like a ‚Äòcrisis‚Äô or a ‚Äòdecline‚Äô occurred at the end of the Roman empire, let alone that a ‚Äòcivilization‚Äô collapsed and a ‚Äòdark age‚Äô ensued. The new orthodoxy is that the Roman world, in both East and West, was slowly, and essentially painlessly, ‚Äòtransformed‚Äô into a medieval form. However, there is an insuperable problem with this new view: it does not fit the mass of archaeological evidence now available‚Ä¶
The Fall of Rome is one of these things that varies from whatever perspective you take. I remember my Roman lecturer on my BA commenting that many historians felt Rome went into terminal decline during the third century. Over two hundred years, he dryly noted, must have been some decline. The British Empire has collapsed in the last century, are we walking in the ruins of a one mighty empire?
Yet Ward-Perkins is right. There is a change. Pottery becomes pretty cruddy stuff. Writing becomes much much rarer. Civic centres fall. If civilisation is living in cities, then there is definitely a collapse of civilisation. While it might not be visible over the course of a lifetime, it is there. It depends what questions you ask of the data. The grand dur√©e of history doesn‚Äôt disappear simply because the individual becomes the fashionable thing to study in the Thatcherite era.
I remember being taught that Saxons didn‚Äôt really invade, they came over as farmers. The Vikings didn‚Äôt invade either, they were peaceful farmers with a bad press. It makes you wonder how and why a lot of weapons came to be invented with all these peaceful farmers going everywhere. Perhaps an understanding of barbarians might remind us why civilisation might be a good idea.
