Feature by Katie McKnoulty
Now one of Europe‚Äôs up-and-coming voices in food, Saghar works with leading editorial and commercial clients; runs cooking workshops across Italy; and has previously contributed to Italy‚Äôs national newspaper, Corriere della Sera. Her debut cookbook, Pomegranates & Artichokes, aims to show our innate similarities as humans by tracking recipes on her journey from Iran to Italy. We couldn‚Äôt wait to discover Saghar‚Äôs Travel Playbook of recommendations to experience when in Rome.
When I was born, we were not only in full Islamic regime, but we were in the middle of a war with Iraq which went from ‚Äô80 to ‚Äô88. It was very traumatic because I was literally born under bombs. My earliest memories are of the sirens that went off in Tehran that announced the bombings, and we used to put big chunks of tape on the windows so that if they broke, they wouldn‚Äôt break into our homes. We would go away for short periods of time when the bombings were very intense, to other cities. I remember very well that they had bombed maybe a few blocks away from our house, and I remember that the curtain of my room had been ripped apart by glass.
From a very early age, the first thing we learned is that your life at home is a very different life from your life outdoors. So indoors, everything is normal ‚Äî you have parties, your family comes, you put on music. And then we would go to school, and we would have to wear the veil and everything. And your parents would tell you, ‚ÄòYou shouldn‚Äôt say to anyone that we were dancing at home yesterday‚Äô or ‚ÄòYou should never, ever say that daddy had a drink, because all of that is illegal, OK?‚Äô. You don‚Äôt know who to trust, and then eventually you learn that almost all of the kids going to your school are living in a similar situation.
At the university where I studied art and architecture in Tehran, we had a very rigid education about composition and light. I struggled a lot in university in Iran to understand things and find my own visual language. Art especially wasn‚Äôt my thing, but my mathematical brain understood composition very well. Then, in Rome, I studied graphic design and design general. And eventually, I moved towards photography and food because I became really passionate about it.
I didn‚Äôt know anything about Rome. I chose Rome mainly because it was the Italian capital and in my silly, 20-year-old head, the capital is the place to go. This is what I thought. But when I arrived here, despite the difficulties that it has, I really fell in love with it. For those of us coming from countries like Iran, as students, the experience of arriving in Italy is very, very different from that sort of Under the Tuscan Sun experience. We live in a different dimension: when we arrive here, our goal is survival and we don‚Äôt have any funds or anything. And we still need to find a job, and we need to do all of these things in Italian. I went through hell because I was really scared of not being able to make it and having to go back to Iran. Even to this day, whenever I go somewhere and I come back here, I‚Äôm happy to come back to Rome. It grabs you and never lets go of you.
Rome is a ridiculously beautiful city. I think that‚Äôs very important to me. There are certain aesthetic things ‚Äî like the trees, Roman pines that are like umbrellas, against the backdrop of the ochre and orange buildings. And the blue sky of Rome is something special. It struck me very, very hard in the beginning. And it still does. And then of course it‚Äôs historical; it‚Äôs charming; it‚Äôs got all of those classic grand things that are very beautiful. They give me joy, as frivolous as it may sound.
I live somewhere between the Colosseum and a neighborhood called Esquilino. And over the years it was not known as a very nice place, but now it‚Äôs becoming very nice and lovely ‚Äî I think there‚Äôs been a bit of gentrification. It has a very, very long street called Via Merulana that leads to the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore; one of Rome‚Äôs biggest treasures. They have extraordinary medieval mosaics there ‚Äî absolutely stunning. I love that church a lot. And then, in terms of museums, Palazzo Massimo and Palazzo Altemps are some of the most beautiful things that you can see ‚Äî not just in Rome, but in Italy, possibly in the world. Often my suggestion to people who can‚Äôt get Vatican tickets or who don‚Äôt want to queue for three-and-a-half hours under the burning sun, is to get a combo ticket. It lasts for two days and you can see all of them, including the Vatican. It‚Äôs mind-blowing, absolutely mind-blowing.
In the side streets of the Via Merulana, there are a couple of nice places. One of them is a new bakery ‚Äî Forno Conti. They have bread of course, but also croissants and cakes, and it‚Äôs become very popular. There‚Äôs a little community around it. It‚Äôs very different from the classic Roman bakery. Then there‚Äôs a little wine bar that‚Äôs quite famous now in Trastevere called Enoteca l‚ÄôAntidoto, and they have very nice natural wines and littles dishes. There‚Äôs another trattoria called Trattoria Pennestri. The food is Roman but with an elegant little twist. You need to book but it‚Äôs not impossible to get in.
I do a lot of shopping at Esquilino Market. To be honest, the quality of fruit and veg is not always, like, a farmers market, but it‚Äôs possibly the most multicultural market in Rome. And you can find a lot of ingredients that you can‚Äôt find anywhere else. The African community shops there; the Chinese community shops there; the Bangladeshi and Indian community shops there. So it‚Äôs very interesting.
After university I discovered food blogs. Some of them were people who were very much like me ‚Äî they had a background in the arts and now they were working with food. Some of them were doing astonishing photography, and that was the moment that it clicked. And I thought, ‚ÄòI can do this‚Äô ‚Äî not so much because I knew how to do photography, because I didn‚Äôt, but because I knew composition and I knew light. So I started practicing. It took me some time but it was also very nice, because for the first time I had found my visual language ‚Äî the thing that I had struggled so much to find. It was very liberating.
The more I worked with food, the more I was intrigued with its cultural and political aspects and what it represents. So I started blogging about it and writing about it. And this is how I came to write my first cookbook, Pomegranates & Artichokes, which is exactly about those things. It‚Äôs also autobiographical, and this is what I do: I love to look at cultures, habits and situations through the lens of food, literally and figuratively.
Pomegranates & Artichokes is a cookbook that starts in Iran; then it travels west, crossing the Mediterranean and the Middle East through Turkey, Greece, Lebanon and Syria, all of those countries. And it arrives in Italy as if you were taking a flight ‚Äî it literally does this journey. I love watching the map thing on the airplane and this is exactly that. I got this idea because this is a book that is born out of my experience of living as an Iranian, but mostly as an immigrant, here in Italy, in the West. This whole book is about how a lot of the flavors, ingredients and cooking methods are super similar. We‚Äôre not even that far, geographically speaking. Basically, you cross Greece and Turkey, and you‚Äôre in Iran ‚Äî so how is it that people from my side of the world are treated so differently where our food is so similar? So this book is a testimony to those similarities.
It started because of the protests of the death of Mahsa Amini, who was murdered because she was showing a few strands of hair. So it is about compulsory hijab, and yet it is not just about compulsory hijab. There are many rights that women in Iran don‚Äôt have: the testimony of a woman in court is worth half of a man‚Äôs; women can work but if your husband says you cannot work then you cannot work; you can‚Äôt have rights to the custody of your child if you get divorced; and you can‚Äôt ask for a divorce ‚Äî the right to divorce lies with the husband. What‚Äôs happening to the women in Iran concerns us all. And the fight against the Iranian regime is the fight to be on the right side of history.
Always window. I like to have space to lean out and look out of the window. But it‚Äôs mostly the leaning thing.
‚ÄòVia da Roma‚Äô by Luca Barbarossa, from the album Roma √® de tutti. The name says it all. It‚Äôs very nice.
Contradictory.
There are a lot of beautiful things and lots of ugly things. Like all big cities.

After a long silence (because reasons), I return to Medium (as intended a while ago!) I actually have several unfinished stories, some that are in old school notebooks and others just existing as a draft in title. So content is in abundance and hopefully I‚Äôll be able to share more and more consistently in the coming weeks. I even acquired a tablet, with one of the main motives being more writing. In fact, my return article is related: I‚Äôll write about a game I‚Äôve been playing on the tablet. So without further ado, let‚Äôs talk Grow Empire: Rome!
As an avid Starcraft UMS and Warcraft 3 custom map player, I‚Äôm always on the lookout for tower defense maps on mobile. My recent search brought me to Grow Empire Rome. The name was familiar, but I hadn‚Äôt give it much thought at first. The reason it was familiar was because of a game I played on my phone before: Grow Castle and I would indeed notice the gameplay parallels quite soon into the game. They aren‚Äôt developed by same people from what it seems and indeed there seems to be a major difference between the games. Okay, enough with the fluff and meta, let me talk about the game!
Grow Empire Rome, GER from now on, is a defense game, rather than a traditional TD. As you might imagine, it has a Roman Empire setting. You have a base where barbarians attack, wave by wave, each wave triggered by you. So you don‚Äôt start a game and play 10 waves. You play one wave and it‚Äôs over. You can start the next one if you like. On top of that, there is an empire map and you can launch invasions on enemy colonies to acquire them, which sort of reverses the roles. Each acquired colony then has 3 waves of rebels you can fight whenever you wish. I haven‚Äôt bested the 3rd level yet, but I‚Äôm guessing that‚Äôs it.
You gain gold from kills in each wave (meaning you get some even if you fail the defense) plus some amount from your colonies. This amount can be increased by upgrading the colonies by investing in some gold. You even generate some of this gold when you are not playing. You will also get the option to watch an ad to get some gold now and then. Gold is used for upgrading your walls, archers, towers and units. The upgrades will occasionally have visual affects too. Units will look better every 4 upgrades and your flimsy fences will turn into actual walls with archers and towers in time.
The other currency, crystals, is acquired after every 10 levels or so, plus by defeating the rebellions in colonies. Crystals are used to buy and upgrade heroes, a type of unit that brings a passive bonus to your army as well as fighting actively on the front line. You also use crystals to upgrade your bank, which in turn improves your gold gain from colonies when you aren‚Äôt playing the game. You can also buy card packs with crystals. These you can use when invading colonies to provide you bonuses. Finally, you can buy mercenaries, which are extra troops you can use in invasions. As you might imagine, you can buy crystals and farming them takes some time (but not too terrible to unlock the most expensive hero to be honest.)
Finally, you gain experience from battles. This is earned by the General, which is basically you. You can level up and distribute skill points to unlock passive and active skills. I‚Äôm not sure if there are ceilings for these bonuses. I believe the cost to increase a skill also increases in time. I have leveled one to 20 and so far haven‚Äôt seen it though.
Each wave is basically a bunch of enemies rushing at your walls, fighting any troops they may encounter on the way. Your archers and towers will attack any enemies in their range but your main fighting force will be the reinforcements you summon. There are several unit types that will attack you and you will use to defend, sort of in a Rock Paper Scissors setup.
Speaking of unit types, there are 4+1+1 in total. 4 are the core units that you can use anywhere: Infantry, anti-cavalry infantry, ranged and cavalry. Then there is the siege unit, which is a battering ram that resembles Age of Empires variants. This is only used by the sieging party, not the defenders. Finally there is the elephant. From what I see this is only for the computer. Oh, and the heroes I mentioned above. I only saw them for our side and I imagine computer do not have them.
Normal waves will only spawn two types of units, one group after the other e.g one ranged, then one infantry, then another ranged‚Ä¶ until the whole wave is cleared. You will have two charges of reinforcements at the start and you can use any of the 4 types, you don‚Äôt need to choose a layout. This will come handy in every 10 levels where there will be bigger groups of enemies in sort of mini waves, and their unit types will also change within a single wave. Every 30 levels you will face elephants that are loaded with hp and offensive power. Luckily, you aren‚Äôt limited to the two types of units at the start: As soon as you summon a unit, the bar will start filling and you‚Äôll be able to summon more during the fight.
In addition to summoning troops, you have a few active powers you can use. These are your defenses (catapult and towers) and your general powers (e.g. raining arrows on enemies.) Some are skill shots (like the catapult) and others just work (like the general power that gives a damage boost.) You can also choose the ammunition type of your towers to be more effective versus troops or siege units.
The second part of the game is the colony map where you invade colonies, upgrade them and defend them against rebels. There are several colonies with increasing defense strengths, indicated by numbers on them. You can have 3 legions in each attack, which have 6 unit slots each. My legion consists of 4 main units, my hero and the siege unit. I believe the rest is to add mercenaries and maybe probably other heroes as well. Not much to do here as you don‚Äôt summon extra units and have no towers. You just use your general powers. The enemy has some troops at the start and gets reinforcements, so usually you‚Äôll use them on cooldown to win as soon as possible. Once you take over, you can upgrade them a few times to increase the income, then fight the rebel waves whenever you want. This is basically a reverse invasion: the strength of base depends on the colony and the whole army attacks altogether.
The game shop is pretty simple. You can buy crystals, which you can use to buy commanders and card packs. If you just want to unlock the heroes, the crystal package around 20‚Ç¨ is enough (Germany IOS store) and a more pragmatic approach might be to buy less crystals and only get the Roman Commander (the most expensive one,) or maybe buy the same amount of crystals and just use the surplus to upgrade him a bunch. For the record, you don‚Äôt need this hero. The one you get through the campaign is pretty good and has a gold bonus that should be useful for a new account.
In the end, it‚Äôs nice that the game does not force you buy anything. But then again, I usually buy something from free games if I spent some time on it‚Ä¶ but I really didn‚Äôt feel like buying anything.
All in all, I did sink some hours into the game in the last days. But it was also because I was sick and resting at home. I feel like I‚Äôll depart ways as I don‚Äôt think there is more to see in this game. It doesn‚Äôt feel challenging, there isn‚Äôt much to see other than a couple soldier models and the grind is way too steep.
That said, if you are looking for something to play on the train or you know, the sacred part of the house, feel free to take a look. I did enjoy majority of the time I sank.
Before I end the article, there is another topic I want to talk about.
Now, checking the downloads and review counts, I notice that GER is way bigger than Grow Castle but since I played Grow Castle first, I want to compare them a bit.
The major difference is that GrowCastle uses the auto fight mechanic. You get some of it via playing and you can purchase it if you want: Basically the game will launch waves on its own and will use skills on cooldown. Sounds weird, but it actually works because in the end, the game is super repetitive and you basically play because of three reasons: Leaderboards, to unlock everything to see how they work (that‚Äôs me) and either lack of or surplus of will power to unlock everything and max them out. For the second, you only need a certain amount of grind and you want to be done with them. The other two makes you grind A LOT. So you want the result but without the effort‚Ä¶ because the effort is really just starting waves after a while, then upgrading something every 5‚Äì10 waves or so. It‚Äôs not skill, it‚Äôs monkey work (no offense to tablet using chimps.)
I really, really expected this to appear in GER because the core loops of the two games are literally the same. But it didn‚Äôt appear and honestly, I‚Äôm a bit disappointed. I would love to see the final forms of the soldiers but I don‚Äôt know if I want to endure through the grind.
Despite GER being the bigger title, I think Grow Castle was more interesting in terms of content. There are many heroes and tower types to choose from and you can actually have builds in that game. Unfortunately, it looked to me like in GER you can just upgrade the main soldiers (which are out of the Rock Paper Scissors ‚Äî they have no advantages or disadvantages) and summon them and only them and succeed. The comments I‚Äôve read online also indicate that way.
So if you liked GER, I would strongly recommend to check out Grow Castle too. In fact, I would recommend it over GER, unless you are here for the theme.

Title: The Best Bite of Rome
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
We sat on the edge of high seats, resting elbows and ales on a wine barrel that had been fashioned into a table. Pigeons cooed on the cobblestones around our feet, foraging for crumbs and shards of cracker crisp crust that rained to the ground as we bit into our sandwiches. I had to hunch over parted legs to keep from covering myself in falling arugula and dripping olive oil as I ate. Mike leaned similarly across from me, his sandwich partially exposed but still neatly cradled in its parchment wrapping, a wad of napkins clutched in his right hand to wipe the corners of his mouth as he sipped and chewed. Over his shoulder I watched my romanticized vision of Rome play like a scrolling vignette, fairytale pictures unfurling from the pages of a luxury travel magazine.
Families and tourists wandered the narrow side street like a driven flock, progressing from the Tiber River on to the Spanish Steps awaiting them at the end of the cobblestone shoot. Heads swiveled and eyes swept in every direction, not a single explorer mindful of the path directly in front of them. Each was lost in their own sense of wonder. I followed the gaze of a little girl in a flowery yellow sundress. She wore a pink hoodie to keep her warm against the early spring breeze and her mother tugged her along by the hand. As she traipsed her attention remained fixed on a large three dimensional cone jutting out above the door of an artisan gelato shop. A huge scoop of pistachio gelato perched so perfectly on the plastic waffle that I imagined it dripping onto her outstretched tongue as she passed underneath.
A young bride-to-be led a parade of attendants from a corner flower stall. They wound their way around and through the creeping throng of tourists. Each had their hands full with a flat of matching centerpiece arrangements. Porcelain white lilies with long slender stalks of green, perfectly positioned and pinned, peaking out of vases the way only an artist could do. The florist, minding brilliant pops of crimson, fuchsia and marigold under a vast white umbrella, beamed with a contented smile as she watched her artistry depart. She was roused from her prideful stare by a lovestruck gentleman wishing to purchase a bouquet. I adored this about Rome, the prevalence of corner flower stalls. These oases struck wild contradiction to the bustling chaos; a fragrant reminder to temper progress with love and frivolity.
Rome was all this way. Everyday life coexisting effortlessly with the fray of visitors. Housewives with canvas bags of fruit and loaves of bread. Delivery drivers beeping and weaving their scooters through seas of pedestrian traffic, indifferent to potential catastrophe. Shopkeepers wandered out of their stores to chat and smoke cigarettes with their neighbors. Fashionable couples walked dogs and tenants added to growing piles of refuse spilling out of already overfilled dumpsters. The sounds of suitcases rolling and clacking over ancient pavers mixing with the patter of peddlers. It was a symphony. I was in love with Rome‚Äôs nuanced perfection. But no moment brought me more joy than this ‚Äî our simple picnic perched outside of IL Salumaio, immersed in it all.
I‚Äôd wanted one experience in Rome: an authentic Italian sandwich made with hand shaved artisan charcuterie, layered on rustic bread with fresh cheeses and fragrant oil. I craved the experience I‚Äôd witnessed TV chefs and travel vloggers drool over time and time again. I wanted to have my own moment. A first satisfying bite that would send my eyes rolling back in my head with gastronomic euphoria. Mike was eager for pizza but Rome to me had to be this consummate sandwich picked up at an authentic corner shop. It had to be a genuine place, a place locals might go themselves for lunch. I wanted the staff to be a little indignant at our brass to invade their native sanctuary with our travel maps and attempts at broken Italian. I‚Äôd been swooning over the fruition of this sandwich months before my first airport margarita.
And I was nervous. I did not want to waste my opportunity on an imitation or weak trattoria contender. How were we to choose? I‚Äôd researched so many possibilities that I was dizzy with worry. What if we got it wrong and my vision of Rome shattered, leaving me with rancid memories of crowded lineups and the unending wail of emergency vehicle sirens? The stakes were high. This was our last day in Rome, we‚Äôd almost used up our half dozen dining opportunities in the city before departing for Sorrento. Until the hunger rumbling in my belly grew louder than the nagging for success I was dangerously close to overthinking the whole thing and missing out on my quintessential sandwich experience entirely.
We were on route to the Spanish Steps, having spent the early part of the day touring the Vatican Museum. It was well past midday and I was growing cranky, I fully admit it. My morning cornetto and cappuccino wore off somewhere between the Sistine Chapel and St. Angelo Bridge and hunger was gaining control of my good mood and cheerful disposition. Mike and I have been married long enough to recognize when we‚Äôve met the point of perturbation that requires one of us to maturely recognize the importance of food. He reeled me in, ‚Äúlet‚Äôs eat.‚Äù and I was fully on board. I no longer cared as much about the authenticity of the trattoria we would find, as I did the necessity to get the thing done and put some food in my belly.
Hunger is under-appreciated by the traveler. We tend so easily to keep full, to graze endlessly and maintain a constantly satiated state. Trying bits of this and that and endeavoring to consume memories with the same fervor we use to fill camera phones. Not often do we allow our bellies to rumble and tell us we‚Äôre low on fuel. But hunger, the small h kind with light pangs and hankerings, the kind that clouds your good humor and makes you snap with insincerity can be a good thing. That kind of hunger spurs creativity and shuts up the food critic who, back home, keeps grape jelly away from corn chips. It makes us fall for gas station hotdogs and lures us to try regional oddities, offal stew and platters of whole sardines grilled with lemon and paprika. Hunger can be a blessing to a food experience traveler. Sometimes it‚Äôs the only thing that gets us out of our own head and opens us up to chance encounters. Hunger, on this day, in its wisdom, turned us left and forced us across the threshold of the first shop we could locate with meats and cheeses hanging in the window.
Inside Il Salumaio the wall displayed a dozen menu offerings, a curated list of combinations customers could order with ease. No sandwich had more than five or six quality components, and every ingredient in its own right sounded downright delicious. Glass cases were filled with cured meats and ripe cheeses. Prosciuttos and aging coppas hung overhead. The smell of fresh bread wafted from behind saloon doors and the resulting large flat sheets of rustic loaves were piled on the counter waiting to be portioned and sliced open. Bowls of sun ripened pomodoro and fresh mozzarella di bufala, marinated artichokes and basil crowded one end of the display case. Bottles of olive oil, truffle oils and an array of balsamics lined a shelf behind the counter. The hinges of my jaw twinged and tingled. I wanted so badly to touch and smell everything, I wanted to devour a chisel of gritty parmesan and secure a handful of olives to stuff in my pocket for later.
I halted my rumbling instead with an offering of whisper thin pistachio studded mortadella piled with wedges of Grana Padano, honey infused truffle oil and a large handful of arugula. Mike opted for the Italiano, a simple combination of prosciutto crudo, mozzarella di bufalo, tomato and basil. And there we sat, out there in the street with the pigeons, taking it all in. Swapping our choices halfway through as we often do. Enjoying the simplest of meals curated by chance and living fully in the moment that will forever encapsulate the memory of Rome for me. That sandwich made it all real. It fixed the impression of Rome to my spirit for eternity and I‚Äôll be forever grateful to hunger and serendipity for this moment.
Back home from time to time, I make large flattish loaves of ciabatta and pile them with the best Italian cured meats I can acquire. It costs a fortune compared to the few euros a hand held lunch with pigeons cost us in Rome but with the best company and a lovely smattering of quality olive oil I can almost smell the orange trees and the Tiber River. I add wedges of parm and ripe tomato, handfuls of arugula and metered doses of the truffle oil we brought home in our suitcase cocooned inside a clean pair of socks. We sit in near silence together, quietly reliving memories. I think of cobblestones and a little girl in a yellow flowered sundress. I crave gelato and run my mind over the smoothly worn treads of the Spanish Steps. Mike tosses coins into Trevi fountain and we circle the trek around the Coliseum. We partake in an evening passeggiata and visit the Pantheon at dusk, but I always come back to that moment on Via Della Croce when my eyes rolled back in my head, fully involved in that first magical bite of Italy.
This is the joy of traveling for me. Losing myself in unplanned encounters, tying my memories to meals I attempt to recreate at home. I owe so much of my joy to moments of hunger and its gentle reminder that letting go is part of the experience. A part that very often leads to the greatest discoveries and experiencing the true authenticity of a place. A reminder that the pleasure of something as mundane as a sandwich should never be overlooked. The whole of a culture could be hiding in just one bite.

Never far from a pen or a passion to share. I write about food and travel, personal development and family. Poetry always finds me.

Me, Chelsey, and Jahan ‚Äî a proper girl group ‚Äî hopped off the plane at Fiumicino. This was my first trip to a non English speaking country. I was a struggling actress, fretting over if my hair was too blonde and how I was coming across on camera. Meanwhile, in the background, something exciting was happening. It just didn‚Äôt know it yet.
We took a cab into the city (90 euros ‚Äî which means we got majorly ripped off. This often happens to Americans. Offer 60 Euros and no more!) and arrived at a breathtaking piazza in Trastevere.
There were kids throwing glow circles into the air, there was live music, and hundreds of Romans and tourists alike were dining on the patios of the surrounding restaurants. The piazza was complete with a fountain and an ancient church‚Äî the pious statues looking down on the raucous social center with irony. We later found out it was the oldest church in Rome. This would be our home.
Our building in the piazza had a large front window where I‚Äôd often sit and stare down in the evening. I was very far from Ohio!

Earlier in 2023, I thought of fulfilling my wanderlust and taking off on a solo trip in Europe ‚Äî something my younger self wouldn‚Äôt have even dreamed of.
In my attempt to live in the present (coupled with my habit of tardily posting photos), I felt it was important to journal my experiences to capture my raw thoughts and feelings while I travel.
I‚Äôm glad I wrote them as it took me months to finally get around to sharing my travel stories, but here we go.
1/X: Barcelona, Spain || June 2023
Rome, Italy || July 2023
The day this photo was taken was the day I just did more sight-seeing: revisiting the Trevi Fountain, exploring the Spanish Steps and going around Piazza di Spagna, and marveling at the Pantheon.
I was grateful I didn‚Äôt have to take a long time in these places because the reality was that I was feeling anxious, looking for a repair shop that could service an American model of my luggage just a day before I depart for Firenze.
I knew and I‚Äôve been warned it was not the wisest idea to travel by myself to my hand-picked destinations with a big luggage in tow. I still did it anyway, thinking I could somehow have a semblance of home and comfort packed in a suitcase.
That time, I was only a week away from home, but boy, did I feel the most alone.
Traveling is definitely fun, but what we don‚Äôt see in photos is how it could invoke some feelings of anxiety too.
I eventually found myself capping the night at Trastevere.
I‚Äôm glad I made it well that day. As usual, thanks to the people providing care and support in person and virtually, and for that night, for that rich plate of truffle pasta and a glass of wine to comfort me.
I leave Roma today to transfer to Firenze.
This city captivated me ‚Äî maybe made me fall in love ‚Äî during last year‚Äôs visit with my family; it‚Äôs one of the main reasons why I wanted to return to Italy.
But today I recognize how life continues to surprise us ‚Äî
like that time I walked through the ruins of the Colosseo and be reminded that I used to wonder about it when I was a child but never deeply dreamed of it because I thought it was impossible to see,
but also I have those times when I‚Äôve been working towards a dream, a desire, and then realizing it may not necessarily be what I want or need.
So here‚Äôs a little (self-)reminder: I hope that when things aren‚Äôt going how you think they‚Äôre supposed to be, open up yourself to the opportunity, and trust that life will continue to surprise you.

Dear friend,
I‚Äôm holding a glass of Aperol spritz, and this is the view in front of me. It‚Äôs a hot April afternoon in Rome, about 25 degrees. I‚Äôm wearing my black dress, feeling the Roman elegance. A slight breeze touches my face.
On the way here, we climbed a hill. There were many people around in their stylish outfits-tourists and Italians. We ascended numerous stairs that seemed to stretch up to the sky. The stairs were made of stone and they were old, like everything in Rome.
After climbing so many stairs, we entered a garden filled with tall trees. There were no tourists here, only Romans. I guess this is one of Rome‚Äôs hidden treasures. I only hear Italian being spoken, no other languages.
It‚Äôs hot, and the sun is shining directly on my face. I take a sip of my Aperol spritz and feel better. It has ice in it. I take a piece of ice into my mouth and let it cool me down.
The view is spectacular. It takes my breath away. There are so many beautiful buildings in front of me. It feels like sitting in a park with a large balcony in the middle of Rome, admiring the city. Rome knows how to melt your heart; you just have to let it. It is so beautiful, maybe the most beautiful city in the world, at least for me up to now.
There is a big church on my left and a few more on the horizon. Far away, you can see trees blending into the cityscape. The street below curves to the right, with many cars passing by. I take out my sketchbook and start to draw.
Valentine is sitting next to me. I love him a lot, and I‚Äôm happy we‚Äôre here together. Now he is talking to me about his girlfriend. I like that we‚Äôre so open with each other.
Too bad, I finished my drink. The sun is shining intensely, and there are two boys next to us. One of them is shirtless. He reminds me of a character from ‚ÄúCall Me by Your Name.‚Äù He looks very young and has a beautiful body like the sculptures in Rome. They‚Äôre smoking weed; I can smell it from here.
People around me are speaking Italian. I don‚Äôt understand it, but I like it. I think if I were Roman, I would come to this place a lot. And if you were visiting me, I would bring you here.
I know you would like to write your diary here or read your book, maybe Fernando Pessoa‚Äôs poems. This place feels like a little escape from the chaos of the city, a spot to sit, relax, and savor Rome.
The place is called Villa Aldobrandini, with the stairs located on Via Mazzarino. I really think you should visit this park. I painted the view for you to find it easily. There is a part of me there, you should visit that place.
Love,
Me

Content:

I found this today:
# hosts# Generate standard hosts tables.# Newnet doesn‚Äôt really use it, it‚Äôs just for easy reference.# Neither does oldnet now, since it‚Äôs doing DNS right.#
It lives on line 327 of a Makefile used to build and distribute various configurations around our infrastructure. And it‚Äôs old. ‚ÄúHow old‚Äù, you might ask?
Those lines have been in that file for 19 years. I know that, because I have primary historical evidence, as they say in archaeology.
When I asked about this ‚Äúoldnet‚Äù thing, my boss told me to look up a document, Tenwen: The Re-engineering Of A Computing Environment. It‚Äôs a peer reviewed paper from LISA‚Äô94 that chronicles the creation of the fabric underlying the network that I administer today.
In the paper, under Fixed Name Service (September 1992):
Once name service was working, we modified the Newnet hosts to do hostname lookups correctly.
This fixed the naming problems for Newnet, but Oldnet was still broken. While we wanted to limit the amount of work we put into Oldnet, we also felt that having name service working correctly could only make it easier to administrate Newnet. We therefore modified Oldnet to use the nameserver on Newnet, and quit using host files on Oldnet as well.
So, those lines date to September, 1992. I was 13 years old.
One time, a couple of weeks after I started working here, one of the other admins asked me what I thought of all of it. The infrastructure, the network, and so on. It took a couple of seconds for me to put my thoughts together, and I said, ‚ÄúHave you ever been to Rome?‚Äù
He had, so I continued, ‚ÄúThis network is Rome‚Äù.
He was confused, understandably, so I explained.
Some networks are like Phoenix, AZ. They‚Äôre relatively new and shiny. They‚Äôre brought up for the purpose they serve, and for the time in which they exist. There‚Äôs not a building in Phoenix over 125 years old. It was built according to relatively modern methods, and the streets are largely laid out in a grid, because there wasn‚Äôt a whole lot to get in their way. The city was started from essentially a clean slate.
Some networks, particularly in non-technological companies, are much more like Ephesus in Turkey. Ephesus is amazing‚Ä¶it‚Äôs kind of like a metropolis the size of Orlando just got up and left. Seriously, I was there, and it was mind-boggling. It‚Äôs almost exactly like it was 1500 years ago. There has been no modern development there, so when you walk through it, you‚Äôre in the midst of miles of ruins.
Rome, on the other hand, is a different sort of beast. Romulus founded the City of Seven Hills 2,500 years old, if you believe the legends, and it has been occupied for pretty much the entire time since. When you climb out of an underground Metro station full of artifacts excavated while digging the subway tunnels you just left, you may find yourself facing an Roman gladiatorial arena turned into a Catholic church. The modern Rome grew up out of the old, and there‚Äôs a continual architectural history of the past 2500 years waiting on you to find it.
It‚Äôs the exact same way here on this network. The new Windows desktop infrastructure runs smoothly alongside the host database mentioned in the paper above, written 20 years ago. It relies on the host database, actually. Like Rome‚Äôs streets, sewer, viaducts, and aquaducts, these antique systems were vital to the time, and if they aren‚Äôt still in use, they paved the way for the modern systems that replaced them.
Being someone who likes archaeology, antiquities, and old libraries and junk stores, working here is a pleasure, because there‚Äôs always something new to discover, and like I did today, a rich history behind it.

Title: How to Find Rome‚Äôs Hidden Magic
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
7
Listen
Share
Everywhere I turned in Rome, there were overwhelmingly inspiring sights, but they were overrun by tourists, myself included. All week, I purposely was getting off the beaten path, scouring the city for places away from the tourist crowds. I find it hard to fully enjoy Rome with the constant crush of tourists everywhere I turn.
This Sunday, however, dawned differently. A strange quiet settled over the city. No honking horns, no chattering crowds, just the gentle gurgling of the Tiber River as I walked along its banks. I‚Äôd gotten up much earlier than usual, setting out on a walk from my Vatican City apartment to Trastevere, a charming neighbourhood in Rome.
The river‚Äôs curvy ribbon unfolded before me, its surface a polished mirror reflecting the soft glow of the awakening sun. Crossing the Ponte Vittorio Emanuele II, a bridge of pale stone and impressive arches, I paused to admire the view. Soft pastel colours, like scoops of gelato, washed over the city ‚Äî a sea of terracotta rooftops dotted with church domes. Rome is a scene straight out of a postcard.
I relish the quietness of the city, broken only by the rhythmic pounding of lone runners and the occasional flash of brightly coloured bikes zipping past me. Sticking to the eastern side of the river, I watched the city slowly stir to life.
Reaching Ponte Garibaldi, I took in the panorama again. This vantage point revealed how far I‚Äôd wandered, with St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica‚Äôs dome just a distant peak. In front of me, a tiny emerald oasis emerged from the river ‚Äî Tiber Island. A bright orange building, like a giant creamsicle, stood at its tip. (This is the hospital, by the way!)
Two bridges connect Tiber Island. Ponte Fabricio, the oldest bridge in Rome, stood strong with its thick stone arches from 62 BC. Beside it, Ponte Cestio is adorned with three graceful arches. Crossing over, I am greeted by the tourist-favourite Trastevere neighbourhood.
Trastevere was just waking up. Street cleaners swept away the remnants of Saturday night‚Äôs partying. Trucks rumbled by, collecting overflowing bins. Storefronts remained shuttered, and chairs and tables stacked high are starting to be dismantled setting up for Sunday lunch. It‚Äôs a neighbourhood waking and preparing for a new day‚Äôs performance.
Wandering through Trastevere‚Äôs narrow streets, I admired its unique beauty. Peeling paint, colourful graffiti, overflowing flower boxes, ivy climbing the walls, and laundry strung cheerfully across the balconies ‚Äî even the ‚Äúrundown‚Äù parts held a charm.
Reaching the tall stone archway, Porta Portese, I entered the famed Sunday flea market. But the peaceful bliss of my morning walk vanished instantly. Chaos engulfed me ‚Äî shouts, haggling, and mountains of stuff piled everywhere. It was a stark contrast to the serenity I‚Äôd enjoyed just hours earlier.
Later that day, nestled in a cozy Trastevere trattoria buzzing with Sunday family lunch, I savoured my delicious cacio e pepe. The quiet morning walk solidified a travel revelation for me: waking up early unlocks a hidden side of the city.
For anyone who truly wants to experience a place, especially one as busy as Rome, consider rising with the sun. Early mornings offer a rare moment of tranquillity, allowing for a deeper connection to a city.
Even if you‚Äôre not a morning person, dedicate one day on your trip to this slow travel approach. You might be surprised by the magic you discover in the quietness of the city.

Enhance your European travel adventures and download my ‚Äú15 Practical Tips to Slow Travel‚Äù.

Content:

‚ÄúTake the first steps in faith. You do not have to see the whole staircase.‚Äù Martin Luther King Jr.
The Spanish Steps are one of the most recognizable places in the Eternal City. This place became popular long before the advent of mass tourism. At the beginning of the 16th century, the first hotels were built here, and in the 17th century, Spain acquired the Monaldeschi Palace and turned the building into an embassy. From that moment on, the square began to be called Spanish.
The stairs were paid for by a French diplomat, √âtienne Gueffier, who thought it would be a great idea to connect The Spanish Square Piazza di Spagna to the French Santissima Trinita dei Monti church as a symbol of unity between Spain and France.
Did you ever count the steps by running up and down the stairs? I counted 270 steps during my round trip from the street level to the top and back ‚Äî until a local policeman, carabinieri, tried to stop me.
They could not catch up and yelled at me not to run up the stairs. I giggled like a schoolgirl caught running by a principal.
As I ran the stairs, I remembered Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck sitting together on the Spanish Steps in their movie Roman Holiday. Watching Hollywood movies was how I learned European geography as a little girl.

Do you ever get the spooky feeling that the world at large is reacting to your personal choices? Not too long ago I finished reading Mary Beard‚Äôs SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome for the first time, and no sooner had I put the book down than it came to my attention that a brand new Nero exhibition was opening at the British Museum and a new TV drama centered on the life of Livia Drusilla was being released. I know the universe isn‚Äôt actually stalking me Truman Show style, but the timing couldn‚Äôt have been more perfect. Both the exhibition and the TV show relate to important takeaways I had from Mary Beard‚Äôs book: that Ancient Roman history is far from set in stone and we should check our assumptions about it.
The popular image of Nero is one of a decadent, greedy, matricidal tyrant. We all know him as the bloke that ‚Äúfiddled while Rome burned‚Äù. Whenever I acted like a spoiled brat as a teenager, my dad would call me Nero. He‚Äôs practically a byword for hedonism. Even if you‚Äôre not familiar with Roman history, you know what it means when his name gets invoked. Title: Rome is Liberated by Allies
Content:
Sign up

Flo is one of the first to enter the city after Nazis retreat
My mother and Audie Murphy ch. 15
The city of Rome was liberated by Allied troops June 4, 1944. Flo got to Rome the next day, June 5. She told me she was proud to come into the city with General Mark Clark and the U.S. 5th Army. The Third Division had taken big hits in battles at Anzio and on the Italian coast. Rome would be an easy victory, a source of prestige for the leaders and pride for infantrymen recovering from those battles. Later, historians and Allied commanders agreed that Clark‚Äôs decision to march into Rome instead of cutting off a large part of the retreating German army was a major blunder, extending the war for maybe another year. In any case, the liberation of Rome was overshadowed by the D-Day landings on the beaches of Normandy in northern France on June 6.
Flo kept detailed notes in a tiny pocket-sized diary. This was the first entry.
Monday June 5, 1944
Came into Rome in amphib Jeep with Frank Gates.
They were traveling from the camp at Pozzuoli, a seaside town on the Gulf of Naples where they‚Äôd been bivouacked with the Third Division. At first I imagined that they drove the 138 miles on the bombed out rutted roads. But these amphibious jeeps were faster in the water than on land, so now I‚Äôm thinking they traveled on the water. Amphib jeeps were used by the Third Division because they were training for an amphibious landing in France that would take place in August.
Flo didn‚Äôt make note of who was with her and Frank Gates, but I‚Äôm imagining all four of the American Red Cross women in her group went to Rome together. Gates was able to secure a promise from a rich anti-Nazi Roman to allow the ARC clubmobilers to stay in his fancy villa. The four women moved in soon after. The man did much to make them comfortable.
I wasn‚Äôt able to find information about Frank Gates but I believe he was Flo‚Äôs boss, the Red Cross director on the Italian front whose job was to establish ARC canteens and clubs near the front lines of fighting. He would be driving around Rome to look for suitable buildings in which to house the clubs.
Unlike Naples, which had been bombed for years, Rome had been spared from widespread destruction by the Nazis in part due to its declaration as an ‚Äúopen city‚Äù by the Italian government and the efforts of the Vatican to protect it, which led to a relatively peaceful occupation and liberation. No one, perhaps not even the Nazis, wanted to be responsible for destroying that historic city.
The 1945 Italian film Rome, Open City, directed by Roberto Rossellini, takes place during the Nazi occupation of Rome. It was one of the first post-war Italian films to gain major acclaim internationally.
The ARC women were some of the first Americans to move into Rome. Before Allied troops started coming in, they had the city almost to themselves and set about seeing all the tourist sights. Flo wanted to see all the famous architectural treasures she had read about as a child.
From a report in the Yakima Herald-Republic:
Life in the Italian theatre of war can be fun as well as hard work for American Red Cross workers, Miss Florence Wick told her mother, Mrs. Gerda Wick of Yakima, in a recent letter.
‚ÄúSo much and so many exciting things have happened since I left home that I can‚Äôt believe any of it yet,‚Äù Miss Wick said. ‚ÄúThis last event is the biggest dream yet. I am writing this in my new home, which is a beautiful, spacious Italian villa. We four girls moved in yesterday from our dusty camp down the road and have the whole villa and grounds to ourselves.
‚ÄúThere is a bathroom and bedroom for each of us and we truly live like princesses in a fairy tale. The villa belongs to a very wealthy Italian, who is an anti-fascist, who lost his whole family to the Germans. He loves to do favors for us.‚Äù
High praise for Capt. Harold Haines of Yakima was voiced by the Red Cross woman.
‚ÄúCapt. Haines is something of a hero over here,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúFighting in a war does things like ‚Äòknocking off‚Äô officers and men, but Haines is one of the very few original officers left. Yakima should be very proud of him. His own men are and that‚Äôs the acid test out here.‚Äù
The nice weather makes it even more pleasant to drive around the various areas to serve the men, Miss Wick said. Because the unit is not yet equipped to turn out doughnuts for all the men, she has had time to visit interesting places she has read about but never expected to see. Mt. Vesuvius and the ancient city of Pompeii are among the sights she has seen.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how long we will be in this beautiful place,‚Äù Miss Wick said, ‚Äúbut we are going to enjoy it as long as we do stay. No doubt we will be roughing it again in a tent or bombed out building before long. I won‚Äôt mind that if I get to stay with this grand division.‚Äù
The ARC women didn‚Äôt stay in the villa in Rome very long. By July 9 Flo is back in the camp, writing in her diary about cleaning their tent.
Ch. 16: https://tradeswomn.medium.com/foot-soldiers-in-rome-99fe43552bb6

I‚Äôm a long-time tradeswoman activist and retired electrician/electrical inspector in Santa Rosa CA.

Title: Rome Autopsy Lesson
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I posted a picture on twitter yesterday from one of my World History lessons where students perform an ‚Äúautopsy‚Äù on the Roman Empire that garnered some attention.
A number of teachers asked for details of the lesson, so rather than try and explain it out in 140 characters several times to several different people, I just decided to put my write up here.
First: Obviously the medical gear is not required for the lesson. But I will say, if you‚Äôre willing to drop about $35 per class, it actually made a difference. This was the first year I added that piece to the lesson (based on student requests from last year), and it definitely played a role in helping get ‚Äúin character‚Äù for performing an autopsy.
The major objective of the lesson is to have students demonstrate the ability to evaluate multiple historical perspectives on why the Roman Empire collapsed and form their own interpretation on why Rome fell based on the available evidence.
This could easily be accomplished without an autopsy ‚Äî I could hand them sources and treat it as a document analysis assignment. But I was looking for something that was a little out in left field (those are the things that stick, right?) and required group collaboration to help vocalize the thought processes necessary for good historical analysis.
Lesson Origins
I will not take credit for this lesson idea. This is a common lesson shared among AP World History teachers. In the original form that I saw, students were asked to conduct autopsies on the ‚ÄúGunpowder Empires‚Äù (Safavid, Mughal, Ottoman Empires). Some teachers also did it for classical empires (like Rome and Han China). So if you like the concept but not my execution, please go look at other iterations of the lesson. You can just google search ‚ÄúAP World Empire Autopsy‚Äù and see tons of examples.
I decided to narrow it down to just Rome because I wanted to have follow up conversations about the collapse of Rome based on their competing interpretations. I usually give student groups at least some unique historical arguments to help produce different results. So I wanted a more in depth approach to Rome versus the broad based comparative option with the original lesson.
I also wanted a lesson I could use in either my regular or AP sections of World History. I‚Äôm really big on the idea that both classes should emphasize the same skills and concepts, and that the only difference is the level of rigor. I don‚Äôt want the idea of developing historical thinking skills to be reserved for just one subset of my students.
Materials Used
Set Up Lecture
I walk them through the chronology of Rome‚Äôs collapse. As I explain it to the students, I‚Äôm going to establish time of death, they‚Äôre going to establish what killed Rome. So we go over the Crisis of the Third Century, Diocletian, Constantine, the East/West split, all the way to the final fall of Rome in 476. We cover the increased use of Germanic troops in the Roman army a little bit, because otherwise Odoacer does not make much sense to the students.
Initial Interpretation Analysis
I have a word document that has summaries of many of the theories for Rome‚Äôs collapse compiled together. I made it so there are even page breaks ‚Äî no summary goes over one page. Some pages may have 2 or 3 different theories if they have shorter explanations. Each student in the group is expected to look at 1‚Äì2 pages and take notes on the main arguments.
A couple group members will need to head out into the hallway or some other space to trace the body outlines on the paper. When they‚Äôre done they come back in and read over some of the interpretations. What I usually do to distribute the work load is have the folks that stay in the room the whole time read 2 pages, and the folks that went out into the hall read 1.
Group Discussion and List Building
After they‚Äôve had time to read through and make their observations, have them come together as a group and share what they found. I put the list of what body parts these ‚Äúinjuries‚Äù would correspond to:
I encourage students to get creative on the type of injury that they are identifying. Is it a minor issue? Maybe that‚Äôs a bruise. Major issue? Broken bone. Don‚Äôt give the students too much guidance because they get pretty creative on their own. For example, a group identified a shutdown of intestine functions to represent sharp decline in farm output in the empire.
Give them a few minutes to have this conversation, and then it is time to conduct the autopsy.
The ‚ÄúAutopsy‚Äù
The students lay their body outline down on the tables and begin marking it up with corresponding injuries. I show them that on most autopsy reports, they simply circle the site of the injury and then write commentary on what the injury is. That is what I expect for them on theirs, although some like to draw in the actual injury (so students draw broken bones, or one group drew kidneys that were a gross brown to represent kidney failure) and I‚Äôm fine with that.
The students have laptops that can flip into tablets, so many of them had their notes up on a google doc that they used for reference while they marked up the body.
Students are still deliberating about where to place injuries at this point ‚Äî and that is totally okay. I try to be active around the room and interject into conversations either to validate their observation OR to encourage them to think of some different angles (e.g. for example, a group mentioned Constantine in reference to the rise of Christianity, because some historical interpretations argue Christianity contributed to the downfall of Rome. I pressed them to think about how Constantine may have contributed to a spinal injury ‚Ä¶ and they looked back and made the connection to him ending Diocletian‚Äôs tetrarchy).
As they wind down marking up the body, students have to pull up their shared google doc with the autopsy report and mark down what injuries they noted on the body (I have them do this step because they will often slim down or modify the list from what they originally developed as they‚Äôre actually mapping the injuries out on the body).
Conclusion
Once they are done, they take off the gear and turn in their body maps. They then sit down as a group and finish the google doc. Under the Opinion section, they need to develop a thorough analysis of cause of death. I usually specify the following requirements:
This is the most challenging part, but it is well worth the student results. They are engaging in a critically important historical skill, and rather than just memorizing a list of reasons why Rome ended, they‚Äôre actually being challenged to answer the question themselves.
I have about 60 minutes for this activity. Usually students start formulating their conclusion but need time the next day to finish. I use this as a pivot to discuss the next day and then introduce the Byzantines.

Title: two more days in Italy: Rome and Milan
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
I traveled through Europe, and I‚Äôve been home a month now. Contrary to what I‚Äôd expected, my time away only made me more acutely aware of just how beautiful it is here‚Ä¶ this little piece of California, where I grew up.
Not that the things I saw in Europe were any less beautiful. No; there, I saw things I could never have imagined, things that took my breath away with their utter unexpectedness and newness (oldness, really, but all new to me). But I think I‚Äôve come back with a kinder, more appreciative eye. I got in the habit, while traveling, of perceiving the wonder in everything; now, when I look around the place where I grew up, I‚Äôm pausing more to reflect, to capture memories as if with a camera, and not forget.
Here, at home, the hills are a deep green this time of year; we‚Äôre starting to get a few of those summery days that are just barely too hot, but then perfect all evening long; children are riding their bicycles in the street and laughing like they can feel the school year coming to its end. The other day, I walked by a big Mexican bush sage, and the smell brought back a thousand memories of childhood, of playing in the backyard with my sisters long after dark, when we had our own bush of that sweet-smelling, lavender-colored plant. And as much as I adored my travels, much as I already can‚Äôt wait to go again someday, and hard as it was to leave, I did miss the context I have here at home: the memories that come with all the smells and sights and tastes. The memories of my life, memories of me.
And the truth, I found, is that one of the things I loved most about the lush greenery, rolling countrysides, and swaying olive trees in Italy was how much it reminded me of home.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
I miss Italy. I missed it as soon as I left it. It‚Äôs in no way very original of me; most people I‚Äôve talked to who have ever visited there say the exact same thing. But there really is just something magnetizing about it to us American folks.
I set up my base in Venice and Florence, but did have the chance to see two other Italian cities ‚Äî only for one day each, mind you, but with the impression they made on me, it only seems fair I give them their own post here. For one day, I saw Rome, and for one day, I saw Milan. Sometime ‚Äî I hope sooner rather than later ‚Äî I‚Äôll go back to Italy, and make it much longer than just two more days.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
I almost didn‚Äôt go to Rome. I had long planned that I would take a day trip from Florence and make the pilgrimage, but found I loved Florence so much that I didn‚Äôt want to spare a moment from it. In the end, I tore myself away and hopped the train ‚Äî because how can you go all the way to Europe and not see Rome? ‚Äî and I‚Äôm so, so glad I did.
Rome is often called the Eternal City, and it is every bit deserving of such a grandiose name. As I walked through the busy downtown, observing the perfect coexistence of ancient ruins, modern buildings, and everything in between, I felt that there really was something eerily eternal about this place. Structures from 2,000 years ago stand as though nothing ever changed, utterly undeterred by the passage of time, the rising and falling of empires and regimes, the growth of a whole new society around them ‚Äî or the nosy wanderings of tourists like me, seeking to get a glimpse into the heart of this place, what so many of us learn is the birthplace of our modern world.
First laying eyes on the Colosseum was surreal. The only thing I can think to compare it to, though obviously I have never had this experience, is that moment that astronauts first see Earth from space: a rush of feelings, mostly it‚Äôs real, and I‚Äôm really seeing this, and we really are so, so small. Because faced with something that‚Äôs survived two millennia, how can you feel any other way?
Of course, thinking of just how many people and animals died horrifically in the Colosseum, all for the entertainment of others, adds a whole other layer to the experience of beholding this long-standing and impressive place. I reflected a lot, while I was there, on our own humanity ‚Äî are we really much better today? We like to think of history as being synonymous with progress, with always getting better, but we are certainly willing to excuse a lot of suffering from our fellow human beings, all in the name of being entertained, aren‚Äôt we?
But then, that‚Äôs another conversation, entirely.
As exciting as it was to see the Colosseum, stumbling upon the Pantheon ‚Äî because stumble is exactly what I did ‚Äî was even more bizarre. While the Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and the Forum all stand somewhat set apart from Rome‚Äôs main city center ‚Äî preserved in their own sort of ancient ‚Äúneighborhood‚Äù ‚Äî the Pantheon is just right there, downtown, surrounded by restaurants, apartments, and businesses of our modern age. You would almost miss it, assume it was a replica or even just an especially pretty building, if you weren‚Äôt looking for it (and I was looking, and still almost walked on by).
If my hometown provides me context for myself, and my own beginnings, Rome gave me some of that for all of us‚Äîfor humanity. Not that we all descended from the Romans, or that our forms of government and society were all influenced by them; rather, being in the Eternal City, seeing this strange marriage of the old and the new, brought me to reflect on ‚Äî despite how young humanity is compared to most of the universe ‚Äî just how long we‚Äôve been here. Surely it‚Äôs been long enough now that there‚Äôs no excuse to still embrace the kind of violence that the Romans loved watching in the Colosseum. I hope that, the longer we stick around, we will keep trying to get better.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
It would be disingenuous of me not to admit the biggest reason I was determined to visit Rome, and it had nothing to do with ancient history. I have wanted to see the city for years because of a certain Romantic poet who spent his last few months, and ultimately died, there.
I was sixteen when I first started reading John Keats. Fascinated at that age by his beautiful yet doomed romance with Fanny Brawne, I upheld a thing of beauty is a joy forever (from his ‚ÄúEndymion‚Äù) as a life motto, and longed to write the way he could. I took a class on English Romanticism in undergrad and felt almost like I was ‚Äúcheating‚Äù on Keats with how much I unexpectedly ended up loving Coleridge‚Äôs work; still, ‚ÄúOde to a Nightingale‚Äù reigned supreme as my favorite poem (it‚Äôs still way up there). And since I discovered him, I‚Äôve been troubled by his tragic early death, but I really could not have predicted how much visiting his museum in Rome was going to affect me.
It‚Äôs called the Keats-Shelley House ‚Äî as it‚Äôs dedicated not just to Keats but to all the Romantic writers, including Percy Bysshe Shelley and Mary Shelley. The rosy-orange house stands, quiet and unassuming, right beside the Spanish Steps. When Keats began to deteriorate, his doctors sent him out of England to take the warmer climate in Rome, hoping that would restore him to health; he moved into this house in late 1820. He was dead in four months. He was 25.
When I first read Keats, at 16 years old, 25 sounded almost old to me. Now, I‚Äôm 25. And God, his life was only starting. Many scholars say that had he lived longer, he would have surpassed Shakespeare as the best and most prolific writer in the English language. He was a baby.
When I visited the museum, I got to see the room where he died. It‚Äôs small, with a fireplace, a desk, a bed, and two little windows, one of which overlooks the Spanish Steps. His illness did not deter him from enjoying the view, and he liked to look out at all the activity below, especially the bubbling clear waters of the square‚Äôs boat fountain (which is still there today). He died of tuberculosis, though his doctors resisted that diagnosis until the very end; and as a result, he was refused ample pain medication, and died suffering, terribly. That was really, really hard to learn, especially while standing in the same room where it all happened. I felt, suddenly, a little sick, and I wanted to cry, but I couldn‚Äôt.
But it isn‚Äôt fair to remember him, or anyone, just for his death. The museum does an excellent job of reminding visitors who Keats and his contemporaries were ‚Äî that, though now they are all gone, they were once full of the gorgeous vibrancy of life, and created beautiful art that will never, ever die.
I learned that, despite the image we have today of a perpetually fragile and delicate Keats, he was a scrappy little guy in school, getting into many a fistfight before he discovered what good outlets reading and writing were. I learned how much he loved his siblings ‚Äî he was the oldest, like me ‚Äî and how much it devastated him when his little brother, Tom, died of tuberculosis at 19 (John had nursed him, as these were, of course, days before it was known to be contagious). I learned that, before he went to Rome to die, he charged his fianc√©e Fanny and his younger sister to always stay in touch, so they would have each other; and I learned that the two women did, and remained best friends for the rest of their long lives. I even saw a lock of his hair, and learned that despite my own vision of John Keats as a brooding brunette, he was, in fact, a towhead blonde.
Hardly anyone left that museum with a dry eye. It‚Äôs not easy subject matter, and they do an incredible job making it all come alive and feel real. But I left feeling hopeful, in a way, because what an incredible thing it is that so many people are still impacted by his story, and his art.
One older Italian woman, who was visiting at the same time as me, kept clutching her chest and rhapsodically saying, ‚Äúoh, me amo Keats, me amo Keats.‚Äù I hope that, somehow, the wonder of the Eternal City allowed him to hear that, and to know how much he means.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Perhaps knowing how reluctant I was to leave Italy, the universe conspired to keep me there an extra day. My plan to visit Bern, the capital of Switzerland, was foiled by weekend rail strikes on ItaliaRail, and I ended up stranded for a night in Milan.
It was quite the stroke of luck, because I absolutely loved Milan. More similar to Berlin than anywhere I visited in Italy, this city was like a hub of art, youth culture, and progressive modernity. I walked to the canal in the late afternoon to soak in the last light; there were young people smoking cigarettes atop brick walls covered in graffiti, and a street market full of vendors selling handmade gifts. I bought a pair of earrings for my sister, then wandered until after dark, trying to savor my last few hours here‚Ä¶ this country I had come to love so much.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Indeed, Italy was somewhere I had always known that I would love, but I guess I couldn‚Äôt have imagined how much. At the Keats-Shelley House, there was a list of American and British artists, writers, and thinkers who, at one point or another, made Rome their home, and it just went on and on. Longfellow, Dickens, Alcott, Browning, Copley, Ruskin. Keats, of course, though I know he must have wished it was under happier circumstances; still, he loved that view of the Spanish Steps, so much.
There‚Äôs just something about you, Italy, that inspires one to create, I think ‚Äî and to make oneself at home. How else would I still be writing about you a month-and-a-half later, still thinking of you when I see my own home‚Äôs green hills, rolling countrysides, and olive trees?
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ROME
Activities: Visit the Colosseum and the Roman Forum (tip: plan ahead! the lines were excruciatingly long, and I didn‚Äôt have time to go in; buy tickets online so you can skip the lines). See the Trevi Fountain (tip: go in the morning, before the crowds arrive, or else you may have trouble even seeing much of that gorgeous, cool, clear water!). Go to the Keats-Shelley House and the Spanish Steps (this museum was so impactful and beautiful, and all in English; and the Spanish Steps are like their own separate world within Rome, just a gorgeous neighborhood).
My Best Meal: I only ate once in Rome, stopping in a little grocery and grabbing a salame and fontina panini. But let me tell you! That was one delicious panini. As with everywhere in Italy, there are a thousand restaurants every where you look and everyone is guaranteed to be amazing; wander off the main tourist tracks to find somewhere more affordable.
MILAN
My Hostel: QUO Milano / Cost: about 25 euros a night / Recommend?: Yes! Great common area, cute decor, nice room (we had our own bathroom, as well), and very affordable. It‚Äôs a tram ride from the train station, but all the main points of interest in the city are walking distance.
Activities: Go see the Milan Cathedral, walk by the canal, look closely at the street art, and talk to people (everyone was so kind in Milan).
My Best Meal: A Sicilian cannoli! One of the best desserts I had the entire trip. Stop into any given bakery as you walk the city, and I promise it will be delicious.
--
--

Content:

by Mark Lamprell
"Let me tell you about Rome, my beloved Roma, so ancient she is called eternal, the city that has always been and will always be. Assured of her own magnificence, her venerable significance, she does not seek comparison - and yet I find it almost impossible not to compare her."
This is the opening of Mark Lamprell‚Äôs The Lovers' Guide to Rome and I fell in love with these words immediately. I was compelled to read them aloud, they have a wonderful lyrical quality to them.
Have you ever been to Rome? The author‚Äôs note says this novel was written outdoors, around the streets and piazzas of Rome and it shows. There is a lovely liveliness and intimacy in the treatment of these locations that took me right back there amongst the stone angels and gelato stands.
This book was given to me with the description that it was a "happy book". As most of my reading material tends toward more UNhappy themes, I thought this might be a nice (and mentally healthy) change.
I was pleasantly surprised. The Lovers' Guide to Rome is a lovely, breezy, sunlit romp through the streets of Roma, as¬†comfortable and cheerful as the best rom-coms, but beautifully written, with descriptions that make you want to read them aloud. I found the cast of characters engaging, with enough about them to be curious about and sympathise with, to make me want to read on.
I zipped through the first half on this on a two hour train journey and it was ideal for the task. Because you shouldn't have to put up with poorly written junk just because you're in the mood for something light!

I was in Rome standing outside St. Peter‚Äôs basilica when a thought crossed my mind: Am I entering a church or a museum? I was perfectly at bliss standing in line to enter one of the most famous architecture in the world. As I wandered through its interior, the more confused I was. Can this be considered as an art gallery? I had musings in my head to fill a notebook.
I had little knowledge about the church. I was astounded to discover it has eight chapels, 24 altars, and about 40 statues. I was bowled over by its grandeur. The moment I looked up, it was hard to look down. Why would you? The hymns and prayers seemed to be coming from above.
Two reasons drew me to the place. One was the movie ‚ÄòDa Vinci Code‚Äô starring Tom Hanks as the lead Robert Langdon; the other was my running away from my problems.
Though I was raised with an amalgamation of Islam, Catholicism, Hindu and Buddhism, the basilicas in Rome offered me comfort that remains inexplicable. They called to me. Maybe it was the beauty of their architecture that drew me to them like a moth to a flame. Some questions are best left unanswered.
All I knew was I had made it to Rome. I was finally at bliss looking up 60 feet towards the‚Ä¶

Title: Bits of advice when traveling to Rome, Berlin and Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Get a good data plan. We used Google Maps to get around EVERYWHERE. So much simpler than asking people for directions. Google Maps tells you which station to walk to, which subway line/bus to board, how long until the next train/bus arrives and how much time it will take you to reach your destination. You can either apply for a local SIM or check with your existing mobile services provider about international roaming plans (we used Airtel, and took their 30-day plan).
Learn how to say ‚Äòplease‚Äô, ‚Äòthank you‚Äô, ‚Äòyou‚Äôre welcome‚Äô, ‚Äòexcuse me‚Äô and ‚Äòsorry‚Äô in the local language. Don‚Äôt bother walking around with a dictionary ‚Äî nobody expects you to master a whole new language. However, people are appreciative of the fact that you can respond in a language they understand ‚Äî especially when you find you have to push your way through a crowd when your train arrives at the stop you need to get off at (‚Äòpardon, pardon, PARDON‚Äô). Once you‚Äôve taught yourself the words, they will roll off your tongue automatically in the appropriate situation because you‚Äôll hear people using them all around you.
Invest in travel passes. All three cities we visited had various options (1-day, 3-day and 7-day passes) that we could use for unlimited trips across different modes of transport including buses, trams, subway and local trains. This makes so much financial sense and saves you the pain of having to buy a ticket for each trip you make. In Rome and Berlin, we had to validate the pass for the first trip after which we just had to make sure we had it with us in case ticket checkers came by. In Paris, we had to validate the ticket each time we entered a subway station/ boarded a bus.
Plan out which attractions/sights are most important to YOU. There are just so many options today. Sure you can get on a bus and do the highlights, but that doesn‚Äôt work for everyone. I desperately wanted to visit the Palace of Versailles and that‚Äôs often not on a typical ‚Äòwhat to see in Paris in 3 days‚Äô list. We also managed to get tickets to a Katy Perry show in Berlin (we booked these about a month and a half before we actually left India!). I would have also loved to do a food tour, but we just didn‚Äôt have the time.
Have a rough idea of the top 3‚Äì4 things you want to do/see/experience well in advance. There are so many advantages to planning ahead. In a lot of cases, you can pre-book entrance tickets and print them out at home to save yourself time and money. This is super critical in cases like visiting the Eiffel Tower. You‚Äôll see tons of ads from private operators charging you the sun, moon and stars for a visit to the second-floor or summit. If you plan ahead (and here I literally mean a month or two ahead), you can pre-book your Eiffel Tower experience for a fraction of the cost AND you can skip the long wait lines. Through this official site, tickets to the second floor (with lift access) cost 16 euros per head ‚Äî that‚Äôs about $18 USD. A quick search for a private-operator led tour on Viator shows that this same experience costs $52. We managed to book afternoon tickets to the second floor (lift access) through the official site and it was totally worth it.
Same thing for our tour of the Colosseum in Rome. I was hell bent on booking the underground tour (with access to the arena floor) because I knew how much G loved ‚ÄòThe Gladiator‚Äô, but the private-operator led tours were outrageously expensive. Then, I stumbled on this helpful post in a forum which led to the Colosseum‚Äôs own booking portal. Again ‚Äî you need to book these well in advance because they sell out super quick but if you‚Äôre lucky (like me) you can book this amazing experience for an super price!
Sign up for a walking tour (or two). We signed up for Sandeman‚Äôs FREE tour of Paris and enjoyed it so much that we signed up for a paid walking tour of the Montmartre neighbourhood the next day. These are often a couple of hours long, so make sure you wear comfortable clothing (preferably layers that you can take off/put on depending on the weather) and very comfortable footwear! Walking tours are simply the best way to see a place, and if you do them early on in your trip, you can decide on which places you may want to come back see in more detail. Plus, they‚Äôre pretty reasonably priced.
Pre-download free audio guide applications and content. Wherever we didn‚Äôt employ the services of a guide, we used Rick Steve‚Äôs free walking tour app on our iPhones. His audio guides are informative and interesting ‚Äî for instance, I discovered (through one of content pieces in the Berlin walking tour guide) that Michael Jackson‚Äôs infamous ‚Äòdangling baby‚Äô incident happened at the balcony of a room at the Hotel Adlon just outside The Brandenburg Gate! The other smart decision we made was downloading all the apps and app content offered by The Palace of Versailles (including audio guides for the Trianons and the Gardens). You actually get an audio guide device with your ticket, but it‚Äôs a tiny recorder like device with no earphones and the apps actually have the same content but in better quality. Also, the audio guide offered with the ticket doesn‚Äôt cover the Trianons and Gardens. Another tip at Versailles? Buy a round trip ticket for the Petit Train. Otherwise, you‚Äôll have to spend an inordinate amount of time walking from the Palace, across the gardens and grounds to the Grand Trianon and then the Petit Trianon.
And perhaps my most important piece of advice:
Choose your travel partner wisely. I‚Äôm incredibly lucky to have found a partner who loves discovering new things (be it food, drinks or experiences) at the same pace as I do. He gives me the lead to do the planning, and I thrive in this role :) And then he surprises me with things like spontaneous tickets to a show at the Moulin Rouge and so much more. So thank you, G, for being the amazing person that you are! Here‚Äôs to more adventures together ‚ù§
Other little bits of advice:
> Figure out the tipping culture ‚Äî carry a few Euros in change for this> Carry a small backpack with your water, an umbrella, sunscreen, your passport (safely tucked away), and some money (our credit cards worked everywhere) aside from other essentials (charger, tissues etc). Your bag will be screened at most attractions, so don‚Äôt carry too many electronics or too large a bag> Watch out for street vendors/hawkers trying to get you buy stuff by catching you off guard (like by giving you a high-five and shoving something into your hand)> Not every touristy thing is overrated. Case in point: the hot chocolate at Angelina in Paris. Walking down the Kurf√ºrstendamm in Berlin. Eating gelato in Rome. The view from the second floor of the Eiffel Tower in Paris. Snacking on currywurst and tucking into a schnitzel in Berlin. Looking up at the oculus in the Pantheon in Rome. The first view of the Sacr√©-C≈ìur as you walk up the hill in Paris. Everything about the Palace of Versailles ;)
