The traditional story of Rome‚Äôs founding is a classic tale, one that every schoolchild used to learn. One of the greatest civilizations of the Western world, Rome shaped our modern society more than any other ancient culture (with the possible exception of Greece). To understand the incredible story ‚Äî somewhat dubious historicity aside ‚Äî is to gain insight into the folklore and heritage that have inspired twenty-five centuries of thinkers, creators, rulers, and ordinary people who looked backwards at the mistakes and achievements of the past for wisdom and direction in the present.
Many charge that learning such tales in the Digital Age is anachronistic at best and exclusionary at worst. But there is undeniably something transcendent about them, a special quality that explains Rome‚Äôs unique ability to capture the hearts and souls of luminaries from every time and place, from Dante to Gibbon to Toni Morrison.
Studying the history of ancient Rome ought not to be an exercise in self-flagellation, in which one allows the often-savage realities of the ancient world to overshadow the innovations and triumphs of an extraordinary time. Instead, it ought to be a celebration of the grandeur that was Rome, imperfections and all, and a recognition of the seminal role she played in shaping the West.
And so without further ado I present the traditional and mythological history of Ancient Rome from its founding to its fall in three parts.
On April 21, 753 BC, the twins Romulus and Remus stood atop a rather unremarkable Italian hillock ‚Äî it was known as the ‚ÄúPalatine‚Äù ‚Äî and founded a small settlement that would rise to become one of the most dominant and lasting empires in world history. This ten-part survey briefly traces the traditional and legendary history of Rome, over the course of which I shall attempt to answer the crucial question: how did a diminutive encampment on the Palatine rise to global dominance, and what became of its grandeur?
Our story begins at Troy. According to legend, in the 1200s BC a titanic struggle was waged between the Greeks and the Trojans, inhabitants of a city known as Troy upon the Dardanelles in modern-day Turkey. The cause of the war was divine; three of the most prominent goddesses in the Greek pantheon (Hera, queen of the gods; Athena, goddess of wisdom; and Aphrodite, goddess of sexual love) found themselves in the midst of a passionate disagreement over who was the most beautiful. To settle their dispute, Zeus (king of the gods) appointed Paris, a Trojan prince, as judge. Attempting to sway Paris, each of the three goddesses offered him a precious reward should he choose her, but it was Aphrodite‚Äôs offer ‚Äî that he be wed to Helen, wife of a Greek king called Menelaus ‚Äî that was most convincing to the Trojan squire. Her promise was swiftly delivered upon, and Helen was spirited away from the court of Menelaus to the high walls of Priam, king of Troy.
War followed forthwith, as Greeks hastened to Troy to support Menelaus and reclaim his snatched wife from Paris. The fighting was intense, lengthy, and heroic ‚Äî much of it is retold in Homer‚Äôs Iliad, most especially the exploits of a Greek general named Achilles. At last, supported by many of the gods and aided by cunning trickery in the ‚ÄúTrojan Horse‚Äù (a fake peace offering that in fact contained Greek soldiers within its belly, allowing the marauders to flood the city by night and open its gates to the invaders waiting outside), the Greeks breached the walls, and began to pillage and burn.
From the carnage escaped a particular Trojan prince ‚Äî Aeneas, a son of Venus ‚Äî accompanied by a retinue of comrades. In search of friendly lands and a place to found a new city, he set out from Troy by ship and, after an arduous journey, arrived on the shores of North Africa to a city called Carthage (modern-day Tunis), the home of Queen Dido. The people were friendly, milk and honey flowed, and, most notoriously, Dido and Aeneas fell into the throngs of love for one another, a rather scandalous affair for the previously-unbetrothed Dido and the now-uxorious Aeneas. Alas, this was not to be the Romans‚Äô final home; for Hermes, the messenger god, flitted down to Aeneas, whom he found strutting bejeweled atop the high walls of Carthage, and bore to him a fateful message from Zeus himself: Aeneas must head to Latium (the region of Italy around modern-day Rome), as was his fate. Immediately, devoted Aeneas (or pius Aeneas, as goes the famous Latin phrase) set out, and soon reaches Latium. However, his departure was not casualty-free; in a fit of woeful despair at seeing her lover gone, Dido stabbed herself to death, leaving a final curse on the Trojans that shall reappear later in this survey. Much of the tale of Aeneas‚Äô journey to Rome, it should be noted, is retold in Vergil‚Äôs Aeneid.
Thus we conclude the first chapter of Rome‚Äôs history, with Trojan ships on Latian sands.
Having shored in Italy, ‚ÄúAeneas f[ound] not peace but another terrible war‚Äù (Ragan, Survey). A local king, Latinus, sparked conflict when he betrothed his daughter Lavinia to the newly arrived Aeneas instead of the man to whom he had already promised her, Turnus. In the ensuing strife, in which the Trojan-Latinus coalition fought Turnus and his local allies, Aeneas slew Turnus and subsequently married Lavinia. He died in another skirmish shortly afterward.
Aeneas‚Äô body was never recovered, but his name remains forever etched into the towering stele of Western civilization, a fleeting ember of once-mighty Troy rekindled into the blazing inferno that was Rome. His legacy would be taken up by his young son Ascanius (also known as Iulus). The year, as legend has it, is circa 1175 BC.
Thirty or so years later, Ascanius founded the town of Alba Longa in the nearby Alban Hills, about twenty miles east of the Seven Hills that will later mark the famous site of Rome. Ascanius is the first in a 400-year line of Alban kings ‚Äî the so-called Silvian Dynasty ‚Äî that ends with King Proca and his two sons: Numitor (the elder) and Amulius (the younger). Upon Proca‚Äôs death sometime in the 8th century BC, Numitor, being the elder brother, ought to have inherited the throne. Amulius, however, had other plans, and he usurped the throne, murdered Numitor‚Äôs sons, and cast Numitor himself into exile. In a rather Machiavellian twist, wanting to end his brother‚Äôs bloodline Amulius forced Numitor‚Äôs daughter Rhea Silvia to become a Vestal Virgin, consigning her to celibate priestesshood.
Divine intervention followed forthwith, and Rhea Silvia became impregnated by Mars, the god of war [virgin pregnancies tend to resurface, no?]. Amulius orders the products of the pregnancy, twin boys named Romulus and Remus, to be left on the banks of the Tiber River to perish [cue Moses‚Ä¶]. Escaping doom, the twins were found and nursed by a she-wolf who brought them to a cave known as ‚Äúthe Lupercal.‚Äù Soon thereafter, the infants were found by a shepherd, Faustulus, who took them in and raised them as his own (along with his wife, Acca Larentia). Eventually, having discovered their family background and having learned of the injustice Amulius had wrought, they wrested back control of Alba Longa and restored Numitor, their now-ag√©d grandfather, to the throne. Wrongs thus righted, the brothers set out, looking to found a city of their own.
The twins and their followers journeyed west to a marshy spot near the Tiber River, ringed by seven hills: the Palatine, the Quirinal, the Viminal, the Esquiline, the Caelian, the Aventine, and the Capitoline. Romulus surmounted the Palatine hill and began setting the boundaries of a new hamlet, Rome. The legendary date of this founding is April 21, 753 B.C. Remus, in brotherly scorn, leapt over the Rome‚Äôs diminutive walls. Romulus, ever the patriot, felled his brother with his blade, declaring, ‚ÄúSic deinde, quicumque alius transiliet moenia mea‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúThus henceforth to anyone who should o‚Äôerleap my bulwarks.‚Äù
Rid of pesky Remus, Romulus set to the task of governance and growth, making Rome (specifically the Capitoline hill) an asylum that welcomed all who wished to join the new town. Unsurprisingly, such an arrangement attracted a less-than-ideal rabble ‚Äî the men were raucous and criminal, the women sparse. Stung by a neighboring tribe‚Äôs refusal to provide their daughters in marriage to the Roman ruffians, Romulus announced a Festival of Neptune (the sea god) in his new town, attracting scores of local tribespeople. With the beady eyes of the Romans fixed upon the Sabine daughters ‚Äî the young, gallivanting women from the Sabine tribe ‚Äî Romulus gave the signal, and the Romans rushed out from their hidey-holes, each seizing a Sabine lass for his own and absconding back onto the fortified heights of the Palatine. The festival, needless to say, quickly dispersed.
The Roman snatching ‚Äî or, as it became known, ‚ÄúThe Rape of the Sabine Women‚Äù ‚Äî was rather poorly received by the duped Sabines, who quickly armed themselves and prepared to make battle. Skirmishes ensued, but the final engagement of the war, the Battle of the Lacus Curtius, was ended when the Roman wives (yes, the very Sabine girls who had only recently been kidnapped) threw themselves into the fray and demanded that conflict cease in an event often called ‚ÄúThe Intervention of the Sabine Women.‚Äù Impelled to peace, the two towns merged, the new entity jointly ruled by Romulus and Titus Tatius, the king of the Sabines.
Around this time Romulus went about planting the societal seeds that would sprout into the grand trunks of Roman civilization. To one hundred hand-picked followers he gave the title ‚Äúpatres‚Äù ‚Äî ‚Äúfathers‚Äù. These men would serve in an official capacity as his advisory council, the Senate. The descendants of these early ‚Äúfathers‚Äù would later be known as the ‚Äúpatricii,‚Äù or ‚ÄúPatricians.‚Äù The rest of the citizenry were merely the ‚Äúplebs,‚Äù or ‚ÄúPlebeians.‚Äù From the union of these two delineated strata (the Senate and the masses) comes the famous phrase SPQR ‚Äî ‚ÄúSenatus PopulusQue Romanus,‚Äù or ‚Äúthe Senate and People of Rome.‚Äù Another division of the city ‚Äî thirty ‚Äúcuriae,‚Äù named after thirty of the Sabine women who had intervened ‚Äî provided the voting units of the ‚ÄúComitia Curiata,‚Äù or ‚ÄúRoman Assembly.‚Äù
Over the next several years of his rule (by now Titus Tatius had perished during a riot in nearby Lavinium, leaving Romulus the sole king), Romulus oversaw the city‚Äôs continued growth as it pressed outward in conquest. In the late 8th century B.C., Romulus died when, while surveying the troops arranged on the Campus Martius (Plain of Mars) from the Quirinal hill, a cloud enshrouded him. When the cloud lifted, Romulus was nowhere to be found ‚Äî either murdered in a conspiracy by the Senators or, as the Roman historian Livy more dubiously asserts, ascended to heaven under the auspices of Mars. Romulus was later deified under the name ‚ÄúQuirinus,‚Äù attracting a significant cult following. He reigned for thirty-seven years, the first of Rome‚Äôs ‚ÄúSeven Kings.‚Äù
Thus we conclude the second chapter of our history of Rome, with Romulus dead and a new king, as we shall soon see, poised to spring from the ashes.
Somewhat unusually, the Roman kingship was elective: The Senate nominated new kings during the interregna that followed monarchs‚Äô deaths (during which nominating process various Senators would serve as temporary rulers), and the Assembly confirmed or rejected those nominees. The arrangements surrounding Romulus‚Äô succession were no exception; the lengthy, one-year interregnum that followed Romulus‚Äô death saw ten Senators rule as interregnes, or ‚Äúbetween-kings,‚Äù before a worthy successor was nominated and confirmed: Numa Pompilius, Rome‚Äôs second king.
Numa Pompilius: The Pacifist and Priest (r. 716‚Äì673 BC)
Numa‚Äôs accession betokened a city exhausted from the constant conflict and rapid expansion of Romulus‚Äô reign: more scholar than fighter, Numa was famed for his disciplined lifestyle, religious dedication, and vast wisdom. Numa‚Äôs selection marked a successful compromise between the Roman and Sabine factions of the population ‚Äî though himself a Sabine himself from the town of Cures, Numa was uncontroversial and widely respected, characteristics that rendered him acceptable to each of the bickering factions.
Numa is chiefly remembered for his pacifism and his institution of the sacra, Rome‚Äôs religious traditions. Among his first decrees as monarch was the dissolution of the guard that had comprised Romulus‚Äô personal entourage ‚Äî an act both of peacemaking and self-preservation, as the guards‚Äô loyalty was questionable. One of Numa‚Äôs most significant contributions was the establishment of several priestly orders, including pontifices and flamines (higher and lower classes, respectively, of standard priests), the Salii (the twelve so-called ‚Äúleaping priests‚Äù of Mars), the fetiales (the priests who advised the Senate on treaties, foreign affairs, and official declarations of war), and the Pontifex Maximus, the high priest of Rome. Most significantly, he imported from Alba Longa the Vestal Virgins ‚Äî the famed priestesses of Vesta (goddess of the hearth) who, as ceremonial stewards of all Rome, kept her sacred fire aflame. Numa also constructed several temples, including the famous Temple of Janus, whose doors were closed during peacetime and flung open during wars. Tellingly, the doors remained closed for Numa‚Äôs entire reign. Another of his lasting contributions was the institution of a twelve-month calendar adjusted to the solar and lunar years, with provisions for ‚Äúholy‚Äù and ‚Äúunholy‚Äù days.
Throughout his reign, Numa asserted his direct connection to the gods by means of his marriage to Egeria, a nymph who supposedly furnished him with divine directives upon his periodic visits to her. Numa died of old age in 673 BC, having presided over a long period of peace and productivity in the city on the Tiber.
Tullus Hostilius: The Warrior (r. 673‚Äì642 BC)
Where Numa was priest, Tullus was warrior. Scornful of the religious obsession that had settled over the city and believing Rome to have grown ‚Äúsoft‚Äù under Numa‚Äôs pacifism, Tullus Hostilius set about renewing the military prowess the city had enjoyed under Romulus and sought to expand its imperium, or ‚Äúsphere of influence‚Äù (later ‚Äúempire‚Äù). Tullus waged war on several neighboring peoples, including the Sabines (whom he defeated with a cavalry charge in a battle near Malitiosa Forest, inflicting heavy casualties), the confederated Veientes and Fidenates (whom he defeated even despite the treacherous retreat of Rome‚Äôs Alban ‚Äúallies‚Äù), and even Alba Longa, the ancient birthplace of Romulus. It is this final conquest for which Tullus is best known today.
Cattle begat the strife. When a small herd of the beasts (owned by a Roman farmer) wandered into Alban territory, and the relevant landowners refused to return them to Rome, Tullus did what any reasonable leader might have done: He declared war against all Alba Longa. Undaunted, the Albans marshaled themselves under their king, Cluilius, and marched to the outskirts of Rome. Quickly, they dug a trench ‚Äî the aptly-named Cluilian trench ‚Äî around the entire city. Soon, though, Cluilius perished of unspecified causes. [‚ÄúCluilius‚Ä¶ moritur,‚Äù the Roman historian Livy helpfully elaborates: ‚ÄúCluilius dies‚Äù (Ab Urbe Condita, 1.23.4).]
To replace Cluilius, the Albans appointed Mettius Fufetius as military dictator, granting him absolute command over the city and its forces. The two leaders ‚Äî Tullus and Fufetius ‚Äî drew up their armies into battle and marched out to face each other. Neither side wanting to wage what would surely be a bloody and destructive war ‚Äî for the neighboring Etruscans would have looked on with glee as their two main territorial rivals tore each other to shreds, ready to swoop in and conquer the weakened victor ‚Äî Fufetius suggested a more efficient resolution: a duel. Miraculously, each army had among its ranks a set of triplets: the Romans had the Horatii brothers, and the Albans had the Curiatii brothers. The teams of brothers would fight to the bloody death for their countries, and Tullus and Fufetius each entered into solemn vows pledging that they would abide by the outcome of the fight. I borrow from Ragan‚Äôs Survey to recount the conflict that ensued:
The contest was exciting: with two Horatians slain, but all three Curiatians wounded, the surviving Horatius began to flee! The Romans no doubt groaned, thinking their champion a coward. But there was method in this. For as he ran, he succeeded in separating the pursuing Curiatii whom he was able to fight individually and each of whom he killed. So, the Albans surrendered themselves and their town. The Romans, however, characteristic of these early wars, took the Albans as a whole into their citizen body; the town was destroyed ‚Äî except for the temples ‚Äî so that the Albans would become fully a part of their new community.
So, with that, Romulus‚Äô hometown was no more, living on only in the memory of its now-Roman residents. A final finishing twist to conclude the conflict: the Alban dictator, Fufetius, soon proved a treacherous man. In the aforementioned Roman war against the Fidenates, it was he who pulled the Albans back from the fight, intending to linger in the backdrop until a winner was evident, at which point he would march out in ‚Äúvictory,‚Äù pretending to have supported whoever won. But Tullus was no fool: perceiving Fufetius‚Äô treachery, he bade his calvary raise their spears, shielding the retreating Alban ‚Äúallies‚Äù from view of his infantry and thus keeping the Roman morale intact, preserving Rome‚Äôs shot at victory. After the battle, Tullus punished Fufetius (also known by his first name, Metius) as he saw fit. I leave it to Vergil to recount the gory details of Metius‚Äô death as he is ripped limb from limb by four horses (Aeneid Book VIII, tr. John Dryden):
Near this, the traitor Metius, stretch‚Äôd betweenFour fiery steeds, is dragg‚Äôd along the green,By Tullus‚Äô doom: the brambles drink his blood,And his torn limbs are left the vulture‚Äôs food.
In addition to these military conquests, Tullus is notable for his construction of a new Senate building ‚Äî the Curia Hostilia ‚Äî which lasted for over 500 years after his death.
Alas, for all his military grandeur Tullus had neglected to honor the gods, and soon the city was afflicted with plague and famine as recompense for his scanty religiosity. Desperate, Tullus turned to the writings of his predecessor Numa, the expert on all things divine, and frantically yet inaccurately attempted to perform the rituals described therein. The gods, in no mood to tolerate such tomfoolery, struck Tullus with a thunderbolt, setting both him and his palace alight and bringing an end to his 31-year rule.
Ancus Marcius: The Builder (r. 640‚Äì616 BC)
Perhaps weary again of conflict and conquest, the Romans chose the more subdued Ancus Marcius ‚Äî grandson of Numa ‚Äî as their fourth king. Where Tullus had erred in the eyes of the gods, Ancus charted a safer course: his first act as king was to have the religious rites laid down by Numa copied down and displayed to the public, lest they ever again be ill-performed.
By Ancus‚Äô time, Rome had become a profitable and well-positioned town controlling a respectable portion of Latium, the territorial region around the city. The city lay along the Via Salaria, or Salt Road, an ancient trading route that proved a welcome boon to the growing city. Taking advantage of the city‚Äôs strategic position, Ancus sent out a colonia (colony) of citizens to found Ostia at the mouth of the Tiber, a crucial expedition that secured the surrounding salt flats (providing a reliable revenue stream for the fledgling city) and extended Roman territory to the sea. He constructed the first bridge across the Tiber, the Pons Sublicius (Sublician Bridge), in 642 BC. The continued arrival of Etruscans from the north, skilled engineers in masonry, road construction, and swamp drainage, further complemented Ancus‚Äô infrastructure projects. He built Rome‚Äôs first prison, the Mamertine Prison (which, in the following centuries, housed a number of high-profile prisoners, including Vercingetorix, Jugurtha, St. Peter, and Sejanus), atop the Capitoline hill. He fortified the Janiculum hill on the west bank of the Tiber, dug a ditch fortification (the Fossa Quiritium) on the city‚Äôs landward side, and constructed Rome‚Äôs first aqueduct.
Though more peaceful than his predecessor, Ancus did not shrink from conflict; he fought against the Latins, conquering the town of Politorum (whose residents were relocated to the base of the Aventine hill in Rome) ‚Äî and later reconquering and destroying it when it was re-settled by more Latin peoples ‚Äî along with Tellenae, Ficana, and Medullia, a conquest that brought loot to the coffers of Ancus and resettled Latins to the base of the Palatine hill. These resettlements, along with a growing population and increasing social stratification, helped form the early stages of the plebeian class at Rome. Furthermore, he expanded Roman territory into the Maesian Forest, seizing it from the Veientes.
After 24 years of successful rule, Ancus, the last of Rome‚Äôs Latin-Sabine kings, died, bringing to a close a period of economic and territorial expansion, infrastructure development, and social growth for the adolescent town on the banks of the Tiber.
Thus we conclude the third chapter of our brief history of Rome, with four successful kings etched into the people‚Äôs memory and new rulers from the north poised to take the throne.
During the reign of Ancus Marcius (640‚Äì616 BC), a talented man named Lucomo arrived from Etruria, a civilization to the north of Rome, with his wife, Tanaquil. Lucomo brought his peoples‚Äô skill in engineering, stonework, and logistics; Tanaquil, their prowess in omen interpretation. According to tradition, this power couple was destined for greatness from the moment of their arrival at Rome: As they approached the city, an eagle swooped down, stole Lucomo‚Äôs hat, and quickly replaced it. Tanaquil, the ‚Äúimpartial‚Äù wife and observer, deemed this an omen of his future greatness.
Biased as it was, Tanaquil‚Äôs observation soon came to fruition. At Rome, Lucomo took the name ‚ÄúLucius Tarquinius‚Äù (‚ÄúPriscus,‚Äù meaning ‚ÄúElder,‚Äù was later added ‚Äî we shall soon see why), gained access to the city‚Äôs high society through favor and courtesy, and, eventually, became a friend of the aging Ancus. So close an associate of Ancus‚Äô was he that the king named him guardian of his two sons, both mere youths. But this was a decision that would prove fatal for the line of poor Ancus.
With old Ancus on his deathbed in 616 BC, crafty Tarquin (or, more likely, the ambitious Tanaquil) sent the two sons on a lengthy hunting expedition. When Ancus died shortly thereafter, Tarquin leapt into action, making a case for his own election to the kingship before the Curiate Assembly (the thirty-tribe popular assembly presided over by the king ‚Äî recall the thirty curiae named after the intervening Sabine women), a case he bolstered with bribery. Needless to say, he succeeded: The two sons, away on their jolly hunt, were exiled, and Lucius Tarquinius Priscus ‚Äî better known by the anglicized Tarquin the Elder ‚Äî became Rome‚Äôs fifth king.
L. Tarquinius Priscus: The Engineer (r. 616‚Äì579 BC)
Scurrilous accession aside, Tarquin oversaw a period of necessary construction, military success, and effective reform in the Eternal City. Though often overtowered by the whirlwind of reforms wrought by Servius Tullius, his successor, Tarquinius Priscus‚Äô fruitful reign ought not be overlooked.
Many of his engineering projects became the defining monuments of Rome. He built the Circus Maximus (a chariot-racing arena) at the base of the Palatine hill; he laid the foundation for the Temple of Iuppiter Optimus Maximus (the High God of the Roman pantheon) on the Capitoline hill, to be completed by his son; and he constructed a massive sewer, the cloaca maxima, to drain the swamp between the Palatine and Capitoline hills, which would later become the site of the famous Roman Forum. He also continued the construction of walled defenses around the entire city.
On the military front, Tarquin initiated a war against the neighboring Latins, seizing the town of Apiolae and a great deal of booty, instituting annual games as celebration. (He would go on to take and assimilate additional Latin cities in subsequent offensives.) He then weathered an Etruscan-supported Sabine assault with exceptional difficulty ‚Äî fighting spilled into the streets of Rome, and the Sabines were only barely repelled. Following an initial surprise attack that inflicted heavy losses, the Sabines withdrew to prepare for another offensive. Livy recounts the dramatic second skirmish (Ab Urbe Condita I.37, tr. Aubrey de S√©lincourt ‚Äî an edition from the Heritage Club that I heartily recommend):
Hostilities with the Sabines were now resumed. The striking-power of Rome had been increased by the expansion of the cavalry [which Tarquin had completed during the Sabine respite], but in what followed it was a strategy that played the decisive part. A stack of dry timber which had been lying on the bank of the Anio was set alight and the blazing logs thrown into the water. A good wind kept them burning, and many were carried down by the stream and became lodged amongst the piles of the bridge, which they set on fire. This was alarming enough for the Sabines while they were fighting, but worse when their resistance broke; for the burning bridge prevented their retreat, and large numbers of them escaped the enemy only to perish in the river. Their equipment floated down the Tiber to Rome, where it was recognized for what it was and brought the news of victory almost before a messenger could get through.
As terms of the parley that followed, Rome received the Sabine town of Collatia, in which Tarquin placed his nephew Egerius as commander of the Roman garrison. Following the victory over the Sabines, Tarquin celebrated a triumph, or general‚Äôs victory parade, on September 13, 585 BC. However, this conflict poked the Etruscan bear, for they had supported the Sabine effort; twelve Etruscan cities banded together and seized a Roman outpost at Fidenae, a town to the north of the city. This seizure kicked off a bloody conflict that saw Tarquin lead the Romans against his native civilization. Rome was victorious, subjugating the truculent Etruscan cities and gaining great wealth.
Tarquin‚Äôs remarkable successes carried over into the social and political realms. To stave off the Sabines (see above), he had expanded the number of cavalry centuries from three to six ‚Äî thus doubling the size of the equites, or knight class. He increased the Senate by one hundred members ‚Äî importantly, among whom was a man from the gens Octavii, the family of Rome‚Äôs first emperor 600 years later. He introduced many Etruscan military, political, and religious rites that later became hallmarks of Roman rule.
Tarquin went as he came, surrounded by divine phenomena and urged on by his ambitious wife. I leave it to Ragan to report the strange story (Survey):
A very unusual event occurred one night in the royal nursery. The woman watching the sleeping children (both royal and household children were there) screamed when the hair of one of the children, a slave-woman‚Äôs [Ocrisia‚Äôs] son, seemed to be on fire. This brought Queen Tanaquil who, when she saw that the fire was not harming the child, took this as a sign of destiny for the child. She convinced her husband that the child, Servius Tullius, was thus designated by the gods to succeed to the throne. Some years later, Tarquin‚Äôs earlier treachery against Ancus‚Äô sons caught up with him. One day, as the king was giving audience to citizens, a foreigner asked to speak to the king in private, on a matter of great importance. The king agreed and, when alone, the man (hired by Ancus‚Äô exiled sons) took an ax to the king‚Äôs head and escaped. Tanaquil, wanting to secure the succession for Servius, carefully managed the situation as the king lay dying. She would give out daily reports about this recovery ‚Äî knowing full well he was dead ‚Äî all the while securing the support she would need to gain the kingship for Servius. This done, the death of Tarquin was divulged, and Servius Tullius, formerly the son of a slave, became the sixth king of the Romans.
And so Servius Tullius, once a slave boy, took power at Rome.
Servius Tullius: The Slave (r. 578‚Äì535 BC)
Servius was a king who knew his origins ‚Äî his allegiances lay with the Plebs, the people, rather than with the aristocratic Patricians and noble families of the old order, to whom he seemed a mere ‚Äúpopulist demagogue‚Äù (Ragan, Survey). Indeed, throughout the reigns of Servius and his successor, Tarquin the Proud, the Roman citizenry came into its own, earning participation in government and power in administration. Perhaps, though, the collapse of the old order brought the state down with it ‚Äî the excesses and exiguities, triumphs and trivialities, virtues and vices of the Roman Kingdom crumbled under Tarquin the Proud. But all that is to come.
Servius‚Äô great triumphs were social. In a reform known today as the Servian Constitution, he organized the Roman citizenry into five classes according to wealth, rather than to birth. The specific mechanism of this system ‚Äî divided according to the armor each man could afford in wartime ‚Äî relieved the poorest of their military duties. To accomplish this feat, he instituted the first census, or counting of Rome‚Äôs citizens and property, overseen by a censor. This division resulted in the Comitia Centuriata (the Centuriate Assembly), a body consisting of 193 ‚Äúcenturies‚Äù into which all Romans were sorted. However, while theoretically granting the Plebeians a voice in governance and law, the Comitia Centuriata did little to ease the Patrician [moneyed elite] chokehold on Roman administration ‚Äî 180 of the 193 centuries consisted of the wealthiest estates, granting 5% of the Roman populace deciding power in all matters of state. (This unbalanced representation was accomplished by a crafty grouping of the classes: While the lowest estates had hundreds or even thousands of members, the highest ones had very few ‚Äî think of a radical version of the U.S. electoral college.)
Though seemingly unbalanced, this division aptly reflected the contribution each class made to the Roman military: The highest classes were expected to contribute vast funds and troops to the city‚Äôs military endeavors, while the lowest ones contributed nothing at all. A democracy? No. But an accurate reflection of the relative weight and import of military matters in ancient societies? Yes. Before we leer at this classist system with a modern eye, perhaps we ought to recall Burke: ‚ÄúA true natural aristocracy is not a separate interest in the state, or separable from it. It is an essential integrant part of any large body rightly constituted. It is formed out of a class of legitimate presumptions, which taken as generalities, must be admitted for actual truths.‚Äù Political philosophy aside, Servius‚Äô reforms laid the political, legal, social, and ideological bases for the Roman Republic to come.
‚ÄãClass questions aside, the developments under Servius extended beyond his Constitution. Legend has it ‚Äî though an archaeologist perhaps doesn‚Äôt‚Äî that he constructed the Servian Wall, enclosing 608 acres and all seven of the famous hills of Rome (Servius had expanded the city onto the Quirinal, Viminal, and Equiline). For the pauper, he was a prince: He eliminated debt imprisonment and eased the tax burden on the lowest classes, albeit in exchange for a paucity of political representation (see above). Furthermore, he entrusted the precariat to its land, labor, and liberty, dividing public land and letting the poor farm and tend to themselves. He divided the people of Rome into four tribes and the entire country into thirty one. He founded a very important shrine to Diana on the Aventine Hill, a shrine that became the administrative center of a critical alliance between Rome and the Latin League (an alliance of neighboring tribes and communities aligned against Roman expansion). For the first time, Servius energetically delineated the bounds of citizenship: His Constitutional ukase placed freedmen within his classes, thus enfranchising former slaves and bolstering the citizen base. Additionally, Servius established several religious festivals, most notably the Compitalia (celebrated in early January each year).
Before we recount the pitiable end of old Servius, let us recap Rome‚Äôs status at the end of his reign. Rome had expanded territorially, occupying all Seven of the famous Hills. Her citizenry was divided by wealth, not birth. The Servian Constitution had laid the basis for the Republic that was soon to come. Rome‚Äôs geopolitical situation was strong, with alliances secured with the Latin League and the Etruscans. Freedman and poor alike were newly protected and empowered.
Alas, Servius‚Äô humble origins returned to haunt him. I once again defer to Ragan to recount the death of Servius and the ascendency of his successor, Tarquin the Proud (Survey):
Servius‚Äô origin, however, continued to plague him as the Roman aristocracy felt demeaned, being ruled by a former slave. Thus, Servius Tullius married his two daughters, both named Tullia, to two sons (or grandsons) of the former King Tarquin [Tarquinius Priscus]: Tarquin (called Superbus, ‚Äúthe proud, arrogant‚Äù) and the younger Arruns. That Servius knew the characters of his daughters and his sons-in-law is shown by his matching. Tullia the Younger, married to Arruns, was as ambitious and conniving as her true love, the man she most admired, Arruns‚Äô younger brother; Tullia the Elder, a devoted, if simple, wife was utterly unlike her conniving, ambitious husband. [i.e the ambitious and conniving Tullia the Younger was married to the simple and devoted Arruns; the simple and devoted Tullia the Elder was married to the ambitious and conniving Tarquinius Superbus. Tullia the Elder pined for Tarquinius Superbus (and vice versa), and was bound to get her way, a marriage from Dante‚Äôs Hell; trouble stewed in each couple‚Äôs nuptial hours.] Livy puts it rather succinctly: ‚ÄúTwo deaths soon followed,‚Äù and the surviving Tullia and Tarquin joined in marriage and conspiracy. Working long behind the scenes, when Tarquin decided it was time to act, he boldly went into the Forum to the Curia (Senate House), sat on the royal throne, and proclaimed himself king before the shocked populace. Tullia shamelessly appeared in public and, from her carriage, heralded her husband‚Äôs usurpation. Hearing the clamor, old Servius came into the Forum (the Regia, or royal palace, was nearby) and attempted to resist Tarquin. The younger man hurled his father-in-law down the steps and, as he was led home, wounded, sent assassins to finish him off! Livy adds a gruesome touch: As she was coming home in her carriage, Tullia saw the body of her father deserted in the street. She ordered her driver to drive over the body, splattering the carriage with blood, and taking the curse home. The street where this happened was called thereafter Via Scelerata, Street of Crime.
Scandal, shock, scurrility ‚Äî these were the accoutrements of Tarquinius Superbus‚Äô accession. Where Tarquinius Priscus had pomp and pageantry, Superbus had profligacy and perfidy; where old Numa had decorum and decency, Superbus had depravity and debasedness; and where Romulus had valor and vigor, Superbus had vanity and villainy. The blood splattered on the wheels of Tullia‚Äôs cabriolet betokened more than the death of a helpless elder; it presaged the end of a mighty chapter in Rome‚Äôs history. The tale of Tarquin the Proud is one of crime for all ages.
Tarquinius Superbus: The Tyrant (r. 535‚Äì509 BC)
And so we come to Tarquin the Proud, as all histories of the Roman Kingdom must, the final king of the great house of Tarquin. His cognomen, ‚ÄúSuperbus,‚Äù (translated as ‚Äúproud‚Äù or ‚Äúarrogant‚Äù) tells all. Ragan aptly characterizes his rule: ‚ÄúThat bloody and inauspicious act was only the beginning to what became a despot‚Äôs reign of terror. As is the case with all tyrants, no class or individual was spared from Tarquin‚Äôs jealousy or cruelty‚Äù (Survey). Indeed, so wretched was the rule of Tarquin that he made the title of rex, or king, forever hateful to the Romans, inscribing his name with blood on the tapestry of Roman descent. As Cicero questioned in his Republica, ‚ÄúAre you not aware that it was the insolence and pride of one man, Tarquinius, that made the title of king odious to our people?‚Äù
Ambition, wealth, and disregard make a vile combination; Tarquin began his reign with a murderous romp. He refused to entomb old Servius, and executed any senator whom he deemed a ‚Äúloyalist‚Äù supporter of Servius, seizing their property for his own and reducing the size of the Senate. He mustered a bodyguard to facilitate his haughty uninhibitedness. Livy captures his philosophy on governance: ‚ÄúWithout hope of his subjects‚Äô affection, he could rule only by fear; and to make himself feared as widely as possible he began the practice of trying capital causes without consultation and by his own sole authority‚Äù (Early History of Rome). He ruled as a tyrant rather than as a king, refusing to consult the Senate on any matters of military or state. His proto-Machiavellian foreign policy was just as brutal, as when he summoned a meeting of local leaders and proceeded to execute one (by drowning him to death, no less) under a manufactured charge, a blatant violation of Rome‚Äôs notions of justified foreign aggression. He used mercenaries for matters of war, a massive faux-pas in the Roman eye. One particular event recalls his military cruelty, the famous skirmish with Gabii (Ragan, Survey):
Unable to defeat the town of Gabii in battle, Tarquin contrived to have his son pretend that he was fleeing his cruel father ‚Äî something easily believed. Established in Gabii, Sextus secretly sent to his father asking what to do next. While the messenger awaited, Tarquin silently went into his garden and with his walking stick lopped off the heads of flowers that towered above others. This ‚Äúobject lesson‚Äù was not lost on the son; many noble heads were lopped off, and Sextus gained power in Gabii only to hand it over to his father.
In religious matters Tarquin the Proud was equally inept. When the Cumaean Sibyl, a priestess of Apollo, came to Tarquin to offer him nine books of prophecy about the future of Rome (albeit for a hefty sum), he declined. The Sibyl, a crafty saleswoman (who knew!), burned three of the scrolls, and offered the six left for the original price. Tarquin yet again refused ‚Äî and yet again the Sibyl set three alight, leaving only three from the original nine. Finally, Tarquin paid six thousand talents of silver ‚Äî an exorbitant sum (about $99 million in today‚Äôs prices!) ‚Äî for a third of the original offering. These books, which came to be known as the Sibylline Books, were housed in the Temple of Jupiter Capitolinus and were consulted by the Roman Senate during national emergencies.
Despite its many disasters, the reign of Tarquin the Proud had one area of success: infrastructure. Tarquin, though deranged, understood the mind of the Roman populace; when kept busy, the people had little time to foment discontent. Accordingly, he imported Etruscan engineers and began several massive and lavish construction projects: the Temple of Jupiter and the excavation of the Cloaca Maxima, in particular. Ironically, however, it was the very area in which Tarquin found limited success that effected his downfall: His incredible infrastructure expenditure left the Roman coffers depleted and himself in need of more funds. And so he laid siege to the rich town of Ardea. I once again turn to Ragan for the downfall that followed (Survey):
The end of the Tarquins, and of monarchy at Rome, occurred with a tragic element. Away at a local siege [at Ardea], some young officers, including the king‚Äôs son, Sextus, his cousin Tarquinius Collatinus, and a friend, the (supposed) fool Lucius Junius Brutus (his name means ‚Äúdull‚Äù), were one night discussing their wives. Whereas the other men bragged about their wives‚Äô beauty and love of luxury, Collatinus spoke of his wife Lucretia‚Äôs great beauty, faithfulness, and diligence in keeping the house ‚Äî at all hours. Finding this claim hard to imagine, the young men headed back to Rome late at night to find the situation exactly as Collatinus had asserted. Sextus was deeply struck with lust for the beautiful and noble woman. He later returned secretly with a sword to force her to lie with him. When at first she refused, preferring death to dishonor, he threatened further to kill her and leave a dead slave in bed with her. Rather than face public disgrace on herself and her family, the noble woman submitted to her shame. Some time later, overcome with remorse, she confessed the crime to her husband, Brutus, and others [including her father, Spurius Lucius Tricipitinus]. The horror related, she committed suicide in their presence. Aroused to mutiny by such an outrage, Brutus threw off the mask of foolishness he had cultivated to survive under a tyrant, and with many nobles, roused the senate and people against the Tarquins. The king was with the army; when he returned, demanding to be admitted to Rome, the gates were shut in his face, his property was confiscated, and the Tarquins were banished forever. Curiously, Sextus sought refuge in Gabii, where he met a just fate by the people he had betrayed. The exiled Tarquin sought the help of the Etruscan king Lars Porsenna to restore his throne. Failing in his attempt, Tarquin died in exile some ten years later.
And so the Roman Kingdom began and ended with rape: It initiated 241 years prior with the Rape of the Sabine Women, the famous snatching that furnished the hooligan hillpeople known as Romans with women, and it concluded with the famous Rape of Lucretia. Rome was now to be a Republic, ruled by two annually elected magistrates known as consuls.
Thus we conclude our fourth chapter of Roman history. The year is 509 BC, 244 years after her founding in 753, and Rome has entered a new era, the Republic, with two emergent leaders at her helm.

Title: 8 Ancient Roman Women You Should Know About
Content:
